Chapter 1
— RMIT University





1.1    Wage Theft



1.1.1    Tutors Are Underpaid



Wage theft of tutors, ultimately, hurts students' interests.

After all, tutors are the backbone of the university, delegated to act on its behalf (including assignments' grading).

However, because RMIT steals their wages, it is only natural that students — who rely on their services — will suffer as a result.


1.1.2    Lawlessness of RMIT



The High Court of Australia notably ruled that "sensibly" courts "decline to review" the "internal budget" of universities because academic staff will be "more cognisant than judges" about "high academic standards".


Is RMIT University "cognisant" about "high academic standards"?

No and no.


Is RMIT honest and trustworthy?

No, no, no, and no.


Does RMIT often break the law?

Yes, yes, yes, and yes.


Does RMIT discriminate against foreign students?

Yes and yes.


Does RMIT dabble in antisemitic propaganda?

Yes.


1.1.3    Students Bear the Consequences of Wage Theft



Tutors depend on RMIT to renew their contracts after the end of each semester.

Consequently, they are unlikely to complain when told by RMIT to work for free.

Instead, they skim-read and cheat in their grading of the exams.

As a result, this student exam's grade plummeted down to 45%, which is below the minimum threshold of 50%.


1.1.4    Deputy Vice-Chancellor Prof. Aleksandar Subic



But who cares?

Certainly, not Prof. Aleksandar Subic, who in the process was able to free up more tax-free resources to be funnelled towards services provided exclusively by companies associated with his lobbying group, which looks promising (especially when viewed through the lenses of his lobbying group).

However, RMIT does not pay for services that would have directly benefit the students (and staff), like proof-reading of exams, teachers' attendance during the exam, and most importantly, the grading of the exam papers.

RMIT expects the temporary tutors to work for free.







1.2    Grading Assignments Without Reading Them





1.2.1    Effective Feedback



By policy, teachers add feedback explaining the grade, which tells the student what was wrong in his answer.

Types of feedback vary in their length, and level of detail.

However, detailed and meaningful feedback is pivotal for a student who decides to appeal the results.

An opaque and vague statement like "the marker does not agree with the student" cannot be disputed because it says nothing of substance.

Right?


To give meaningful feedback for a computer-programming assignment, a tutor has to:

  1. Scour thousands of lines of convoluted code to pinpoint the missing iota that caused the tests to fail.
  2. Explain for each question in the exam why points were deducted, and what was wrong in the student's answer.



Now, did RMIT tutors do any of the above?

No.


1.2.2    Vacuous Feedback



RMIT, shrewd and resourceful as ever, has overhauled its assignment-grading process to be more efficient and cost-effective.

To that end, RMIT has developed a one-size-fits-all grading software.

With it, RMIT guaranteed that its tutors no longer had to spend extra hours to cater for individual students and their different answers.


As a central part of its grading software, RMIT has prepared in advance — on behalf of the tutor — a drop-down list of meaningless statements (saying nothing of substance) and told the tutor to select one of those vacuous statements as "his" feedback.

Ingenious!

And cost-effective.


Feedback is as specific as "the marker does not agree with the student" or – wait for it – "the marker agrees with the student".

The anonymous tutor (hiding behind the "your friendly cpt220 marking team" nickname) clicks his mouse to select one of those hollow statements as his "feedback" for the assignment and calls it a day.

RMIT then sends the feedback to the student and warns him to be "polite and respectful" in his "communications".


Mind you, the marker never read the assignment.

But hey, this is expected.

After all, he wasn't paid.


In reality, the selected feedback had zero relevance to the answers submitted by the student.

On the contrary.

The tutor selected three different and contradictory statements for the same question.

Because he arbitrarily (without ever reading the assignment itself) clicked on random checkboxes in the grading software.


To be safe, however, markers aimed for the middle ground.

They had to ensure that their random marks were not too far from reality.


The marker, for example, had to choose the number of debugging tools used by the student.

RMIT's grading software allowed three choices, namely:
  • 0 tools
  • 1 tools
  • 2 tools


The shrewd marker was slick and gambled wisely by selecting: 1 tool.

However, my submission demonstrated 2 tools.


And make no mistake, students had to tick off checkboxes and specify which tools they were using.

There was no uncertainty regarding the number of tools I had used.

Clearly, RMIT did not read it.


1.2.3    Appeal: "Feedback Says Nothing of Substance"



In my appeal on Monday 04/05/2020 at 11:54, I asked RMIT to review the above.

I showed how their vacuous and meaningless feedback ("the marker does not agree with the student") was laughable because, obviously, my submission was correct.

I told them (in the same email) that this feedback "says nothing" of substance.

It was sent 3 hours and 8 minutes after the release of the final results.


On Friday 15/05/2020 at 19:13, I wrote again and provided exact details where the "feedback" was false.

This email was confirmed by the office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic on Tuesday 19/05/2020 at 16:31, saying, they "can confirm that your email [...] of Friday 15 May 2020, at 7:13 pm was received."


1.2.4    Blatant Dishonesty of Academic Board



On Friday 05/06/2020 at 17:13, my appeal got rejected by the office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic.

RMIT claimed that "the feedback provided was sufficient and consistent" with "the requirements" of RMIT.


So again, RMIT claims that the vacuous and false feedback provided (namely, "the marker does not agree with the student") was "sufficient and consistent" with "the requirements" of RMIT.


RMIT's College Appeals committee headed by Prof. Aleksandar Subic lie through their teeth when responding to students' complaints.

Why?

Because they can.


1.2.5    Revenge on Complaining Students



On Saturday 06/06/2020 at 12:12, I asked the Associate Dean and Discipline Head of Computer Science and IT to review the above.

He never responded.

However, on Wednesday 10/06/2020 at 18:01, the office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic told me that asking another academic for help was disrespectful to their office and, to exact revenge on the student, ordered my suspension from the university.

Welcome to RMIT.







1.3    Error-Ridden Exams





1.3.1    No Proof-Reading of Exams



RMIT does not proof-read its exams, nor does it verify the technical accuracy of the questions.

Consequently, students had to bear the consequences of RMIT's negligence.


1.3.2    Flawed Exams



Students were left helpless at the exam venue, and they had to cope with examination papers that included:

  • Gibberish and false descriptions.
  • Technical errors in the question; no correct answer was possible.
  • Typos that rendered the question incomprehensible.
  • Nonsensical instructions.
  • Half-baked questions missing their essential parts.
  • Data structure shown was unrelated to the question.
  • Inconsistent with exam description in course guide.
  • Discriminatory questions disadvantaging foreign students.



1.3.3    Unrealistic Time Allocation



To add insult to injury, RMIT expected students to write 221.6 characters per minute with a pencil, which is impossible to do.


1.3.4    Error-Ridden Marking Guide



And To make matters worse, RMIT gave me 0 points for a correct answer only because it did not match their error-ridden "approved" answer in the marking guide.


1.3.5    RMIT Blaming Students for Its Own Mistakes



In its shrewd and calculated trickery, RMIT illegally ignored my petitions regarding the errors in the marking guide.

After all, they knew full well that it was indefensible.

However, RMIT went behind the students' back and blamed its own errors on the students.

As RMIT has done elsewhere.







1.4    Teachers Are Unavailable





1.4.1    No Help At Exam



As noted, RMIT's exams are flawed.

And to add insult to injury, teachers are not available during the exam to respond to students' queries regarding errors in the exam.


In contrast to RMIT, teachers are available during the exam in every other university in Australia.

What are the chances that RMIT promised the accreditation body one thing, only to do the opposite in order to save a few pennies at the expense of its paying students?


1.4.2    RMIT's Lies



Make no mistake, RMIT are bold-faced liars.

This was their official response on Tuesday 25/02/2020 at 16:50:

[...] despite [name of the Unit Coordinator] being nominally available to answer questions and there being a mechanism in place for the exam venue to forward your queries to the relevant academic.



I have indisputable evidence from the chief supervisor at the exam venue that no academic was available for any of the courses, and no "mechanism" was "in place", to begin with.







1.5    Skim-Reading of Exams





RMIT's tutors are tasked with a huge pile of exam papers, which they have to mark for very little pay.


A tutor had to mark 12 questions per exam.

Each question was further divided into many parts.

One of the questions, for example, had 15 parts; each part had its own mark.


What was the length of each answer?

Up to 2,073 characters.


RMIT expects students to write 221.6 characters per minute.

Do you get the picture?

At that rate, it is hard to maintain neat and clean handwriting.

Right?

Especially for foreign students whose native writing systems are not based on the Latin alphabet.


So, for each question, the marker had to do the following:

  1. First, read long pages of illegible code written by hand.
  2. Then, for each part of the question, he had to scour through thousands of characters of handwritten code to see if this part matched the "approved" one in the marking guide.


As mentioned, each question had up to 15 parts.


RMIT "expected" the tutor to do all of the above in one minute.


Had Prof. Aleksandar Subic testified under penalty of perjury that tutors were paid enough, he would have faced 15 years' imprisonment.


Should we expect the tutors to do the honourable thing and work for free?

Or resign?

I am not sure.


RMIT tutors, however, had a "better" idea.

They read just a selected few of the exams, but they cheated in the rest.

Namely, they gave full (and favorable) attention to their favorite students (including extra help at exam venue) but skim-read the exam papers of other students.

For example, my score plummeted down to 45%; just below the minimum threshold of 50%.


In RMIT, papers are not marked anonymously (where the name of the student is concealed).

And RMIT is unwilling to pay for double marking (where a second marker grades independently of the first one).

In RMIT, students are not allowed to know the results of their own exam (yes, you read that right).

Not long after the release of the final results, all exam papers are shredded, and all records of the results are permanently disposed of and destroyed.

And as noted, RMIT underpays the markers.

It is only natural that systematic skim-reading and a deceiving culture would build up and exacerbate in such a rotten and corrupt environment.


Any wonder why RMIT went berserk when I asked them to see a copy of the marked exam?

Why were they so afraid?







1.6    Incorrect Information





1.6.1    Grading Schedule



RMIT states in Assessment Processes that:

1.53.1 Assessors normally provide marks and feedback on in-course assessment tasks within 10 working days of the deadline for submission of the assessment work or, if a student is granted an extension, within 10 working days of the date when the student submitted the work. 1.53.2 Assessors normally provide students with marks for all in-course assessments before students sit any end-of-course exam. Chapter 1 "Assessment – General Processes" section 1.53 (page 10)




1.6.2    Query to Program Manager



On Tuesday 25/02/2020 at 9:54, I sent a query to the Program Manager regarding a prolonged and on-going delay in the release of the results of the last three assignments.


1.6.3    Inexplicable Delay



Please note it was already after the end of the semester.

According to the policy quoted above, all assignments should have long been released.

However, no student had received any score or feedback for any of the last assignments, which were submitted as far as 44 days earlier (on Sunday 12/01/2020 at 16:21).

Teachers, for some reason, went on a partial strike and pretended it was business as usual, while in reality – behind the curtain – dragged the assignments grading to a grinding halt.


1.6.4    Program Manger Refuses to Intervene



As noted, I sent the query to the Program Manager and hoped he would clarify things.

On the next day, on Wednesday 26/02/2020 at 08:46 and Wednesday 26/02/2020 at 10:48, he told me he had no desire to intervene or help.

Frankly, it raised my suspicion even more.


1.6.5    Incorrect Statement



More emails followed, and on Wednesday 26/02/2020 at 14:39, he sent me the following:

I have spoken with [the Unit Coordinator] and he has indicated that your actual detailed feedback for Assignment 2, Submission 1 and 2, have been sent to your RMIT (Outlook) student email account.



1.6.6    Retraction of Incorrect Statement



One day later, however, on Thursday 27/02/2020 at 10:18, the teacher himself admitted that the results of assignment 2(A) were still not released neither to me nor to any other student.

On the contrary.

The feedback for assignment 2(A) was delayed for extra 11 days until Sunday 08/03/2020 at 22:55, which was 56 days after its submission (on Sunday 12/01/2020 at 16:21).


This manager also misled me for 2 days (on phone and email) that assignment 2(C) had already been sent.

In reality, however, it was not.

Rather, it was delayed for extra 50 days until Thursday 16/04/2020 at 22:36, which was 64 days after its submission (on Wednesday 12/02/2020 at 19:27).

Not a single student received any mark or feedback for assignment 2(C) before that date.


1.6.7    Misuse of Students Charter



When I gently implied that his answers were not consistent with reality, he brandished the Student Charter and scolded me, saying, I had to "treat" him "with respect".


Ironically, the Student Charter was intended to affirm students' rights.

One of RMIT's commitments in the charter was to "address problems and complaints fairly and promptly".

And to "provide timely and accurate information about student's progress".


Now, "information about student's progress" means the marks of the assignments.

Right?

Was it "timely"?

Did I receive "accurate information" or did the Program Manager just lie to my face?

And did he "address problems [...] promptly", or did he flat-out refuse to intervene?


This is what I wrote to the Program Manager in response on Friday 28/02/2020 at 09:20:

Why do you go around.

You misled me for 3 days regarding a2p3.

Then after i raised my concerns you kept misleading me yet again regarding a2p1.

Both are fact. All documented.

[...]

Your threat is very much welcome.

Thanks








1.7    Delay of Final Results





1.7.1    Release Date of Final Results



RMIT states in Assessment Processes that:

5.8.1 For flexible delivery courses, however, schools/colleges set the result release date when scheduling the class: this date must be within 28 calendar days after the course end-date. Chapter 5 "Assessment — Management of results" (page 29)




RMIT listed the "results released" for "study period 4, 2019" as 30 march, 2020.


1.7.2    Inexplicable Delay of Final Result



The actual release date, however, was on Monday 04/05/2020 at 08:46.

This was a whopping 70 days after the examination date.







1.8    Students Not Told Exam's Results





1.8.1    Students Kept in the Dark



RMIT are swindlers.

And I mean it literally.


You pay them tens of thousands of dollars in tuition fees.

Then you take an exam.

They refuse to tell you the score.


1.8.2    Conspiracy to Deny Right of Appeal



This is very convenient (for them).

After all, releasing the results is bound to disappoint students who expected a higher grade than the one given.

Feeling aggrieved, they would cry foul and try to overturn the results.

God forbid, they might even contact the Academic Board and request a review.

But this is a no-no!


The Academic Board has no time or patience for nagging foreigners.


RMIT could not let students harass the Deputy Vice-Chancellor regarding their boring and petty appeals.

After all, Prof. Aleksandar Subic is busy "shaping the global technology agenda", and you are (at best) a cog on his (lobbying group) wheel.







1.9    Threaten Students Requesting Copy of Marked Exam





1.9.1    Petulance, Aggression and Bullying



As noted, RMIT ignored my requests to know the results of my own exam.

True to its tradition, RMIT resorted to petulance, aggression, and bullying.


1.9.2    Email to Office of Deputy Vice-Chancellor



After 5 working days of deafening silence, I wrote to the office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic on Friday 08/05/2020 at 17:58:

Also, no response again regarding the exam.

I did not get any feedback and i reject the mark.

I requested a copy and the feedback and this is still ignored.

You can not keep me in the dark regarding 50% of the final result (i.e. the exam) and prevent me from submitting an appeal.

My previous request to get the feedback for the exam — and no response so far — was 5 days ago.



1.9.3    Urgent Plea Before the Deadline



3 days later, I wrote again to the office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic on Monday 11/05/2020 at 10:03.

Please reply today regarding the exam copy and feedback.

As I am racing against your deadline of next week to submit the appeal, you should provide me with marks and the feedback.

Keeping me blind to the exam, which forms 50% of the total mark and to which I strongly objected, is a clear violation of my rights.

I was hoping for a fair process. So far, I am denied.



1.9.4    Vacuous Response



In response, the office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic sent me an email on Monday 11/05/2020 at 13:56 with a lot of words (blah blah...) that said nothing of substance.

Not one iota of that email addressed (not even remotely) my only question I had, i.e. what was my score on the exam.

Their condescending email, however, referred me to "advocacy services" (to get "mental health support") and sent me to counselling at the chaplaincy.


This is not different from any self-righteous bully who breaks your nose but gives you 20 dollars to catch a taxi to the hospital.


1.9.5    Ignored by Office of Deputy Vice-Chancellor



I wrote in response on Monday 11/05/2020 at 14:17 that they failed to answer my question.

They never responded.


1.9.6    Treated like Dirt



You see, the office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic, other than taking care of his (private) lobbying group, treats the students like dirt.

Literally.


1.9.7    Ignored by Nominated Academic



Four days earlier, on Friday 08/05/2020 at 18:08, I sent a similar email to the nominated academic enquiring about my results on the exam.


That email (to the nominated academic) on Friday 08/05/2020 at 18:08 reads:

Please provide me a copy of the exam as no feedback was provided.

I need to fill up a report and an appeal regarding the mark.

Thanks



He flat-out ignored it (as he ignored my other email where I introduced myself per RMIT's instructions for my appeal).


1.9.8    Reaching a Roadblock



Now, in a distance-learning environment, you never meet any of the staff involved, nor is the student allowed to make a phone call to the teachers (as I was told on Thursday 02/05/2019 at 12:01 and on Thursday 06/02/2020 at 11:10, among others).


And since my emails were ignored, and there was no other way to contact my teacher, I reached a roadblock and did not know how to proceed.


1.9.9    Plea With Associate Dean



Trying my luck on Monday 11/05/2020 at 13:02, I wrote to the Associate Dean and Discipline Head of Computer Science and IT: "Can you please help me? Thanks."


In this email, I forwarded the email sent to the office of Prof. Subic quoted above.


When he asked me to elaborate, I sent the following to the Associate Dean on Monday 11/05/2020 at 13:19.

I was asked to appeal.

But without the exam copy or feedback — which makes up 50% of the final result — it can not be done, as i have zero! Information about its marking.

I was promised otherwise, and it seems that nobody even checks their emails - except you.

Thanks



He asked me on Monday 11/05/2020 at 13:49 if I contacted the nominated academic, to which I responded on Monday 11/05/2020 at 14:04 that I was unsure if I had his correct email address (or if he was even monitoring his email) since he never confirmed any of my emails.


Other emails followed, and the Associate Dean assured me on Monday 11/05/2020 at 14:05 (while avoiding to address the issue directly) that the nominated academic "will manage things."


On Monday 11/05/2020 at 14:36, I forwarded this correspondence (and the entire thread) to the nominated academic, adding one word, namely: "Thanks".


1.9.10    Written Warning



The rest is history.

And a very sad one.


On Tuesday 12/05/2020 at 10:21, I received a threatening email from the nominated academic (which was his very first response) where he gave me a "written warning" (exact quote).

He scolded me that he was right to ignore all of my emails because he "decided the communication" from the office of Prof. Subic (quoted above) "was a sufficient response".


And no, not even one iota in his email addressed my urgent request regarding the results of my exam.


By the Ombudsman policy, quoted later, complaints must be acknowledged "quickly" in which it "should outline the complaint process".

He has done neither.

But he was quick to brandish his authority, wield his (suspension) powers, and whip me into submission.

And this was how he opted to introduce himself as an impartial arbitrator delegated to adjudicate my appeal.


Complaint Handling At Universities (by the Commonwealth Ombudsman) states:

Acknowledging complaints A complaint should be acknowledged quickly to reassure the complainant that their complaint is receiving attention. An acknowledgement can be an important tool in managing the complainant's expectations. [A/NZ S 8.6] The acknowledgement should outline the complaint process, provide a contact number and preferably the name of a contact person. As far as possible, the acknowledgement should indicate how long it is likely to take for the complainant to next be contacted. Chapter 4: Assessing complaints ("Acknowledging Complaints", page 20)




1.9.11    Associate Dean Runs Interference



Soon after, on Tuesday 12/05/2020 at 11:05 and on Tuesday 12/05/2020 at 11:09, the Associate Dean was quick to run interference for his colleague and — falsely — suggested I was already given all the required information.

Even though, neither he nor anyone else was willing to even remotely acknowledge my request and/or to explain why I was not allowed to know the results of my own exam.

This is, despite my emails to him 9 days earlier requesting to know the results of the exam.

And despite my emails to him just one day earlier (quoted above).

And despite the email sent to him earlier (on that day) on Tuesday 12/05/2020 at 10:03.


1.9.12    Ignored by Associated Dean



I responded to the Associate Dean on Tuesday 12/05/2020 at 15:23 telling him that after all the lies and threats, the nominated academic was still ignoring my request to know the results of my exam and never acknowledged it.

He never replied.


1.9.13    Lawless Institution



This is how RMIT breaks the law and muzzles Freedom of Information requests.

Make no mistake, RMIT is a lawless institution.







1.10    Engage in Ad Hominem Attacks





1.10.1    Summary



On Saturday 16/05/2020 at 12:00, I requested a copy of my own assignment.

In response, the office of Deputy Vice-Chancellor Prof. Aleksandar Subic waited until the last day before the deadline in order to reply.

And instead of giving me a copy, they opted for slanderous and abusive attacks that served no purpose other than to derail my appeal.


Simply put, they had a copy of my assignment.

I didn't.

I needed that copy for the appeal.

Therefore, I requested a copy.

Simple.

Right?


Well, not for the office of the Deputy Vice-Chancellor of RMIT University.

They torture the hell out of you until the last day of the deadline, and then they call you a liar.


1.10.2    Waste of Public Resources



This was clearly a waste of public funding.

They could have simply sent me a copy (by forwarding an email).

It would have taken only ten seconds of their time (namely, a few mouse clicks).

Instead, they chose to waste public money by engaging in (multiple of) pointless and provocative emails in which they tried to antagonize the student by (falsely) accusing him of being a liar.


1.10.3    Abuse of Bully Pulpit



Those personal attacks are a cynical abuse of their bully pulpit.

They knew well that a foreign student – responding in kind – would end up on a deportation flight back home subsequent to his permanent suspension from the university.


1.10.4    Appeal Deadline of Six Days



As mentioned, the final results were released on Monday 04/05/2020 at 08:46, a whopping 70 days after the end of the semester.

Students were not allowed to appeal before that date.

RMIT told me on Thursday 14/05/2020 at 17:08 that the deadline for my appeal was Wednesday 20/05/2020 at 17:00.


1.10.5    Assignment 2(B)



A central part of my appeal focused on assignment 2(B).

As you can see here, here, here, here, here, and here.


1.10.6    Assignment Not Accessible on Portal



This assignment was submitted on Wednesday 29/01/2020 at 17:01.

Usually, students can access past submissions on RMIT's portal.

This assignment, however, disappeared on Wednesday 12/02/2020 at 19:27.

This was discussed at length on Friday 14/02/2020 at 18:59 and its associated thread.

On Saturday 16/05/2020 at 12:00, I forwarded the full thread — proving the assignment was no longer available on the portal for the last 94 days (since Wednesday 12/02/2020 at 19:27) — and, hence, requested a copy.


1.10.7    Request for Copy of Assignment



The following is the email sent on Saturday 16/05/2020 at 12:00.

I do not have access to my submission to a2p2, as it was deleted when it was filed under a2p3 [...]

Please see the attached emails.

Basically [...] and thus I lost record of the original a2p2.

So, kindly attach my submission to a2p2.

This is very important to me, as I can not argue without the copy.

[...]

Thanks



1.10.8    Passive Aggressive Bullying



True to its bullying tradition, RMIT decided to ignore my email.

Not even an acknowledgement was sent.


1.10.9    Urgent Plea on Last Day Before Deadline



On the last day before the deadline, I sent another email.


The following is the email sent on Tuesday 19/05/2020 at 11:59 to the office of Prof. Subic.

As my requested documents — essential to my appeal — had not been provided before the deadline, you are requested to provide the 1)server project for a2p1, 2)a2p2 submission.

You are also requested to adjust the deadline to reflect those delays.

Previous emails clearly explained why I am missing those documents.



1.10.10    Malicious Bullying



In response, the office of Deputy Vice-Chancellor Prof. Aleksandar Subic sent me an email on Tuesday 19/05/2020 at 16:31 in which they "explained" why they would not send me a copy.

The reason was because — wait for it — I "can" use my own copy.


Then, after they refused to send me a copy because I "can" use my own copy, they urged me to "please use this copy" that I didn't have.


Do you see the nauseating and fake politeness when they told me to "please" use a copy that I didn't have and they refused to send?

What a prick!

The only thing missing in their email was some evil laughter ("mwahahaha!").


1.10.11    Urgent Plea



I responded on Wednesday 20/05/2020 at 08:53.

I have written a very detailed email why I can not access a2p2.

I have supported my email with a record of correspondence with [...] from 3 months ago.

Please, read it and respond to it.

It is very insulting to advise me where to find a2p2 when I took the trouble to give a long and supported record why I can not do it.

This is not an allegation.

This is something you are consistently guilty of.

You write very long emails pretending to address my questions while wasting my time.

Did you read the record of the emails from [...] from 3 months ago?

Do they explain why I have lost the record?

Are you still blaming me for that?

Are you going to suggest again to get a2p2 where I have proven that it is not possible and not for my fault?

Again, you have failed to confirm my email from Saturday.

And you have done a disservice by giving me the wrong advice how to find a2p2.



1.10.12    Urgent Plea to Office of Deputy Vice-Chancellor



Then I added on Wednesday 20/05/2020 at 10:06, writing to the office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic.

Professional?

No, this is outright insulting.

A very long email that tells me how to fix the issue, when my question proved with records why this is not possible.

I have provided records from 3 months ago that goes into detail why a2p2 disappeared.

So, why bother writing a very long email to direct me something that could not possibly be done?

And since when am I not allowed to ask for an extension, if [...] fails to provide the documents, takes many days to confirm an email, and then given this misleading answer.



1.10.13    Malicious Defamation of Students



The rest is history.

And a very sad one.


On Wednesday 20/05/2020 at 16:42, the office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic doubled down, saying, I was a liar and still had a copy of the assignment.

Mind you, this assignment was submitted on Wednesday 29/01/2020 at 17:01, which was 112 days earlier, and was not accessible on their portal for the last 98 days since Wednesday 12/02/2020 at 19:27.

Yet, they claimed that I had mentioned this assignment 83 days earlier (when I still had access to the original), and therefore they "determined" (exact quote) that I was liar.


Meaning, the impartial office of Prof. Subic — nominated to adjudicate my appeal — had already "determined" that I was a liar before they even read my appeal.

And to add insult to injury, they were determined to taunt and bait the student into endless and futile fights rather than facilitate his appeal.

And this is the office of Prof. Subic in a nutshell.







1.11    Coerce Students Not to Complain





1.11.1    Dictates Scope and Language of Appeal



In order to gain the upper hand, RMIT bullies you to sign their Appeal Form where they put words in your mouth.

You are forced to retract any claim you had raised before regarding impropriety or negligence in the exam's grading.

Then, they force you to base your appeal solely on the grounds of a supposed mathematical "mistake in the calculation of the results".

This is the only available option; you are forced to select it; confirm it; and then declare it to be true.


1.11.2    Students Forced to Play Dumb



You are not allowed to allege negligence, skim-reading, favouritism, discrimination, or malicious motives (even though they were all true allegations in my case).

On the contrary.

You are forced to play dumb and pretend that all of the above was just a "clerical error" and due to some elusive mistakes in the calculations of the results.


1.11.3    Dishonest Manipulation to Silence Complaints



Now, imagine complaining about excessive force by a police officer.

Does the state force you to sign a form saying there was a "mistake regarding the calculation" of the officer's fist movements, and, as a result, you got a bloody nose?

I sure hope this is not the case.


1.11.4    RMIT's Policy of Evasive Replies



However, RMIT wants your complaint to be as ambiguous as it gets, so they would get away with their evasive and smarmy responses.


1.11.5    Hands Tied, Blindfolded and Muzzled



They "allow" you to appeal but, at the same time, ensure that your hands and feet are tied, you are blindfolded, muzzled, and a gag is shoved into your mouth.


1.11.6    Form Inconsistent With Complaint



I told RMIT on Wednesday 13/05/2020 at 17:09 that their form was inconsistent with my complaint.


Following is an extract from my email sent on Wednesday 13/05/2020 at 17:09.

My appeal was NOT because there were "errors in calculation".

[...]

I think that the example speak for itself.



I repeated the above again on Friday 15/05/2020 at 19:13.

This email was confirmed by the office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic on Tuesday 19/05/2020 at 16:31, saying, they "can confirm that your email [...] of Friday 15 May 2020, at 7:13 pm was received."


1.11.7    Illegal Refusal to Process Complaints



In response, RMIT held a gun to my head and told me that if I refused to sign the form they would not progress my appeal, and I would be doomed with a failing grade (45% out of 100%) on the exam.


Are RMIT bullies?

Yes.

Are they criminals?

Yes.


1.11.8    RMIT: "Unacceptable to Accuse Staff Members"



There is more.

My emails laid out substantial evidence that the marker did not read my assignments.

However, on Monday 25/05/2020 at 14:15, the office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic threatened me with suspension if I dared to speak up.

I was warned that "accusing staff members of improper behaviour" (such as negligence or skim-reading) was "unacceptable".


And you thought that North Korea got it wrong.


1.11.9    Hypocrisy Galore



And there is more.

While they threatened me not to "accuse staff members" (of things they were evidently guilty of), this office of Prof. Subic was busy making false accusations in order to malign my character.

Hypocrisy much?


1.11.10    Shuts Up Discrimination Complaint



And if this was not enough, the office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic told me on Wednesday 13/05/2020 at 10:39 ("I have been advised") that I was not allowed to bring up my discrimination complaint (or base my appeal on its grounds).


Other venues of RMIT (such as RMIT Connect) refused to look into any complaint regarding the results of the exam (or any issue related).

For example, on Thursday 07/05/2020 at 10:41 they "closed" my complaint without any help, advice or referral because the "issue falls under the appeal process".


However, the Appeals Committee itself, headed by Prof. Aleksandar Subic, did not allow me to base my appeal on the discriminatory grounds.

And when he was asked for information, Prof. Subic illegally went silent and refused to acknowledge my emails.


1.11.11    Foreign Students Are Easy Prey at RMIT



As a lone gazelle in a foreign land, there is nothing you can do about it.

On the contrary.

You are vulnerable and easy prey.

Be careful before you speak up!

Never forget that the office of Prof. Subic did not hesitate to illegally exact revenge on a foreigner who dared to complain.







1.12    Reject Appeals Without Explanation





1.12.1    Vacuous and Inexplicable Decisions



On Friday 05/06/2020 at 17:13, my appeal got rejected by the office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic.

No explanation or details were provided.

However, I was told that he "can confirm" the above.


1.12.2    Violation of Law



The law says that students should be "informed in writing" the outcome "and the reasons".

The explanation provided should be "sufficiently detailed to permit an assessment of its validity and the viability of pursuing any available avenue of appeal."


Have they done so?

No.

Did they break the law?

You bet!


1.12.3    The Higher Education Standards Framework (2015) Act



The Higher Education Standards Framework (2015) Act says that:

1. Current and prospective students have access to mechanisms that are capable of resolving grievances about any aspect of their experience with the higher education provider, its agents or related parties. 2. There are policies and processes that deliver timely resolution of formal complaints and appeals against academic and administrative decisions without charge or at reasonable cost to students, and these are applied consistently, fairly and without reprisal. 3. Institutional complaints-handling and appeals processes for formal complaints include provision for confidentiality, independent professional advice, advocacy and other support for the complainant or appellant, and provision for review by an appropriate independent third party if internal processes fail to resolve a grievance. 4. Decisions about formal complaints and appeals are recorded and the student concerned is informed in writing of the outcome and the reasons, and of further avenues of appeal where they exist and where the student could benefit. 2.4 Student Grievances and Complaints




1.12.4    Ombudsman's Directives



Complaint Handling At Universities by the Commonwealth Ombudsman states:

Finalising an investigation [....] It generally requires: • A statement of the reasons for the complaint determination that is sufficiently detailed to permit an assessment of its validity and the viability of pursuing any available avenue of appeal. • Advice about the existence of any avenues of appeal or review and how to access them. • Where practical, provision of a copy of or at least significant extracts from or summaries of the content of the report of the complaint investigation. Investigating Complaints (page 27)









1.13    No Appeal of Initial (First-Level) Decision





1.13.1    Stage-1 Review Decision



On Friday 05/06/2020 at 17:13, the office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic told me that they "have received notification" that stage-1 review "has been completed".


1.13.2    Blocks Appeal of Stage-1 Review



After telling me the "outcome" of the stage-1 review, they told me — in the same email — that "this matter is considered closed".


Was it against the law?

Yes.

Did the office of Prof. Subic make a mockery of federal guidelines?

Yes.


The law says that "appeals-processes" include "provision for review by an appropriate independent third party if internal processes fail to resolve a grievance".

And, that students should be "informed in writing" about "further avenues of appeal where they exist and where the student could benefit".


1.13.3    Violation of Ombudsman's Directions



Complaint Handling At Universities by the Commonwealth Ombudsman states:

Reviewing decisions Good complaint handling practice provides at least one level of internal review of initial decisions about complaints. This simply recognises the possibility of error in an initial decision. Bringing fresh eyes to review that decision provides the opportunity either to detect and correct any initial error or provide greater certainty about the correctness of the initial decision. [...] Reasons should always be given for any decisions about a review. This applies even if there is no further avenue of internal review or appeal since, if nothing else, it gives confidence that the review was given proper consideration. A 'three level' model has been much discussed as offering best practice in effective complaint handling. Under this model, the aim is to resolve the majority of complaints at the first level – the front line. Level two of the model is the processes of internal assessment, facilitated resolution or internal review that the university itself would be able to offer – including investigation by an external investigator under contract. The third level of review consists of the participation of organisations such as Parliamentary Ombudsman, professional oversight bodies and anti-corruption commissions who have the capacity to investigate matters. At each level, either the complainant or the university can decide to escalate the issue to a higher level. In some cases, a right of appeal or review to a tribunal or court may also exist and could also be considered as a third level option. Dissatisfied complainants should be advised of these avenues of appeal or review and of any relevant known time limits. Investigating Complaints (page 30)









1.14    No Independent Third-Party Review





1.14.1    Cabal of Academics With Self-Serving Bias



Academics are unlikely to "betray" a colleague by officially disputing his academic judgement in favour of a student's appeal.

Turning your neighbour or a colleague into your personal enemy is the last thing you want in your life.


What you see, however, is the exact opposite, namely, they tend to stick together as a team, watch each other's back and circle the wagons to protect their own interests.

This is all the more true when a foreign student is involved who:

  • Has a language barrier and lacks resources/connections.
  • Is at the mercy of the university to extend his visa and can — at any time — be suspended and deported.



1.14.2    High Court of Injustice



Academics in Australia are virtually infallible and cannot be challenged neither internally nor in a court of law.

In fact, the courts have granted universities an unconditional shield and automatic protection against litigation or lawsuits.


Notably, in his ruling, Justice of the High Court of Australia Michael Kirby said:

I recognize that Universities are in many ways peculiar public institutions. They have special responsibilities as the University Act envisages in this case, to uphold high academic standards, about which members of the academic staff will often be more cognisant than judges. There are issues pertaining to the intimate life of every independent academic institution that, sensibly, courts decline to review: the marking of an examination paper; the academic merit of a thesis; the viability of a research project; the award of academic tenure; and internal budgets. Others might be added: the contents of a course; particular styles of teaching; and the organisation of course timetables. Griffith University v Tang (2005) 221 CLR 99, 156-7 [165].




1.14.3    TEQSA Is Not Responsive



The Tertiary Education Quality and Standards Agency (TEQSA) is a federal agency that monitors universities' compliance with the law.

Or so they claim.


TEQSA states the following:

[...] expect the provider's policy and procedures to be followed where a student lodges a complaint or appeal. These policies and procedures should explicitly make provision for review by an appropriate independent third party if internal processes fail to resolve any grievance, and should specify indicative timeframes for resolution of complaints. [...] Providers are required to make available to their students specific avenues of appeal to independent third parties for matters not within the jurisdiction of the ACCC or an ombudsman. TEQSA Commentary: 2.4 Student Grievances and Complaint (page 19)




This student contacted TEQSA and showed evidence that RMIT failed to comply with the above.

TEQSA did not bother to respond.


1.14.4    Ignored by the Executive Dean



On Tuesday 16/06/2020 at 11:38, I wrote to the Executive Dean that:

This is where the university makes a mockery of its degrees and reduces them to garbage, while giving zero marks for correct answers.

[...]

Please, also compare all the other questions, where my questions completely match his answers, but I was not given full points.

[...]

I was given half the marks for other answers, where my answers were completely compatible with the "approved" answers.

Does RMIT allow such dishonesty?

Every single answer in the exam should be checked and explained why I was not given the full points.

[...]

I call for a 3rd party to look again into my answers.

I call for the university to immediately retract its failed answers to exam 1C, and fix the mark for all the student that gave the correct answer



On Wednesday 17/06/2020 at 16:46, I wrote further to the Executive Dean and expanded on the above.

He never replied.


As quoted, I told him that "I call for a 3rd party to look again into my answers".

As mentioned, he ignored me.

Did he break the law?

Yes.


And as quoted, I told him that "I call for the university to immediately retract its failed answers to exam 1C, and fix the mark for all the student that gave the correct answer."

As mentioned, he ignored me.

Did he break the law?

Yes.







1.15    Suspends Students Requesting Third-Party Reviews





1.15.1    Legally-Deficient Reply



As noted in previous chapters, RMIT rejected my appeal.

However, their reply was legally deficient because:

  • RMIT merely "confirmed" but failed to explain why.
  • They prevented me from appealing their initial (first-level) decision.
  • They blocked an independent third-party review.



And to add insult to injury, they mocked my appeal and lied through their teeth.


I was naturally disappointed, to say the least, and I did not know how to proceed.


1.15.2    Plea to Associate Dean



Picking up the pieces, I contacted the Associate Dean and Discipline Head of Computer Science and IT, who, at the very start of the appeal process, assured me that the school "will manage things".

I poured my heart out to him, described my predicament and asked him to do an independent review.


This is the email I sent to the Associate Dean on Saturday 06/06/2020 at 22:34.

I applogize if you are too buzy, and prefer not to handle my issue anymore.

It is only because I believe that there was here a blatant travesty of justice.

And tbh, you were the only one that was fair with me and provided timely and constructive responses.

I am hoping for some guidance and a little help, and I will be very thankful if you would accept this request.

But If you choose not to correspond with me, it will be perfectly fine with me, although, I am genuinely shocked and deeply disappointed of the results so far.

Please accept my apology and whatever you choose, allow me to thank you for your leadership so far.

Regards



On Wednesday 10/06/2020 at 20:46, I further wrote to the Associate Dean regarding the exams.

[...]

My answers matched completely to the answers in the "marking guide" and surprisingly i was not given the marks.

The same is true for a specific example i have shown from assignment 2 part 2 and many more.

[...]

And lastly, I am still very hurt that my discrimination ("racism") appeal regarding exam question 4, was not looked into, but I did not want to disturb you any further, even though I feel VERY bad about it.

[...]

Finaly, my applogies and sincere thanks.



1.15.3    Ignored by Associate Dean



The Associate Dean never confirmed or acknowledge any of the above.


1.15.4    Reprisals Against Complaints



However, on Wednesday 10/06/2020 at 18:01, the office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic told me that requesting help from another academic was disrespectful to his office and, therefore, ordered my suspension from RMIT.


Mind you, this punishment was a direct retaliation to my legitimate and justified complaint.

The federal government has clear guidelines regarding "reprisals against complaints".


Complaint Handling At Universities by the Commonwealth Ombudsman states:

Protecting complainants against reprisals There is both an individual and public interest in protecting a complainant against reprisals that may arise from a complaint made in good faith, regardless of whether the complaint is ultimately found to be sustained or dismissed. The university should be prepared to issue strong warnings to those who may consider reprisals and, if these are ignored, act promptly and decisively against those involved in any reprisals. In addition, the university should be prepared to make arrangements to prevent disadvantage to a complainant. These necessary steps may include, for example, arranging an alternative lecturer or course supervisor for the complainant or appointing a mentor. [...] It should be stressed, however, that extreme care must be taken with such matters. A complaint that seems to lack plausibility or is not found to be substantiated is not necessarily false. Whether cases are decided 'beyond a reasonable doubt' or 'on the balance of probabilities', there will always be cases where there is insufficient evidence to reach certainty about the facts of a matter. This does not and cannot mean that the way is now free for that person or authority to take reprisal action against the individuals who complained about them. Universities have a particular power imbalance between students and staff that unfortunately provides many opportunities for reprisals to be taken against student complainants in ways that may be difficult to expose. There is a corresponding responsibility on university administrations to ensure that students who make legitimate complaints are given every reasonable protection. Ultimately, the best protection comes from strong leadership - committed to promoting an administrative culture that welcomes complaints and treats complainants as assets of good management and organisational improvement. Protecting complainants against reprisals (page 34)




Sadly, these guidelines are all talk, no action.

When push comes to shove, the authorities let RMIT run amok with their malicious retaliations without any consequences or outside scrutiny.

In fact, the Commission itself told me – after a tormenting delay of 42 days – that the university "is not responding", and there is nothing in the law to "force" their hand.


"Power tends to corrupt. Absolute power corrupts absolutely."








1.16    Ombudsman's Total Servitude to Corrupt University





1.16.1    Ombudsman at RMIT



The University Ombudsman's role is described as:

The RMIT Ombuds provides an avenue of confidential and independent review for staff and students who have unresolved complaints. The Ombuds is not an advocate but aims to mediate and conciliate disputes with a focus on systemic improvement. The Ombuds has extensive academic and administrative experience in the tertiary education sector.




1.16.2    Ombudsman Refuses to Intervene



On Thursday 25/06/2020 at 21:07, Thursday 25/06/2020 at 22:11, Friday 26/06/2020 at 00:37, and Wednesday 01/07/2020 at 23:56, I wrote to the University Ombudsman and the self-described "values-driven" General Counsel.

I showed in full detail how RMIT — secretly — blamed its own mistakes on the students and then refused to publish the results.

Then, I outlined my racial discrimination complaint in detail and asked them for help.


On Thursday 16/07/2020 at 13:02, my petition got rejected without any explanation.

Nor did the General Counsel provide any advice, referral or other options.

But I was urged to contact the office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic "to obtain further information".


Mind you, they told me to "obtain further information" from the same office I had just complained about.

Puke!


But there is more.

As quoted, RMIT's Ombudsman's role is to "mediate and conciliate disputes".

Or to provide "an avenue of confidential and independent review for students who have unresolved complaints".

Now, did the Ombudsman ever reached out in order to "mediate" or to do an "independent review"?

No.


1.16.3    Lawlessness of University Ombudsman



RMIT's Ombudsman told me that "following the School level review decision, you were provided with the opportunity to appeal your assessment grade with the College Appeals Committee".

Is RMIT's Ombudsman a bold-faced liar?

Yes.


I told the Ombudsman that I failed the exam because of "a word from a language and a culture that I was not familiar with."

I also told RMIT's Ombudsman that "I was discriminated because of my cultural background."

I also told RMIT's Ombudsman that "the only thing that failed me the 4th question, is my cultural background, that should not have been taken as a factor, when they failed me - with 0 mark".

I also told RMIT's Ombudsman that "I was hoping [...] RMIT will know well to spare me this racist attitude."

RMIT's Ombudsman declined to review my case.

In other words, RMIT's Ombudsman willfully participated in direct racial discrimination.

Did the Ombudsman break the law?

Yes.


I told the General Counsel that "the exam text was discriminatory (where they failed me only because I did not know the meaning of an obscure term, that has nothing to do with the course, and no help was provided, when I asked for, while still in the exam room and this was against policy to have the teacher on standby to prevent such "mistakes")".

RMIT's General Counsel refused to response.

Did the "values-driven" General Counsel break the law.

Yes.


I told the Ombudsman that the exam "should be reviewed independently by a 3rd party".

RMIT's Ombudsman blocked a third-party review.

Did the Ombudsman break the law.

Yes.


I showed how RMIT — secretly — blamed its own mistakes on the students and refused to publish the results.

RMIT's Ombudsman declined to take action.

By perpetuating RMIT's error, the Ombudsman committed theft by finding.

Did the Ombudsman break the law?

Yes.







1.17    Hostile and Mean-Spirited Invigilators





1.17.1    Discrimination



Long story short, one of the programming questions was based on the intricacies of a TV game show.

Foreign students were (culturally and linguistically) unable to understand the question through no fault of their own.


When I asked the invigilators for help, they told me no help is available.


When I asked them to see a supervisor, they told me: "No".

When I asked them to affirm my note on the exam paper (that no supervisor was available), they told me: "No."

When I asked them what was the name of the supervisor, they told me it was "confidential".


After lengthy negotiations, a supervisor (finally) turned up.

I pointed at the obscure term, told her I did not know the meaning of the word and asked her for guidance.

She told me that teachers were not available, and help was not allowed.

I explained the discrimination issue, but she couldn't care less.

I asked her to document the interaction on my paper for evidence purposes, but she refused.

I asked her to identify herself for future reference, but she would not give me even her first name.


After the exam ended, I refused to turn in the paper unless I was allowed to attach a cover letter detailing my discrimination.

Soon, I was swarmed by a horde of invigilators and was told that if I did not give in the papers, I would be suspended.


I proceeded, however, to pick up my pencil to write my complaint on the exam paper itself.

Forthwith, the self-identified chief supervisor warned me that I was prohibited from "touching" my pencil since it was past the 2-hours writing time.


Some "negotiations" proceeded, and after a slew of passive-aggressive responses and a relentless stream of threats, I was given a phone number of a junior colleague of theirs and told to ring in tomorrow to make a complaint.


1.17.2    Broken Promises



Prof. Aleksandar Subic told the world in his press release that he had a passion for driving "positive student experiences and outcomes".

Likewise, we were told, he had a passion for "building a culture of inclusion".


Did he put any of those self-proclaimed passions into action?

No.







1.18    Charity Status





1.18.1    Tax-Free Charity Status



As late as 03/2019, Universities Australia submitted to the Treasury that:

Universities do not and should not pay income tax This section addresses the public policy rationale for universities being exempt from paying income tax and why such an exemption should continue. [...] Any income earned by public universities is ultimately put to the provision of public services such as subsidised education, not to the distribution of profit to individuals, which is why universities are not and should not be subject to any proxy income taxes.




1.18.2    Tax Fraud



"Any income earned by public universities is ultimately put to the provision of public services such as subsidised education".

This statement is a bold-faced lie and amounts to tax fraud.


1.18.3    Misappropriation of Tuition Fees



Contrary to their self-righteous assertion, this is what RMIT does:

  • First, they extort from the students (and the federal government) expensive and overpriced tuition fees.
  • Then, they cancel all meaningful services.
  • Then, they steal from their own (temporary) tutors.
  • Then, they misappropriate just about all of the tuition fees to their own self-serving business dealings.
  • Then, they torment the students with sloppy and error-ridden exams while refusing to offer help.
  • Then, they disregard federal law.
  • Then, they discriminate against foreign students.
  • Then, they ignore the Ombudsman, state commissions (among others).
  • And then, they have the nerve to submit the sanctimonious statement quoted above ("subsidised education") and demand tax-free status.








Chapter 2
— Freedom of Information





2.1    The Crimes Act



Public Record Office Standard (Victoria) states:

It is an offence under the Crimes (Document Destruction) Act 2006 for individuals or organisations to destroy documents that they know are reasonably likely to be required in a future legal proceeding, with the intention of keeping the documents out of evidence. 1.2.1 — The Crimes (Document Destruction) Act 2006 (page 10)




2.2    Preservation of All Records



I urge RMIT to adhere to the law and keep all records intact until further notice.

This includes: assignments, examination papers, results, feedback, appeals, emails, documents, etc., in relation to any of the students in any course offered by this Unit Coordinator in the last five years.


2.3    Caution Staff Against Destruction of Evidence



In addition, any correspondence regarding this course involving any member from RMIT (or anyone directly or indirectly related) should be preserved.

I urge RMIT to immediately contact any member in the following list and unambiguously caution them — in writing — against destruction of evidence.

These include (among many others not mentioned):
  • Deputy Vice-Chancellor Prof. Aleksandar Subic
  • College Appeal Committee (ColAC)
  • Executive Dean Prof. Rxxxxxx Cxxxxxxx (retired)
  • Governance Officer Ms. Melissa Dxxx
  • Associate Dean And Discipline Head of Computer Science and IT Prof. Lxxxxxxx Cxxxxxx
  • Associate Dean, Student Experience Prof. Jxxxx Hxxxxxx
  • Senior Lecturer, Program Manger Dr. Pxxx Vxxxx
  • First-year Coordinator for the Bachelor of IT program Dr. Txxxxxx Wxxxx
  • General Counsel and University Secretary Ms. Bxxxxx Lxxxx
  • University Ombudsman (including executive officer)
  • Unit Coordinator
  • Tutors involved in this course (at least 3)
  • Invigilators, including Ms. Sam Dxxxxxx
  • RMIT Connect
  • The Open University
  • TEQSA
  • Program Manager for IT courses (OUA coordinator) Cxxxx Hxxxxxxx
  • Federal Ombudsman
  • State Ombudsman (Victoria)
  • Fair Trading Commission
  • Any member of RMIT who corresponded with one of the above



2.4    Full Disclosure of Grading Process



By policy, the following records are permanently retained. See Assessment Processes.

These include:

  • "declaration that they have been proofed [...] retained [...] in an auditable manner" (2.7.7).
  • An "auditable record of the completion of proofing" (2.8.4).
  • Minutes of the Course Assessment Committee (3.7).
  • Minutes of the Program Assessment Board (3.18).
  • The moderation process (3.23.2, 3.25.6).
  • The validation of the assessments (3.28 and 3.30).
  • Records of the quality-assurance reviews (3.25.9).
  • Changes to published results (5.11; see email on Wednesday 10/06/2020 at 18:01).








Chapter 3
— Exam 2(A)
— Allocate Memory for the Lines





3.1    Identical Answers by RMIT and Student



3.1.1    "Approved" Answer of RMIT



Extract from RMIT's "approved" answer to question 2(A) in the exam

227 /* allocate memory for the lines – 3 marks */ 228 229 thedoc->lines = (struct line **)malloc(sizeof(struct line) * MINLINES); 230 if (!thedoc->lines) { 231 perror("malloc"); 232 free(thedoc); 233 return NULL; 234 }




3.1.2    Answer of the Student



Extract from the student's answer to question 2(A) in the exam

255 if ((d->lines = malloc(50 * sizeof *d->lines)) == NULL) { 256 fprintf(stderr, "alloc error\n"); 257 exit(1); 258 }




3.2    Zero Marks for a Correct Answer



First, let's get the MINLINES macro out of the way.

Although used three times in the "approved" answer, it was never defined.

However, its expansion to '50' is obvious from the context.

Right?


Now, both answers (of RMIT and the student) were (virtually) identical.


Furthermore, I even got the placement of the nested parentheses (and their balance) right.

This extra pair of parentheses was added to override the (default) low precedence of the assignment ('=') operator.

And no, it was not trivial.

Because RMIT expected us to write 221.6 characters per minute using a pencil and paper.


However, I was given zero marks.


3.3    RMIT's Answer Is Lacking



But wait, there is more.

It turns out, RMIT's answer was incorrect.

Unlike the student's one, which was 100% correct.

And for which he was given zero marks.


When you break it down, you see that RMIT — unlike the student — used a computer to write their answers.

Meaning, they had access to vital development tools, including:

  • Keyboard (instead of pencil and paper).
  • Text editor (syntax highlighting, autocomplete, and gazillions of other features of a modern editor).
  • Compiler (to detect compilation errors or warnings).
  • Operating system (to run the executable; discover runtime errors or unexpected output).
  • Debuggers (Valgrind, libasan, etc., that pinpoint any conceivable error or issue).



In addition, they had unlimited time to think, write, run the executable, and debug.

(Not to mention the freshly-ground cup of coffee and the occasional snack).

Then, they were able to take a step back, retire for a good night's sleep and come back to review their code with fresh eyes and a new perspective.


Students, however, were running a 2-hours marathon (with no breaks), writing many pages of convoluted code with a pencil.


There were 12 questions.

And students were expected to write their answers in a few minutes (ranging from 2.5 to 12.5 minutes, depending on the question).

And to make matters worse, RMIT forced the students to write — per each question — up to 2,073 characters with a pencil.

Meaning, instead of letting the students answer the technical question, RMIT forced them to waste their limited time writing long pages of text that added nothing of value other than inhibiting the much-needed focus on the crucial parts of the question.


Add to that the incessant harassment of the (sullen) invigilators who constantly stroll around you in circles, snoop on you behind your back and stare into your soul for the entire duration of the exam.

And to make matters worse, they invade your personal space just about when you are deep down in the middle of a long, convoluted answer and tell you to lift your face from the examination paper.

What perfect timing!


Apparently, they decided to conduct — in the middle of the exam — an in-depth analysis of your facial features to see if you match the picture on your ID card.

RMIT is run by idiots.


Not long after, they came back for another analysis, this time with an angrier tone, telling me to lift my face even higher in order for them to get a more in-depth look.

So, now they distracted the student for the second time.

Success, I guess.


Remarkably, it was rather RMIT that stumbled twice(!) by:

  1. Failing to allocate the correct memory size.
  2. Accessing out-of-bound memory areas.



On the other hand, the student gave a correct answer (and frankly, the only one possible).

And for that correct answer, he was given zero marks.


Do you really think that RMIT has an ounce of credibility left?

And can you finally see why the office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic was eager to break the law and refused to submit to a third-party review?


Answer of RMIT to question 2(A) in the exam 'sizeof' mix-ups are emphasized

227 /* allocate memory for the lines – 3 marks 228 229 thedoc->lines = (struct line **)malloc(sizeof(struct line) * MINLINES); 230 if (!thedoc->lines) { 231 perror("malloc"); 232 free(thedoc); 233 return NULL; 234 } 235 236 237 /* initialise with sensible values – 2 marks */ 238 239 memset(thedoc->lines, 0, sizeof(struct line) * MINLINES);




RMIT (in its "approved" answer) fails to (correctly) allocate the required size.

And then, upon repeating the same mistake for the second time, they write to out-of-bound memory areas.

The nastiest (and most lethal) bug by far.


Those errors occurred by incorrectly using:

sizeof(struct line)


Instead of:

sizeof(struct line *)



sizeof of a pointer-to-a-struct and sizeof of the struct (itself) are two different beasts.

Those two memory areas have different and unrelated sizes.

To confuse between those two guarantees to reduce your program to pure garbage.


Please note that those errors, while alarming by themselves, are not the key issue here.

Rather, the purpose here is to bring to light a grotesque absurdity.

Namely, that an incorrect answer was put on a pedestal as an exemplary model and the ultimate truth (i.e. the "approved" answer), while, in contrast, a correct answer (of the student) was silently ignored and left without any grade.


3.4    Memset() the Memory Area of 'lines'



You may have noticed that the "approved" answer (of RMIT) contains:

Extract from RMIT's "approved" answer to question 2(A) in the exam

239 memset(thedoc->lines, 0, sizeof(struct line) * MINLINES);




However, later on, when calling realloc(), they forgot to memset() the added memory slots.

Extract from RMIT's "approved" answer to question 2(B) in the exam

324 struct line **newlines = (struct line **)realloc(thedoc->lines, 325 sizeof(struct line *) * newsize); 326 if (!newlines) { 327 perror("realloc"); 328 return FALSE; 329 } 330 331 thedoc->lines = newlines;




ANSI C (89) says that:

ANSI C

4.10.3.4 The realloc function Synopsis #include <stdlib.h> void *realloc(void *ptr, size_t size); Description The realloc function changes the size of the object pointed to by ptr to the size specified by size. The contents of the object shall be unchanged up to the lesser of the new and old sizes. If the new size is larger, the value of the newly allocated portion of the object is indeterminate.




POSIX states that:

Realloc: The Open Group Base Specifications Issue 6

If the new size is larger, the contents of the newly allocated portion of the object are unspecified.




Linux man page states that:

Realloc(3): Linux Man Page

Any bytes in the new object beyond the size of the old object have indeterminate values.




However, truth to be told, this memset() call was never necessary.


Because there was a (silent) assumption that all valid pointers resided consecutively in lines.

I.e. there were no holes in the memory area of lines.

Thus, the only thing you had to take care of is to initialize numlines, once, to 0.

From then on, you are guaranteed that numlines will always reflect the number of (consecutive) valid pointers (within the memory area of lines).

Consequently, you can safely assume when traversing the memory area of lines that any slot number in [0,numlines-1] contains a valid memory pointer.


This assumption was (explicitly) written by the student in his answer.

Extract from the student's answer to question 2(B) in the exam

345 /* Assumption: 346 All occupied lines follow each other. 347 There are no holes. */




This is (also) well supported by the "approved" answer (of RMIT).

Here you can see how RMIT's "approved" answer unconditionally stores a new line into the numlines slot.


Extract from RMIT's "approved" answer to question 2(B) in the exam

319 if (thedoc->numlines == thedoc->lines_alloced) { 320 321 /* allocate space for more lines – 4 marks */ 322 int newsize = thedoc->numlines * 2; 323 324 struct line **newlines = (struct line **)realloc(thedoc->lines, 325 sizeof(struct line *) * newsize); 326 if (!newlines) { 327 perror("realloc"); 328 return FALSE; 329 } 330 331 thedoc->lines = newlines; 332 thedoc->lines_alloced = newsize; 333 } 334 335 /* store the line – 1 mark */ 336 337 thedoc->lines[thedoc->numlines++] = aline;




The following assumes the same.

Extract from RMIT's "approved" answer to question 2(C) in the exam

402 /* iterate over the lines and free each line, 2 marks */ 403 for (count = 0; count < thedoc->numlines; ++count) { 404 linefree(thedoc->lines[count]); 405 }




The same assumption is evident in the following.

Extract from RMIT's "approved" answer to question 3(B) in the exam

550 /* iterate over each line in the document – 1 mark */ 551 552 for (count = 0; count < doc->numlines; ++count) { 553 int charcount; 554 struct line *curline = doc->lines[count]; 555 char *text = doc->lines[count]->text;




3.5    Recovery From malloc() Errors



Finally, another point (that will be regurgitated tediously in the next chapters) regarding allocation errors whether they necessitate an immediate exit/abort call, or a recovery attempt is feasible and/or recommended.

Obviously, the student follows the first strategy, whereas the "approved" answer does the latter.

The merits of those conventions (and their arguments) will be discussed elsewhere.

4.1.2    Answer of the Student

263 return d;









Chapter 5
— Exam 2(B)
— Allocate Space for the String





5.1    Equivalent Answer, Yet Zero Marks



5.1.1    "Approved" Answer of RMIT



Extract from RMIT's "approved" answer to question 2(B) in the exam

296 /* allocate space for the string and copy the data in – 3 marks */ 297 298 theline->text = (char *)malloc(sizeof(char) * (theline->len + 1)); 299 strcpy(theline->text, line);




5.1.2    Answer of the Student



Extract from the student's answer to question 3(A) in the exam

516 if (doc_add_line(d, strdup(buf)) == FALSE) 517 return NULL;




5.2    Malloc() and strdup() Are Equivalent



Both (RMIT and the student), effectively, do the same thing, namely:

  1. Allocate new memory area for the line's text.
  2. Store (copy) the text into the allocated area.



Those operations (of allocation+copy) can be achieved by either one of the following:

  • malloc() + strcpy(), as was done in the "approved" answer (of RMIT).
  • strdup(), as was done by the student.



In the student's implementation, it was the caller's responsibility to strdup() the text before calling doc_add_line().

This was done by:

Extract from the student's answer to question 3(A) in the exam

516 if (doc_add_line(d, strdup(buf)) == FALSE) 517 return NULL;




And since the caller had already called strdup() on the buffer, the student noted that there was no need to strdup() the (already dynamically-allocated) line's text.

Extract from the student's answer to question 2(B) in the exam

356 /* No strdup() on line */




5.3    strdup() Is a POSIX Standard function



Although strdup() is not standardized by ANSI C, it is a POSIX standard function.

It is readily available in any Linux distribution and its usage is prevalent in everyday UNIX/Linux projects.

As a reminder, this course targeted the Linux environment as the only "legitimate" platform.


5.3.1    strdup() in This Course



In fact, the following is an extract from the Unit Coordinator's instructions for this course, in which he described strdup() as a "commonly available convenience function".

/home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a1/startup/helpers.c

15 /** 16 * a commonly available convenience function that mallocs space for a copy of 17 * the string passed in and if that succeeds, copy the data and return a 18 * pointer to the copy and otherwise return NULL. 19 **/ 20 char *strdup(const char *oldstr) { 21 char *copy; 22 /* get the length of the string */ 23 ssize_t len = strlen(oldstr); 24 /* malloc space */ 25 copy = (char *)malloc(sizeof(char) * (len + 1)); 26 /* if this failed, return NULL */ 27 if (!copy) { 28 perror("malloc"); 29 return NULL; 30 } 31 /* otherwise, copy the data */ 32 memcpy(copy, oldstr, sizeof(char) * (len + 1)); 33 return copy; 34 }









Chapter 6
— Exam 2(B)
— Reasonable Variable Declaration





6.1    Identical Answers, Yet Zero Marks



6.1.1    "Approved" Answer of RMIT



Extract from RMIT's "approved" answer to question 2(B) in the exam

310 /* 2 marks for reasonable variable declarations */ 311 struct line *aline;




6.1.2    Answer of the Student



Extract from the student's answer to question 2(B) in the exam

349 struct line *line;




6.2    Abnormal Naming Convention (of RMIT)



There is only one difference between the "approved" answer (given by RMIT) and the student's one.

RMIT named the variable:

aline


While the student named it:

line



If you wondered, 'aline' (in the "approved" answer) stands for 'a line'.


RMIT's naming convention is unconventional.

As you know, the most common word in the English language is the word 'the'.

RMIT often takes this word and adds it (as a prefix) to local variables.

As a result, their code became cumbersome and turned into an undecipherable blob of "the" identifiers.


As an example, in this exam, RMIT saw fit to prepend a 'the' prefix to any other local variable, including:

  • thedoc
  • theline
  • thestats
  • theword
  • thelist



As shown later, this was a 562,264% inflation of "the" variables compared to everyday software projects.


When RMIT got tired of the 'the' prefix, it resorted to the 'a' prefix.

Somehow, this local variable was deemed to be less important, and thus, instead of 'theline', RMIT named it 'aline' ("a line").


Everyday software projects, however, do not contain neither 'thefoo' nor 'afoo'.

Instead, their variables are unvarnished and plain 'foo'.


Nevertheless, RMIT decided to give me zero marks.

Because I failed to name the variable 'aline' ("a line").

And instead called it, pure and simple, 'line'.


Hey mister, you forgot the 'a' prefix!
