10.2    Abuse of BUFSIZ Macro



However, there is one difference regarding the size definition of the buffer.

RMIT used BUFSIZ, while the student used BUFSIZE.

Which one is correct?

I discuss it here.







Chapter 11
— Exam 3(A)
— Open the File for Reading





11.1    Identical Answers, Yet 50% Marks



Every element of both answers (of RMIT and the student) was identical, including:

  1. The function used, namely: fopen().
  2. The two arguments, namely:
    1. The filename.
    2. The mode argument, i.e. "r".
  3. The return type, namely: a FILE stream.
  4. The error checks, namely: a NULL return value as an error indicator.
  5. The diagnostics, namely: error messages are sent to stderr.



Furthermore, I even got the placement of the nested parentheses (and their balance) right.

This extra pair of parentheses was added to override the (default) low precedence of the assignment ('=') operator.

And no, it was not trivial.

Because RMIT expected us to write 221.6 characters per minute using a pencil and paper.


However, I was given 1 mark (out of 2).


11.1.1    "Approved" Answer of RMIT



Extract from RMIT's "approved" answer to question 3(A) in the exam

462 /* open the reader and check for success – 2 marks */ 463 464 reader = fopen(filename, "r"); 465 if (!reader) { 466 perror("fopen"); 467 return NULL; 468 }




11.1.2    Answer of the Student



Extract from the student's answer to question 3(A) in the exam

506 if ((F = fopen(f, "r")) == NULL) /* 1 mark */ 507 fprintf(stderr, "error\n"), exit(1);









Chapter 12
— Exam 3(A)
— Read Each Line From the File





12.1    Identical Answers, Yet 50% Marks



Every element of both answers (of RMIT and the student) was identical, including:

  1. The looping construct, namely: while.
  2. The function used, namely: fgets().
  3. The three arguments, namely:
    1. The buffer.
    2. The size.
    3. The FILE stream.
  4. The controlling predicate of the loop, namely: return value != NULL.



However, the student was given only 1 mark (out of 2).


12.1.1    "Approved" Answer of RMIT



Extract from RMIT's "approved" answer to question 3(A) in the exam

476 /* read each line from the file – 2 marks 477 478 while (fgets(line, BUFSIZ + 2, reader)) {




12.1.2    Answer of the Student



Extract from the student's answer to question 3(A) in the exam

513 while (fgets(buf, sizeof buf, F) != NULL) { /* 1 mark */




12.2    Hard-Coded Size of Buffer



There was a tiny difference, though.

RMIT hard coded the second argument to fgets(), namely: BUFSIZ + 2.

Whereas the student used: sizeof buf.


Which one is preferable?


Well, redundant and duplicate data lead to anomalies and corruption.

Right?

Because, one day, you may make changes to one of them.


For example, you may replace the unrelated BUFSIZ macro (in the "approved" answer) that was "stolen" from setvbuf().

Because the length of the lines in a file has nothing to do with stream I/O efficiency on your system and its associated buffer.

Right?

Or, you may remove the "+ 2", which makes little sense since the buffer is presumably (already) large enough to accommodate a NL and the terminating NULL character.


However, since this definition was repeated twice, chances are that modifying the above will lead to inconsistent (size) definitions.

Because you will either forget to update all the duplicate (size) definitions or make a mistake in one of the modifications.


In short, RMIT's answer was a maintenance nightmare, unlike the student's one; yet, he was not given the marks.







Chapter 13
— Exam 3(A)
— Remove the Newline Character





13.1    Strip Newline?



I did not ignore the ambiguity whether we had to strip the NL character.

On the contrary.

I laid it out in the most explicit terms.


Unfortunately, the marker did not read it.


13.1.1    "Approved" Answer of RMIT



Extract from RMIT's "approved" answer to question 3(A) in the exam

480 /* remove the newline characters – 1 mark */ 481 line[strlen(line) – 1] = 0;




13.1.2    Answer of the Student



Extract from the student's answer to question 3(A) in the exam

514 /* Strip newlines ? */




13.2    RMIT Is Inconsistent and Incorrect



13.2.1    Inconsistency



Wait, there is more.

The "approved" answer (of RMIT) to question 3(B) is adamant that NL characters should not be removed.

Question 3(B) builds on the functionality of 3(A), as you can see here.


13.2.2    Unconditional Truncation of Last Character



And BTW, this is not how you remove a NL character after a call to fgets().

Extract from RMIT's approved answer to question 3(A) in the exam

480 /* remove the newline characters – 1 mark */ 481 line[strlen(line) – 1] = 0;




This is wrong for two reasons:

  1. The terminating newline of the last line might have been missing, thus you truncated a legitimate character (i.e. the very last character of the file).
  2. The function fgets() might have stopped reading before the NL character due to the size limit of the second argument to fgets().



13.2.3    Summary



To summarize:

  1. RMIT's own answer shows that NL characters should not be removed.
  2. Newline Stripping was done incorrectly in the "approved" answer (of RMIT).



And, as always, I was left with zero marks for a correct answer.







Chapter 14
— Exam 3(A)
— Add the Line to the Document





14.1    Identical Answers, Yet Zero Marks



Every element of both answers (of RMIT and the student) was identical, including:

  1. The function used, namely: doc_add_line().
  2. The two arguments, namely:
    1. The document.
    2. A line of text.
  3. The error checks, namely: return value != FALSE.
  4. The error handling, namely: return NULL on error.




Yet, the student was given 0 points.


14.1.1    "Approved" Answer of RMIT



Extract from RMIT's "approved" answer to question 3(A) in the exam

484 /* add the line to the document – 1 mark 485 486 if (!doc_add_line(doc, line)) { 487 document_free(doc); 488 return NULL; 489 }




14.1.2    Answer of the Student



Extract from the student's answer to question 3(A) in the exam

516 if (doc_add_line(d, strdup(buf)) == FALSE) 517 return NULL;




14.2    Recovery From malloc() Errors



As mentioned in a later chapter, malloc() errors trigger (by convention) an immediate exit() or abort() of the program.

Therefore, 'document_free(doc)' (in RMIT's "approved" answer) is unnecessary.


Wait, there is more.

On occasion, the "approved" answer did not even bother to check for errors after a malloc() call.


Equally, RMIT did not even bother to check for NULL returns from document_make().

Unlike the student who did but was given only 40% for that answer.









Chapter 15
— Exam 3(B)
— Iterate Over Characters





15.1    Identical Answers, Yet Zero Marks



15.1.1    "Approved" Answer of RMIT



Extract from RMIT's "approved" answer to question 3(B) in the exam

558 /* iterate over each line of text – 1 mark */ 559 560 for (charcount = 0; charcount < curline->len; ++charcount) { 561 char curchar = text[charcount];




15.1.2    Answer of the Student



Extract from the student's answer to question 3(B) in the exam

676 char c; 677 char *p = line->text; 678 679 while ((c = *p++)) {




15.2    Iterate Over All Characters of a String



'curline->len' is defined (in the "approved" answer of RMIT) as:

293 theline->len = strlen(line);




Thus, both of the following are equivalent and practically identical operations to traverse the characters of the line's text:

  • for (...; charcount < curline->len; ...)
  • while ((c = *p++))



The first one was done by RMIT, while the latter was done by the student.

And while being (virtually) identical, RMIT gave the student 0% marks.

Chapter 23
— Exam 3(B)
— Handle Word Count





23.1    Marking Rubric



In this part of the question, we were asked to write a program that counts the number of words in a file.

Extract from exam question 3(B)

539 A word is considered to be alphabetical characters surrounded by 540 whitespace or punctuation. 541 Digits may be part of a word.




4 marks were given for a correct answer.


Summary of marks allocation for 3(B).

• 15 marks were given for an answer as a whole. • 4 of those marks were given for the word-count component. Those 4 marks (and their corresponding lines) are emphasized below.


Exam: Question 3(B): Answer of RMIT

542 struct stats collect_stats(struct document * doc) 543 { 544 struct stats thestats = { 0 }; 545 546 int count; 547 BOOLEAN isword = FALSE; 548 549 550 /* iterate over each line in the document – 1 mark */ 551 552 for (count = 0; count < doc->numlines; ++count) { 553 int charcount; 554 struct line *curline = doc->lines[count]; 555 char *text = doc->lines[count]->text; 556 557 558 /* iterate over each line of text – 1 mark */ 559 560 for (charcount = 0; charcount < curline->len; ++charcount) { 561 char curchar = text[charcount]; 562 563 564 /* handle new line chars – 1 mark */ 565 566 if (curchar == '\n') { 567 thestats.linecount++; 568 569 570 /* handle turning off the word marker – 1 mark */ 571 572 if (isword) { 573 /* increment the word count – 1 mark */ 574 ++ thestats.wordcount; 575 isword = FALSE; 576 } 577 578 break; 579 } 580 581 582 /* handle alphabetical characters – 1 mark */ 583 584 else if (isalpha(curchar)) { 585 ++thestats.alphacount; 586 587 588 /* handle upper case characters – 1 mark */ 589 590 if (isupper(curchar)) { 591 ++thestats.uppercount; 592 } else { 593 594 /* handle lower case characters – 1 mark */ 595 ++ thestats.lowercount; 596 } 597 598 599 /* handle beginning of word – 1 mark */ 600 601 if (!isword) { 602 isword = TRUE; 603 } 604 } 605 606 607 /* handle digits – 1 mark */ 608 609 else if (isdigit(curchar)) { 610 ++thestats.digitcount; 611 } else { 612 613 /* handle end of word not at end of line – 1 mark */ 614 615 if (isword) { 616 thestats.wordcount++; 617 isword = FALSE; 618 } 619 620 621 /* handle white spaces – 1 mark */ 622 if (isspace(curchar)) { 623 624 ++thestats.whitespacecount; 625 /* handle spaces separate from whitespace – 1 mark */ 626 627 if (curchar == ' ') { 628 ++thestats.spacecount; 629 } 630 } 631 632 633 /* handle punctuation – 1 mark */ 634 635 if (ispunct(curchar)) { 636 ++thestats.punctcount; 637 } 638 } 639 } 640 } 641 642 /* return the structure – 1 mark */ 643 return thestats; 644 }




23.2    RMIT's Spaghetti Code



23.2.1    Repetitive Code



You probably noticed that RMIT's implementation repeats the logic and calculation related to word count in three different places.


Why?

In order to answer this question, first notice how RMIT used a single function to account for all the (possible) attributes of a character.

The attributes (and their related stats) are:

  1. Line count
  2. Word count
  3. Alpha count
  4. Upper-case count
  5. Lower-case count
  6. Space count
  7. White-space count
  8. Punctuation count
  9. Digit count



They've done so by branching off to different blocks (execution paths) depending on whether the character was a newline character, an alphabetic character, a digit or else (none of the above).


In each of those branches (blocks), they had to, yet again, deal with the word-count stat.

Thus, the word-count logic was regurgitated in three different blocks, namely:

• The block associated with reading a NL character.

• The block associated with reading an alpha character.

• The block associated with none of the above.


All of those checks in the aforementioned blocks toggled the boolean variable isword (on and off) and (accordingly) incremented the word count.


23.2.2    Duplicate Code



Note how the following two blocks are identical.


Extract from "approved" answer 3(B) Increments word count when reading a NL character

572 if (isword) { 573 /* [...] */ 574 ++ thestats.wordcount; 575 isword = FALSE; 576 }




Extract from "approved" answer 3(B) Increments word count when reading a space/punctuation character

615 if (isword) { 616 thestats.wordcount++; 617 isword = FALSE; 618 }




23.2.3    Modular Approach in Student's Code



The design of the student's answer, however, lays out the need for nine separate functions, each dealing (exclusively) with its (own) pertinent stat.

Namely, one scans the text for punctuation, the other for white-space, and so on.

Consequently, there is exactly one block of code that deals with word count where it checks (for each character) the isalnum() predicate and increments the word count every time a new word is found.


There are plenty of arguments (and sound ones) that a modular approach is the (only) sane one.

Right?


23.2.4    Spaghetti Code Gone Wrong



Wait, there is more.

By failing to use a modular approach, the "approved" answer forgot to increment the white-space count for a newline.

To exclude newlines from white-space (while including '\r', '\f', '\v', etc.) is inconsistent with ANSI C quoted hereafter.


ANSI C (89)

4.3.1.9 The isspace function Synopsis #include <ctype.h> int isspace(int c); Description The isspace function tests for the standard white-space characters or for any of an implementation-defined set of characters for which isalnum is false. The standard white-space characters are the following: space (' '), form feed ('\f'), new-line ('\n'), carriage return ('\r'), horizontal tab ('\t'), and vertical tab ('\v'). In the C locale, isspace returns true only for the standard white-space characters.




23.3    Inconsistency



Wait, there is even more.

As noted, Question 3(B) builds on the functionality of 3(A), as you can see here.

However, the approved answer to 3(B) is certainly not consistent with their approved answer to 3(A).


As noted, RMIT inflicted a penalty on my answer because I did not strip newlines from added lines.

However, following this convention (of removing newlines) will result in the following inconsistent results.


Word-count output for the following lines of text:
  • 7 elven
  • 7th 11th
  • 7th 11th.
  • a\nb\nc\n
  • a\n b\nc\n
  • a\nb\n c\n
  • a\n b\n c\n
  • a A\nb B\nc C\n
  • a A\n b B\nc C\n
  • a A\n b B\n c C\n
Text Word Count
7 eleven 0 words (no digit-only words!)
7th 11th 1 word (i.e. "7th")
7th 11th. 2 words (i.e. "7th", "11th")
a\nb\nc\n 0 words
a\n b\nc\n 1 word (i.e. "a")
a\nb\n c\n 1 word (i.e. "ab")
a\n b\n c\n 2 words (i.e. "a", "b")
a A\nb B\nc C\n 3 words (i.e. "a", "Ab", "Bc")
a A\n b B\nc C\n 4 words (i.e. "a", "A", "b", "Bc")
a A\n b B\n c C\n 5 words (i.e. "a", "A", "b", "B", "c")



In other words, since newlines were removed, the branch of code dealing with newlines is unreachable.

And a file with 100 lines, each containing one word, will be counted as 0 words.

Now, RMIT wrote its code in a conducive environment using a computer and modern development tools.

This was in sharp contrast to the unfavourable conditions it inflicted on the students at the examination venue.

Still, do you think that RMIT wrote that verbose answer in less than 7.5 minutes?


The student, however, was restricted to pencil and paper only.

And he was further limited to an unrealistic time-frame.

And to make matters worse, he was repeatedly distracted by the dirty tricks and the evasive answers from the invigilators regarding the next question.

"Approved" Answer of RMIT to exam 3(B) (spaces/newlines/comments removed)

structstatscollect_stats(structdocument*doc){structstatsthestats={0};intcount;BOOLEANiswor d=FALSE;for(count=0;count<doc->numlines;++count){intcharcount;structline*curline=doc->line s[count];char*text=doc->lines[count]->text;for(charcount=0;charcount<curline->len;++charco unt){charcurchar=text[charcount];if(curchar=='\n'){thestats.linecount++;if(isword){++thest ats.wordcount;isword=FALSE;}break;}elseif(isalpha(curchar)){++thestats.alphacount;if(isupp er(curchar)){++thestats.uppercount;}else{++thestats.lowercount;}if(!isword){isword=TRUE;}} elseif(isdigit(curchar)){++thestats.digitcount;}else{if(isword){thestats.wordcount++;iswor d=FALSE;}if(isspace(curchar)){++thestats.whitespacecount;if(curchar==''){++thestats.spacec ount;}}if(ispunct(curchar)){++thestats.punctcount;}}}}returnthestats;}




Students had to write those 790 characters in 15 minutes using a pencil and paper.

How many characters can you write in one minute?


24.1.1    Average Writing Speed



The average is 40 letters per minute.

No planning in advance, and no reviewing afterwards and no stopping in the middle.


You were not allowed to reflect, think or breathe.

You had to write for 120 minutes straight — at the fastest speed imaginable — without lifting the pencil from the paper, not even for a split second.


In RMIT's universe, programmers just fire up their computers and smash the keyboard round the clock with no plan, strategy, design or review.

Or so they pretend.

24.2.4    Artificial Hurdles



RMIT was grading exam papers for many years.

They knew full well that some foreign students struggled to write 100+ characters per minute — for 2 hours straight — in their non-native writing system.

They also knew that they could have, equally, written far-superior exam questions that would have required less than a dozen handwritten words as an answer.

Nevertheless, they opted to write (stupid) questions that required ridiculously long (and incredibly verbose) answers, knowing full-well that some foreign students would fail this (artificial and discriminatory) hurdle.


Alternatively, RMIT could have adapted itself to the technologies of the last century.

Namely, provide computers (editors+compilers) in the exams and allow students to use a keyboard (and software development tools).

Because code development is not merely a "scribbling" job.

Nor is any real development done by pencil and paper.

Does one get a pilot licence by flying a paper airplane?


After all, this was not a pure computer-science course, nor did it focus on abstract theory.

Rather, it was a practical and programming course dedicated exclusively to a very specific programming language.

A heavy focus was put on distinct development tools like Valgrind and libasan.

And then, a specific LINUX environment was laid out as the only legitimate and possible platform.

You see, it was a technical rather than a computer-science class.


Every tool or instrument used (down to their exact version or configuration) was a prerequisite to this course and part of an assumed reality.

However, on the examination day, they all suddenly disappeared.

No computers, operating systems, editors or development tools.

No nothing.

Just you, your pencil and four walls.

It was like RMIT lost its mind.

Or, they couldn't care less because it saved them a few pennies.

staticintword_score(charconstword[],conststructletter_scorescoretable[],intscoretable_size ){intlettercount,tablecount;intwordlen=strlen(word);intscore=0;for(lettercount=0;lettercou nt&lt;wordlen;++lettercount){for(tablecount=0;tablecount&lt;scoretable_size;++tablecount){ if(word[lettercount]==scoretable[tablecount].letter){score+=scoretable[tablecount].score;} }}returnscore;}structword_node*make_node(constcharword[],conststructletter_scorescore_tabl e[],intscoretable_size){structword*newword=make_word(word,score_table,scoretable_size);str uctword_node*newnode;if(!newword){returnNULL;}newnode=(structword_node*)malloc(sizeof(stru ctword_node));if(!newnode){perror("malloc");word_free(newword);returnFALSE;}newnode-&gt;th eword=newword;newnode-&gt;next=NULL;returnnewnode;}intwordcmp(conststructword*first,consts tructword*second){returnstrcmp(first-&gt;text,second-&gt;text);}BOOLEANword_list_add(struc tword_list*thelist,constcharnewword[],conststructletter_scorescoretable[],intscoretable_si ze){structword_node*current,*prev=NULL;structword_node*new;new=make_node(newword,scoretabl e,scoretable_size);if(!new){returnFALSE;}if(!thelist-&gt;head){assert(thelist-&gt;len==0); thelist-&gt;head=new;++thelist-&gt;len;returnTRUE;}for(current=thelist-&gt;head;current&am p;&amp;wordcmp(current-&gt;theword,new-&gt;theword)&lt;0;prev=current,current=current-&gt; next);if(!prev){new-&gt;next=thelist-&gt;head;thelist-&gt;head=new;}else{prev-&gt;next=new ;new-&gt;next=current;}++thelist-&gt;len;returnTRUE;}




This consists of 1493 characters.

A far cry from the 12.5 minutes "expected" by RMIT.

Right?

These are 580 characters.

2073 / 40 = 51.825 minutes.

A far cry from the 12.5 minutes "expected" by RMIT.


Of course, RMIT assumed the speed of a local student.

2073 characters / 12.5 minutes = 165.84 characters per minute.


Is it possible?


The Journal of the Forensic Science Society Volume 31, Issue 1, January 1991, Pages 21-29 concludes:

A study has been made of the speeds of writing (expressed as characters per minute) achieved in police interview records and in controlled tests with volunteer subjects.

In undisputed police interview records, the highest speeds observed fell in the range 120–155 cpm; in the controlled tests the highest speeds were in the range 150–160 cpm.

It is concluded that in real interview situations, speeds of 150–190 cpm are unlikely to be attained and speeds above 190 cpm cannot be attained.

— Exam 1(C)
— Realloc





25.1    Summary



Imagine a basic arithmetic quiz.

The question was: How much is 73 * 11?

Your answer was: 803.


Then, for some reason, they delayed the results for 70 days.


Then, you are told by the school that you failed the exam!

You ask them: "Why? What was the score?"

No response!

"Can I see the marked paper?" you ask.

They ignore you.


Finally (after a slew of threats and ad hominem attacks), they released the marked paper.


You had only 20 days to appeal.

However, 17 days were already gone and wasted in vain trying to fend off bullying attempts from the school to shut you up by refusing to release the documents essential to the appeal.


You are exhausted, disappointed and demoralized.

But you pick up the pieces and give it one last go.


You are happy to confirm (on the exam's copy) that your answer was correct, as it reads: 73 * 11 = 803.


They also released their official marking guide (with the "approved" answers) used by the teacher when marking your exam.

But, to your astonishment, you see that the "approved" answer (to how much is 703 * 11) was: 51.


You may wonder, how was that (dumb) mistake even possible?

The answer is simple.

Usually, examiners pick up bits and pieces from past exams (because RMIT is unwilling to pay towards a brand-new exam for each recurring study period).

A common mistake when moving text around by copy-and-paste is to either copy from the wrong line or paste the copied text into the wrong location.

Thus, when the examiner pulled questions and "approved" answers from past exams, he made a mess when he copy-and-pasted an answer from an unrelated question as the "approved" answer to this question.


The "approved" answer was obviously incorrect.

Your answer, however, was correct.

But it did not match the "approved" answer.

Consequently, you were given 0 points.

Because RMIT's policy is to blame its own mistakes on the students.


Long story short, you appealed.

The office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic responded that they "can confirm" that your appeal got rejected.

They did not explain why, nor did they go into details.

However, they added that the decision was final and no third party review would be allowed.

You then ask them for a further review, which his office found to be disrespectful and, to exact revenge on the student, advised his underlings on the disciplinary committee to suspend you from the school.


Sadly, this event was not a fictional story.

On the contrary!

This was an exact rendition of what (actually) happened at RMIT.

The question (in the exam) may have been a little different, but, for all intents and purposes, it was the exact same scenario.


25.2    Exam Question 1(C) a Mix-Up



A fundamental concept in programming-languages is scope rules.


In the C Programming Language, for example, you mark-off (and isolate) a block of code by surrounding it with '{' and '}', respectively.

Entities that reside within that block are not "visible" outside.


As expected, one of the questions (in the exam) was about scope rules.

Simply put, students were asked to identify a scope violation in a small chunk of code.

The student's answer was correct.

In fact, the only one possible.

As noted, RMIT's answer was irrelevant and incorrect for this question.


The rest was already described above.

Namely, they gave me 0 points, blocked my appeal, and when I asked them for a further review, they pulled off their revenge.

Welcome to RMIT.


25.3    Question 1(C)



Exam: Question 1(C)

86 C) There is a potential bug in the following function. 87 88 What is it and how would I fix it (5 Marks)? 89 90 Hint: this has something to do with the use of the realloc() function. 91 92 Please identify the line numbers you would change and what you would 93 replace them with. 94 95 1 BOOLEAN lengthen_string(char *string, const char newcontents[]) 96 2 { 97 3 int newlen = strlen(string) + strlen(newcontents) + 1; 98 4 string = realloc(string, newlen); 99 5 if (!string) 100 6 { 101 7 perror("malloc"); 102 8 return FALSE; 103 9 } 104 10 strcat(string, newcontents); 105 11 return TRUE; 106 12 }




25.3.1    "Approved" Answer of RMIT



"Approved" Answer of RMIT

107 Line 4 realloc returns a NULL pointer when it fails to allocate. 108 This means that on failure the original data is lost. 109 110 To fix this, 111 assign the result of realloc to a temporary variable and test that first. 112 113 i.e. line 4: 114 char *temp = realloc(string, newlen); 115 if(!temp) ... (all remains the same) 116 117 After old line 9: 118 string = temp; 119 120 5 marks for identifying the problem and the solution.




25.3.2    Answer of the Student



Answer of the Student

121 Modifies the local @string, 122 where the caller will still hold the memory to the old area.




25.4    Scope Rules in C



Extracts from the literature regarding scope rules in C are quoted in the following.

Those include:

  • The standard (ANSI C).
  • The "Bible" (K&R).
  • The GCC documentation.



25.4.1    ANSI C (89) "Programming Language C" (X3.159-1989)



ANSI C

3.1.2.1 Scopes of identifiers

An identifier is visible (i.e., can be used) only within a region of program text called its scope . There are four kinds of scopes: function, file, block, and function prototype. (A function prototype is a declaration of a function that declares the types of its parameters.)

A label name is the only kind of identifier that has function scope. It can be used (in a goto statement) anywhere in the function in which it appears, and is declared implicitly by its syntactic appearance (followed by a : and a statement). Label names shall be unique within a function.

Every other identifier has scope determined by the placement of its declaration (in a declarator or type specifier). If the declarator or type specifier that declares the identifier appears outside of any block or list of parameters, the identifier has file scope, which terminates at the end of the translation unit. If the declarator or type specifier that declares the identifier appears inside a block or within the list of parameter declarations in a function definition, the identifier has block scope, which terminates at the } that closes the associated block.

If the declarator or type specifier that declares the identifier appears within the list of parameter declarations in a function prototype (not part of a function definition), the identifier has function prototype scope, which terminates at the end of the function declarator.

If an outer declaration of a lexically identical identifier exists in the same name space, it is hidden until the current scope terminates, after which it again becomes visible.



25.4.2    The C Programming Language by D. Ritchie & B. Kernighan (K&R)



The C Programming Language

1.8 Arguments – Call by Value

One aspect of C functions may be unfamiliar to programmers who are used to some other languages, particularly Fortran. In C, all function arguments are passed ``by value.'' This means that the called function is given the values of its arguments in temporary variables rather than the originals. This leads to some different properties than are seen with ``call by reference'' languages like Fortran or with var parameters in Pascal, in which the called routine has access to the original argument, not a local copy.

Call by value is an asset, however, not a liability. It usually leads to more compact programs with fewer extraneous variables, because parameters can be treated as conveniently initialized local variables in the called routine.


4.4 Scope Rules

[...]

The scope of a name is the part of the program within which the name can be used. For an automatic variable declared at the beginning of a function, the scope is the function in which the name is declared. Local variables of the same name in different functions are unrelated. The same is true of the parameters of the function, which are in effect local variables.


5.2 Pointers and Function Arguments

Since C passes arguments to functions by value, there is no direct way for the called function to alter a variable in the calling function.

For instance, a sorting routine might exchange two out-of-order arguments with a function called swap.

It is not enough to write

swap(a, b);

where the swap function is defined as


void swap(int x, int y) /* WRONG */ { int temp; temp = x; x = y; y = temp; }


Because of call by value, swap can't affect the arguments a and b in the routine that called it. The function above swaps copies of a and b.


A.7.3.2 Function Calls

[...]

The term argument is used for an expression passed by a function call; the term parameter is used for an input object (or its identifier) received by a function definition, or described in a function declaration. The terms ``actual argument (parameter)'' and ``formal argument (parameter)'' respectively are sometimes used for the same distinction. In preparing for the call to a function, a copy is made of each argument; all argument-passing is strictly by value. A function may change the values of its parameter objects, which are copies of the argument expressions, but these changes cannot affect the values of the arguments. However, it is possible to pass a pointer on the understanding that the function may change the value of the object to which the pointer points.



25.4.3    The GNU C Reference Manual



The GNU C Reference Manual – Function Parameters

5.4 Function Parameters

Function parameters can be any expression – a literal value, a value stored in variable, an address in memory, or a more complex expression built by combining these.

Within the function body, the parameter is a local copy of the value passed into the function; you cannot change the value passed in by changing the local copy.

int x = 23; foo (x); [...] /* Definition for function foo. */ int foo (int a) { a = 2 * a; return a; }

In that example, even though the parameter a is modified in the function 'foo', the variable x that is passed to the function does not change.



25.5    Realloc Recovery



I once was playing trivia with my neighbour.

My question was: "How long does it take to drive a car between Sydney and Melbourne?"

He told me: "10 hours, give or take".

"No!" I yelled victoriously.

"The car in question just stopped working!".

"To drive it from Sydney to Melbourne, you have to push it, all the way, with your bare hands".


He gave me 100 dollars (trivia prize) not before he called me an idiot.


If you think I cheated by failing to disclose an outlandish assumption, wait until you enrol at RMIT.

RMIT made an assumption that upon a realloc() failure, the caller would "ignore" that error and continue to use/free the (old) memory area.


The problem is, this assumption was never shown in the question.

Only the callee function was shown.

The caller part, however, was assumed but never shown.

Was such an assumption reasonable?


As shown, this assumption is not the norm.

On the contrary.

The overwhelming convention is to exit/abort upon allocation errors.

This is especially true for the platform (Linux) we exclusively developed for (touted as the only "legitimate" one).

And it is evident in the library interfaces we exclusively relied on in this course.

And it is the convention used in programs that embody the Linux culture.


25.6    Summary



To summarize:

1. This question violated scope rules; hence, the "approved" answer was irrelevant.

2. Even without the scope rules violation, this question was illegitimate because it failed to disclose an outlandish assumption, namely, that the caller (to this function) would "ignore" allocation errors.







Chapter 26
— Exam 4(B)
— Single Element Instead of Array





In question 4(B), we were asked to add a new word to a linked-list of words.

However, before adding the word, we had to calculate its "score" by adding up all of its component letters' scores.

A score of a letter is its value in Scrabble.


The question follows:

Exam: Question 4(B)

818 B) Next, we want you to implement the function to add a new word in sorted 819 order to the defined list structure. As part of this you should calculate the 820 word score which is the same of the scores of each letter. (25 Marks)




RMIT told us to use the following prototype (for calculating the total score of a word).

831 The function prototype for this function is (25 Marks): 832 833 BOOLEAN add_word(struct word_list *thelist, const char newword[], 834 const struct letter_score scoretable, int scoretable_size);




Namely, for each letter, we had to traverse the constituent elements of the scoretable array to find a pertinent element (associated with that letter) and fetch its (tile) value, which would be added to the total score.

It was assumed that each alphabetical character had a corresponding element in the scoretable array.

scoretable_size is the number of elements in the scoretable array.


The problem is, scoretable was not an array.


When RMIT copy-and-pasted this question (from its exams in past years), they forgot to copy the '[]' characters (while making 3 other disastrous errors).

Consequently, scoretable became a single element.

As a result, this prototype had zero resemblance to Scrabble.

And because of this, the question (as a whole) made no sense.


Foreign students never heard about this phenomenon of tiles that have different values depending on the frequency of their letters.

So, RMIT owed them some explanation.

However, the data structure shown in the exam was not a table (array) of tile values, but it was one single value and, therefore, had zero relevance to the issue at hand.


Were foreign students given a fair chance?

No.

Were they given a reasonably-correct explanation about the game?

No.

Did RMIT confuse the hell out of them by showing a data structure that defied the very basics of Scrabble?

Yes.


You see, RMIT thought that nobody would notice when they looted the federal grants meant for the proof-reading of the exams.

Not much later, they stopped paying their teachers to be available during the exam (to answer students' queries).


"What could possibly go wrong?" said the top-echelon of the university (while allowing themselves 7-figure salaries and unlimited perks and benefits).

Sadly, the only ones who had to bear the consequences of this slippery slope of corruption were their paying customers.

And, as always, it disadvantaged the foreigner about whom the university does not give a damn.

As a consequence, my score on the exam fell below the minimum threshold of 50%.


The office of Prof. Subic told me that I was not allowed to appeal based on the above.

Basically, they blamed me for not understanding this question.


According to RMIT, it was my fault; after all, only two characters (namely '[]') were missing.


But, would Prof. Aleksandar Subic board an airplane that was missing only two screws on its tail wing?

After all, it was missing only two screws!

What could possibly go wrong?







Chapter 27
— Exam 4(B)
— Gibberish and False Descriptions





27.1    Errors in Question 4



The last question in the exam was based on Scrabble.

Foreign students, who made up more than 50% of this class, never heard about this game before.


27.1.1    Gibberish



RMIT provided (for those foreign students) the following "explanation".

819 [...] As part of this you should calculate the 820 word score which is the same of the scores of each letter. (25 Marks)




A "word score" is "the same of the scores of each letter".

Let's try again.

A "word score" is "the same of the scores" of "each letter".

Hello! Is this English?


Do you think that foreign students were given a fair go with this explanation?


Besides, isn't it false that a word score is the "same" as "each" of its letters?


27.1.2    More Gibberish



Wait, there is more.

The very next statement (in the same question) is equally moronic.

822 The parameter scoretable is an array letter scores.




What does "array letter scores" even mean?


27.1.3    Even More Gibberish



And yes, there is more!

The very next statement is equally incomprehensible.

(Note: The marking guide does not have this statement; the quote is from the exam paper given to the students).

824 Please note that each letter is stored A letter score is an instance of the following struct:




"Please note that each letter is stored A letter score is [...]".

There is probably a missing dot here (before "A letter score"), but this statement still doesn't make sense (even after adding the missing dot).

"Please note that each letter is stored".

"each letter is stored".

"stored" where?

And what was the (important) thing that we had to "note"?

"That each letter is stored"?

Meaning what?


27.1.4    Disastrous Typos



And shockingly, there is even more!

RMIT mangled the prototype and thus completely distorted the essence of its data structure.

As a result, the variable had zero resemblance to Scrabble.


27.2    Negligence by Academic Board Leading to Discrimination



You see, RMIT was slick and thought to itself that nobody would notice when they indulged in a little misappropriation of funds here and there.

And consequently, they cut off the funding for the proof-reading of the exam.


Soon after, they cut off the funding for the availability of help during the exam.

Mind you, this service is required by the accreditation-body and available in every other university down under.

The student repeatedly sought help from the invigilators during the exam but was told that nobody was available.


"What could possibly go wrong?" said the top-echelon of the university while allowing themselves 7-figure salaries and unlimited perks and benefits.

Sadly, the only ones who had to bear the consequences of this slippery slope of corruption were their paying customers.

And, as always, it disadvantaged the foreigner about whom the university does not give a damn.

As a consequence, my score on the exam fell below the minimum threshold of 50%.


The office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic warned me not to appeal this question based on the above and, later on, joined the rest of their Academic Board in ignoring my appeal.


Make no mistake, RMIT is pure evil.







Chapter 28
— Exam 4(B)
— Scrabble's Calculation Is Unrelated to Question





28.1    Summary



I once enrolled in an English as a Second Language course.

On its first day, I was told to write a short story (of 100+ words).


However, there was a bizarre twist.

I was told that after writing each word, I had to do the following:

  1. Count the number of letters (in that word).
  2. Go down to the floor and get on all fours.
  3. Do as many push-ups as the number of letters in that word.


And then repeat (all of the above) for each of the following (100+) words.


The first 4 words of my story were: "once upon a time".

Consequently, for those 4 words alone, I had to:

  • Write the word: "once".
  • Do 4 push-ups.
  • Write the word: "upon".
  • Do 4 push-ups.
  • Write the word: "a".
  • Do 1 push-up.
  • Write the word: "time".
  • Do 4 push-ups.


And so on, for the rest of the 100+ words of my story.


I was angry and demanded a full refund for two reasons.

First, I asked them where did those push-ups come from, and why were they integrated into, of all things, an English class.

My biggest concern, however, was that my train of thought was interrupted.

Because, sure enough, after writing the first three words while juggling — for every single word — between writing and push-ups, I had completely forgotten what the hell I was writing about.


They tried to offer me a discount, but I told them that their class was a mess.

My advice to them was: stick to teaching English, or alternatively, focus completely on fitness.

Mixing those two unrelated activities is just confusing, annoying, and counter-productive.


One day later, I enrolled at RMIT University.

Basically, I was looking for a school with a modicum of sanity.


Boy, was I wrong!

They were far worse.


As you know, Modular programming is an important principle of program design.

Writing a function that implements one idea while adding to the mix an unrelated chunk of code is doomed to end up in a disaster.


Yet, RMIT ordered the students to write a specific function while forcing them to cram (into the same function) some game-show shenanigans and horseplay that had nothing to do with any part of that function (or the entire exam, for that matter).

It was as if RMIT had (randomly) copy-and-pasted chunks of texts (from its past exam) without carefully paying attention to what they were doing.

Actually, it was not "as if".

Because this is exactly how RMIT "writes" (by copy-and-paste) the questions for their exams.


And while the federal government allocated funds to ensure that this does not happen, RMIT defrauded the public by misappropriating those funds to its self-serving interests.


28.2    Sloppy Mess



Question 4(C) asked students to:

  1. Insert a new word (in alphabetical order) into the linked list.
  2. Calculate the "score" of this word (which is the sum of its component letters' scores).



Note how RMIT described the second task.

"As part of this you should calculate the word score".

Again, "as part of this" (namely, of "implement[ing] the function to add a new word in sorted order"), "you should calculate the word socre".


However, it is evident that the first part has nothing to do with second part.

I.e. the requirement to insert a word (in alphabetical order) into a linked-list has nothing to do (not even remotely) with Scrabble (or its "scores").


Nowhere does the word_list_add() function (that inserts the word into the linked list in alphabetical order) use the (helper) function word_score() (that calculates its score in Scrabble).

In fact, the function word_score() was never used nowhere in the exam.


28.2.1    Question 4(B)



Question 4(B)

818 B) Next, we want you to implement the function to add a new word in sorted 819 order to the defined list structure. As part of this you should calculate the 820 word score which is the same of the scores of each letter. (25 Marks) 821 822 The parameter scoretable is an array letter scores. 823 824 A letter score is an instance of the following struct: 825 826 struct letter_score { 827 char letter; 828 int score; 829 }; 830 831 The function prototype for this function is (25 Marks): 832 833 BOOLEAN add_word(struct word_list *thelist, const char newword[], 834 const struct letter_score scoretable, int scoretable_size);



Answer 4(B) of RMIT

835 /* 4 marks for score calculation */ 836 static int word_score(char const word[], const struct letter_score scoretable[], 837 int scoretable_size) 838 { 839 int lettercount, tablecount; 840 int wordlen = strlen(word); 841 int score = 0; 842 843 for (lettercount = 0; lettercount < wordlen; ++lettercount) { 844 for (tablecount = 0; tablecount < scoretable_size; ++tablecount) { 845 if (word[lettercount] == scoretable[tablecount].letter) { 846 score += scoretable[tablecount].score; 847 } 848 } 849 } 850 return score; 851 } 852 853 struct word_node *make_node(const char word[], const struct letter_score score_table[], 854 int scoretable_size) 855 { 856 struct word *newword = make_word(word, score_table, scoretable_size); 857 struct word_node *newnode; 858 859 if (!newword) { 860 return NULL; 861 862 } 863 864 newnode = (struct word_node *)malloc(sizeof(struct word_node)); 865 if (!newnode) { 866 perror("malloc"); 867 word_free(newword); 868 return FALSE; 869 } 870 871 newnode->theword = newword; 872 newnode->next = NULL; 873 return newnode; 874 } 875 876 int wordcmp(const struct word *first, const struct word *second) 877 { 878 return strcmp(first->text, second->text); 879 } 880 881 882 /* 883 * the main function for q4b although there are some helper functionis that 884 * contribute marks 885 */ 886 887 BOOLEAN word_list_add(struct word_list *thelist, const char newword[], 888 const struct letter_score scoretable[], int scoretable_size) 889 { 890 /* 2 marks for reasonable declarations */ 891 struct word_node *current, *prev = NULL; 892 struct word_node *new; 893 894 /* 5 marks for memory allocations and checking they succeed */ 895 new = make_node(newword, scoretable, scoretable_size); 896 if (!new) { 897 return FALSE; 898 } 899 900 /* 2 marks for insertion at the head */ 901 if (!thelist->head) { 902 assert(thelist->len == 0); 903 thelist->head = new; 904 ++thelist->len; 905 return TRUE; 906 } 907 908 /* 4 marks for iteration */ 909 for (current = thelist->head; current && wordcmp(current->theword, new->theword) < 0; 910 prev = current, current = current->next) ; 911 912 /* 3 marks for insertion at the start */ 913 if (!prev) { 914 new->next = thelist->head; 915 thelist->head = new; 916 } 917 918 /* 3 marks for inseration elsewhere */ 919 else { 920 prev->next = new; 921 new->next = current; 922 } 923 924 /* 2 marks for increment */ 925 ++thelist->len; 926 return TRUE; 927 }




28.3    Copy and Paste Leading to Disaster



28.3.1    Recycled Exams



What is going on?

Very simple.

RMIT is not willing to pay towards (the writing of) a brand-new exam for each recurring study period.

Consequently, RMIT tells its teachers to pick up bits and pieces ("copy and paste") from past exams.


RMIT has prepared (over the years) different versions of this course (namely, CPT220).

Each version selects a different topic (game, project, etc.) and builds the assignments around that idea.

The examination papers (of each version of the course) usually follow suit by regurgitating the same underlying topic (and using extracts from the assignments preceding the final exam).


One of those versions was based on Scrabble.

RMIT recycles this (Scrabble) version every other year.

Students who took this course at the start of 2021 (SP4/2020), for example, were given this Scrabble version in which 'main.c' was renamed to 'wuzzle.c' ("word puzzle").


The study period I was enrolled in, however, was based on other (recycled) concepts (namely, text editors, etc.).

Scrabble was not one of them.


28.3.2    Sloppy Seconds



This did not prevent RMIT's (lazy and negligent) exam-authors to pull bits and pieces from an old version of this course while (irresponsibly) stripping away core components of the questions.

Consequently, the structure of the questions fell apart, and they barely made any sense.


And to make matters worse, they made three disastrous errors in their copy-and-paste that resulted in utterly bizarre and incomprehensible gibberish.


And, to add insult to injury, they mangled the data type, dooming their foreign students (who never heard about Scrabble before), as RMIT confused the hell out of them by showing a data structure that defied the realities of Scrabble.


As the icing on the cake, RMIT created utter chaos by throwing in (to the mix) a slew of functions that were never (otherwise) mentioned, declared or defined anywhere in the exam.


And as the cherry on top, RMIT copied irrelevant identifiers that had zero relevance to the question.


And to affirm their lawlessness, the office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic warned me not to base my appeal on the above.

Later, he joined the rest of its Academic Board in ignoring my appeals regarding the exam.







Chapter 29
— Exam 4(A & B)
— Data Structure Shown Unrelated to Question





29.1    Summary



Question 4 was divided into 2 parts.

The first part — namely, question 4(A) — defined the data structure.

And the second part — namely, question 4(B) — provided the implementation.

Sounds legit.

Right?


The problem is, part B had no connection whatsoever with part A.

Namely, the identifiers defined in part A were not used in part B.

In fact, they were not used anywhere in the exam.


29.2    Identifiers Shown but Not Used



29.2.1    Identifiers in Question 4(A)



Look at the two following identifiers defined in answer 4(A):

• play_count

• best_word


29.2.2    Description of Identifiers



This was their description in part A of the question.

795 II. A count of how many times this word has been played. 796 III. An entry somewhere in this data structure that stored the best 797 scoring word and its score.



Students had to modify the data structure in order to add identifiers representing the above.


29.2.3    Not Used



However, they were never used in part B of the question or elsewhere in the exam.

This was extremely confusing because students expected the function implementations (in part B of the question) to be related to the data structure defined in part A.


29.2.4    Sloppy Seconds



What is going on?

I provided a clue in a previous chapter.







Chapter 30
— Exam 4(B)
— Unimplemented Functions From Past Exams





30.1    Summary



Take a look at the two following function-calls used in RMIT's "approved" answer to question 4(B):

• make_word()

• word_free()


Where did those functions come from?

What are their definitions or implementations?

Where are their declarations?


Were students supposed to write/mention those functions to get full marks?


30.2    The Missing Functions



The following is the "approved" answer for question 4(B) of the exam.

The functions under discussion are emphasized.

Question 4(B)

818 B) Next, we want you to implement the function to add a new word in sorted 819 order to the defined list structure. As part of this you should calculate the 820 word score which is the same of the scores of each letter. (25 Marks) 821 822 The parameter scoretable is an array letter scores. 823 824 A letter score is an instance of the following struct: 825 826 struct letter_score { 827 char letter; 828 int score; 829 }; 830 831 The function prototype for this function is (25 Marks): 832 833 BOOLEAN add_word(struct word_list *thelist, const char newword[], 834 const struct letter_score scoretable, int scoretable_size);



"Approved" Answer 4(B) of RMIT

835 /* 4 marks for score calculation */ 836 static int word_score(char const word[], const struct letter_score scoretable[], 837 int scoretable_size) 838 { 839 int lettercount, tablecount; 840 int wordlen = strlen(word); 841 int score = 0; 842 843 for (lettercount = 0; lettercount < wordlen; ++lettercount) { 844 for (tablecount = 0; tablecount < scoretable_size; ++tablecount) { 845 if (word[lettercount] == scoretable[tablecount].letter) { 846 score += scoretable[tablecount].score; 847 } 848 } 849 } 850 return score; 851 } 852 853 struct word_node *make_node(const char word[], const struct letter_score score_table[], 854 int scoretable_size) 855 { 856 struct word *newword = make_word(word, score_table, scoretable_size); 857 struct word_node *newnode; 858 859 if (!newword) { 860 return NULL; 861 862 } 863 864 newnode = (struct word_node *)malloc(sizeof(struct word_node)); 865 if (!newnode) { 866 perror("malloc"); 867 word_free(newword); 868 return FALSE; 869 } 870 871 newnode->theword = newword; 872 newnode->next = NULL; 873 return newnode; 874 } 875 876 int wordcmp(const struct word *first, const struct word *second) 877 { 878 return strcmp(first->text, second->text); 879 } 880 881 882 /* 883 * the main function for q4b although there are some helper functionis that 884 * contribute marks 885 */ 886 887 BOOLEAN word_list_add(struct word_list *thelist, const char newword[], 888 const struct letter_score scoretable[], int scoretable_size) 889 { 890 /* 2 marks for reasonable declarations */ 891 struct word_node *current, *prev = NULL; 892 struct word_node *new; 893 894 /* 5 marks for memory allocations and checking they succeed */ 895 new = make_node(newword, scoretable, scoretable_size); 896 if (!new) { 897 return FALSE; 898 } 899 900 /* 2 marks for insertion at the head */ 901 if (!thelist->head) { 902 assert(thelist->len == 0); 903 thelist->head = new; 904 ++thelist->len; 905 return TRUE; 906 } 907 908 /* 4 marks for iteration */ 909 for (current = thelist->head; current && wordcmp(current->theword, new->theword) < 0; 910 prev = current, current = current->next) ; 911 912 /* 3 marks for insertion at the start */ 913 if (!prev) { 914 new->next = thelist->head; 915 thelist->head = new; 916 } 917 918 /* 3 marks for inseration elsewhere */ 919 else { 920 prev->next = new; 921 new->next = current; 922 } 923 924 /* 2 marks for increment */ 925 ++thelist->len; 926 return TRUE; 927 }




Where did this mix-up come from?

I provided a clue in a previous chapter.


30.3    Implementation of the Missing Functions



However, I added here my own implementation to those missing functions for the purpose of another chapter.

I aimed to keep it consistent with RMIT's style and naming conventions in their "approved" answers of the marking guide.

Prototype for make_word() was copied from make_node().

malloc() + memset() was borrowed document_make().

malloc() + strcpy() was borrowed from make_line().

malloc() error handling was borrowed from the above 3 functions.

Finally, the newword identifier was borrowed from make_node().


Added implementation of the missing functions 'make_word()' and 'word_free()'

1 struct word *make_word(const char word[], const struct letter_score score_table[], 2 int scoretable_size) 3 { 4 int score; 5 struct word *newword; 6 7 score = word_score(word, score_table, scoretable_size); 8 9 newword = (struct word *)malloc(sizeof(struct word)); 10 11 if (!newword) { 12 perror("malloc"); 13 return NULL; 14 } 15 16 memset(newword, 0, sizeof(struct word)); 17 newword->score = score; 18 newword->line_len = strlen(word); 19 20 newword->text = (char *)malloc(sizeof(char) * (newword->line_len + 1)); 21 22 if (!newword->text) { 23 perror("malloc"); 24 free(newword); 25 return NULL; 26 } 27 28 strcpy(newword->text, word); 29 30 return newword; 31 } 32 33 void word_free(struct word *word) 34 { 35 free(word->text); 36 free(word); 37 }









Chapter 31
— Exam 1(D)
— Valgrind





31.1    Summary



For this question, RMIT showed a buggy piece of code.

And to answer it correctly, students had to recite (from memory) the diagnostics outputted by Valgrind for such a scenario.


31.1.1    Three Different Messages



The problem is, there were three different error messages.


RMIT decided, however, that only the first message was legitimate.

Why?

Because!


31.1.2    RMIT's Clue to the Answer Is Misleading



RMIT provided in the exam a clue to the bug: "the culprit is the list_init() function."


However, Valgrind issues the exact same diagnostics even after removing the list_init() call (including removing the function itself).


Valgrind is not (that) smart.

It can only track (and analyze) the execution of your compiled program.

Valgrind, however, does not have access to (nor does it understand) your source code.


Thus, Valgrind outputs the same output for either of the following two scenarios:

  • Initialization was missing altogether.
  • An initialization function existed, it was called, but the inner workings of that function was lacking.



31.1.3    Detailed Diagnostics Provided by Student



The student provided an answer similar to the "approved" one of RMIT.

The phrasing of his answer, however, was different.

Because, unlike Valgrind, his answer also explained why the variable was left uninitialised (because initialization was done on a block assigned to a local copy of the var; this dynamically-allocated block was not identical to the caller's one residing on the stack).

This is a far cry from the robotic diagnostics of Valgrind about "uninitialised values", which it repeats, word by word, no matter if you called list_init(), or if that function didn't even exist, to begin with.


31.1.4    Almost Zero Marks for Correct Diagnostics



RMIT, however, took away 80% of my marking points.

Yet, you read that right.

I lost 80% of my marking points.


I was left with only 20% because my answer added relevant diagnostics not outputted by Valgrind.

Students, it seems, were expected by RMIT to rehearse all the infinite possibilities of buggy programs and robotically recite the exact (and rather inferior) diagnostics that were provided by Valgrind.

Adding better and more relevant "human" diagnostics will get you (close to) zero marks.


31.2    The Three Warnings of Valgrind



If you actually read the output of Valgrind, you can see 31 warnings:

  • 26 warnings of: "conditional jump or move depends on uninitialised value(s)."
  • 3 warnings of: "use of uninitialised value of size 8."
  • 2 warnings of: "syscall param writev(vector) points to uninitialised byte(s)."



Why RMIT chose only one of them (namely, the first one) as the only legitimate answer is beyond me.


31.3    Copy and Paste



Wait, there is more.

RMIT gave me zero marks for a fully-correct answer because it was not an exact copy-and-paste from Valgrind.

However, did RMIT's own "approved" answer accurately copy-and-paste the output of Valgrind?

No.

Because it should have been:

"Conditional jump or move depends on uninitialised value(s)."


And not:

"Conditional based on uninitialised values."



Now, does it matter?

No.

Because parroting "conditional jump or move" means nothing as long as you do not pinpoint the libc code that actually jumps depending on the uninitialised variable, and then explain what was uninitialized and why.

Has RMIT done any of these?

No.


You see, robotic copy-and-paste is useless unless you also pinpoint the root cause of the bug and give tailor-made diagnostics that are specifically relevant to that scenario.

In other words, you had to explain why the bug occurred, not only what.

Specifically, why was the variable not initialized despite calling list_init().

RMIT's "approved" answer did not do that.

The student's answer, however, did.

But, he was not given the marks.


BTW, I've never encountered an interview question where they tell the candidate to recite the exact output from a programming tool (like GCC) for a given error.

A correct answer to such a question depends on the particular version, configuration, and so on.

And, honestly, who cares?

Can he (the candidate) identify the bug and then indicate how to fix it correctly?

Then, why does the exact wording matter?


And this is especially true when we're dealing with an obscure debugging tool whose usage significantly declined with the advent of modern and far superior tools, such as sanitization libraries.

After all, this was a programming course, not a Valgrind course.


31.4    Inconsistent With Exam Topics



Valgrind is not listed in the Examination Topics provided by RMIT on their website.

Nor is the requirement to rehearse and robotically recite the (inferior) diagnostics of Valgrind.

Nor does it say that providing better (and more relevant) diagnostics will result in zero marks.


31.5    Resources



31.5.1    Question 1(D)



Exam: Question 1(D)

123 D) Consider the follow C program. 124 Lines 42-43 cause an error to be printed by valgrind. 125 What is the error message? 126 127 (I don't need all the detail, just the first line of the error message). 128 129 Also, it turns out the culprit is the list_init() function. 130 How would you change this to avoid the problem? 131 Identify the line numbers you would change and the new code. (10 Marks) 132 133 1 #include <stdio.h> 134 2 #include <stdlib.h> 135 3 #include <string.h> 136 2 137 5 typedef enum 138 6 { 139 7 FALSE, 140 8 TRUE 141 9 } BOOLEAN; 142 10 143 11 struct node { 144 12 struct node *next; 145 13 int data; 146 14 }; 147 15 148 16 149 17 struct list 150 18 { 151 19 struct node *head; 152 20 int size; 153 21 }; 154 22 155 23 BOOLEAN list_init(struct list *alist) 156 24 { 157 25 alist = malloc(sizeof(struct list)); 158 26 if (!alist) { 159 27 return FALSE; 160 28 } 161 29 162 30 alist->head = NULL; 163 31 alist->size = 0; 164 32 return TRUE; 165 33 } 166 34 167 35 int main() 168 36 { 169 37 struct list newlist; 170 38 if (!list_init(&newlist)) { 171 39 return EXIT_FAILURE; 172 40 } 173 41 174 42 printf("Contents of the new list is: %p, %d\n",(void *)newlist.head, 175 43 newlist.size); 176 44 return EXIT_SUCCESS; 177 45 }




31.5.2    "Approved" answer of RMIT



"Approved" answer of RMIT to exam question 1(D)

178 Error message: conditional based on uninitialised values 179 Fix: simply delete lines 25-29 (5 marks for error message and 5 marks for fix).




31.5.3    Answer of the Student



Answer of the student to exam question 1(D)

180 All assignments are to a local copy of @alist. 1 mark 181 182 Fix: Delete lines 25-29, 183 as @newlist resides on the stack and not from the heap. 5 marks




31.5.4    Exam's Topics



Week 12: Exam Resources: Examination Topics

• data types and operators (associativity and precedence rules) • flow control statements • standard input/output statements (scanf, printf, getchar, gets, putchar, puts) • functions, definitions and declarations, value and reference parameters, function return type; • storage classes • C pre-processor (#define, #include) • file handling (fopen, fclose, ftell, fseek, fscanf, fread, fprintf, fwrite, fgets, fputs, fgetc, getc, fputc, putc, rewind) • string handling (strcmp, strncmp, strlen, strcat, strcpy, strncpy, etc) • pointers, pointer arithmetic, array, 2-dimensional array • header files familiarity of basic symbols, macros and library support: ctype.h, string.h, stdio.h, stdlib.h and others you may have encountered • structs including dynamic allocation thereof, use as parameters, function return types • command line arguments • dynamic memory allocation of objects of built-in and userdefined types • dynamic data structures: singly-linked lists • Function pointers • Void pointers




31.5.5    Full Output of Valgrind



The following is the output from Valgrind for the buggy program shown above.

Details vary among libc versions, etc.

Full output from Valgrind for the program in exam question 1(D)

1 ==3385== Memcheck, a memory error detector 2 ==3385== Copyright (C) 2002-2017, and GNU GPL'd, by Julian Seward et al. 3 ==3385== Using Valgrind-3.13.0 and LibVEX; rerun with -h for copyright info 4 ==3385== Command: /tmp/a.out 5 ==3385== 6 ==3385== Conditional jump or move depends on uninitialised value(s) 7 ==3385== at 0x40194A fmt_x (vfprintf.c:157) 8 ==3385== by 0x4036FB printf_core (vfprintf.c:639) 9 ==3385== by 0x403AAF vfprintf (vfprintf.c:796) 10 ==3385== by 0x400972 printf (printf.c:9) 11 ==3385== by 0x40020D main (main.c:31) 12 ==3385== 13 ==3385== Conditional jump or move depends on uninitialised value(s) 14 ==3385== at 0x403719 printf_core (vfprintf.c:640) 15 ==3385== by 0x403AAF vfprintf (vfprintf.c:796) 16 ==3385== by 0x400972 printf (printf.c:9) 17 ==3385== by Chapter 32
— Assignment 1(A)
— Spelling Mistakes





32.1    Summary



Assignment 1(A) was about basic UNIX commands.

The question was

5) Enter the command to remove all rights to the file "readme.txt" other than read rights for the owner. No other user should have any access.




The student submitted on Sunday 15/12/2019 at 15:12 a correct answer, which included:

  • The correct UNIX utility, i.e. chmod.
  • The correct mode argument, i.e. 400.
  • And, as the second argument, the target file name.



However, I made a spelling mistake when I copied the file name from the question, namely, I put as the 2nd argument 'runme.txt' instead of 'readme.txt'.


What caused this "error"?

I can name at least three reasons, namely:

  • The previous question (i.e. question 4) used runme as the name of the example file.
  • runme.txt and readme.txt look very similar if you skim-read the questions.
  • Neither English nor its Latin-alphabet writing system are native to my cultural background.



You would expect them to give me full marks.

In fact, RMIT is obliged by law not to deliberately fail foreign students in a technical exam only because of an inconsequential spelling error.


However, RMIT saw fit to give me zero marks.


Had RMIT given me 99%, I would have said: "stupid but OK".

But no.

RMIT gave me 0%!


32.2    The Appeal Process



32.2.1    The first Appeal



On Sunday 29/12/2019 at 21:29 my appeal was dismissed as "gripes" and was told to "wait until one of the many opportunities provided to you where you can give us feedback on the course."


32.2.2    The Second Appeal



On Monday 30/12/2019 at 9:18, I wrote the following:

If i get the exact answer correct and the only offence was a slight misspelling by copying the name of the file in question - than i should not be punished for.

There is no need to disparage my voice as gripe or complaints



32.2.3    Formal Warning



This appeal got rejected on Monday 30/12/2019 at 12:09.

And on this second rejection, I was issued a "formal warning" because I dared to re-appeal despite "the directions of an officer of the university."







Chapter 33
— Assignemnt 1(C)(5)
— Self-Service Checkout





Note: This chapter is an introduction to the next chapter.



33.1    cpt220_menu_system Developed by RMIT



The core of assignment 1(C) was to develop a self-service checkout system.

The system had a (virtual) cash-register and a till drawer (with 8 compartments) storing its available cash (in coins/notes).

The register calculated if (hypothetical) transactions were possible.

Namely, if combinations of notes/coins were available to give change, do check-out, etc.


There were 8 compartments in the till, namely:
  • 5 cents (coins)
  • 10 cents (coins)
  • 20 cents (coins)
  • 50 cents (coins)
  • 1 dollars (coins)
  • 2 dollars (coins)
  • 5 dollars (notes)
  • 10 dollars (notes)



33.1.1    A Typical Script



A typical batch file (script) for the self-checkout system

# (Please note that comments are illegal and should be removed before running this script). # First, choose option 5 (out of the "menu-system") for the self-checkout system. 5 # This is the first input-prompt # Here, you feed the cash-register with its available (virtual) cash (in coins/notes). # "100 x 1" means 1 unit of "100"; "100" means 1 dollar (of 100 cents). # To terminate the prompt, add an empty line. 100 x 1 # This is the second input-prompt. # Type here the requested amount (for cash-out, change, etc.). # "1.00" means 1 dollar. # Then, you either add additional lines for further requests # or terminate the prompt with an empty line. 1.00




33.2    Case Study: cpt220_menu_system



The following shows "live" results of its operation.

In all 10 examples shown later, the register had exactly 1 unit of 1 dollar coin.


The first example requested 1 dollar (in cash-out).

As expected, this transaction completed successfully.


The following 9 examples were (increasingly) more "complex" operations where the customer requested larger amounts of cash-out.

Thus, in the second example, the customer requested 2 dollars cash-out (while there was only 1 dollar available in the register).

As expected, the machine rejected this request because:

"We could not match the requested changes"



The following examples requested increasingly larger amounts of cash-out, such as 3 dollars (in the third example), 4 dollars (in the forth example), and so on.


As for the last (and the tenth) example, the customer requested 10 dollars (while there was only 1 dollar available in the register)

After 367 hours, 30 minutes, and 5.151 seconds of intensive calculations, the system (developed by RMIT) concluded that:

"We could not match the requested changes".



33.2.1    Cash-out 1 Dollar Out of 1 Dollar



The program runs for 0.001 seconds before approving the transaction with a success message that "all requested changes could be matched."

Self-service checkout – developed and produced by RMIT Trying to cash-out 1 dollar while there is only 1 dollar left in the system

$ readelf -a /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a1/smaple/cpt220_menu_system \ | grep 'Build ID' Build ID: c870dd928f370f0ec12ae12e71fcbbc9059bb5f6 # The batch file. Choose option 5 of the menu; insert 1 dollar (100 cents x 1); request 1.00 dollar. $ cat /tmp/input.1 5 100 x 1 1.00 $ time /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a1/smaple/cpt220_menu_system \ </tmp/input.1 Welcome to my menu ------------------ 1) reverse a string 2) play guess a number 3) fold a string 4) validate tictactoe winner 5) check if change can be given 6) access the help menu 7) quit the program Please enter your choice: Can we issue sufficient change ? [...] all requested changes could be matched. The denominations used are: 5x0 10x0 20x0 50x0 100x1 200x0 500x0 1000x0 real 0m0.001s user 0m0.001s sys 0m0.000s




33.2.2    Cash-out 2 Dollars Out of 1 Dollar



The program runs for 0.138 seconds before finalizing its "calculations" with an error message that "we could not match the requested changes."

Self-service checkout – developed and produced by RMIT Trying to cash-out 2 dollars while there is only 1 dollar left in the system

$ readelf -a /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a1/smaple/cpt220_menu_system \ | grep 'Build ID' Build ID: c870dd928f370f0ec12ae12e71fcbbc9059bb5f6



# The batch file. Choose option 5 of the menu; insert 1 dollar (100 cents x 1); request 2.00 dollars. $ cat /tmp/input.2 5 100 x 1 1.00 1.00 $ time /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a1/smaple/cpt220_menu_system \ </tmp/input.2 Welcome to my menu ------------------ 1) reverse a string 2) play guess a number 3) fold a string 4) validate tictactoe winner 5) check if change can be given 6) access the help menu 7) quit the program Please enter your choice: Can we issue sufficient change ? [...] Error: we could not match the requested changes. Error: option not run successfully. real 0m0.138s user 0m0.138s sys 0m0.000s

33.2.7    Cash-out 7 Dollars Out of 1 Dollar



The program runs for 28 minutes, 36.125 seconds before finalizing its "calculations" with an error message that "we could not match the requested changes."

Self-service checkout – developed and produced by RMIT Trying to cash-out 7 dollars while there is only 1 dollar left in the system

Chapter 34
— Assignemnt 1(C)
— The "No Comments" Penalty





34.1    False Claim by RMIT



RMIT claimed that my implementation contained "little to no comments".


In reality, however, comments (in my code) were in abundance and were added to any function.

On occasion, comments were longer than the body of the function itself.


34.1.1    List of Comments



List of comments in assignment 1(C).

1. Out-of-range guesses. Convention in the sample. 2. A while-loop control-variable was (unexpectedly) incremented within the loop body. 3. Prototype and usage for ind_to_value(). 4. Prototype and usage for get1(). 5. Prototype, usage and internals for get(). 6. A struct (imposed by RMIT's prototype) was unused (except for one of its fields). 7. fold replaces space w/ NL instead of appending a NL; conventions in UNIX and sample. 8. Aborting for unimplemented (and too short) column widths; why. 9. Enumeration constant ROW_0. Meaning. 10. Enumeration constant COL_A. Meaning. 11. Enumeration constant DIAG_NW. Meaning. 12. Enumeration constant DIAG_NE. Meaning. 13. Prototype and usage for board_to_array(); the expected size of @a. 14. Prototype and usage for win_at_slots(); the expected size, order and format of @s. 15. Function-local static variables. Intent and purpose. 16. Impact of the function-local static variable. 17. Logic behind the string "1000x2147483647\n" (as the expansion for the BUFSIZE macro). 18. Macro TTT_DEBUG. Usage and purpose. 19. str_to_int constrained to [0,INT_MAX]. How, why. TODO to change the misleading prototype. 19. str_to_int() truncates from long (getlong()) to int. Why it was safe to do so. 20. Files not terminated by NL. The buggy convention in the sample. How and why we differ. 21. Prototype and usage for scan(). FIXME the limitation of 2 fields. 22. Limitation of 2 fields in scan(). FIXME to remove limitation. 23. tokenize(): Assumptions. Limits. Rationale for implementation. FIXME(1) and FIXME(2). 24. parse(): Prototype and usage; the expected prototype of @callbacks. 25. Prototype, usage and purpose for parse_input(). 26. get_reg(): Rationale for aborting. 27. Empty line terminates the input-prompt. Why. 28. fold(1) conventions (in UNIX and the sample) regarding replace space versus append NL. 29. Files not terminated by a NL; convention in the sample; why we differ. 30. The sample interprets '1...00' as '1.00'. Why we differ. 31. On the ambiguity of '0.5'; should it be interpreted as '0.50' or '5 cents'. Rationale.




34.2    RMIT's Useless Comments



One of the idiosyncrasies of RMIT is to "document" every other line of code with obvious and tedious "explanations".

Comments were added to simple lines of code in order to provide English "translations" of the code.

For example:

/home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a1/startup/imp.c

76 /* increase the number of items */ 77 thelist->num_items++;




You see, I have nothing against the English language.

But this is a source-code file written in C.

Right?

English translations are good for hello world tutorials but are otherwise a distraction.

It is annoying and unhelpful.


Worse yet, those inline comments have to be adjusted and re-written after each tiny modification of the code.

A maintenance nightmare.


34.3    Linux Coding Style Regarding Comments



Linux's coding style states that:

linux/Documentation/process/coding-style.rst

547 8) Commenting 548 ------------- 549 550 Comments are good, but there is also a danger of over-commenting. NEVER 551 try to explain HOW your code works in a comment: it's much better to 552 write the code so that the **working** is obvious, and it's a waste of 553 time to explain badly written code. 554 555 Generally, you want your comments to tell WHAT your code does, not HOW. 556 Also, try to avoid putting comments inside a function body: if the 557 function is so complex that you need to separately comment parts of it, 558 you should probably go back to chapter 6 for a while. You can make 559 small comments to note or warn about something particularly clever (or 560 ugly), but try to avoid excess. Instead, put the comments at the head 561 of the function, telling people what it does, and possibly WHY it does 562 it.




34.4    RMIT's abnormal Naming Conventions



To make matters worse, I received an email from RMIT on Monday 27/01/2020 at 10:39.

They (sadistically) noted that my grade was "too high" (direct quote!!).

Because there was a "problem" in my code.

The variable 'f' (quoted in the next section) was not properly named, they claimed.

RMIT rebuked me in that email: "What's that supposed to signify".


The variable 'f' in question is quoted hereafter.

Extract from assignment 1 part 3
Submitted by student on Thursday 09/01/2020 at 18:45

206 struct falsible_register can_give_change(cash_register reg, 207 const change_requests requests, 208 int num_requests) 209 { 210 int i; 211 struct falsible_register f; /* only f.succcess field is used! */




Now, did RMIT read the above?

Didn't I note in the same line that this variable was unused?

I left it only because of the prototype.

This prototype was designed by RMIT and there is nothing I could do about it.


Now, is 'falsible_register' a meaningful name for a data type?

I am not sure.

Did I like it?

No.

But I was forced to use it and reluctantly complied.


The unused variable was named after its data type (and the first letter thereof), namely: 'f'.

"What's that supposed to signify?"

Nothing.

And, frankly, who cares?


For more on naming conventions in the alternate universe of RMIT, read here.


34.5    Self-Documenting Code



And since RMIT took issue with my recursion implementation (and its choice of identifiers), let us look at my implementation and see if it is self-explanatory because RMIT pretended it wasn't, and they threatened to deduct points from my grade if I would dare to ask them for a review.


As noted, the first assignment was about implementing a self-service checkout system.

It assumed a (virtual) till drawer with 8 compartments, including:

  • 5 cents (coins)
  • 10 cents (coins)
  • 20 cents (coins)
  • 50 cents (coins)
  • 1 dollars (coins)
  • 2 dollars (coins)
  • 5 dollars (notes)
  • 10 dollars (notes)



To get the required coins/notes, my program uses a recursive function get().

This function calls itself recursively until it successfully assembles the required currency (in coins/notes) or (when unable to find the required notes/coins) reports an error.


The get() function is "helped" by a sub-function called: get1().

Sub-functions are named (by convention) foo_sub or foo1.

This is an example of self-documenting code.

Both functions were file-local static functions and were not visible outside this file.

The meaning of their identifiers, therefore, were strictly related to the context of this file, where the interaction of these two related functions and their semantics were self-evident.

And as noted before, detailed comments were added to each function regarding prototype and usage.


And there is more.

The expectations of those functions were also fully documented by two assertions (BUG() and BUG()).


Here is an example run of the get() function in its deepest recursion frame trying to add coins from the lowest-valued compartment (holding 5-cents coins).

Note how get() was called recursively 8 times.

On the 8th recursive-call, it branched out (like it did in the previous ones) and called the helper function: get1().


Frames go from bottom to top.

For each frame, the target return address (of that frame) is noted by its offset from the start of its (respective) function.


An example run of the self-service checkout system.

Trying to cash-out 18.85 dollars.

The program assembles 1 unit (coin/note) of each of the following:
  • 1 note of 10 dollars.
  • 1 note of 5 dollars.
  • 1 coin of 2 dollars.
  • 1 coin of 1 dollar.
  • 1 coin of 50 cents.
  • 1 coin of 20 cents.
  • 1 coin of 10 cents.
  • 1 coin of 5 cents.

get1 +82 get +64 get +90 get +90 get +90 get +90 get +90 get +90 get +90 can_give_change +181 menu_process_choice +435 main +267 libc_start_main_stage2 +44 __libc_start_main +54 _start_c +82 _start +15
