Submitted by student on Thursday 09/01/2020 at 18:45

1 /* 2 * [...] run indent -linux and further development. 3 * Initial skeleton provided by RMIT as part of assignment 1. 4 */ [...] 36 37 /** 38 * play the guess a number game. Generate a random number between 1 and 10. 39 * Give the user ten guesses to guess the number. 40 **/ 41 static int guess_a_number_sub(void); 42 void guess_a_number(long seed) 43 { [...] 50 } 51 52 static int guess_a_number_sub(void) 53 { [...] 64 65 while (k--) { [...] 79 if (!(j > 0 && j < 11)) { 80 error_output 81 ("number is not in the allowed range. Please try again.\n"); 82 /* sample program does not count this as a try - 83 * i.e. is not counted twoards the 10 allowed guesses. 84 */ 85 k++; /* ouch! */ 86 continue; 87 } [...] 113 } 114 return 0; 115 } 116 117 /* convert enum denom_ind to enum denom_val */ 118 static enum denom_val ind_to_value(enum denom_ind idx) 119 { [...] 160 } 161 162 /* 163 * For level @l (where @l is [0,NUM_DENOMS-1]), 164 * cash in from @reg[@l] some x, where value of x is <= @v 165 */ 166 static unsigned int get1(cash_register reg, int l, unsigned int v) 167 { 168 unsigned int i; 169 unsigned int n; 170 171 if (!v) { 172 BUG(); 173 } 174 if (l < 0 || l >= NUM_DENOMS) { 175 BUG(); 176 } 177 178 n = reg[l].count; 179 i = 0; 180 while (i < n && (i + 1) * ind_to_value(l) <= v) { 181 i++; 182 } 183 reg[l].count -= i; 184 return i * ind_to_value(l); 185 } 186 187 /* 188 * For level @l (where @l is [0,NUM_DENOMS-1]), 189 * cash in from @reg[@l] some x, wehre value of x is <= @v. 190 * 191 * This works by recursion. 192 * Idea inspired by assignment 1 spec (provided by RMIT). 193 */ 194 static BOOLEAN get(cash_register reg, int l, unsigned int v) 195 { 196 if (!v) { 197 return TRUE; 198 } 199 if (l < 0) { 200 return FALSE; 201 } 202 v -= get1(reg, l, v); 203 return get(reg, l – 1, v); 204 } 205 206 struct falsible_register can_give_change(cash_register reg, 207 const change_requests requests, 208 int num_requests) 209 { 210 int i; 211 struct falsible_register f; /* only f.succcess field is used! */ [...] 234 f.success = TRUE; 235 return f; 236 } 237 238 /** 239 * folds a string passed in so that no line is longer than the specified width. 240 * This function should behave the same as the unix "fold" command. You should 241 * compare your output to calling the fold program at the terminal as follows: 242 * fold -s -w [width] [filename] 243 * Where width is the desired width to fold at and filename holds the contents 244 * that you wish to fold. 245 * 246 * The recommended approach here is to jump forward by width characters and 247 * then step backwards until you find a space character and replace it with 248 * a newline character. 249 250 * TODO: This version differs a little from the fold utility. 251 * See readme.txt for rationle. 252 **/ 253 254 char *fold(char str[], unsigned w) 255 { [...] 259 while ((e += w) < end) { [...] 263 if (e == s) { 264 error_output("Please use a larger width to fold at.\n"); 265 /* Per the spec, we don't care here... */ 266 BUG(); 267 } [...] 271 } 272 return str; 273 } 274 275 enum method_win { 276 ROW_0, /* horizontal */ 277 ROW_1, 278 ROW_TWO, 279 COL_A, /* vertical */ 280 COL_B, 281 COL_C, 282 DIAG_NW, /* diagonal. top is north-west */ 283 DIAG_NE, /* diagonal. top is north-east */ 284 NUM_WINS 285 }; 286 287 /* Get the "flat" represenation of the board @b in @a. 288 * Order is left-to-right, top-to-bottom. 289 * sizeof (array pointed to by @a) is BOARD_SIZE of enum ttt_result. 290 */ 291 static void board_to_array(ttt_board b, enum ttt_result *a) [...] 301 /* 302 * Helper function called by each of the 8 possible win methods. 303 * Each method calls this helper function, with @s 304 * (which is pointing to an array of 3 the indexs in the board 305 * that are at interest for that method). 306 * 307 * Example: 308 * For row_0_win(), array pointed by @s is [0, 1, 2]. 309 * For diag_nw_win(), array pointed by @s is [0, 4, 8]. 310 * And so on... 311 * 312 * Remember, that order is from top-to-bottom, left-to-right. 313 */ 314 315 static enum ttt_result win_at_slots(ttt_board b, win_slots s, enum method_win m) [...] 420 enum ttt_result ttt_check_win(ttt_board b) 421 { 422 unsigned int i; 423 enum ttt_result r = TTT_INVALID_RESULT; 424 BOOLEAN stop = FALSE; 425 426 /* 427 * @init and @wins are static variables. 428 * Thus, initialized only at compile-time! 429 */ 430 static BOOLEAN init = FALSE; 431 static win *wins[NUM_WINS]; 432 433 /* Initialization. Done only in the first invocation. */ 434 if (init == FALSE) { 435 install_wins(wins); 436 init = TRUE; 437 } [...] 485 }

1 /* 2 * [...] run indent -linux and further development. 3 * Initial skeleton provided by RMIT as part of assignment 1. 4 */ [...] 19 #define BUFSIZE (sizeof "1000x2147483647\n") /* (10 dollars * MAX_INT) */ 20 #undef TTT_DEBUG /*turn-on to get debugging info*/ [...] 31 /** 32 * The famous read_rest_of_line() function. 33 * It reads chars from stdin (most of the time the keyboard) until we 34 * reach either the end of the operating system's input buffer or we 35 * reach a newline character (that's the end of the buffer that we should 36 * read). 37 **/ 38 static void read_rest_of_line(void) 39 { [...] 43 } 44 45 /* 46 * FIXME: str_to_int() will fail if the parsed value is < 0. 47 * This semantic parsing is a necessity of the current 48 * fuctions calling this function. 49 * TODO: Change the name/prototype, so it shows that we 50 * return only a non-negative value into @output. 51 */ 52 static enum input_result str_to_int(char *buf, int *output) 53 { [...] 64 /* No truncation here, as we allow only [0, INT_MAX]. */ 65 *output = (int)l; 66 return IR_SUCCESS; 67 } 68 [...] 78 79 enum input_result get_string(const char prompt[], char buf[], size_t n) 80 { 81 char *s; 82 while (1) { [...] 95 96 /* NOTE: not fully compliant with sample program. see readme.txt */ 97 if (!feof(stdin) && buf[strlen(buf) – 1] != '\n') { 98 error_output("input was too long. Please try again.\n"); 99 read_rest_of_line(); 100 continue; 101 } [...] 105 } 106 107 } [...] 143 /** 144 * allows the user to select a menu item to run from the menu 145 **/ 146 147 enum menu_choice select_menu_item(char menu[NUM_MENU_ITEMS][SCREENWIDTH + 1]) 148 { [...] 164 } 165 [...] 185 /* 186 * Simple state-machine that matches a text that contains 187 * exactly @n of @sep within @p. 188 * 189 * FIXME: currently, only @n==2 is implemented. 190 */ 191 static BOOLEAN scan(const char *p, char sep, unsigned int n) 192 { 193 /* FIXME: implement for @n != 2 */ 194 if (n != TWO) 195 BUG(); [...] 216 } 217 218 /* 219 * Install @n tokens in @output. 220 * Returns number (possibly < @n) of token installed in @output. 221 * 222 * FIXME(1): Currenty we assume that @buf does not contain more than 223 * @n tokens, as @buf has already succedded a sanity check via a previous 224 * helper function (like scan()). 225 * 226 * In fact, in the current scheme, where we verify via scan() before 227 * a call to tokenize(), this function will always return @n. 228 * 229 * Thus, currently, for every call to tokenize() in this program, if the 230 * (return value) != (initial value of @n), the program BUG()s. 231 * 232 * FIXME(2): tokenize() verifies that we have =>1 @sep between the tokens. 233 * Thus, a sanity check (like scan()), should first verify that we have 234 * exactly *one* @sep in between the tokens. 235 * 236 * Rationale for the current implementation, is the semantics of strtok() 237 * that (for now) drives this function. 238 */ 239 static unsigned int tokenize(char *buf, const char *sep, char *output[], 240 unsigned int n) 241 { [...] 259 } 260 261 /* 262 * Install parsed value of input[] in output[]. 263 * If the semantic parser installed for that slot in callback[] fails, 264 * We stop the parsing and return a value less than initial value of @n. 265 * 266 * Any callback installed via the callbacks[], should return -1 on failure. 267 */ 268 static unsigned int parse(char *input[], int output[], unsigned int n, 269 callback * callbacks[]) 270 { [...] 288 } 289 290 /* Return @n values in ip[], while parsing the input wia callbacks[] */ 291 static enum input_result parse_input(const char *prompt, unsigned int n, 292 char *sep, int ip[], 293 callback * callbacks[]) 294 { [...] 328 } [...] 383 static void get_reg(cash_register reg) 384 { [...] 409 while ((r = parse_input(p, TWO, "x", intp, callbacks)) != IR_EOF) { [...] 416 ind = get_denom_index(intp[0]); 417 if (ind == -1) { 418 /* Should had fail the semantic parser in callbacks[] */ 419 BUG(); 420 } 421 reg[ind].count += intp[1]; [...] 425 }




34.6.3    Comments in readme.txt



Comments in file readme.txt: Assignment 1(C)
Submitted by student on Thursday 09/01/2020 at 18:45

23 NOTES 24 ----- 25 26 1) Per the spec, either EOF on a newline from a terminal (in default canonical configuration), 27 or an empty line (interactive mode, or reading from a file), both terminate the programe, 28 or when in an input session, will return from the prompt and process the input. 29 30 31 2) Extra care (and many unfortunate hacks) were added to mimic the debugging messages 32 of the sample program – as far as the test cases are involved in the tester program. 33 34 Other cases (not covered in the tester), may still show a different order or some variation 35 in the error messages, as the debugging messages are first and foremost shown to indicate 36 the current version's implementation. 37 38 39 3) The fold program was implemented as shown by the sample program, even though, the unix utility 40 shown in the skeleton differs a little, by *appending* a <NL> instead of *replacing* the white-space 41 with a <NL>. 42 The following example shows the unix variation vs the sample implementation of the fold option. 43 44 $ fold -s -w 5 <<\EOF | xxd 45 foo bar 46 EOF 47 00000000: 666f 6f20 0a62 6172 0a foo .bar. 48 49 50 a1/sample/cpt220_menu_system <<\EOF 2>&1 | grep 'foo\|bar' | xxd 51 3 52 foo bar 53 5 54 EOF 55 00000000: 666f 6f0a 6261 720a foo.bar. 56 57 58 4) Current version does not fail for "long" string, only when they are actually "long". 59 i.e. if we read from a file, and line read is shorter than max allowed, even though 60 it was not terminated by a <NL>, it will succeed. 61 In particular, this version does not show "input was too long", for such a string. 62 63 Such a case was not covered under the tests suite. 64 65 The sample program differs in some cases, as demonstrated in the following examples: 66 67 $ printf 1 >/tmp/1 68 $ /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a1/sample/cpt220_menu_system </tmp/1 69 Error: input was too long. Please try again. 70 71 $ echo 1 >/tmp/1 72 Please enter a string to reverse (maximum of 80 characters): 73 74 $ printf 1 >/tmp/1 75 $ <current_version_compiled> </tmp/1 76 Please enter a string to reverse (maximum of 80 characters): 77 78 $ echo 1 >/tmp/1 79 $ <current_version_compiled> </tmp/1 80 Please enter a string to reverse (maximum of 80 characters): 81 82 5) While the sample program is more permissive when entering the currency requests, as demonstrated 83 in the following example, the current version insists on the format '?.?' like (1.00), 84 to be more consistent with the restriction in the cash_register input, where it 85 should match exactly the '?x?' format (like '100x1'). 86 Rationale: Because this allows us to reuse the same parser in both cases, thus improving the consistency and 87 reusability of the program as a whole. 88 89 $ /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a1/sample/cpt220_menu_system <<\EOF 90 5 91 100x2 92 93 1..00 94 1... 95 EOF 96 all requested changes could be matched. 97 The denominations used are: 5x0 10x0 20x0 50x0 100x2 200x0 500x0 1000x0 98 99 6) We follow the sample program, where '0.5' as an input for the change_requests prompt, 100 is interpreted as 5 cents, the same as '0.05', and *NOT* as '0.50'. 101 102 Example: (where the prompt messages were omitted, for the case of brevity). 103 104 $ /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a1/sample/cpt220_menu_system <<\EOF 105 5 106 5x1 107 108 0.5 109 110 EOF 111 all requested changes could be matched. 112 The denominations used are: 5x1 10x0 20x0 50x0 100x0 200x0 500x0 1000x0 113 114 $ /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a1/sample/cpt220_menu_system <<\EOF 115 5 116 5x1 117 118 0.05 119 120 EOF 121 all requested changes could be matched. 122 The denominations used are: 5x1 10x0 20x0 50x0 100x0 200x0 500x0 1000x0 123 124 $ /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a1/sample/cpt220_menu_system <<\EOF 125 5 126 5x1 127 128 0.50 129 130 EOF 131 Error: we could not match the requested changes. 132 Error: option not run successfully.









Chapter 35
— Assignment 2(A)
— Debugging Assignment





Note: This chapter is an introduction to the following 3 chapters.



35.1    Summary



Thiz santence haz 5 speling errorz.

Right?


This is a common exercise when learning a foreign language.

Students are given a short story in which they have to find five spelling-errors.


Programming languages are not very different.

Students were given a short source code file and told to find five errors.


RMIT told us to document our journey by copying the output of the debugging tools (run by the students to find the bugs).

RMIT advised us to use (at least) 2 different debugging tools. And to that end, RMIT provided a list of recommended debugging tools available on their server.


Lastly, we had to fix the errors by re-writing the buggy lines.


The prize for the assignment was 20 marks.


Because of its importance, RMIT deemed it "the most important topic in the entire course".


The evolution of this assignment goes back to 2014 (and following years) when RMIT funded a team of three researchers to do a (multi-year) survey towards its development.

Over its many years of research, RMIT conducted "three macro research phases" (including "data collections" involving "mixed methods").

Back in 2016, RMIT reported that the "latest round" of the "research cycle" was still "under analysis" and "to be reported elsewhere".


35.2    Resources



35.2.1    Assignment Instructions



Although listing its recommended tools, RMIT promised to give marking points for any tool on its server, including grep.

Surprisingly, when I used a debugging-tool which RMIT "very much encourage[d]" us to use, I was not given the points.


Debugging exercise instructions

1 CPT220 – Programming in C 2 Due date: Sunday 12th January, 9pm 3 4 Please note that the debugging exercises themselves will not be released until Monday 6th January at 5 9 am. This will give you almost a week to complete the exercise. I estimate it should only take 3-4 6 hours at most to complete so you should allow for that amount of time. 7 8 Assignment 2 – Part A – Debugging Exercise Instructions 9 10 This assignment has been designed to assist you in learning the skill of debugging. The lack of 11 debugging skills has been listed as a shortcoming of programming graduates as such we have decided 12 this is an important focus for teaching and learning in a course in programming. 13 14 15 For this reason, this is an important part of the course in "Programming in C" and should be a skill 16 you should prioritise in order to be successful in the course, later in your degree and beyond to 17 the world of work. 18 19 20 The debugging activity 21 22 The programs to debugged will be available in a directory under: 23 24 ~e70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/debugginglabs 25 26 On the core teaching servers (saturn, titan, jupiter). 27 28 29 You will have a week to complete this assignment which may seem like a shorter amount of time than 30 we give you for the other assignments. That's true but it is actually a lot less work. When I ran 31 this exercise with on-campus students, they were required to complete it within 24 hours and were 32 able to do it. I have allowed more time for the OUA offering as you may have scheduled different 33 times in the week for your study in this course and I want to allow you to have that flexibility. 34 35 36 The lab you need to debug is different according to the your RMIT student ID. Below is a table 37 explaining which lab you need to do: 38 39 Your ID Ends in: Your should do lab contained in the directory: 40 1 or 6 lab1 41 2 or 7 lab2 42 3 or 8 lab3 43 4 or 9 lab4 44 5 or 0 lab5 45 46 You need to copy the directory specified to a directory under your linux home directory so that you 47 may compile and debug the program. Please note that if you download to your home computer and then 48 upload you will lose all permissions on files. We recommend you copy these files using the command 49 line. If you are having any problems with this, your first step should be to consult the Unix 50 Survival Guide, available here: http://titan.csit.rmit.edu.au/~e70949/inductionguide.pdf 51 52 53 Once you have copied these files, you will have a series of .c and .h files for a program. Read the 54 "readme.txt" file for an explanation of what the program is supposed to do. 55 56 57 Please do not ask questions about this exercise until you have read the readme.txt file as this is 58 the first place I will refer you to. 59 60 61 The problem you are faced with is that this program has been broken. The last person to edit the 62 program left it in a sorry state. The comments in the files explaining what the program is supposed 63 to do are correct but the actual code is buggy and we need you to fix it. 64 65 66 Each program has a file called "Makefile" which tells the compiler how to compile the program. You 67 may assume that the Makefile is correct and all you need to do to compile the program is type "make" 68 at the command line. The problems however will be in the .c and .h files. 69 70 71 You will need to follow the method outlined in the week 6 chat session(s). You need to read output 72 and deduce what the problems are and then fill in a bug report for each bug you find. 73 74 75 You may use any strategies to do so but a tool based approach is to be preferred. We are interested 76 in the strategies you use but also in the tools you select to solve this problem. We very much 77 encourage you to use tools which we covered when you studied the course such as gdb and valgrind and 78 libasan but feel free to use anything else installed on the server (see the course materials in week 79 6). For example, if you are more familiar with linux, you might use grep to find the source of the 80 bug and that would get marks too, so long as you use the tool correctly. 81 82 83 As you debug this program, you are required to keep track of the strategies you are using. We have 84 provided a google form for this purpose which you must use. The google form is located at: 85 86 https://tinyurl.com/cpt220-debex-sp4-2019 (available after 9 am, 6th January). 87 88 You will receive an email link upon submission of this form so you can go back into this form as often 89 as you like and make changes to your submission. Save / submit this form often while your are working 90 on your debugging assignment. 91 92 93 Please note that you will need to be logged into google using your rmit student email account in 94 your web browser or you will not be able to complete this assessment. I recommend you logout of 95 other google accounts to avoid problems while completing this assessment. 96 97 98 The data you enter on the google form is the basis for your grade for this assessment so the more up 99 to date you keep it, the better your chance to score well. 100 101 102 103 The Makefile 104 105 Each debugging project contains a Makefile that tells gcc how to compile your program. 106 107 108 If you just want to compile the program normally to run it, simply type "make" in the directory with 109 all the files for the project. 110 111 112 113 Available make targets: 114 115 make – compile the program without debugging symbols (that's variable and function names). 116 make debug – get the debugging symbols so you can use vagrind and gdb on the compiled executable. 117 make sanitize – use the memory sanitization library which is compile into the program. 118 make cleean – delete all files created by compilation. 119 In particular you will have to do this when switching to / from valgrind and libasan. 120 121 122 If you want to export debugging symbols for use with gdb and valgrind, type "make debug". 123 124 125 If you want to build in libasan so that memory will be hardened to simplify finding memory problems, 126 type "make sanitize". 127 128 Please note that with the sanitize target, you must run the following command first: 129 130 scl enable devtoolset-8 bash 131 132 133 If you want to delete all files created as part of compilation, type "make clean" 134 135 136 137 Marks Breakdown 138 139 There is 20 marks available for this lab which will amount to 10 percent of your mark for assignment 2. 140 141 The breakdown of marks is as follows: 142 143 One mark for each correct bug found. An additional mark for a correct fix. An additional mark for a 144 correct write-up of the bug using the provided google form. There is an additional bonus mark if you 145 have 5 correctly identified and corrected bugs and the report is filled out correctly. You should 146 provide sufficient detail in your report such that someone could follow your instructions to find 147 and fix that problem. What you are providing is a bug fix for your fellow employees in your company 148 to use to fix the bug. 149 150 151 The other four marks are awarded for a good use of a debugging tool – two marks for each tool you 152 use. For example, if you used valgrind or gdb to track down a bug, make sure you note that down as 153 that will contribute to your marks. Give as much detail as you can about this so we can see how you 154 used it. You may use any tool available on saturn / jupiter / titan for this purpose. 155 156 157 So the marks are: 3 * 5 + 1 + 2 mark (each) for showing a good use of 2 tools covered in the 158 debugging section (week 6) of this course. 159 160 161 Please ensure that as you solve each bug that you enter data about that bug into the google form. 162 Insufficient information about a bug will result in a mark deduction, incorrect identification of a 163 bug will result in 0 marks. It will not be much good to wait until you have found all bugs as you 164 may not have time to enter all the data about your debugging strategies at that point. A job you may 165 have to do early in your career is work as a tester. As a tester you will need to provide this kind 166 of information on each bug you find. 167 168 169 Please feel free to ask any questions about this process. This exercise is there to help you learn. 170 171 172 Late Submission Policy 173 174 Once the due date has passed, you will lose 10% of the possible marks for 175 each day late that your submission is. If your submission is more than 5 days late it will not be 176 marked. In other words, if you submit your assignment after 9 pm on the 14th July it is considered a 177 day late, after 9 pm on Tuesday 15th July it is considered two days late, and so on. 178 179 180 As usual, everything you submit is required to be your own work. It is an offense to pass off 181 someone else's work as your own.




35.2.2    Lecture



Here, again, RMIT promised students to "get marks" even for using grep, etc.

Nevertheless, RMIT listed its recommended tools, including GDB and libasan.

Surprisingly, this student, who followed suit and analyzed in detail both of the aforementioned recommended tools, did not get the marks.


Week 06 Lecture (30/12/2019 19:30)

1 This little topic here, I kind of considerer to be a little bit my baby. 2 3 When I got involved in the C Programming Course on campus, I've noticed that students would ignore 4 this material. 5 6 They would be told: "Over on the side here is this thing called GDB, and you can have a look at 7 it when you want to". 8 9 The inference being: not that important! 10 11 My view, my experience as a teacher of C Programming is that this is probably the most important 12 topic in the entire course! 13 14 And for that reason, we also have an assessment based on it. 15 16 So we are gonna talk a little bit about that today as well. 17 18 But yeah. Really important. Don't skip over this! 19 20 In fact, if you put some timing to this, you will find completing assignment 1 easier 21 22 And you will find completing all your other programming from now on easier. 23 24 Wow, that's a big sales-pitch! 25 26 And I mean to deliver! 27 28 The key thing is, we want to produce code that has minimal bugs. 29 30 That is, to have code that is, relatively, bug-free. 31 32 There is a debate amongst teachers, and I think it is a stupid debate, quite frankly, but anyway it 33 is a debate. 34 35 About whether you teach programming or debugging first. 36 37 I think, it needs to be intertwined! 38 39 You can not enjoyably learn programming unless you learn techniques of debugging. Right? 40 41 ... 42 43 Get to know the tools in your environment. 44 45 That is really the assignment, actually. 46 47 Get to know the tools in your environment and how to use them to help you solve your problems. 48 49 So, on our servers there are: Gdb, Valgrind and related tools, like: Grep, Diff, Bash, Awk, Sed, 50 and so on. 51 52 You are free to use any of those, and you would actually get, in particular for the debugging 53 assessment, you can get marks for using those. 54 55 So long it shows a good way to solve a problem. 56 57 So, the problem-solving is the key thing. The tools underpin your problem-solving. 58 59 And this is even more important if you are less comfortable with UNIX. 60 61 Because we are building a new skill-set that helps you broaden-out where you can work. 62 63 That is part of what I am trying to do. 64 65 ... 66 67 Marks Breakdown. 68 69 10% of your marks for assignment 2. 70 71 So, 1 mark for each correct bug found. 72 73 Additional mark for a correct fix. 74 75 Additional mark for a correct write-up. 76 77 So, explain what you did to find the problem, what you did to fix the problem. 78 79 How was this a big fix. 80 81 And in fact, I need to be convinced that it is a bug fix for you to get the full marks. 82 83 So, that means when marking this out of 20 there are 3 marks per bug and 5 bugs. 84 85 And you want to make sure the ones you submit are correct. 86 87 There is one mark bonus if you manage to get all. If all five bug fixes are correct. 88 89 Then there are 2 marks each for showing a good use of: Gdb, Valgrind, LibASAN or some other tool. 90 91 That ends up being 20, then divide by 2 to get you a mark out of 10. 92 93 I will putting the spec up soon enough, but ignore the date because this was a previous offering, 94 but it is the same thing we are going to be doing. 95 96 Basically, you have a week to complete. 97 98 I would say 2-hours work. 99 100 But I know students who were struggling to do it during 2 hours, so I give you a week to do it. 101 102 The best of you will complete it within an hour or 2.

35.2.4    Class Notes



While listing both, Valgrind and libasan, in his list of available tools, the Unit Coordinator singled out one of those two (namely, libasan) and told us that "you should use it".

My submission followed suit (by using libasan), only to get 0 marks.


Lecture 6: Class Notes

[...] LibASAN More modern gcc has a new library that "hardens" memory so that your program crashes with a stack trace highlighting where the problem occurred. This library tends to be more conservative than valgrind and so when it is available you should use it.




35.2.5    Tutorial Chat



In the following, the Unit Coordinator discussed whether we had to use Valgrind or libasan.

His verdict was: "up to you".

I had done so by using libasan, only to be given zero marks.


Week 6 – Group A – Tutorial Chat On 31/12/2020 19:30

[...] The next thing to do before we finish is I wanted to show how to use libsanitizer: "make sanitize".

[...]

These two (valgrind and LibAsan), I find personally that sometimes Valgrind gives me more information and sometimes LibAsan gives me more information.

But here, I'm getting more or less the same data. Right?

So, which do you use Valgrind or LibAsan? Up to you!

Just be aware that they are not compatible with each other so when you want to use valgrind, you have to do: "make debug". Because it is a different form of an executable in each case. [...]



35.2.6    Google Form



RMIT's own Google Form clearly states that any tool on the list other than "compiler warnings and errors" will "get marks".

My assignment clearly demonstrated two tools — from the list — other than "compiler warnings and errors"; however, I was not given the marks.

And since I had to tick-off checkboxes for each of the bugs and state clearly which tool I had used (and the output of demonstrated tools were fully quoted, for each bug, followed by detailed analysis), this makes it outright criminal.


The Following is an extract from the Google Form (authored by the Unit Coordinator), which was repeated for each of the 5 bugs.



Extract from the Google Form for the debugging assignment

23 To get marks for tool use, compiler warnings and errors will not be considered 24 but they will inform us of your overall strategy to fix the problem. 25 26 ☒ GDB 27 ☐ Valgrind 28 ☐ Compiler warning 29 ☐ Compiler error 30 ☐ Libsanatize 31 ☐ Other




35.2.7    Source Code for the Debugging Assignment



This was the source code for the compiled program.

Student had to find five bugs in the following file.


/home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/debugginglabs/lab3/phonebk_strtok.c The source code for the (intentionally buggy) program of assignment 2(A)

1 #include <stdio.h> 2 #include <stdlib.h> 3 #include "fsupport.h" 4 #include "phone.h" 5 6 int load(struct phone_entry*, FILE*); 7 void print_book(struct phone_entry*, int); 8 typedef enum { FNAME, LNAME, NUMBER } token_number; 9 10 int main(int argc, char** argv) 11 { 12 FILE *fpRead; 13 struct phone_entry list[DIRECTORYSIZE]; 14 int result; 15 16 /* zero out the array so it is fully initialised */ 17 memset(list, sizeof(struct phone_entry) * DIRECTORYSIZE,0); 18 19 /* check for the correct number of command line arguments */ 20 if(argc != NUMARGS) 21 { 22 fprintf(stderr, "Error: invalid arguments.\n\n"); 23 return EXIT_FAILURE; 24 } 25 /* open the input file */ 26 fpRead = gropen(*argv); 27 /* load the data and handle errors */ 28 result = load(list, fpRead); 29 /* check that the data loaded successfully */ 30 if(result > 0) 31 { 32 fprintf(stderr, "Error: failed to load data.\n\n"); 33 return EXIT_FAILURE; 34 } 35 /* print out the data */ 36 print_book(list, result); 37 38 return EXIT_SUCCESS; 39 } 40 41 /************************************************************************** 42 * load data in from disk. 43 ***************************************************************************/ 44 int load(struct phone_entry* entries, FILE* fpRead) 45 { 46 char line[MAXWIDTH+EXTRASPACES]; 47 unsigned entrycount; 48 /*read in each line from the file, ensuring there is space to store */ 49 while(fgets(line, MAXWIDTH+EXTRASPACES, fpRead) != NULL && 50 entrycount < DIRECTORYSIZE) 51 { 52 char fname[NAMELEN], lname[NAMELEN], number[PHONELEN]; 53 char linecpy[MAXWIDTH+EXTRASPACES]; 54 char * token; 55 /* keep a count of the current token */ 56 token_number curtoken=0; 57 58 /* remove the newline from the line read in so it does not get 59 * stored in the last token 60 */ 61 line[strlen(line)-1]=0; 62 /* make a copy of the line in case we need to use in in (sic) error 63 * messages 64 */ 65 strcpy(line, linecpy); 66 67 /* start string tokenization */ 68 token = strtok(line, delim); 69 while(token == NULL) 70 { 71 /* check which token we are up to and copy the data into the 72 * appropriate string 73 */ 74 switch(curtoken) 75 { 76 case FNAME: 77 strcpy(fname, token); 78 break; 79 case LNAME: 80 strcpy(lname, token); 81 break; 82 case NUMBER: 83 strcpy(number, token); 84 break; 85 default: 86 /* if there are too many tokens, display an error */ 87 fprintf(stderr, "invalid line in file: %s\n", linecpy); 88 return EOF; 89 } 90 /* get the next token */ 91 token = strtok(line, delim); 92 ++curtoken; 93 } 94 /* insert the data into the array */ 95 strcpy(entries[entrycount].fname, fname); 96 strcpy(entries[entrycount].lname, lname); 97 strcpy(entries[entrycount].number, number); 98 ++entrycount; 99 } 100 return (int)entrycount; 101 } 102 103 /*************************************************************************** 104 * print out the data in the phone book. 105 ***************************************************************************/ 106 void print_book(struct phone_entry* entries, int num_entries) 107 { 108 unsigned count; 109 /* document our assumption that the array has already been 110 * processed already 111 */ 112 assert(num_entries=0); 113 /* print out each entry */ 114 for(count = 0; count < (unsigned)num_entries; ++count) 115 { 116 printf("%s\t%s\t%s", entries[count].fname, entries[count].lname, 117 entries[count].number); 118 } 119 }




35.2.8    List of the "Approved" Bugs; Marking Guide of RMIT



/home/el9/E70949/debugging_exercise/solutions/lab3/solution.txt

1 fsupport.h:13 2 #define NUMARGS 0 3 should be 4 #define NUMARGS 2 5 6 phonebk_strok.c:45 7 unsigned entrycount; - entrycount is not initialized before use. 8 should be: 9 unsigned entrycount = 0; - we start with an empty phonebook. 10 11 phonebk_strtok.c:63 12 strcpy(line, linecpy); 13 should be: 14 strcpy(linecpy, line); 15 16 phonebk_strtok.c:50 17 each of fname, lname and number should have a +1 for the nul terminator 18 19 phonebk_strok.c:59 20 line[strlen(line)-1]=0; this is fine but before we do that we need to 21 check for the newline in the file, so: 22 solution: 23 if(line[strlen(line)-1] !='\n') /*error*/ return EOF ; 24 line[strlen(line)-1]=0; 25 26 phonebk_strtok.c:110 27 assert(num_entries=0); 28 should be: 29 assert(num_entries > 0); - there should be some entries in the phone 30 book. 31 32 phonebk_strtok.c:29 33 if(result > 0) 34 should be: 35 if(result <= 0) - if we failed to load data from the file 36 37 phonebk_strtok.c:26 38 fpRead = gropen(*argv); 39 should be: 40 fpRead = gropen(argv[FILE_INDEX]); and #define FILE_INDEX 1 elsewhere. 41 It would also be acceptable for simply write 1 and not have a #define 42 for the purposes of this debugging exercise. 43 44 fsupport.h: 45 #define MAXWIDTH 1 - this shoudl be the length of a line in the file 46 should be 47 #define MAXWIDTH 80 - allow a line of 80 characters to be read in. 48 49 phonebk_strtok.c:67 50 while(!token) 51 should be: 52 while (token) or while (token != NULL) 53 54 phone.h:10 55 #define delim "|" 56 should be: 57 #define delim "," 58 59 phonebk_strtok.c: 66 and 89: 60 token = strtok(line, delim); 61 should be: 62 token = strtok(linecpy, delim); 63 64 phonebk_strtok.c:89 65 token = strtok(line, delim); 66 should be: 67 token = strtok(NULL, delim); 68 69 phonebk_strtok.c:114 70 printf("%s\t%s\t%s", entries[count].fname, entries[count].lname, 71 entries[count].number); 72 should be: 73 printf("%s\t%s\t%s\n", entries[count].fname, entries[count].lname, 74 entries[count].number); 75 76 phonebk_strtok.c: 77 exit from main() without closing the FILE pointer. 78 solution: 79 fclose(fpRead);




35.2.9    Research Paper by RMIT Regarding This Assignment



Following is an extract of RMIT's research paper (July 2016) regarding this assignment.

Additionally, the students in the trial session were tasked with articulating their debugging processes into a Google form. While this prompted them to express and reflect on the steps they took and their successes/non-successes, it also allowed the researchers an additional view into their knowledge and skills. “There can be no truthful reporting or effective changes to teaching in the absence of faithful diagnosis of students’ understandings” (Ramsden, 2003, p. 205). This articulation part of the assessment was initially proposed as both a data collection tool and a trial grading method but was determined to be a useful innovation that in the future should aid teaching staff to determine student understanding. It also actually helped to ensure authenticity of the assessment by enabling explicit demonstration of effective performance with new knowledge (Herrington et al, 2014). Indeed, this articulation component was implemented into classroom practice in the third phase of the action research. HERDSA volume 39 (2016), page 220




35.3    Recycling Assignments



RMIT states in Assessment Processes that:

"Exams and assessment tasks must be materially different from any assessment task in the course in previous teaching periods across locations (over a two-year period) unless restricted by requirements for specific competencies for reasons of accreditation or safety." Chapter 1, Design of Assessment, section 1.1




However, RMIT recycled this (same) assignment on each study period (of the last decade).

Clearly, this assignment was an exception.

And because so many students took this assignment over the years, RMIT narrated in its tutorial (Group A, Week 6, 31/12/2020 at 19:30 at 47:42 timestamp) that "every single bug that I have injected, some student has found it at some point".


Curiously, when one of those bugs was (re-)submitted by this student, RMIT decided, all of a sudden, that "the marker does not agree with the student".

Without explaining why he "does not agree with the student."

Clearly, RMIT did not read it before they decided to give me zero marks.







Chapter 36
— Assignment 2(A)
— strcpy() Bug





36.1    Order of Arguments to strcpy()



The C standard library provides functions to copy data from one place (hereinafter, "source") to another (hereinafter, "destination").


Among those functions, you can find:

  • memcpy() — to copy memory.
  • memmove() — to copy ("move") between (overlapping) memory areas.
  • strcpy() — to copy strings (i.e. NULL-terminated sequence of characters).



These functions are standardized by ANSI C.

4.11.2 Copying functions

4.11.2.1 The memcpy function Synopsis #include <string.h> void *memcpy(void *s1, const void *s2, size_t n); Description The memcpy function copies n characters from the object pointed to by s2 into the object pointed to by s1 . If copying takes place between objects that overlap, the behavior is undefined. Returns The memcpy function returns the value of s1 . 4.11.2.2 The memmove function Synopsis #include <string.h> void *memmove(void *s1, const void *s2, size_t n); Description The memmove function copies n characters from the object pointed to by s2 into the object pointed to by s1 . Copying takes place as if the n characters from the object pointed to by s2 are first copied into a temporary array of n characters that does not overlap the objects pointed to by s1 and s2, and then the n characters from the temporary array are copied into the object pointed to by s1 . Returns The memmove function returns the value of s1 . 4.11.2.3 The strcpy function Synopsis #include <string.h> char *strcpy(char *s1, const char *s2); Description The strcpy function copies the string pointed to by s2 (including the terminating null character) into the array pointed to by s1 . If copying takes place between objects that overlap, the behavior is undefined. Returns The strcpy function returns the value of s1 . ANSI C (89) "Programming Language C" (X3.159-1989)




Now, there is a consistent pattern here.

Namely, they all have the destination as the first argument and the source as the second argument.

Right?



kkk


Compare:

strcpy(destination, source) ✔


To this:

strcpy(source, destination) ✘



It is not rocket science to conclude that doing the opposite will get you opposite results.

Namely, if you interchange their order (and place the source as the first parameter and the destination as the second parameter), the program will copy in the opposite direction and clobber the source with data from the destination and, in all likelihood, will set off a disastrous ripple-effect, reducing your program to garbage.


This is no different than turning left at a road junction, while the direction-sign points to the right.

No matter how hard you try and keep driving after the wrong turn, you will never reach your destination in the opposite direction.


36.2    Bug Submitted by Student



As noted, students had to find at least five bugs in a program.

The program (and its intentional bugs) was written by the Unit Coordinator, specifically, for this debugging assignment.


36.2.1    The strcpy() Bug



One of the bugs was in the following line.


/home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/debugginglabs/lab3/phonebk_strtok.c

65 strcpy(line, linecpy);




Here the program tried to copy from a source ('line') to a destination ('linecpy').

Notice, however, the (incorrect) order of the arguments (namely, the source followed by the destination).


Like other students, I immediately jumped on that bug and included it in my report.


36.2.2    Bug Is Listed as an "Approved" Bug



This bug is listed as an "approved" bug in the marking guide for this assignment.


36.2.3    Bug Submission Supported by Quoted Documentation



In my report, I quoted the prototype from the manual, which this program violated.


36.2.4    GDB Analysis in My Submission



Firing up GDB, I put a breakpoint right before the following line of code:

65 strcpy(line, linecpy);




I showed how the memory area of line contained reasonable data when the program reached this breakpoint.

The data was a line of text that had just been read from the input-file.

Then, I showed that as soon as the next line of code was executed, the memory area of line was clobbered and overwritten with garbage data (erroneously copied-in from linecpy).


36.2.5    Detailed Explanation in My Submission



I then concluded that because the arguments were written in the opposite direction, the program followed-suit.

Namely, instead of copying from line to linecpy, it had done the opposite.

As a result, the memory area of line was overwritten with garbage data copied from the uninitialized linecpy automatic variable.


36.2.6    Bug Fix Provided in My Submission



I then suggested a fix.

As expected, it consisted of a rewrite of the line by ordering the arguments in the opposite direction.

Written in Unix diff convention, it reads:

Bug 4 submission for assignment 2(A) Submitted on Sunday 12/01/2020 at 16:21

16 – strcpy(line, linecpy); 17 + strcpy(linecpy, line);




36.2.7    Submission Date and Unreasonable Delay in Feedback



The assignment was sent on Sunday 12/01/2020 at 16:21.

56 days later, on Sunday 08/03/2020 at 22:55 (a couple of weeks after the end of the study period), I finally got the feedback for that assignment.

The score was: 0% marks.


36.3    RMIT's Vacuous Feedback



36.3.1    Meaningless Statements



The following is the feedback sent by RMIT "explaining" the 0% marks.

Bug 4 Feedback – sent on Sunday 08/03/2020 at 22:55

1 Identification: Your marker does not agree that this was a bug in the 2 original source code 3 4 Fix: This is not a correct fix for the bug 5 6 Write-up: Incorrect write-up of the bug report 7 8 Marks: 0 9 10 It is not a problem/bug with the program




As you see, a lot of words ("your marker does not agree" blah blah...) without saying anything of substance.

Infuriating, but typical of any correspondence with RMIT, including the office of Deputy Vice-Chancellor Prof. Aleksandar Subic.


I provided a clue for this fiasco in a previous chapter.


36.3.2    Contradictory Statements



Notice, however, the (maddening) absurdity of their "feedback".

RMIT provided me with 3 contradictory statements explaining the 0% marks.

Namely:

  • First, they claim that it was not a bug.
  • Then, they admit that it was a bug, but the fix was not good enough.
  • Then, they claim that it was all good, but the write-up was incorrect.



Again, I've discussed this deep-rooted corruption of RMIT in a previous chapter.


36.4    Appeal Process



I had to wait for the release of the final results on Monday 04/05/2020 at 08:46 before I was allowed to appeal my results.

This was 113 days after its submission (on Sunday 12/01/2020 at 16:21).


36.4.1    Formal Appeal



On Monday 04/05/2020 at 11:54 (3 hours and 8 minutes after I was given permission to appeal), I wrote in full detail why I was incorrectly marked for this assignment.

In that email, I quoted the standard (ANSI C), my assignment, the marks I was given, and then showed where the school was wrong.


On Friday 15/05/2020 at 19:13, I wrote again and provided exact details where the "feedback" was false.

This email was confirmed by the office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic on Tuesday 19/05/2020 at 16:31, saying, they "can confirm that your email [...] of Friday 15 May 2020, at 7:13 pm was received."


36.4.2    Request for Documents Rejected



On Wed 13/05/2020 17:20 and Wed 13/05/2020 17:23 and Friday 15/05/2020 at 19:13, I requested the school for a copy of my submission for this assignment.

Students submitted the assignment through an online Google Form.

However, they were not provided a copy except for a corrupted and indecipherable confirmation.


Alarmingly, RMIT refused to release my very own assignment.

Can you smell the corruption?

They "allow" you to appeal but withhold the crucial evidence at all costs.

On Friday 05/06/2020 at 17:13, the office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic told me that they "can confirm" that my appeal got rejected.

They did not explain why but added that I wouldn't be allowed to appeal and that a third-party review would be denied.


36.4.4    Appeal to the Associate Dean



Reaching a roadblock, I sought the help of the Associate Dean and Discipline Head of Computer Science and IT on Saturday 06/06/2020 at 12:12 (and the following days).

I reminded him of my previous email I sent him on Monday 04/05/2020 at 11:54 (discussing this very issue), and how it was clear (in that email) that the school was wrong.


The following is my email to the Associate Dean on Saturday 06/06/2020 at 12:12:

My email to you [...] on the 4th of MAY 2020, at 11:54 was very specific.

  • I quoted the full assignment.
  • I have submitted the "feedback" where I was told that bug 4 that I reported was not considered a bug by the marker.
  • Further, the feedback does little to clarify why, other than "It is not a problem/bug with the program".


The email, I received yesterday, [...] found my appeal as false.

So, for how long will the school keep lying [...]

Please read the following short description,

and for a full report, please read the original email sent to you on the 4th of may.

I was asked in assignment 2 part 1 to fix 4 bugs in the program.

I reported the following line:

  • strcpy(line, linecpy)


I fixed it to:

  • strcpy(linecpy, line)


This is in accordance with the ANSI C, the following is a quote from the standard.

  • 4.11.2.3 The strcpy function

    Synopsis

    #include <string.h> char *strcpy(char *s1, const char *s2);

    Description

    The strcpy function copies the string pointed to by s2 (including the terminating null character) into the array pointed to by s1 . If copying takes place between objects that overlap, the behavior is undefined.

    Returns The strcpy function returns the value of s1



36.4.5    Ignored by the Associate Dean



To this day, I am still waiting for his confirmation to any of the emails.

Nor would he bother to confirm any of my following emails regarding theft and racism.


36.4.6    Illegal Retaliation by RMIT



However, I was told on Wednesday 10/06/2020 at 18:01 that the office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic found my request for help from another academic to be disrespectful to his office and, to exact revenge on the student, ordered my suspension from RMIT.

This is RMIT in a nutshell.


36.5    Bug 4 Submission



Assignment 2(A) bug 4 fix; submitted by student on Sunday 12/01/2020 at 16:21

1 What were the incorrect line(s) of code? 2 3 enter the incorrect line(s) of source code (you can describe the bug in words too) - 4 please include the filename(s) and line number(s) that were the cause of the problem, 5 as well as the actual code. 6 7 debugginglabs/lab3/phonebk_strtok.c:66 strcpy(line, linecpy); 8 9 10 What source code have your replaced the buggy line(s) with – include filename and linenumber for these. 11 12 you may also describe the changes you made in words but your explanation needs to be 13 in sufficient detail that another programmer could follow your remarks and repeat your 14 fixes. 15 16 – strcpy(line, linecpy); 17 + strcpy(linecpy, line); 18 19 20 What tools did you use to help you fix this bug? 21 You may not have used a tool and if there is nothing appropriate you may skip this question. 22 23 To get marks for tool use, compiler warnings and errors will not be considered 24 but they will inform us of your overall strategy to fix the problem. 25 26 ☒ GDB 27 ☐ Valgrind 28 ☐ Compiler warning 29 ☐ Compiler error 30 ☐ Libsanatize 31 ☐ Other 32 33 34 35 Using dot points, outline briefly the steps you took to solve this problem. 36 37 38 We have at: /src/debug/debugginglabs /lab3/phonebk_strtok.c:65 39 40 strcpy(line, linecpy); 41 42 43 $ make debug && gdb -q ./phonebk 44 45 Reading symbols from ./phonebk...done. 46 47 (gdb) break 65 48 Breakpoint 1 at 0xb9e: file phonebk_strtok.c, line 65. 49 50 (gdb) run /tmp/input 51 Starting program: debugginglabs/lab3/phonebk /tmp/input 52 53 Breakpoint 1, load (entries=0x7fffffffe080, fpRead=0x555555757260) at phonebk_strtok.c:65 54 65 strcpy(line, linecpy); 55 56 57 (gdb) x/s line 58 0x7fffffffdff2: "John Smith 0238067106" 59 60 (gdb) next 61 68 token = strtok(line, delim); 62 63 (gdb) x/s line 64 0x7fffffffdff2: "n Smith 0237167106" 65 66 67 Clearly, the @line variable has assumed a very suspicious value. 68 69 man strcpy, reads: 70 71 char *strcpy(char *dest, const char *src); 72 73 and we had above (on line 54): 74 char linecpy[MAXWIDTH+EXTRASPACES]; 75 76 Thus, @linecpy, residing on the stack (an "automatic" variable), was 77 still not initialized ("garbage" memory). 78 79 So, it wouldn't make sense to override the @line array, that was 80 just populated from gfets() with garbage data. 81 82 Obviously, as the name @linecpy suggests, and from tracking 83 these two variables (@line and @linecpy), later in the program, 84 it should have been the opposite, like: 85 86 strcpy(linecpy, line);









Chapter 37
— Assignment 2(A)
— Bonus Mark





37.1    Summary



RMIT are criminals.

In their response on Wednesday 10/06/2020 at 18:01, they did not dispute my claim that I had fully documented 5 bugs as required.

However, they:

  • Refused to apologize for the false grade; no remorse or explanation was conveyed to the student.
  • Refused (to this day) to restore the bonus mark for a submission of 5 bugs.



37.2    Talking to a Brick Wall



Have you ever wondered how it feels talking to a brick wall?

Then, come to RMIT.

Reluctantly, you will gain a lot of experience.


It goes like this.

You enrol at RMIT.

For this privilege, you are forced to pay, in advance, the full (overpriced) tuition fees.

OK.


Then, you are given an assignment.

You work hard.

You submit (on time) a correct solution.

OK.


RMIT delays its grading for 56 days.

Then, after 56 days (and weeks after the end of the study period), you get zero marks.

Why?

"Your marker does not agree with the student."

Which says nothing.


In order to appeal, RMIT forces you to wait 113 days before you are allowed to appeal.

You appeal immediately.

Namely, 3 hours and 8 minutes after they gave you the green light.

In your appeal, you go into details and prove your case.

You show how you are owed a bonus mark for a successful write-up of five bugs.


On Friday 05/06/2020 at 17:13, you are told by the office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic that your appeal got rejected.

No explanation or details are provided

But they tell you that they "can confirm" the above.

Then they add that the decision is final and a third-party review is denied.

When you appeal to the State Ombudsman and the State Commission, you get a reply — after an excruciating delay of 42 days — that the university is "not responding" and there is nothing in the law to "force" their hand.


You see, when in RMIT, you are talking to a brick wall.

RMIT's walls may be shining marble or exquisite glass, but those (fancy) walls are, equally, not responding.

Nor would anyone of their Academic Board even bother to acknowledge your emails.

38.3.1    Bug 2 Submission



Assignment 2(A) bug 2 fix; submitted by student on Sunday 12/01/2020 at 16:21

1 What were the incorrect line(s) of code? 2 3 enter the incorrect line(s) of source code (you can describe the bug in words too) - 4 please include the filename(s) and line number(s) that were the cause of the problem, 5 as well as the actual code. 6 7 8 debugginglabs/lab3/phonebk_strtok.c:70 while(token == NULL) 9 10 11 What source code have your replaced the buggy line(s) with – include filename 12 and linenumber for these. 13 14 you may also describe the changes you made in words but your explanation needs to be 15 in sufficient detail that another programmer could follow your remarks and repeat your 16 fixes. 17 18 – while(token == NULL) 19 + while(token != NULL) 20 21 22 What tools did you use to help you fix this bug? 23 You may not have used a tool and if there is nothing appropriate you may skip this question. 24 25 To get marks for tool use, compiler warnings and errors will not be considered 26 but they will inform us of your overall strategy to fix the problem. 27 28 ☐ GDB 29 ☐ Valgrind 30 ☐ Compiler warning 31 ☐ Compiler error 32 ☒ Libsanatize 33 ☐ Other 34 35 36 37 Using dot points, outline briefly the steps you took to solve this problem. 38 39 40 $ make sanitize && ./phonebk 41 42 43 ASAN:DEADLYSIGNAL 44 =================================================================== 45 ==11395==ERROR: AddressSanitizer: SEGV on unknown address 0x000000000000 46 (pc 0x7ff8ce1e7646 bp 0x7ffdf6ac4d90 sp 0x7ffdf6ac44f8 T0) 47 ==11395==The signal is caused by a READ memory access. 48 ==11395==Hint: address points to the zero page. 49 50 #0 0x7ff8ce1e7645 (/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6+0xb1645) 51 #1 0x7ff8ce58cff5 (/usr/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libasan.so.4+0x65ff5) 52 #2 0x55eaccf487d4 in load (/src/debug/debugginglabs/lab3/phonebk_strtok.c:78) 53 #3 0x55eaccf48446 in main (/src/debug/debugginglabs/lab3/phonebk_strtok.c:29) 54 #4 0x7ff8ce157b96 in __libc_start_main (/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6+0x21b96) 55 #5 0x55eaccf48139 in _start (/src/debug/debugginglabs/lab3/phonebk+0x1139) 56 57 AddressSanitizer can not provide additional info. 58 SUMMARY: AddressSanitizer: SEGV (/lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6+0xb1645) 59 60 ==11395==ABORTING 61 62 63 So, from the line above: 64 #2 0x55eaccf487d4 in load (/src/debug/debugginglabs/lab3/phonebk_strtok.c:78) 65 66 And the line: 67 ==11395==ERROR: AddressSanitizer: SEGV on unknown address 0x000000000000 68 (pc 0x7ff8ce1e7646 bp 0x7ffdf6ac4d90 sp 0x7ffdf6ac44f8 T0) 69 70 It clearly shows that we tried to access a NULL address, from line 78. 71 72 Line 78 reads: 73 strcpy(fname, token); 74 75 Meaning, that either: 76 1) @fname is NULL 77 2) @token is NULL 78 79 Now, for 1) @fname, fname is defined (in line 53), as: 80 char fname[NAMELEN], lname[NAMELEN], number[PHONELEN]; 81 82 Thus, @fanme resides on the stack. 83 84 And from the output above: 85 ==11395==ERROR: AddressSanitizer: SEGV on unknown address 0x000000000000 86 (pc 0x7ff8ce1e7646 bp 0x7ffdf6ac4d90 sp 0x7ffdf6ac44f8 T0) 87 88 We see that: 89 1) %rbp is: 0x7ffdf6ac4d90 90 2) %rsp is: 0x7ffdf6ac44f8 91 92 So, the @fname, residing in the stack between %rsp and %rbp, is clearly not NULL. 93 94 95 @token, on the other hand, is define (in line 55): 96 char * token; 97 98 And actually, on line 70, we have: 99 100 while(token == NULL) 101 102 Where, it should had read: 103 104 while(token != NULL)









Chapter 39
— Assignment 2(B & C)
— Text Editor Development





Note: This chapter is an introduction to the following 14 chapters.



39.1    Summary



The second assignment was to develop a (limited) text editor.

To assist the students, RMIT presented its own text editor, which was developed by its staff.

It was called 'cpt220_ed' ('cpt220' is the course ID, while 'ed' references the ed editor discussed later).

Source code for this program was not provided, as students had to develop their own code to mimic its operation.


39.2    Overview



39.2.1    cpt220_ed VS ed Regarding Line-Addresses



Much of the semantics and the work-flow of the editor were in the tradition of the classic ed text editor.

However, there were a few (notable) differences in the syntax for the commands, including the following:

  • In ed, line-addresses precede the command, like: '1,100p'.

    In cpt220_ed, however, the command precedes the line-addresses, like: 'p1-100'.

    Other than this difference, both do the same thing, i.e. print all the lines in the range of [1,100].
  • In ed, line-addresses have the following syntax: '1,100', I.e. a comma separates the two line-addresses (namely, the first & last lines of the command).

    In cpt220_ed, however, a '-' (dash) separates the two numbers. Example: '1-100'.
  • ed allows arithmetic operators, '$', ';', and regex for line-addressing.

    None of the above exist in cpt220_ed.
  • 4. In ed, there is a concept of a current address, and commands, by default, operate only on the current line.

    cpt220_ed, however, has no such concept, and commands by default (i.e. without any line specifier) operate on all the lines.



39.2.2    cpt220_ed VS ed Regarding Command Letters



In addition, ed and cpt220_ed use different command letters for the following three operations.

  • 'e(dit)' is used in ed, while 'l(oad)' is used in cpt220_ed.
  • 'w(write)' is used in ed, while 's(ave)' is used in cpt220_ed.
  • 's(ubstitute)' is used in ed, while 'r(eplace)' is used in cpt220_ed.



39.3    Summary of cpt220_ed Commands



A quick comparison between ed and cpt220_ed regarding: commands, line-addresses, etc.

ed cpt220_ed Compatibility
help h ? In ed, the help ('h') command prints an "explanation of the last error".


In cpt220_ed, the help ('?') command lists the available commands.

Further info can be obtained with '?[command]', like: '?insert'.


Section Help Feature discusses bugs.
load e(dit)
r(ead)		 l(oad)
  • Before Jan 26, 2020 18:17, cpt220_ed mimicked the read command.
  • After Jan 26, 2020 18:17, cpt220_ed mimicked the edit command.
Jan 26, 2020 18:17 was 2+ hours before the deadline for assignment 2(B).


Section Load Feature discusses bugs.
insert i(nsert)
a(ppend)		 i(nsert) in ed, insert puts the added text before the line-address, which must be a number less than or equal to the line-count of the file.

The append command puts the added text after the line-address, which must be a number less than or equal to the line-count of the file.

You can also insert or append using the '0' line-address ('0i' or '0a').

However, '1i' is invalid for an empty file in ed.


In cpt220_ed, the insert command puts the added text before the line-address, which must be a number less than or equal to one more of the line-count of the file.

Using 'i0' for an empty-file, however, is sketchy. At first, cpt220_ed "accepts" this command. However, it seg-faults on the first line of input from the input-prompt.


In cpt220_ed, you can, however, use 'i1' for an empty file to insert its first line(s).

And, for example, 'i4' is legal (in cpt220_ed) for a file of only three lines (which has the same effect as '3a' in ed).

Both of the above are illegal in ed.


In ed, the input-mode is terminated by a line consisting of a single period ('.').

In cpt220_ed, the input-mode is terminated only by EOF.

Meaning, no command (not even quit) can follow insert in batch mode.

(Furthermore, it is impossible to exit (in batch-mode) after an insert command, as cpt220_ed does not exit on EOF).

Consequently, it was virtually impossible to test the insert command from a batch file.


Section Insert Feature discusses bugs.
delete d(elete) d(elete) Valid line-addresses in ed (for delete) must be a number > 0 and not larger than the current line-count of the file.

Line '0' is NOT valid for this command in ed.


As a bug in cpt220_ed, the first line-address (or the single address used as the only line-address) must be a number < line-count of the file.

Line '0' (in cpt220_ed) is a valid line-address interpreted as: '1'; however, there is a twist; see later.

line-addressing for delete has many inconsistencies, including:

  • '0-0' deletes line 1.
  • '0-1' deletes lines 1-2.
  • '1-1' deletes line 1 (valid only if line-count > 1).
  • '0-2' deletes lines 1-3.
  • '1-2' deletes lines 1-2.
  • '1-1' is NOT valid for a file with a line-count < 2.
  • '2-2' is NOT valid for a file with a line-count < 3.


In other words, there is no way to delete only the last line. Unless the file has only 1 line, and you do: 'd0', 'd0-0', 'd0-1', 'd0-2', and so forth.

The delete command by itself without a line-address (namely: 'd') is invalid for a file w/ a line-count < 2.

For more of this madness, read the table below.


Section Delete Feature discusses bugs.
search / In ed, '/' is a line-addressing operator.

However, in cpt220_ed there is neither regex nor line-addressing using search-patterns.


In cpt220_ed, this command is very similar to ed's global command (1,$)g/re/command-list.

Except that: 1) There is no line-addressing for this command; it operates on all the lines. 2) No regex. (Namely, only basic text search). 3) The command-list is always the print command.
replace s(ubstitute) r(eplace) Unlike ed, there is no line-addressing for this command; It operates on all the lines.

As noted, cpt220_ed does not support regex.


This feature is horribly broken in cpt220_ed.

Compare:

  • r/foo// # Seg-fault!
  • r/foo//g # Replaces only first 'foo' (despite 'g' flag).
  • r/foo//z # Replaces the first 'foo' with 'z' (not the empty string).
  • r/foo/g/? # Replaces every 'foo' with the empty string (not 'g').
  • r/foo/g/r # Replaces every 'foo' with the empty string (not 'g').
  • r/foo/g/g # Replaces every 'foo' with the empty string (not 'g').
  • r/g/g/ # Replaces only first 'g' with the empty string (not 'g').
  • r/g/g/g # Replaces every 'g' with the empty string (not 'g').
  • r/g/g/? # Replaces every 'g' with the empty string (not 'g').


Section Replace Feature discusses bugs.
print p(rint) p(rint)
throw t(hrow) Not available in ed.


Section Throw Feature discusses bugs.
save w(rite) s(ave) Section Save Feature discusses bugs.
quit q(uit) q(uit) cpt220_ed has a 'qw [filename]' variant of this command, which is interpreted as 'q(uit)' after 'w(rite)' to (optinal) filename.


Section Quit Feature discusses bugs.


39.4    help Feature



The help ('?') command outputs the available commands.

Note, however, the unprintable characters at the end of the output.


The output of the '?' (help) command in cpt220_ed

# This is the very binary released by RMIT. $ readelf -a /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed \ | grep 'Build ID' Build ID: 0f27b56d6523065e799b430313e3035c6b64b786 # '/tmp/input' is a batch file containing the commands for 'cpt220_ed'. # It contains 2 commands: # 1. '?', the help command. # 2. 'q', the q(uit) command. $ cat /tmp/input ? q # Run cpt220_ed. # The editor outputs (for the help command) the list of all available commands. # Note, however, the unprintable characters at its end. $ /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed </tmp/input > help ---- The following commands are available: help, load, insert, delete, search, replace, print, throw, save, quit, (­û,  ­û,  ­û, You may get further details on any command by typing ? followed by the command name.




Students were testing compliance by comparing their output with RMIT's one.

To that end, students were forced to artificially add the unprintable garbage (shown above) to their own output in order to achieve a successful match.

Ouch!


So, what was the culprit for this madness?


Inspecting the binary, we find the help_help() function.

help_help() traverses the help_strings[] array

000000000040146c <help_help>: 40146c: 55 push %rbp 40146d: 48 89 e5 mov %rsp,%rbp 401470: 48 83 ec 20 sub $0x20,%rsp 401474: 48 c7 45 e8 58 3c 40 00 movq $0x403c58,-0x18(%rbp) 40147c: 48 8b 45 e8 mov -0x18(%rbp),%rax 401480: 48 89 c7 mov %rax,%rdi 401483: e8 48 f7 ff ff callq 400bd0 <puts@plt> 401488: c7 45 f4 00 00 00 00 movl $0x0,-0xc(%rbp) 40148f: eb 0e jmp 40149f <help_help+0x33> 401491: bf 2d 00 00 00 mov $0x2d,%edi 401496: e8 f5 f6 ff ff callq 400b90 <putchar@plt> 40149b: 83 45 f4 01 addl $0x1,-0xc(%rbp) 40149f: 48 8b 45 e8 mov -0x18(%rbp),%rax 4014a3: 48 89 c7 mov %rax,%rdi 4014a6: e8 45 f7 ff ff callq 400bf0 <strlen@plt> 4014ab: 3b 45 f4 cmp -0xc(%rbp),%eax 4014ae: 7f e1 jg 401491 <help_help+0x25> 4014b0: bf 0a 00 00 00 mov $0xa,%edi 4014b5: e8 d6 f6 ff ff callq 400b90 <putchar@plt> 4014ba: bf 98 3c 40 00 mov $0x403c98,%edi 4014bf: e8 0c f7 ff ff callq 400bd0 <puts@plt> 4014c4: 48 c7 45 f8 40 61 60 00 movq $0x606140,-0x8(%rbp) 4014cc: eb 1e jmp 4014ec <help_help+0x80> 4014ce: 48 8b 45 f8 mov -0x8(%rbp),%rax 4014d2: 48 8b 00 mov (%rax),%rax 4014d5: 48 89 c6 mov %rax,%rsi 4014d8: bf bf 3c 40 00 mov $0x403cbf,%edi 4014dd: b8 00 00 00 00 mov $0x0,%eax 4014e2: e8 29 f7 ff ff callq 400c10 <printf@plt> 4014e7: 48 83 45 f8 08 addq $0x8,-0x8(%rbp) 4014ec: 48 8b 45 f8 mov -0x8(%rbp),%rax 4014f0: 48 8b 00 mov (%rax),%rax 4014f3: 48 85 c0 test %rax,%rax 4014f6: 75 d6 jne 4014ce <help_help+0x62> 4014f8: bf 08 00 00 00 mov $0x8,%edi 4014fd: e8 8e f6 ff ff callq 400b90 <putchar@plt> 401502: bf 20 00 00 00 mov $0x20,%edi 401507: e8 84 f6 ff ff callq 400b90 <putchar@plt> 40150c: bf 0a 00 00 00 mov $0xa,%edi 401511: e8 7a f6 ff ff callq 400b90 <putchar@plt> 401516: bf 0a 00 00 00 mov $0xa,%edi 40151b: e8 70 f6 ff ff callq 400b90 <putchar@plt> 401520: bf c8 3c 40 00 mov $0x403cc8,%edi 401525: e8 a6 f6 ff ff callq 400bd0 <puts@plt> 40152a: c9 leaveq 40152b: c3 retq




That function iterates over the help_strings array, which is an array of 10 pointers (char *) to the following strings:

  1. [0x606140] 0x403c58: "help"
  2. [0x606148] 0x403c5d: "load"
  3. [0x606150] 0x403c62: "insert"
  4. [0x606158] 0x403c69: "delete"
  5. [0x606160] 0x403c70: "search"
  6. [0x606168] 0x403c77: "replace"
  7. [0x606170] 0x403c7f: "print"
  8. [0x606178] 0x403c85: "throw"
  9. [0x606180] 0x403c8b: "save"
  10. [0x606188] 0x403c90: "quit"



Now, in order to iterate properly over an array-list of valid pointers, one expects a (terminating) sentinel NULL value at the end in order to break out of the loop.

Right?


Actually, I can summarize the bug in 2 lines.

  1. The array-list (help_strings) was not terminated by a NULL sentinel.
  2. Thus, when help_help() traverses the help_strings array, it exceeds the boundary and reads out-of-bound memory slots (which explain the garbage shown above).



As noted, the help_strings array has 10 quadwords, namely, 10 pointers to the commands' strings quoted above.

help_strings resides in 0x606140.

Right after help_string (starting at 0x606190) is the BSS section.

Its first three quadwords are the three FILE pointers:

  1. stdout.
  2. stdin.
  3. stderr.



Although zeroed at compile-time, those FILE pointers are assigned valid (non-NULL) values (by libc code) at runtime.


As noted, there was no sentinel boundary separating help_strings from the BSS section.

The function help_help(), which iterates over help_strings, looks for a terminating NULL value in order to break out of the loop.

As no NULL is found right after help_strings, help_help() exceeds its boundaries and reads out-of-bound memory (namely, the FILE pointers), which it prints out as if they were legitimate strings.


Demonstrating the unprintable output from the 'help' command

# This is the very binary released by RMIT. $ readelf -a /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed \ | grep 'Build ID' Build ID: 0f27b56d6523065e799b430313e3035c6b64b786 # '/tmp/input' is a batch file containing the commands for 'cpt220_ed'. # It contains 2 commands: # 1. '?', the help command. # 2. 'q', the q(uit) command. $ cat /tmp/input ? q # Run cpt220_ed from within gdb. $ gdb -q /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed Reading symbols from /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed...(no debugging symbols found)...done. # help_help() at 0x4014e2 calls printf(format, help_strings[i]). (gdb) break *0x4014e2 Breakpoint 1 at 0x4014e2 (gdb) run </tmp/input Starting program: /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed </tmp/input > help ---- The following commands are available: Breakpoint 1, 0x00000000004014e2 in help_help () # Shows how help_strings[] (and its 10 valid pointers) butts against the start of the .bss section. # Note the missing sentinel (of a NULL value) to indicate the boundary. (gdb) x/gx &help_strings 0x606140 <help_strings>: 0x0000000000403c58 (gdb) x 0x606148 <help_strings+8>: 0x0000000000403c5d (gdb) x 0x606150 <help_strings+16>: 0x0000000000403c62 (gdb) x 0x606158 <help_strings+24>: 0x0000000000403c69 (gdb) x 0x606160 <help_strings+32>: 0x0000000000403c70 (gdb) x 0x606168 <help_strings+40>: 0x0000000000403c77 (gdb) x 0x606170 <help_strings+48>: 0x0000000000403c7f (gdb) x 0x606178 <help_strings+56>: 0x0000000000403c85 (gdb) x 0x606180 <help_strings+64>: 0x0000000000403c8b (gdb) x 0x606188 <help_strings+72>: 0x0000000000403c90 (gdb) x 0x606190 <stdout@@GLIBC_2.2.5>: 0x00007ffff7dd0760 (gdb) x 0x606198 <stdin@@GLIBC_2.2.5>: 0x00007ffff7dcfa00 (gdb) x 0x6061a0 <stderr@@GLIBC_2.2.5>: 0x00007ffff7dd0680 (gdb) x 0x6061a8 <completed.6355>: 0x0000000000000000 # The 10 (consecutive) read-only strings (for the help command). # help_strings[] is initialized (at compile-time) with these values. (gdb) x/s 0x403c58 0x403c58: "help" (gdb) x 0x403c5d: "load" (gdb) x 0x403c62: "insert" (gdb) x 0x403c69: "delete" (gdb) x 0x403c70: "search" (gdb) x 0x403c77: "replace" (gdb) x 0x403c7f: "print" (gdb) x 0x403c85: "throw" (gdb) x 0x403c8b: "save" (gdb) x 0x403c90: "quit" # help_help() calls printf(format, help_strings[i]) at least 13 times. # The second argument to printf (i.e. %rsi) is either a command's string or a FILE pointer misidentified as a string. # The 13 times consist of: # 1. The 10 pointers from help_strings[]. # 2. Then, out-of-bound memory slots from the adjacent BSS section (namely, # stdout, stdin, stderr) misidentified as string pointers. (gdb) display/s $rsi 1: x/s $rsi 0x403c58: "help" (gdb) continue Continuing. Breakpoint 1, 0x00000000004014e2 in help_help () 1: x/s $rsi 0x403c5d: "load" (gdb) continue Continuing. Breakpoint 1, 0x00000000004014e2 in help_help () 1: x/s $rsi 0x403c62: "insert" (gdb) continue Continuing. Breakpoint 1, 0x00000000004014e2 in help_help () 1: x/s $rsi 0x403c69: "delete" (gdb) continue Continuing. Breakpoint 1, 0x00000000004014e2 in help_help () 1: x/s $rsi 0x403c70: "search" (gdb) continue Continuing. Breakpoint 1, 0x00000000004014e2 in help_help () 1: x/s $rsi 0x403c77: "replace" (gdb) continue Continuing. Breakpoint 1, 0x00000000004014e2 in help_help () 1: x/s $rsi 0x403c7f: "print" (gdb) continue Continuing. Breakpoint 1, 0x00000000004014e2 in help_help () 1: x/s $rsi 0x403c85: "throw" (gdb) continue Continuing. Breakpoint 1, 0x00000000004014e2 in help_help () 1: x/s $rsi 0x403c8b: "save" (gdb) continue Continuing. Breakpoint 1, 0x00000000004014e2 in help_help () 1: x/s $rsi 0x403c90: "quit" (gdb) continue Continuing. Breakpoint 1, 0x00000000004014e2 in help_help () 1: x/s $rsi 0x7ffff7dd0760 <_IO_2_1_stdout_>: "\204(\255\373" (gdb) continue Continuing. Breakpoint 1, 0x00000000004014e2 in help_help () 1: x/s $rsi 0x7ffff7dcfa00 <_IO_2_1_stdin_>: "\210 \255\373" (gdb) continue Continuing. Breakpoint 1, 0x00000000004014e2 in help_help () 1: x/s $rsi 0x7ffff7dd0680 <_IO_2_1_stderr_>: "\206 \255\373" (gdb) continue Continuing. help, load, insert, delete, search, replace, print, throw, save, quit, (­û,  ­û,  ­û, You may get further details on any command by typing ? followed by the command name. > [Inferior 1 (process 12510) exited normally] (gdb) quit




39.5    Load Feature



39.5.1    Load vs. Edit vs. Read



As mentioned, the load command is used in cpt220_ed to load a file.

"Loading" a file means either "reading" a file or "editing" a file.

In ed, there are two separate commands to either read or edit a file.


read in ed appends the file's contents to the buffer.

It also sets the file name for the buffer (although, only if it was not set before).


This was, roughly, the behavior of the load command in cpt220_ed during the entire season of assignment 2(B).

However, it was not in compliance with its own help output for the load command:

"loads a file into memory. Will not succeed if there is a file loaded into memory already that has unsaved modifications."



Later, it was changed to mimic the edit command in ed.


Discussion Board – Assignment 2(B)

Jan 25, 2020 at 22:52

Whilst writing my tests I have found that the a2 sample program will load files without checking if anything is loaded first and just appends lines to the already filled buffer.

Is this how our program is intended to work for part C?


Jan 26, 2020 at 6:27

No, that's a bug.

In all things your starting point should be the assignment spec.

What does it say on this point?

Also, great job in finding this bug.

cheers


Jan 26, 2020 at 18:17

Hi

This bug should also be fixed now.

cheers



The ed Utility: The Open Group Base Specifications Issue 6 IEEE Std 1003.1, 2004 Edition

Edit Command Synopsis: e [file] The e command shall delete the entire contents of the buffer and then read in the file named by the pathname file. [...] Read Command Synopsis: r [file] The r command shall read in the file named by the pathname file and append it after the addressed line. [...] The currently remembered pathname shall not be changed unless there is no remembered pathname.




The GNU ed line editor: GNU Documentation

'e FILE' Edits FILE, and sets the default filename. If FILE is not specified, then the default filename is used. Any lines in the buffer are deleted before the new file is read. [...] 'r FILE' Reads FILE to after the addressed line. If FILE is not specified, then the default filename is used. If there is no default filename prior to the command, then the default filename is set to FILE. Otherwise, the default filename is unchanged.




39.5.2    Loading a Missing File Dooms the Editor



If you load a non-existing file, you will be blocked from using the insert commands (for any file) even after successfully loading an existing file.

You will also be blocked from using line-addresses for the print/delete commands for any file, including files successfully loaded in the future.


Why?

Inspecting the binary, we see that RMIT calls range_from_string() to verify the line-addresses.

In that function, every strtol() call is followed by a test checking the value of errno.

If errno is set (namely, unequal to 0), the associated command fails.


The problem is, errno was not set to 0, first, prior to the strtol() call.


POSIX states that:

errno – The Open Group Base Specifications Issue 7, 2018 edition

An application that needs to examine the value of errno to determine the error should set it to 0 before a function call, then inspect it before a subsequent function call.




An example run of cpt220_ed where legal line-addresses are rejected

# The very cpt220_ed developed by RMIT. $ readelf -a /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed \ | grep 'Build ID' Build ID: 0f27b56d6523065e799b430313e3035c6b64b786 $ rm -f /tmp/missing # '/tmp/foo' has 2 valid lines; ('d1' command expects 2 valid lines; see delete bugs). $ printf 'foo\nbar\n' >/tmp/foo # '/tmp/missing' does not exist; fopen() fails; 'errno' is set. # The insert commands that follow are rejected (due to the old 'errno'). # Then, a valid file '/tmp/foo' is opened ("loaded"). # Then, valid insert commands follow; they are rejected due to old 'errno'. # 'd1' fails too. # 'p1' fails too. $ /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed > l /tmp/missing fopen: No such file or directory > i1 strtol: No such file or directory > i0 strtol: No such file or directory > i strtol: No such file or directory > l /tmp/foo Successfully loaded /tmp/x > i1 strtol: No such file or directory > i0 strtol: No such file or directory > i strtol: No such file or directory > d1 strtol: No such file or directory > p1 strtol: No such file or directory ?




range_from_string() fails to clear errno before strtol() calls

0000000000402ea5 <range_from_string>: 402ea5: 55 push %rbp 402ea6: 48 89 e5 mov %rsp,%rbp 402ea9: 53 push %rbx 402eaa: 48 83 ec 38 sub $0x38,%rsp 402eae: 48 89 7d c8 mov %rdi,-0x38(%rbp) 402eb2: 48 89
