0x202ff8(%rip),%rax # 6061a0 <stderr@@GLIBC_2.2.5> 4031a8: 48 89 c1 mov %rax,%rcx 4031ab: ba 38 00 00 00 mov $0x38,%edx 4031b0: be 01 00 00 00 mov $0x1,%esi 4031b5: bf b8 4c 40 00 mov $0x404cb8,%edi 4031ba: e8 81 db ff ff callq 400d40 <fwrite@plt> 4031bf: b8 00 00 00 00 mov $0x0,%eax 4031c4: eb 11 jmp 4031d7 <range_from_string+0x332> 4031c6: 48 8b 45 c0 mov -0x40(%rbp),%rax 4031ca: 48 8b 55 d8 mov -0x28(%rbp),%rdx 4031ce: 48 89 50 08 mov %rdx,0x8(%rax) 4031d2: b8 01 00 00 00 mov $0x1,%eax 4031d7: 48 83 c4 38 add $0x38,%rsp 4031db: 5b pop %rbx 4031dc: 5d pop %rbp 4031dd: c3 retq




39.5.3    Loading Lines Not Terminated With a Newline Character



As a minor note, cpt220_ed rejects lines not terminated by a newline.

Thus, if the command-line argument is a file not terminated by a newline (on its last line), no matter how short its last line is, cpt220_ed will immediately exit with an error message about a "line too long".

Why?

Because cpt220_ed mistakenly blames the lack of a newline on "line too long".

Namely, it misinterprets the lack of a newline as if the line's length exceeded the specified size of the second argument to fgets().


Assignment 2(B): Solution of RMIT: fileio.c Released on Monday 03/02/2020 at 17:00

35 while (fgets(line, BUFSIZ + EXTRACHARS, reader)) 36 { 37 ssize_t len; 38 struct line* newline; 39 len = strlen(line); 40 /* check that the line read is not longer than allowed */ 41 if (line[len – 1] != '\n') 42 { 43 fprintf(stderr, "Error: line too long.\n"); 44 fclose(reader); 45 return FALSE; 46 }




39.6    Insert Feature



39.6.1    Using the Line-Address '0' for the Insert Command



In ed, the line-address for the insert command must be a number less than or equal to the current line count of the file.

The command puts the added text before the line-address of this command.

Thus, '1i' puts the added text before line 1.


Since 'i1' is illegal in ed for an empty file, an exception was made for this (and the append) command to allow the '0' line-address.

Thus, either '0i' or '0a' puts the added text as the first line(s) of the file, and it is the only way to insert text in an empty file.

Note, however, that line-address '0' is still illegal (in ed) for other commands (like: print, delete, etc).


In cpt220_ed, the situation is sketchy.

It "accepts" the '0' line-address for insert, namely, 'i0'.

However, it seg-faults as soon as you enter the first line of text from the input-prompt.


Interestingly enough, RMIT threatened to inflict a penalty on a student who failed to (graciously) reject 'i0'.

"Do as I say, not as I do".


For more, read here.


39.7    Delete Feature



39.7.1    Line Addresses for the Delete Command



In ed, delete and print are comparable to each other regarding line-addresses.

Both delete and print delete (or print) the same line(s) for comparable line-addresses.


However, in cpt220_ed, the delete command (and its associated line-addresses) is a mess, to put it mildly.


The following is a summary of print vs. delete regarding line-addressing.

Note how print and delete columns are identical for ed; not so for cpt220_ed.


Comparison of line-addresses rules for print/delete (ed vs. cpt220_ed)

ed cpt220_ed
print delete print delete
'1,1' for a file with 1 line Line 1 Line 1 Line 1 Error
'0,0' for a file with 1 line Error Error NONE Line 1
'0,1' for a file with 2 lines Error Error Line 1 Line 1 and Line 2
'0,2' for a file with 3 lines Error Error Lines 1 and 2 Lines 1, 2 and 3
'0,4' for a file with 5 lines Error Error Lines 1-4 Lines 1-5
'2' for a file with 2 lines Line 2 Line 2 Line 2 Error
'5,5' for a file with 5 lines Line 5 Line 5 Line 5 Error



39.7.2    Bugs Ignored by RMIT



Students repeatedly complained about this insanity, but RMIT was short of funds to fix its bugs.

Priorities as preached by RMIT.


However, RMIT stated (on the discussion board) on Feb 5, 2020 at 10:24 that:

There are various bugs that students have reported and they will be taken into account in my tests.



39.7.3    Delete Bugs Discussed in readme.txt



The following extracts from my submission discuss the above:

readme.txt – Assignment 2(C)
Submitted by student on Wednesday 12/02/2020 at 19:27

86 14) The sample program will delete the first line with 'd0'. 87 Even worse, d0-0 will delete the 1st line. 88 Illegal. 89 90 Compare with p0-0 or p0, where sample program will NOT print the 1st line. 91 Consistency?




readme.txt – Assignment 2(C)
Submitted by student on Wed Wednesday 12/02/2020 at 19:27

153 20) Can we delete from a file that has one line? 154 According to sample program, yes and no. 155 'd0-0' => success 156 'd1-1' => fail 157 'd' => fail 158 'd0' => success 159 'd1' => fail




39.8    Replace Feature



The replace command in cpt220_ed (developed by RMIT) was a mess.

For example, a command to replace a string with 'g' deletes the matching string but fails to insert the replacement string.

In other words, the replace command (in this case) deletes but does not replace.


As another bug, any character or set of characters added after the third '/' (of the replace command) acted as if the global modifier ('g') was specified.

Thus, all the following are equivalent.

  • r/foo/bar/a
  • r/foo/bar/b
  • r/foo/bar/c
  • r/foo/bar/.
  • r/foo/bar/;
  • r/foo/bar/?
  • r/foo/bar/g



As another example of the sheer insanity, compare the following commands:

  • r/foo// # Seg-fault!
  • r/foo//g # Replaces the first 'foo' with the empty string (despite the global flag).
  • r/foo//z # Replaces the first 'foo' with 'z' (not the empty string).
  • r/foo/g/? # Replaces every 'foo' with the empty string (not with 'g' specified).
  • r/foo/g/r # Replaces every 'foo' with the empty string (not with 'g' specified).
  • r/foo/g/g # Replaces every 'foo' with the empty string (not with 'g' specified).



As another example:

  • r/g/g/ # Replaces one 'g' with the empty string (not with the 'g', specified).
  • r/g/g/g # Replaces every 'g' with the empty string (not with the 'g', specified).
  • r/g/g/? # Replaces every 'g' with the empty string (not with the 'g', specified).



As always, RMIT was short in resources to fix the bugs but promised to "take into account" when grading the assignments.


My assignment submission discussed the above.

Extract from 'readme.txt' of assignment 2(C) submitted on Wednesday 12/02/2020 at 19:27

55 10) The sample program will *delete* instead of replace in the following command: 56 r/a/g/ 57 58 And for the following, will delete the every string matching the pattern. 59 i.e. instead of REPLACING 'a' with 'g', it will just DELETE 'a' 60 r/a/g/g 61 62 We differ. 63 64 11) The sample program will seg-fault, on the following: 65 r/a// 66 But will do the right thing for: 67 r/a//g 68 69 We replace the pattern 'a' with the empty replacement string. 70 71 12) The sample program will Replace 'a' with 'b', rather then replace 'b' with 'c' 72 ra/b/c/ 73 74 Of course, this is illegal, and thus is the diagnosis in our program. 75 76 13) The sample program will replace globally for each of the follwing patterns. 77 r/a/b/ g 78 r/a/b/ abcdefg 79 r/a/b/ ggggggg 80 r/a/b/abcdefghijklmnopqrstuvwxyz 81 r/a/b/:g: 82 r/a/b/?g? 83 84 We do not – for NONE of them. For global use: 'r/a/b/g'.




39.9    Throw Feature



throw ("discard" changes) worked sporadically (and varied between versions).

Unfortunately, even after their "fix", throw merely discards the old file but does not get rid of the "discarding changes to..." message if you try to quit.

Am I doing it wrong? I can't see the expected behavior because of it?

throw does not get rid of the error message "discarding changes to..."

# The very cpt220_ed developed by RMIT. $ readelf -a /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed \ | grep 'Build ID' Build ID: 0f27b56d6523065e799b430313e3035c6b64b786

$ printf 'foo\n' >/tmp/foo

# load the file; delete; throw; quit. # Despite the 'throw', cpt220_ed outputs "Discarding changes to". $ /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed > l /tmp/foo Successfully loaded /tmp/foo > d > t Discarded previously loaded / edited file > q Discarding changes to (null)




39.10    Save Feature



39.10.1    Saving Does Not Set the File Name for the Edited File



readme.txt – Assignment 2(C)
Submitted by student on Wednesday 12/02/2020 at 19:27

130 18) Consider the following sequence: 131 l /tmp/old 132 r/a/b/g 133 s /tmp/new 134 r/b/c/g 135 s 136 137 The sample will do 2nd saving back to /tmp/old. 138 139 This contradicts the spec: 140 141 "Otherwise, save to the new file name and store that in the 142 system as the name of the file". 143 (spec, line 252). 144 145 We do all the oparation on /tmp/new, once the file name was changed 146 to 'new' via the save command.




Notably, though, the behaviour of cpt220_ed here is compatible with ed.

The Gnu Ed Manual

'(1,$)w FILE' Writes the addressed lines to FILE. Any previous contents of FILE is lost without warning. If there is no default filename, then the default filename is set to FILE, otherwise it is unchanged. If no filename is specified, then the default filename is used. The current address is unchanged.




The only complaint is that the cpt220_ed is not in compliance with its own spec.


It is also not in compliance with its own help output:

"save ---- saves the current file to disk. If you just press s on its own, the currently open file will be saved to file it was opened from. If the file was not loaded from disk, an error message will display. if you press s followed by non-space characters, this will be treated as a path to save the file to and that becomes the current filename for the open file."


39.10.2    Saving File After a Full Delete



As another bug, save does not toggle off the modified flag if issued after a full deletion of the file.

Thus, a full delete followed by save followed by quit issues a warning that:

Discarding changes to '[name of the file]'



Full delete followed by save still outputs the error message "discarding changes to..." for quit

# The very cpt220_ed developed by RMIT. $ readelf -a /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed \ | grep 'Build ID' Build ID: 0f27b56d6523065e799b430313e3035c6b64b786

# 'd(elete)' command w/o line-addresses assumes line-count > 1; see delete bugs. $ printf 'foo\nbar\n' >/tmp/foo

# loads the file; deletes; saves; quits. # Despite 'save', cpt220_ed outputs "Discarding changes to". $ /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed > l /tmp/foo Successfully loaded /tmp/foo > d > s > q Discarding changes to /tmp/foo




readme.txt – Assignment 2(C)
Submitted by student on Wednesday 12/02/2020 at 19:27

48 9) The sample program fails to save after a full delete (the whold buffer). 49 So 's' or 'qw' will fail after 'd'. 50 And will complain about a modified buffer, even *after* a save command.




However, my submission was completely correct regarding every aspect of the save command, including saving an empty file.

But, this did not stop RMIT from lying that my submission "refuse[s] to save an empty file".


39.11    Quit Feature



39.11.1    Unsaved Changes



Here is a question.

If changes — made to the edited file — were not saved, should this command succeed?

As shown later, editors generally refuse to exit (which would silently discard the unsaved edits) but, instead, prompt the user to either save or discard the changes.

However, RMIT hit me with a penalty for doing the above.


39.11.2    Inconsistency Regarding Case-Sensitivity



As a minor bug, read the following.

readme.txt – Assignment 2(C)
Submitted by student on Wednesday 12/02/2020 at 19:27

Chapter 40
— Assignment 2(B)
— Create a Non-Existing File





40.1    Summary



On Monday 24/02/2020 at 21:24, RMIT told me I lost half of my marking points.

Why?

Because my (developed) editor refused to load a non-existing file.


The problem is that:

  1. Neither does cpt220_ed (developed by RMIT), which was put on a pedestal for all students to follow.
  2. Neither does their own source code released to the students as the ultimate truth.
  3. In cpt220_ed, after loading a non-existing file, you are blocked from inserting text to any file (or using line-addresses for any command) even after successfully loading legitimate files.
  4. Furthermore, cpt220_ed exits immediately with an error if the command-line argument was a non-existing file.
  5. The student explained in his readme.txt why he had done so, but RMIT did not read it.
  6. The instructions (while being ambiguous) are leaning towards my interpretation.



You see, there is no end to RMIT's inconsistencies.


Then, they made an outlandish claim that my editor saves to (and clobbers) a read-only file.

Which is false.

Or the next false claim that I did not implement the linked-list operations.


Both of the above are complete fabrications without a grain of truth to them.

They are bold-faced lies.


40.2    The Appeal Process



40.2.1    Formal Appeal



My appeal discussed the above and showed how the results of 'a2p2' (i.e. assignment 2 part 2) were ludicrous, given that my code completely matched the "approved" one.


Extract from my appeal on Friday 15/05/2020 at 19:13:

The same goes for a2p2 [...] you will simply compare my assignment to the "solution" that was offered afterwards by [...], as the basis for a2p3, and see my point. [...]

I want a fresh review on EVERYTHING.



This email was confirmed by the office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic on Tuesday 19/05/2020 at 16:31, saying, they "can confirm that your email [...] of Friday 15 May 2020, at 7:13 pm was received."


40.2.2    Appeal Rejected Without Explanation



On Friday 05/06/2020 at 17:13, the office of Prof. Aleksandar Subic responded that they "can confirm" that my appeal got rejected without explaining why.

This is RMIT in a nutshell.


40.3    Comparison of RMIT's and Student's Code



40.3.1    Source Code of RMIT



Assignment 2(B): Solution of RMIT – Released on Monday 03/02/2020 at 17:00

19 BOOLEAN load_file(const char fname[], struct linkedlist* thelist) 20 { 21 FILE* reader; 22 char line[BUFSIZ + EXTRACHARS]; 23 ssize_t line_count = 0; 24 25 /* document our assumption that the list cannot be NULL */ 26 assert(thelist); 27 /* open the file for reading */ 28 reader = fopen(fname, "r"); 29 if (!reader) 30 { 31 perror("fopen"); 32 return FALSE; 33 } 34 /* read each line from the file */ 35 while (fgets(line, BUFSIZ + EXTRACHARS, reader)) 36 { 37 ssize_t len; 38 struct line* newline; 39 len = strlen(line); 40 /* check that the line read is not longer than allowed */ 41 if (line[len – 1] != '\n') 42 { 43 fprintf(stderr, "Error: line too long.\n"); 44 fclose(reader); 45 return FALSE; 46 } 47 /* remove the newline character now we know the line has been 48 * read completely 49 */ 50 line[len – 1] = 0; 51 ++line_count; 52 --len; 53 newline = line_make(line_count, line, len); 54 if (!linkedlist_add(thelist, newline, line_count – 1)) 55 { 56 fclose(reader); 57 return FALSE; 58 } 59 } 60 /* double check that we are at the end of the file, otherwise an 61 * error has occured */ 62 if (!feof(reader)) 63 { 64 perror("read failed"); 65 return FALSE; 66 } 67 fclose(reader); 68 printf("Successfully loaded %s\n", fname); 69 return TRUE; 70 }




40.3.2    Source Code of the Student



Note how the student's solution matches RMIT's one regarding the fopen() call.

Assignment 2(B): Solution by Student – Submitted by student on Sun 29/01/2020 17:01

47 BOOLEAN linkedlist_load(const char fname[], struct linkedlist *head) 48 { 49 char buf[BUFSIZ + 2]; 50 FILE *f; 51 ssize_t i = 0; 52 struct linkednode **pp = &head->head; 53 if ((f = fopen(fname, "r")) == NULL) { 54 FATAL("fopen()"); 55 } 56 while (getline(buf, sizeof buf, f) == TRUE) { 57 /* First line is 1. */ 58 struct linkednode *node; 59 i++; 60 node = string_to_node(buf, i); 61 link(&pp, node); 62 head->size++; 63 } 64 /* A little awkward. To be revisited in part 3. */ 65 if (feof(f)) { 66 printf("successfully loaded %s\n", fname); 67 return TRUE; 68 } 69 /* TODO: Painful state here, as we possibly loaded only some lines. 70 Should we clean up? terminate? abort? 71 Left to part 3. 72 */ 73 return FALSE; 74 }




As you see, both — RMIT and the student — used fopen(..., "r").

ANSI C states that fopen(..., "r") does not create the file if it doesn't exist.


40.3.3    Binary of RMIT



The compiled binary of RMIT does the same.

You can see that load_file() calls fopen() with its second argument (%rsi) as 0x404d93.

The string at 0x404de3 is: 72 00, which is ascii for "r".

1 $ readelf -a /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed \ 2 | grep 'Build ID' 3 Build ID: 0f27b56d6523065e799b430313e3035c6b64b786 4 5 $ objdump -d 403461: 48 83 7d f0 00 cmpq $0x0,-0x10(%rbp) 29 403466: 75 14 jne 40347c <load_file+0x77> 30 403468: bf 95 4d 40 00 mov $0x404d95,%edi 31 40346d: e8 7e d8 ff ff callq 400cf0 <perror@plt> 32 403472: b8 <fwrite@plt> 54 4034d5: 48 8b 45 f0 mov -0x10(%rbp),%rax 55 4034d9: 48 89 c7 mov %rax,%rdi 56 4034dc: e8 ff d6 ff ff callq 400be0 <fclose@plt> 57 4034e1: b8 00 00 00 00 mov $0x0,%eax 58 4034e6: e9 b8 40.4    Resources



40.4.1    RMIT's cpt220_ed Refusing to Load a Non-Existent File



$ readelf -a /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed \ | grep 'Build ID' Build ID: 0f27b56d6523065e799b430313e3035c6b64b786

$ ls /tmp/missing ls: cannot access '/tmp/missing': No such file or directory

# There are 3 commands here: # 1) 'l(oad)' /tmp/missing (a non-existing file); it fails. # 2) 's(ave)' to the default file (set by last load/save); note how cpt220_ed complains 'file name not set...'. # 3) 'q(uit)'. $ /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed > l /tmp/missing fopen: No such file or directory > s Error: file name not set or specified > q




40.4.2    RMIT's cpt220_ed Is Doomed After Loading a Non-Existent File



Not only does cpt220_ed reject a load command for a non-existing file, but it also ceases to operate properly from then on.

In other words, the editor is doomed, and (almost) all following commands will fail even after successfully loading existing files.

The student's editor, however, graciously rejects a non-existing file but continues to operate normally.

And for it, he got hit with a 50% penalty.

Now, this is way beyond hypocrisy.


40.4.3    RMIT's cpt220_ed Exits With an Error for a Non-Existing File Argument



cpt220_ed exits (immediately) with an error for a command-line argument of a non-existing file

$ readelf -a /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed \ | grep 'Build ID' Build ID: 0f27b56d6523065e799b430313e3035c6b64b786

$ ls /tmp/missing ls: cannot access '/tmp/missing': No such file or directory

# Run cpt220_ed with a command-line argument of a non-existing file. # Note how cpt220_ed exits immediately with an error. $ /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed /tmp/missing fopen: No such file or directory

# exit status is 1. $ echo $? 1




40.4.4    ANSI C Regarding fopen(..., "r") a Non-Existing File



ANSI C (89) "Programming Language C" (X3.159-1989)

4.9.5.3 The fopen function

Synopsis

#include <stdio.h> FILE *fopen(const char *filename, const char *mode);

Description

The fopen function opens the file whose name is the string pointed to by filename, and associates a stream with it.

[...]

Opening a file with read mode ('r' as the first character in the mode argument) fails if the file does not exist or cannot be read.




40.4.5    Load Instructions



As noted, the instructions are leaning towards my interpretation (for example, "you don't need to validate the path string as the operating system will do this for you", meaning, we had to reject files not accepted by the system calls, which include non-existing files fopen'ed for reading).



Extract from assignment 2(B) instructions

Requirement 4: Load Data (4 marks)

This requirement is to be implemented in the fileio module in the function: BOOLEAN load_file(const char filename[], struct linkedlist * thelist);

You are to open the file specified by the filename passed in and load each line of text from the file, ensuring each line is within the maximum permitted line length. Next, add it into the linked list of lines.

Along with being able to load valid files, your program should reject all files with invalid entries.

Please note though you don't need to validate the path string as the operating system will do this for you when you attempt to open the file.




40.4.6    Rationale Provided By Student



Long before I received the results for this assignment (on Monday 24/02/2020 at 21:24), I had submitted the solution to Assignment 2(C) on Wednesday 12/02/2020 at 19:27 where it reads:



Assignment 2(C): readme.txt
Submitted by student on Wednesday 12/02/2020 at 19:27

33 5) Load a file, does not create it, and will fail for a non-existing file.

Extract from the results to assignment 2(B)
Sent on Monday 24/02/2020 at 21:24

Requirement 1 – Command Line Arguments (2 Marks) ------------------------------------------------------------------------- Mark: 1 Comments: Fair – Major Problems (1 mark) cannot create a non-existing file: sh-4.2$ ./output ttt.tt Error: linkedlist.c:54:fopen(): No such file or directory sh-4.2$ ls action.c fileio.h line.c linkedlist.h Makefile shared.h ui.h action.h helpers.c line.h main.c output tests fileio.c helpers.h linkedlist.c main.h readme.txt ui.c









Chapter 41
— Assignment 2(B)
— Valgrind Leaks





41.1    Background



The second assignment was about implementing a file as a linked-list of nodes; each node represented a line in the file.

This assignment was submitted in two stages.


The first stage — namely, assignment 2(B) — was a preliminary blueprint implementing only the bare minimum of linked-list operations.

The only operations required were to open the file specified as the first command-line argument (if any), add its lines as nodes to the linked list, only to immediately save them back to the file and — immediately — exit the program.

In other words, the editor was not able to dynamically open any other file.


The second stage — namely, assignment 2(C) — expanded on the above to provide the full range of commands, including: open (load), close (throw), delete, replace, search, etc.


The instructions for the first stage (assignment 2 part B) say that: "The only penalties we apply is if your code cannot compile, or if you submit late. You should aim for your code to also compile without warnings but that is not required at this stage."


41.2    Valgrind Penalty



My submission was 100% correct.

No runtime errors.

No compilation errors or warnings.

None.


However, Valgrind reported a "still reachable" leak because the program did not close() a file before exit().

But, truth to be told, there was no point to do so because this program was not allowed to dynamically open any file.

It could only open the first command-line argument (if specified), only to exit() immediately.


Do you free all allocated memory before exit()?


And do you close stdin, stdout and stderr before exit()?


POSIX says:

The exit() function shall then flush all open streams with unwritten buffered data, close all open streams, and remove all files created by tmpfile().




Wait, there is more.

RMIT made it clear that the only possible penalty was if "code cannot compile".


There is even more.

RMIT even allowed for compilation warnings, noting they will not incur a penalty.


41.3    Resources



41.3.1    Feedback



Assignment 2(B) Results; sent on Monday 24/02/2020 at 21:24

Requirement 3 – Linked List Implementation (4 Marks) ------------------------------------------------------------------------- Mark: 2 Comments: Fair (2 Marks) Valgrind error: ==61217== 568 bytes in 1 blocks are still reachable in loss record 1 of 1 ==61217== at 0x4C29E63: malloc (vg_replace_malloc.c:309) ==61217== by 0x4EA5BAC: __fopen_internal (in /usr/lib64/libc-2.17.so) ==61217== by 0x401292: linkedlist_load (linkedlist.c:53) ==61217== by 0x400E4E: load_file (fileio.c:45) ==61217== by 0x4014F7: init_system (main.c:39) ==61217== by 0x401651: main (main.c:85) Probably there is issue here: struct linkednode **pp = &head->head; if ((f = fopen(fname, "r")) == NULL) { FATAL("fopen()"); } while (getline(buf, sizeof buf, f) == TRUE) {




41.3.2    Assignment 2 part B Instructions



Extract from assignment 2(B) instructions

Requirement 3: Linked List Implementation (4 marks)

You need to implement enough of the linked list functionality to be able to initialise the list, add lines to it and save lines back out, and free the list and any associated data.

At this stage I don't expect you to implement the deletion of elements from the list.

As part of this requirement you will need to consider the functional aspects listed above and make some sensible design decisions about what functions you need to implement for this Linked List structure.

You will be graded in part on the design decisions you have made, with respect to which functions are required, and how they are declared / implemented. For example, accessing the internal data of the list in the fileio module will result in a mark deduction as it's not good practice in terms of encapsulation.

[...]

At this stage the only penalties we apply is if your code cannot compile, or if you submit late.

You should aim for your code to also compile without warnings but that is not required at this stage.

The intention is that we will give you feedback on your submission at this point, as well as setting a minimum level of progress you need to complete for it to be feasible for you to complete the assignment.

If you find you cannot complete this part of the assignment on time, it is now time to consider whether you will be able to complete the assignment and also to consider your options going forward from here.




41.4    "Definitely Lost" Leaks in RMIT's Code



Wait, there is more.

The "sample" code that was released by RMIT on Monday 03/02/2020 at 17:00, when run under Valgrind, outputs many errors of "definitely lost" leaks.

The student-developed program, however, did not have even one "definitely lost" leak error.

Hypocrisy much?


In the following, the "approved" solution for assignment 2(B) is compiled and run.

Compilation and tests were all run on RMIT's platform; the exact same platform used by RMIT to mark my assignment.

Program is run twice, namely:

  1. Without a command-line argument.
  2. With one command-line argument.


As you can see, leak errors galore.


Plus, there is an error of "Syscall param open(filename) points to unaddressable byte".

42.2    Comparison of RMIT's and Student's Code



The following is the "approved" implementation of RMIT followed by the student's one.

As you can see, they are 100 per cent compatible with each other.


42.2.1    Code by RMIT



/home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/a2part2/linkedlist.c
Released on Monday 03/02/2020 at 17:00

1 /****************************************************************************** 2 * Student Name : 3 * RMIT Student ID : 4 * 5 * Startup code provided by [...] for use in "Programming in C", 6 * study period 4, 2019. 7 *****************************************************************************/ 8 #include "linkedlist.h" 9 #include <assert.h> 10 #include <ctype.h> 11 #include <stdio.h> 12 #include <stdlib.h> 13 #include <string.h> 14 #include "ui.h" 15 16 /** 17 * allocates space for a linked list header structure and initialises it to 18 * a known safe empty state 19 **/ 20 struct linkedlist* linkedlist_make(void) 21 { 22 /* allocate space for the list */ 23 struct linkedlist* thelist = 24 (struct linkedlist*)malloc(sizeof(struct linkedlist)); 25 if (!thelist) 26 { 27 perror("malloc"); 28 return NULL; 29 } 30 /* zero out the data structure as that's a good safe starting 31 * state 32 */ 33 memset(thelist, 0, sizeof(struct linkedlist)); 34 return thelist; 35 } 36 37 /** 38 * creates a new linked list node with the line specified 39 **/ 40 static struct linkednode* new_node(struct line* newline) 41 { 42 /* allocate space for the line */ 43 struct linkednode* newnode = 44 (struct linkednode*)malloc(sizeof(struct linkednode)); 45 if (!newnode) 46 { 47 perror("malloc"); 48 return NULL; 49 } 50 /* attach the data */ 51 newnode->data = newline; 52 newnode->next = NULL; 53 return newnode; 54 } 55 56 /** 57 * adds the newline parameter to the offset specified by the insert_offset. It 58 * is assumed that newline has been separately malloced and it is not a 59 * stack address as then the behaviour of this list is undefined. 60 **/ 61 BOOLEAN linkedlist_add(struct linkedlist* thelist, struct line* newline, 62 ssize_t insert_offset) 63 { 64 ssize_t count; 65 struct linkednode* newnode = new_node(newline); 66 struct linkednode* current = thelist->head; 67 struct linkednode* prev = NULL; 68 69 /* verify that creation of the node succeeded */ 70 if (!newnode) 71 { 72 return FALSE; 73 } 74 /* check that there is no out of bounds inserts */ 75 if (!current) 76 { 77 if (insert_offset != 0) 78 { 79 fprintf(stderr, "Error: invalid offset requested.\n"); 80 } 81 thelist->head = newnode; 82 ++thelist->size; 83 return TRUE; 84 } 85 /* find the insertion position in the list */ 86 for (count = 0; count < insert_offset; ++count) 87 { 88 assert(current->data->lineno == count + 1); 89 prev = current; 90 current = current->next; 91 } 92 /* check the insert offset matches the expected line number */ 93 if (current) 94 { 95 assert(current->data->lineno == insert_offset + 1); 96 } 97 /* insert at the front of the list */ 98 if (!prev) 99 { 100 /* verify that an insertion at the front of the list was indeed 101 * requested */ 102 if (insert_offset != 0) 103 { 104 fprintf(stderr, 105 "Error: attempt to insert at the head when the " 106 "requested offset is not 0.\n"); 107 return FALSE; 108 } 109 newnode->next = thelist->head; 110 thelist->head = newnode; 111 } 112 else 113 { 114 /* insert somewhere else in the list */ 115 prev->next = newnode; 116 newnode->next = current; 117 } 118 ++thelist->size; 119 /* renumber all lines from this point forward */ 120 for (; current; current = current->next) 121 { 122 ++current->data->lineno; 123 } 124 return TRUE; 125 } 126 127 /** 128 * saves teh linked list to the file pointer specified. 129 **/ 130 BOOLEAN linkedlist_save(FILE* receiver, const struct linkedlist* thelist) 131 { 132 const struct linkednode* current; 133 ssize_t outcount = 0; 134 135 for (current = thelist->head; current; current = current->next) 136 { 137 outcount += fprintf(receiver, "%s\n", current->data->text); 138 } 139 return outcount > 0; 140 }




42.2.2    Code by Student



linkedlist.c — Assignment 2 Part 2
Submitted by student on Sun 29/01/2020 17:01

1 /****************************************************************************** 2 * Student Name : 3 * RMIT Student ID : 4 * 5 * Startup code provided by [...] for use in "Programming in C", 6 * study period 4, 2019. 7 *****************************************************************************/ 8 #include "linkedlist.h" 9 BOOLEAN getline(char *buf, size_t n, FILE * f); 10 11 /** 12 * Implement the functions to manage the linkedlist type here. 13 **/ 14 15 static struct linkednode *string_to_node(const char *s, ssize_t i) 16 { 17 struct linkednode *n; 18 if (((n = calloc(1, sizeof *n)) == NULL) 19 || (n->data = calloc(1, sizeof *n->data)) == NULL) { 20 FATAL("calloc()"); 21 } 22 if ((n->data->text = strdup(s)) == NULL) { 23 FATAL("strdup()"); 24 } 25 n->data->len = strlen(s); 26 n->data->lineno = i; 27 return n; 28 } 29 30 /* link in new line, and advance the caller's cursor to added line */ 31 /* @ppp is a pointer to the local cursor in the caller function. */ 32 static void link(struct linkednode ***ppp, struct linkednode *node) 33 { 34 struct linkednode **pp = *ppp; 35 struct linkednode *next = *pp; 36 37 /* TODO: Remove this assert, 38 * if (or when) we have to support the insert command. 39 */ 40 assert(next == NULL); 41 node->next = next; 42 *pp = node; 43 *ppp = &node->next; 44 } 45 46 /* buffer implemented as linked list. read @fname. */ 47 BOOLEAN linkedlist_load(const char fname[], struct linkedlist *head) 48 { 49 char buf[BUFSIZ + 2]; 50 FILE *f; 51 ssize_t i = 0; 52 struct linkednode **pp = &head->head; 53 if ((f = fopen(fname, "r")) == NULL) { 54 FATAL("fopen()"); 55 } 56 while (getline(buf, sizeof buf, f) == TRUE) { 57 /* First line is 1. */ 58 struct linkednode *node; 59 i++; 60 node = string_to_node(buf, i); 61 link(&pp, node); 62 head->size++; 63 } 64 /* A little awkward. To be revisited in part 3. */ 65 if (feof(f)) { 66 printf("successfully loaded %s\n", fname); 67 return TRUE; 68 } 69 /* TODO: Painful state here, as we possibly loaded only some lines. 70 Should we clean up? terminate? abort? 71 Left to part 3. 72 */ 73 return FALSE; 74 } 75 76 /* write buffer to file */ 77 BOOLEAN linkedlist_save(const char fname[], struct linkedlist * head) 78 { 79 FILE *f; 80 struct linkednode *node; 81 if ((f = fopen(fname, "w")) == NULL) { 82 FATAL("fopen()"); 83 } 84 node = head->head; 85 while (node) { 86 fprintf(f, "%s\n", node->data->text); 87 node = node->next; 88 } 89 printf("successfully saved %s\n", fname); 90 return TRUE; 91 }




42.3    Linked List Traversal Done Right



Note, however, how the linked-list traversal is slightly different in the student's implementation.

And, as a result, there is a notable difference regarding the length of the function.

Compare:

• linkedlist_add() in RMIT's code, which is 65-lines long.

• link() in the student's code, which is only 13-lines long.


Linus Torvalds described it best (in a Slashdot interview) where he said:

At the opposite end of the spectrum, I actually wish more people understood the really core low-level kind of coding.

Not big, complex stuff like the lockless name lookup, but simply good use of pointers-to-pointers etc.

For example, I've seen too many people who delete a singly-linked list entry by keeping track of the "prev" entry, and then to delete the entry, doing something like:

if (prev) prev->next = entry->next; else list_head = entry->next;

and whenever I see code like that, I just go "This person doesn't understand pointers".

And it's sadly quite common.

People who understand pointers just use a "pointer to the entry pointer", and initialize that with the address of the list_head.

And then as they traverse the list, they can remove the entry without using any conditionals, by just doing a "*pp = entry->next".

So there's lots of pride in doing the small details right.

It may not be big and important code, but I do like seeing code where people really thought about the details, and clearly also were thinking about the compiler being able to generate efficient code (rather than hoping that the compiler is so smart that it can make efficient code *despite* the state of the original source code).








Chapter 43
— Assignment 2(B)
— Saving to Read-Only File





43.1    Summary



On Thursday 16/04/2020 at 22:36, I lost 50% of my marking points.

Why?

Because my (developed) editor was "saving in a read-only file".


Basically, RMIT claims that my editor clobbers a read-only file.


This is a complete fabrication without a grain of truth to it.

A bold-faced lie.


43.2    Comparison between RMIT's and Student's Solutions



The following compares RMIT's "approved" solution to the student's one.

Notice how they both (RMIT and the student) use the same function call, namely, fopen(..., "w").

POSIX states that fopen(..., "w") fails for a read-only file.


43.2.1    Implementation of RMIT



/home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/a2part2/linkedlist.c
Released on Monday 03/02/2020 at 17:00

130 BOOLEAN linkedlist_save(FILE* receiver, const struct linkedlist* thelist) 131 { 132 const struct linkednode* current; 133 ssize_t outcount = 0; 134 135 for (current = thelist->head; current; current = current->next) 136 { 137 outcount += fprintf(receiver, "%s\n", current->data->text); 138 } 139 return outcount > 0; 140 }




/home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/a2part2/fileio.c
Released on Monday 03/02/2020 at 17:00

72 /** 73 * saves the currently loaded file's data into the tilename specified. 74 **/ 75 BOOLEAN save_file(const char fname[], struct linkedlist* thelist) 76 { 77 FILE* writer; 78 BOOLEAN funcresult = TRUE; 79 80 /* open the file for writing */ 81 writer = fopen(fname, "w"); 82 if (!writer) 83 { 84 /* handles the case when we try to write to a readonly file */ 85 perror("fopen"); 86 return FALSE; 87 } 88 /* send the file data to the output file */ 89 if (linkedlist_save(writer, thelist)) 90 { 91 printf("Successfully saved %s\n", fname); 92 funcresult = TRUE; 93 } 94 else 95 { 96 funcresult = FALSE; 97 } 98 /* don't forget to close the output file */ 99 fclose(writer); 100 return funcresult; 101 }




43.2.2    Implementation by Student



./linkedlist.c (Assignment 2 Part 2 – Submitted by student on Sun 29/01/2020 17:01)

76 /* write buffer to file */ 77 BOOLEAN linkedlist_save(const char fname[], struct linkedlist * head) 78 { 79 FILE *f; 80 struct linkednode *node; 81 if ((f = fopen(fname, "w")) == NULL) { 82 FATAL("fopen()"); 83 } 84 node = head->head; 85 while (node) { 86 fprintf(f, "%s\n", node->data->text); 87 node = node->next; 88 } 89 printf("successfully saved %s\n", fname); 90 return TRUE; 91 }




./fileio.c (Assignment 2 Part 2; Submitted by student on Sun 29/01/2020 17:01)

48 /** 49 * saves the currently loaded file's data into the tilename specified. 50 **/ 51 BOOLEAN save_file(const char fname[], struct linkedlist *e) 52 { 53 return linkedlist_save(fname, e); 54 }




43.2.3    The Compiled Program of RMIT Does the Same



Inspecting the binary, we find that cpt220_ed (developed by RMIT) does the same thing.

Note how save_file() calls fopen() with the second argument as 0x404dca.

The string 0x404dca contains 77 00, which is ascii for: "w".


The compiled version of the cpt220_ed (developed by RMIT)

$ readelf -a /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed \ | grep 'Build ID' Build ID: 0f27b56d6523065e799b430313e3035c6b64b786

$ objdump -d /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed \ | sed -n '/<save_file>:/,/^$/p' 00000000004035a5 <save_file>: 4035a5: 55 push %rbp 4035a6: 48 89 e5 mov %rsp,%rbp 4035a9: 48 83 ec 20 sub $0x20,%rsp 4035ad: 48 89 7d e8 mov %rdi,-0x18(%rbp) 4035b1: 48 89 75 e0 mov %rsi,-0x20(%rbp) 4035b5: c7 45 fc 01 00 00 00 movl $0x1,-0x4(%rbp) 4035bc: 48 8b 45 e8 mov -0x18(%rbp),%rax 4035c0: be ca 4d 40 00 mov $0x404dca,%esi 4035c5: 48 89 c7 mov %rax,%rdi 4035c8: e8 13 d7 ff ff callq 400ce0 <fopen@plt> 4035cd: 48 89 45 f0 mov %rax,-0x10(%rbp) 4035d1: 48 83 7d f0 00 cmpq $0x0,-0x10(%rbp) 4035d6: 75 11 jne 4035e9 <save_file+0x44> 4035d8: bf 95 4d 40 00 mov $0x404d95,%edi 4035dd: e8 0e d7 ff ff callq 400cf0 <perror@plt> 4035e2: b8 00 00 00 00 mov $0x0,%eax 4035e7: eb 53 jmp 40363c <save_file+0x97> 4035e9: 48 8b 75 e0 mov -0x20(%rbp),%rsi 4035ed: 48 8b 45 f0 mov -0x10(%rbp),%rax 4035f1: b9 00 00 00 00 mov $0x0,%ecx 4035f6: ba 00 00 00 00 mov $0x0,%edx 4035fb: 48 89 c7 mov %rax,%rdi 4035fe: e8 30 f5 ff ff callq 402b33 <linkedlist_print> 403603: 85 c0 test %eax,%eax 403605: 74 1f je 403626 <save_file+0x81> 403607: 48 8b 45 e8 mov -0x18(%rbp),%rax 40360b: 48 89 c6 mov %rax,%rsi 40360e: bf cc 4d 40 00 mov $0x404dcc,%edi 403613: b8 00 00 00 00 mov $0x0,%eax 403618: e8 f3 d5 ff ff callq 400c10 <printf@plt> 40361d: c7 45 fc 01 00 00 00 movl $0x1,-0x4(%rbp) 403624: eb 07 jmp 40362d <save_file+0x88> 403626: c7 45 fc 00 00 00 00 movl $0x0,-0x4(%rbp) 40362d: 48 8b 45 f0 mov -0x10(%rbp),%rax 403631: 48 89 c7 mov %rax,%rdi 403634: e8 a7 d5 ff ff callq 400be0 <fclose@plt> 403639: 8b 45 fc mov -0x4(%rbp),%eax 40363c: c9 leaveq 40363d: c3 retq

$ objdump -D /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed \ | grep -A1 '404dc9:'

404dc9: 00 77 404dcb: 00 53 75 add %dl,0x75(%rbx)




43.2.4    POSIX Regarding fopen() Readonly Files for Writing



fopen – The Open Group Base Specifications Issue 6 IEEE Std 1003.1, 2004 Edition

fopen – open a stream. [...] ERRORS

The fopen() function shall fail if:

[EACCES]

Search permission is denied on a component of the path prefix, or the file exists and the permissions specified by mode are denied, or the file does not exist and write permission is denied for the parent directory of the file to be created.









Chapter 44
— Assignment 2(B)
— Linked-List Traversal





How long does it take to walk 1 km?

Google says: 10 to 12 minutes.


I have conducted my own test (by walking 1,000 meters).

But it took me 83 hours and 25 minutes.


Here is how my test went.

I positioned myself at the starting line, and then: • I walked 1 meter and went back to the starting line. • Then, walked 2 meters and went back to the starting line. • Then, walked 3 meters and went back to the starting line. • Then, walked 4 meters and went back to the starting line. • Then, walked 5 meters and went back to the starting line. • Then, walked 6 meters and went back to the starting line. • Then, walked 7 meters and went back to the starting line. • ........................................................ • ........................................................ • ........................................................ • Then, walked 997 meters and went back to the starting line. • Then, walked 998 meters and went back to the starting line. • Then, walked 999 meters and went back to the starting line. • Then, walked 1000 meters.


Evaluating this arithmetic series, we have: (((1000 + 1) * 1000) / 2) = 500,500 meters.

(Walking back not included; I rode my electric scooter).


Assuming the best-case scenario of walking 1km in 10 minutes, we have: 500.5 km * 10 minutes = 83 hours and 25 minutes.


I have reported this bug to Google.

To my dismay, I never heard back.

I wonder why.


If you think I was ridiculous in my (ingenious) way of walking, wait until you enrol at RMIT.

Students had to append nodes to a linked list.

To this end, students had to walk (traverse) a linked list to find its last node.


A conventional way of walking is maintaining a tail pointer (pointing to the last node in the list).

RMIT, however, reprimanded a student attempting this normal way of walking.

He ordered the student to get rid of the tail.

And then told us to go back to the head of the list, for every single append, and traverse all the nodes in order to find the last one.

This scaled (and exploded) as expected, turning a split-second operation of loading big.txt into a whopping 14 minutes and 22.5 seconds nightmare running at a snail's pace.


cpt220_ed (the editor developed by RMIT) as it "loads" 'big.txt' (under Valgrind)

# The very binary released by RMIT. $ readelf -a /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed \ | grep 'Build ID' Build ID: 0f27b56d6523065e799b430313e3035c6b64b786

# This batch file contains 2 commands: # 1. l(oading) i.e. editing the 'testfiles/big.txt' file. # 2. q(uit). $ cat /tmp/input l testfiles/big.txt q

# Test a Valgrind run of loading 'testfiles/big.txt'. $ time valgrind /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed \ </tmp/input >/dev/null real 14m22.525s user 14m19.563s sys 0m2.788s




Note how RMIT claims (in the following quote) that linked lists are "very rarely used" in "real systems".

For more on linked lists (in the alternate universe of RMIT), read here.


JAN 25, 2020 at 22:17



Do not implement a tail.

This learning, that linked lists take a lot of time to run is an important learning outcome.

It's not accidental.

Personally, I don't care how long it takes to run on your laptop as that's not the deployment machine anyway.

But yes, on titan, when using valgrind I found that file took about half an hour to load for me.

It's entirely possible that you are doing something that's taking more time than my implementation though.

Once again, do not modify the startup code.

Each issue you face has been set up by me with an intention - something I want you to learn.

Yes, in real systems singly linked lists are very rarely used. But we are starting on our journey of data structures. It's enough for you to realise at this point that linked lists are slow. Even better if you understand why they are slow - much slower than arrays when doing the same task.

cheers








Chapter 45
— Assignment 2(B)
— Linked List VS Arrays





45.1    Linked List VS Array List



To quote Knuth in The Art of Computer Programming Volume 1 (page 255):

2.2.3. Linked Allocation

Instead of keeping a linear list in sequential memory locations, we can make use of a much more flexible scheme in which each node contains a link to the next node of the list.

[...]

2) It is easy to delete an item from within a linked list. For example, to delete item 3 we need only change the link associated with item 2. But with sequential allocation such a deletion generally implies moving a large part of the list up into different locations.

3) It is easy to insert an item into the midst of a list when the linked scheme is being used. For example, to insert an item 2.5 into (1) we need to change only two links:

1 ⟹ 2 3 ⟹ 4 ⟹ 5 \ / ⟹ 2.5 ⟹

By comparison, this operation would be extremely time-consuming in a long sequential table.



Insertion and deletion in linked list are very efficient because, unlike arrays, they do not require realloc()/memcpy() after each modification.



45.1.1    Linked List Crippled by Hard-Coding



However, RMIT insisted on including a lineno field in each node (of the linked list).

This hard-coded lineno contained the position of the node in the list.

Meaning, that any modification of the list incurs a further (and tedious) linked-list traversal of all the following nodes in the list in order to update their respective lineno field.


/home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/a2part2/line.h
Released on Monday 03/02/2020 at 17:00

15 struct line 16 { 17 /* the current line number of this line in the text file */ 18 ssize_t lineno; 19 /* the text itself */ 20 char* text; 21 /* the length of the line. This is stored so we don't need to call 22 * strlen 23 * a whole bunch of times as each call to strlen involves traversing the 24 * line of text. 25 */ 26 ssize_t len; 27 };




For example, if you have a 5-lines long file, and you add a line at the beginning, you will have to traverse all the following nodes in order to increment their lineno (by the number of lines added at the top).

Now, imagine files with 100,000s of lines, and you insert/delete lines at the top of the file.


45.2    Insertion in RMIT's cpt220_ed



45.2.1    Case Study: Insertion at Line 0 for a 5-Lines Long File



This example illustrates the insert command in cpt220_ed. Note how after inserting a new line, cpt220_ed traverses all the nodes that follow this newly inserted node in order to fix their lineno field.

RMIT implemented the above via a loop in linkedlist.c.

• The loop contains 10 instructions. • Its source code is lines 120 to 123. • And the compiled code start at 0x4025f8 with the last one at 0x40261a.

45.3    Comparison of RMIT's and Student's Code



Compare the "approved" solution (that relies heavily on the lineno field) to the student's solution (where the lineno field was never used).


45.3.1    RMIT's Code



/home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/a2part2/linkedlist.c
Released on Monday 03/02/2020 at 17:00

56 /** 57 * adds the newline parameter to the offset specified by the insert_offset. It 58 * is assumed that newline has been separately malloced and it is not a 59 * stack address as then the behaviour of this list is undefined. 60 **/ 61 BOOLEAN linkedlist_add(struct linkedlist* thelist, struct line* newline, 62 ssize_t insert_offset) 63 { 64 ssize_t count; 65 struct linkednode* newnode = new_node(newline); 66 struct linkednode* current = thelist->head; 67 struct linkednode* prev = NULL; 68 69 /* verify that creation of the node succeeded */ 70 if (!newnode) 71 { 72 return FALSE; 73 } 74 /* check that there is no out of bounds inserts */ 75 if (!current) 76 { 77 if (insert_offset != 0) 78 { 79 fprintf(stderr, "Error: invalid offset requested.\n"); 80 } 81 thelist->head = newnode; 82 ++thelist->size; 83 return TRUE; 84 } 85 /* find the insertion position in the list */ 86 for (count = 0; count < insert_offset; ++count) 87 { 88 assert(current->data->lineno == count + 1); 89 prev = current; 90 current = current->next; 91 } 92 /* check the insert offset matches the expected line number */ 93 if (current) 94 { 95 assert(current->data->lineno == insert_offset + 1); 96 } 97 /* insert at the front of the list */ 98 if (!prev) 99 { 100 /* verify that an insertion at the front of the list was indeed 101 * requested */ 102 if (insert_offset != 0) 103 { 104 fprintf(stderr, 105 "Error: attempt to insert at the head when the " 106 "requested offset is not 0.\n"); 107 return FALSE; 108 } 109 newnode->next = thelist->head; 110 thelist->head = newnode; 111 } 112 else 113 { 114 /* insert somewhere else in the list */ 115 prev->next = newnode; 116 newnode->next = current; 117 } 118 ++thelist->size; 119 /* renumber all lines from this point forward */ 120 for (; current; current = current->next) 121 { 122 ++current->data->lineno; 123 } 124 return TRUE; 125 }




45.3.2    Student's Code



./linkedlist.c (Assignment 2 Part 2 – Submitted by student on Sun 29/01/2020 17:01)
Note how 'lineno' is unused (in my implementation)

30 /* link in new line, and advance the caller's cursor to added line */ 31 /* @ppp is a pointer to the local cursor in the caller function. */ 32 static void link(struct linkednode ***ppp, struct linkednode *node) 33 { 34 struct linkednode **pp = *ppp; 35 struct linkednode *next = *pp; 36 37 /* TODO: Remove this assert, 38 * if (or when) we have to support the insert command. 39 */ 40 assert(next == NULL); 41 node->next = next; 42 *pp = node; 43 *ppp = &node->next; 44 } 45 46 /* buffer implemented as linked list. read @fname. */ 47 BOOLEAN linkedlist_load(const char fname[], struct linkedlist *head) 48 { 49 char buf[BUFSIZ + 2]; 50 FILE *f; 51 ssize_t i = 0; 52 struct linkednode **pp = &head->head; 53 if ((f = fopen(fname, "r")) == NULL) { 54 FATAL("fopen()"); 55 } 56 while (getline(buf, sizeof buf, f) == TRUE) { 57 /* First line is 1. */ 58 struct linkednode *node; 59 i++; 60 node = string_to_node(buf, i); 61 link(&pp, node); 62 head->size++; 63 } 64 /* A little awkward. To be revisited in part 3. */ 65 if (feof(f)) { 66 printf("successfully loaded %s\n", fname); 67 return TRUE; 68 } 69 /* TODO: Painful state here, as we possibly loaded only some lines. 70 Should we clean up? terminate? abort? 71 Left to part 3. 72 */ 73 return FALSE; 74 }




45.3.3    Student's Rationale in readme.txt



My readme.txt reads:

readme.txt – Assignment 2(C)
Submitted by student on Wednesday 12/02/2020 at 19:27

9 1) @lineno field in struct line, never used. C done right.




45.3.4    Student's Rationale in Discussion Board



I also rationalized my implementation on the Discussion Board.

Discussion Board; Monday 27/01/2020 9:01 AM

Treating linked-list as arrays is unforgivable.

Linked lists are very officiant for dynamic resizing, as there is no remalloc() or memcpy(), only linking and unlinking.

Linked lists are the basis behind the vast majority of algorithms.

Take self-balancing trees, like red-black trees. What is it if not a linked-list.

But if you will treat them as arrays by hardcoding in the nodes their static location (Who does that? Mixing arrays semantics in linked list?), then you have reduced them to garbage.

In your list, on every insert, let's say, I add a line numberd #500, out of #1000 lines.

That means, that after i insert the line #500, I have to traverse all the lines from #501 to #10001, and increment their hardcoded lineno field.

Now imagine with your example file, with 100,000 lines.

With so many writes, your cache-miss penalty skyrockets exponentially, and whatever sophisticated machine you have, will fail.

I stress again, this has nothing to do with linked list.

You traverse a linked list, and instead of their implicit location in the list, you check every node to "discover" their hard-coded "lineno" field. Really? Nobody, does that.

Of course, if you are trying to travel by a car, but instead of using the engine, you try to push the car by hand, it will take you weeks to crawl out from your suburb.

Why would anybody expect differently in algorithm design?




45.4    RMIT's Lie



Since I did not resort to the (superfluous and harmful) lineno field, RMIT ruled that "linked list operations" were "not implemented".


In reality, my implementation was 100% compatible with the "approved" one, including the linked-list operations of adding and saving.

The only difference was that my implementation loaded a file in a split second.

Unlike the 14 minutes and 22.5 seconds of the "approved" solution.







Chapter 46
— Assignment 2(C)
— Initialization





46.1    Introduction



46.1.1    Enumeration Constants



One of the data types in C is enumeration-constants.

You can use them to replace hard-coded integer variables (or integer literals) in your code.


The values represented by the enumeration constants are not set in stone, as they may change during the development cycle.

But this is a good thing.

In fact, this is what you want and need when writing maintainable code.


C has other constants variants (including: constant variables or macros expanding to literal constants), but enumeration-constants have the benefit of relating all of the associated constants under a unifying enum structure.

This has a twofold advantage.

  • First, each one of them is (mostly) guaranteed to be unique in the context of the enum.
  • Second, compilers can take a cue from the enum definition to issue a warning if you forgot to account for one of its constituent constants in a switch statement (in GCC, for example, -Wswitch / -Wswitch-enum).



46.1.2    Menu Represented by Enumeration Constants



Imagine developing a menu of different options for some program.

This can be implemented via enumeration-constants where each option is assigned (internally) a unique constant.


One day, you may add another option to the menu.

Let's say you insert it somewhere in-between all the other enumeration-constants of the enum.

Consequently, the value of following enumeration-constants would change (and increase by one).


Does it break your code?

No.

Because you never made any assumption regarding their real values (nowhere) in your program.

They were merely referenced by their identifiers.

Their (actual) values, however, were only implied and not explicitly specified.


46.2    Array Initialization



46.2.1    Commands as Enumeration Constants



In assignment 2, we were asked to develop a text editor.

As part of the instructions, we were introduced to a menu of "actions" associated with the editor.

The actions (also known as 'commands') were: edit, delete, search, etc.

Their data type was enum action_type (AT for short).


action.h (Student's Submission)
Submitted by student on Wednesday 12/02/2020 at 19:27

16 enum action_type { 17 AT_UNDEFINED = -1, 18 AT_HELP, 19 AT_LOAD, 20 AT_INSERT, 21 AT_DELETE, 22 AT_SEARCH, 23 AT_REPLACE, 24 AT_PRINT, 25 AT_THROW, 26 AT_SAVE, 27 AT_QUIT 28 };




If you need any reminder, enumeration-constants are auto-incremented by a value of 1.

Thus: AT_UNDEFINED is (appropriately) given an "illegal" value of -1.

Then, AT_HELP has a value of 0.

The following AT_LOAD, then, has a value of 1.

The next one will have a value of 2.

And so on.


This is how I initialized the array (assigning function pointers to the actions).

action.c (Student's Submission)
Submitted by student on Wednesday 12/02/2020 at 19:27

22 void init_action_array(actionfunc f[]) 23 { 24 f[AT_HELP] = &do_help; 25 f[AT_LOAD] = &do_load; 26 f[AT_INSERT] = &do_insert; 27 f[AT_DELETE] = &do_delete; 28 f[AT_SEARCH] = &do_search; 29 f[AT_REPLACE] = &do_replace; 30 f[AT_PRINT] = &do_print; 31 f[AT_THROW] = &do_throw; 32 f[AT_SAVE] = &do_save; 33 f[AT_QUIT] = &do_quit; 34 }




46.2.2    Inexplicable Penalty



RMIT told me that I lost 25% of my marking points.

"This will not scale so easily", RMIT scolded me.

You had to "create" a "local array", "initialize" it, and then "use memcpy()".


Results: Assignment 2(C)
Sent on Thursday 16/04/2020 at 22:36

Requirement 2: Initialise the function array to have it work correctly (4 Marks) ---------------------------------------------------------------------------- Mark: 3 Comments: Good – Menu is not initialised in a maintainable way (3 Marks) this will not scale so easily. A better approach would be to create a local array and initialise that and then use memcpy to copy that the 'f'.




I will give you a million dollars if you tell me what the hell RMIT is talking about.


46.2.3    Array Initialization by RMIT



This is how RMIT actually initialized the array.

/home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a1/a1partb/menu.c
Released on Sun 29/12/2019 22:41

45 void init_menu(char menu[NUM_MENU_ITEMS][SCREENWIDTH + 1]) 46 { 47 char menu_template[NUM_MENU_ITEMS][SCREENWIDTH + 1] = { 48 "reverse a string", "play guess a number", 49 "fold a string", "validate tictactoe winner", 50 "check if change can be given", "access the help menu", 51 "quit the program" 52 }; 53 memcpy(menu, menu_template, sizeof(menu_template)); 54 }




You see, RMIT initialized the array in a "maintainable" way because they created "a local array" and "used memcpy()" to copy its contents.

Seriously, what the hell is wrong with them?


RMIT assumed that because they didn't hard-code the actual value of the enumeration-constants, the code somehow became maintainable.

However, note that their code is completely dependent on the current order of the enumeration constants (in their associated enum definition), and as soon as you add another enumeration constant (to their enum), their program will be reduced to garbage.

— Insert for an Empty File

Yet, RMIT threatened to inflict a penalty on any student who accepted this illegal command.

Hypocrisy?


47.1.2    Bold-Faced Lies



Wait, there is more.

RMIT told a lie about my assignment and hit me with a penalty.

However, my implementation was correct in all regards, namely: 1. It (graciously) rejected 'i0' (unlike cpt220_ed, which seg-faults). 2. It accepted 'i1' for an empty file.

In other words, the claim (by RMIT) that my editor "can't insert into an empty file" is a lie, for lack of a better word.

47.2    Using Line 0 for the Insert Command



47.2.1    Assignment Instructions



Assignment 2 part 3 instructions

I/i – invoke the insert functionality.

The format is:

I/i followed by a line number. The line number must be within the range of the file, that is, between 1 and the number of lines+1 already in the file. The program will then be put into insert mode. This should like (sic) like follows:

> i5 5: foo 6: bar 7: baz 8:

The insert mode is terminated by pressing ctrl-d at the beginning of a line. I don't want you to use [enter] here as a blank line is valid content for a file.




47.2.2    Line 0 in cpt220_ed



An example run of cpt220_ed with a command 'i0', which ultimately seg-faults

$ readelf -a /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed \ | grep 'Build ID' Build ID: 0f27b56d6523065e799b430313e3035c6b64b786

$ wc /tmp/empty_file 0 0 0 /tmp/empty_file

# The command is: 'i0', i.e. insert at line 0, which cpt220_ed "accepts", # but it seg-faults as soon as you enter the first line of input. $ /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed /tmp/empty_file > i0 0 : foo /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed: line.c:16: line_make: Assertion `lineno > 0' failed. Aborted




47.2.3    Student's Rationale in readme.txt



readme.txt – Assignment 2(C)
Submitted by student on Wednesday 12/02/2020 at 19:27

150 20) The sample program seg-faults on i0, but only after the first input on the following prompt. 151 Should rather, handle illegal input graciously.




47.2.4    Line 0 in ed



Gnu Ed Documentation

'(.)a' Appends text to the buffer after the addressed line, which may be the address '0' (zero). Text is entered in input mode. The current address is set to last line entered.

'(.)i' Inserts text in the buffer before the current line. The address '0' (zero) is valid for this command; it is equivalent to address '1'. Text is entered in input mode. The current address is set to the last line entered.




47.2.5    Line 0 in sed



Gnu Sed Documentation

'0a' does not work (gives an error)

There is no line 0. 0 is a special address that is only used to treat addresses like '0,/RE/' as active when the script starts: if you write '1,/abc/d' and the first line includes the word 'abc', then that match would be ignored because address ranges must span at least two lines (barring the end of the file); but what you probably wanted is to delete every line up to the first one including 'abc', and this is obtained with '0,/abc/d'.




47.2.6    Line 0 in RMIT's Test Files



'mytests/r5_insert_0_line_readme' (readme file for 'r5_insert_0_line_input')
Sent on Wednesday 13/05/2020 at 10:39

1 this test is designed to test what happens when line 0 is specified 2 as the start of insertion of text. This request should be rejected.




'mytests/r5_insert_0_line_input' (internal test file of RMIT)
Sent on Wednesday 13/05/2020 at 10:39

1 i0 2 q




47.2.7    Summary of Line Addresses Rules for the Insert Command in ed/cpt220_ed/sed/Vim



Using the line '0' address for the 'insert' command,
Or using the line '2' address for a file with only one line

ed cpt220_ed Sed Vim
Line '0' for an empty file, namely:
  • '0i' for ed/Vim/sed
  • 'i0' for cpt220_ed
 Valid Valid.
But
seg-faults soon!		 Error Valid
Line '1' for an empty file, namely:
  • '1i' for ed/Vim/sed
  • 'i1' for cpt220_ed
 Error Valid Not Valid Valid
Line '2' for a file w/ 1 line, namely:
  • '2i' for ed/Vim/sed
  • 'i2' for cpt220_ed
 Error Valid Not Valid Error








Chapter 48
— Assignment 2(C)
— Quit Without Saving





48.1    Summary



48.1.1    Universal Convention



Do you recognize the following?

⚠ Save changes before exit? Yes No Cancel




Here is an experiment.

Choose any text editor and use it to make changes to a file.

Then, try to exit.

You cannot.

Instead, you get a prompt asking if you want to save the changes first.


This is a universal convention.

And it is true for any editor on any platform.

Namely, instead of exiting unconditionally (which would discard all the unsaved edits), the editor seeks your explicit affirmation to either save the changes or delete them.


48.1.2    cpt220_ed Inspired by ed



This assignment, as noted, was inspired by the tradition of the ed text editor.

ed and its derivatives (including Vim) generally refuse to exit without first discarding/saving the edited file's changes.


48.1.3    Annoy the User



However, cpt220_ed (the program developed by RMIT) proceeds to exit, immediately, right after it warns the user about unsaved changes.

Now, what was the purpose of the warning?

It certainly did not help the user.

After all, the program, immediately, proceeded to exit and deleted all of his unsaved data without giving him a fair chance to recover.


You see, the editor could have been helpful by alerting the user that he would lose all of his hard work.

Instead, the editor deleted his data and taunts him: "discarding changes to file". Mwahahaha!


Super annoying.

And unhelpful.

Right?


48.1.4    Penalty for Following ed



To make matters worse, RMIT hit me with a penalty for opting not to exit without first asking the user if he wants to save/discard the changes.


48.1.5    Ambiguous Instructions



Wait, there is more.

The instructions were silent regarding this case, so it was only fair to follow in the footsteps of ed, the editor we were aiming to emulate.


48.1.6    RMIT Is Inconsistent



And there is more.

In a similar scenario but for the load command, cpt220_ed refuses to clobber the unsaved changes, and the command fails.


48.1.7    RMIT Does Not Bother to Read



And there is even more.

RMIT did not bother to read my assignment before they hit me with a penalty.

Had they done so, they would have seen my rationale for the above.

But tutors are not paid.

Hence, do not read.


48.2    Resources



48.2.1    Feedback

Sent on Thursday 16/04/2020 at 22:36

Requirement 10: Implement the throw away / discard command (2 Marks) -------------------------------------------------------------------- Mark: 1.5 Comments: Good (1.5 Marks) your message when exiting is not correct. It should just notify the user rather than refusing to quit.




48.2.2    Assignment Instructions



Extract from the instructions for this assignment
Note how the instructions are silent regarding unsaved changes whether it fails

Quit Program

This is invoked via q or Q as the start of a command.

Optional extra parts are w to save the current file and an optional file path after w to specify where to save it.




48.2.3    Student's Rationale in readme.txt



Extract from readme.txt – Assignment 2(C)
Submitted by student on Wednesday 12/02/2020 at 19:27

43 8) Quit command fails if buffer is modified. This is in line with any editor. 44 To allow quit a modified buffer – to pass through – by dumping an error message 45 that we are "discarding..", (like the sample program) is cheating the user 46 from a chance to fix it before the quit is finalized.




48.2.4    Quit Without Saving Changes in GNU ed



The Gnu Ed Manual

'q' Quits ed. A warning is printed if any changes have been made in the buffer since the last 'w' command that wrote the entire buffer to a file.

'Q' Quits ed unconditionally. This is similar to the 'q' command, except that unwritten changes are discarded without warning.




48.2.5    Quit Without Saving Changes in POSIX ed



Ed: The Open Group Base Specifications Issue 6: IEEE Std 1003.1, 2004 Edition

If changes have been made in the buffer since the last w command that wrote the entire buffer, ed shall warn the user if an attempt is made to destroy the editor buffer via the e or q commands.

The ed utility shall write the string: "?\n" (followed by an explanatory message if help mode has been enabled via the H command) to standard output and shall continue in command mode with the current line number unchanged.

If the e or q command is repeated with no intervening command, it shall take effect.




48.2.6    Quit Without Saving Changes in VIM



vim/runtime/doc/editing.txt:1088

1088 :q[uit] Quit the current window. Quit Vim if this is the last 1089 |edit-window|. This fails when changes have been made 1090 and Vim refuses to |abandon| the current buffer, and 1091 when the last file in the argument list has not been 1092 edited.




48.3    Refusing to Load Another File Before Discarding Changes



cpt220_ed refuses to load another file without first saving/discarding the old file's changes.

Trying to load a file without discarding (or saving) changes will get: "Error: cannot load over a modified file. Either save the file or discard it first."


As noted, in the same situation but for a quit command, cpt220_ed proceeded to exit immediately.

Consistency?


48.4    Exit on EOF



RMIT made two unsavoury choices regarding insert and exit.

As a result, it was impossible to test (or investigate) the insert command while running in batch-mode.


Issuing the insert command gets you the input-prompt.

How do you terminate an input-prompt?

In ed, this is done by a line consisting of a single period ('.').

In cpt220_ed, however, this is only possible with EOF.

In other words, no command (not even the quit command) can follow the insert command in batch mode.


And to make matters worse, cpt220_ed does not exit on EOF.

Meaning, that even after seeing the EOF in its batch file, cpt220_ed loops forever and litters the terminal with gazillions of prompts asking the user for (impossible) further commands from stdin (that was redirected to read from that batch file).

Consequently, not only is it impossible to issue any command after the insert command in batch-mode, but the editor also refuses to exit and will, forever, prompt the user for further commands.


I had to rationalize in my readme.txt why my submission differed.

I also mentioned there how the documented behavior in ed was different.


48.4.1    EOF in ed



Ed: The Open Group Base Specifications Issue 6: IEEE Std 1003.1, 2004 Edition

If an end-of-file is detected on standard input:

If the ed utility is in input mode, ed shall terminate input mode and return to command mode.

It is unspecified if any partially entered lines (that is, input text without a terminating <newline>) are discarded from the input text.

If the ed utility is in command mode, it shall act as if a q command had been entered.




48.4.2    Student's Rationale in readme.txt



Extract from 'readme.txt' of assignment 2(C)
submitted on Wednesday 12/02/2020 at 19:27

26 3) Program exits on EOF. 27 This solves the other infinite loops in the sample. 28 This follows the ed utility behaviour.




48.5    Summary



You see, even without all the countless bugs in RMIT's cpt220_ed, it was unreliable with its inconsistent (and insane) choices regarding exit and/or unsaved changed.

Namely: 1. It exits and permanently deletes unsaved changes. 2. It refuses to load a new file (less, unsaved changes of the old file would be lost). 3. It loops forever even after reading EOF and asks the user for (impossible) input.

— Saving an Empty File

RMIT claimed that my editor "refuses to save an empty file".

But it was false.

A complete fabrication without a grain of truth to it.


Wait, there is more.

It turns out, the opposite is true.

Namely, it was rather their editor (cpt220_ed) that was lacking in this regard.


RMIT has zero integrity.

49.2.2    Confusing Feedback



"minor problems in your implementation such as valgrind" strongly implies that there was a Valgrind error.

There were none, rest assured. I double-checked the logs of RMIT-run tests.

This is just an unfortunate "feature" of the drop-down list in the grading software, this robotic marker was choosing from.

The second option (on that drop-down list) was: "minor problems [...] such as vlagrind [...]".

A bit confusing, but this is the least of my issues with RMIT.


49.2.3    Case Study: Saving an Empty File in the Student's Program



Simple test demonstrating that empty files CAN be saved

# This is the compiled version (of my source code) RMIT used for all the tests in the assignment. $ readelf -a student_submission/cpt220_ed | grep 'Build ID' Build ID: a97cf4506485514308efd07905e00fdbd97d47de

# '/tmp/x' before any edit took place $ cat /tmp/x foo bar baz

# There are 4 commands here. # 1. l(oad), i.e. edit the file '/tmp/x' # 2. d(elete) ALL the lines. cpt220_ed, by default, operates on ALL lines. # 3. s(ave) the file. # 4. q(uit). $ student_submission/cpt220_ed <<\eof > l /tmp/x > d > s > q > eof > Successfully loaded /tmp/x > > Successfully saved /tmp/x >

# '/tmp/x' is now empty. # This proves that empty files can be saved in the student's editor. $ wc /tmp/x 0 0 0 /tmp/x









Chapter 50
— Assignment 2(C)
— Example Files





Note: This chapter is an introduction to the next chapter; it is also referenced here.



50.1    Summary



The second assignment was to develop a text editor.

RMIT provided example files in the /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/testfiles/ directory.

Students had to demonstrate successful editing of all the example files using their developed editors.


50.2    List of Example Files



There were 13 files.

However, some of them were virtually duplicates and differed only in their permission mode or in their formatting (namely, long lines vs. folded ones).


The following is a list of the 13 example files (ordered by size in increasing-order):

  1. Ibid (unfolded, 22 lines, 10,200 bytes) — by H. P. Lovecraft.
    1. File name: ibid.
  2. Ibid (folded, 147 lines, 10,325 bytes) — by H. P. Lovecraft.
    1. File name: ibid_folded.
  3. The Other Gods (unfolded, 25 lines, 11,050 bytes) — by H. P. Lovecraft.
    1. File name: othergods.
  4. The Other Gods (folded, 153 lines, 11,178 bytes) — by H. P. Lovecraft.
    1. File name: othergods_folded.
  5. From Beyond (unfolded, 22 lines, 17,295 bytes) — by H. P. Lovecraft.
    1. File name: frombeyond.
  6. From Beyond (folded, 237 lines, 17,510 bytes) — by H. P. Lovecraft.
    1. File name: frombeyond_folded.
  7. Unnamable (unfolded, 32 lines, 17,322 bytes) — by H. P. Lovecraft.
    1. File name: unnamable.
  8. Unnamable (unfolded & readonly, 32 lines, 17,322 bytes, mode 0444) — by H. P. Lovecraft.
    1. File name: unnamable_readonly.
  9. Unnamable (folded, 239 lines, 17,529 bytes) — by H. P. Lovecraft.
    1. File name: unnamable_folded.
  10. The Astounding Stories of Super-Science (12,902 lines, 538,285 bytes) – by Various.
    1. File name: pg28617.txt; p[roject] g[utenberg] #28617 (http://www.gutenberg.org/2/8/6/1/28617/).
  11. The King James Bible (unfolded, 1 line, 4,352,284 bytes).
    1. File name: pg10long.txt; p[roject] g[utenberg] #10 (http://www.gutenberg.org/1/10/).
    2. 'long', meaning it was unfolded.
  12. The King James Bible (folded, 100,231 lines, 4,352,285 bytes).
    1. File name: pg10.txt; p[roject] g[utenberg] #10 (http://www.gutenberg.org/1/10/).
  13. big.txt ("big". 128,457 lines, 6,488,666 bytes).



50.2.1    Example File 'big.txt'



File big.txt is a compilation of 6 books.

The first 4 books were quoted verbatim (including: full license, prologue, epilogue, etc.) from Project Gutenberg (linked, for each book, in next section).

The 5th book is a list of the 6,318 most common words in the English language based on the British National Corpus.

The 6th book is a list of the 10,000 most common words in the English language based on Project Gutenberg as of 04/2006.


  1. The Adventures of Sherlock Holmes — by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle.
    1. Lines 1 — 5,499 in /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/testfiles/big.txt.
  2. The History of the United States — by Charles A. Beard and Mary R. Beard.
    1. Lines 5,503 — 29,920 in /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/testfiles/big.txt.
  3. Manual of Surgery — by Alexis Thomson and Alexander Miles.
    1. Lines 29,921 — 54,263 in /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/testfiles/big.txt.
  4. War and Peace — by Leo Tolstoy.
    1. Lines 54,265 — 121,706 in /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/testfiles/big.txt.
  5. 6,318 Most Frequent Words — (800+ occurrences in the British National Corpus) — by Adam Kilgarriff.
    1. Lines 121,708 — 128,025 in /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/testfiles/big.txt.
  6. 10,000 Most Frequent Words — based on Project Gutenberg (04/2006)
    1. Lines 128,027 — 128,444 in /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/testfiles/big.txt



The beginning of each of those 6 books is quoted in the following section.

Emphasis was added at the start of each partially-quoted book (book 1, book 2, book 3, book 4, book 5, and book 6).


Extracts from '/home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/testfiles/big.txt'

A Scandal in Bohemia 59 II. The Red-Headed League 60 III. A Case of Identity 61 IV. The Boscombe Valley Mystery 62 V. The Five Orange Pips 63 VI. The Man with the Twisted Lip 64 VII. The Adventure of the Blue Carbuncle 65 VIII. The Adventure of the Speckled Band 66 IX. The Adventure of the Engineer's Thumb 67 X. The Adventure of the Noble Bachelor 68 XI. The Adventure of the Beryl Coronet 69 XII. The Adventure of the Copper Beeches
