5503 The Project Gutenberg EBook of History of the United States 5504 by Charles A. Beard and Mary R. Beard 5505 5506 This eBook is for the use of anyone anywhere at no cost and with 5507 almost no restrictions whatsoever. You may copy it, give it away or 5508 re-use it under the terms of the Project Gutenberg License included 5509 with this eBook or online at www.gutenberg.net 5510 5511 5512 Title: History of the United States 5513 5514 Author: Charles A. Beard and Mary R. Beard 5515 5516 Release Date: October 28, 2005 [EBook #16960] 5517 5518 Language: English 5519 5520 Character set encoding: ISO-8859-1 5521 5522 *** START OF THIS PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK HISTORY OF THE UNITED STATES *** 5523 5524 5525 5526 5527 Produced by Curtis Weyant, M and the Online Distributed 5528 Proofreading Team at http://www.pgdp.net 5529 5530 5531 5532 5533 5534 5535 5536 HISTORY 5537 5538 OF THE 5539 5540 UNITED STATES 5541 5542 5543 BY 5544 5545 5546 CHARLES A. BEARD 5547 5548 AND 5549 5550 MARY R. BEARD 5551 5552 5553 5554 New York 5555 5556 THE MACMILLAN COMPANY 5557 5558 1921 5559 5560 _All rights reserved_ 5561 5562 COPYRIGHT, 1921, 5563 5564 BY THE MACMILLAN COMPANY. 5565 5566 5567 Set up and electrotyped. Published March, 1921. 5568 5569 5570 5571 5572 Norwood Press 5573 5574 J.S. Cushing Co.--Berwick & Smith Co. 5575 5576 NORWOOD, MASS., U.S.A. 5577 5578 5579 5580 5581 PREFACE 5582 5583 5584 As things now stand, the course of instruction in American history in 5585 our public schools embraces three distinct treatments of the subject. 5586 Three separate books are used. First, there is the primary book, which 5587 is usually a very condensed narrative with emphasis on biographies and 5588 anecdotes. Second, there is the advanced text for the seventh or eighth 5589 grade, generally speaking, an expansion of the elementary book by the 5590 addition of forty or fifty thousand words. Finally, there is the high 5591 school manual. This, too, ordinarily follows the beaten path, giving 5592 fuller accounts of the same events and characters. To put it bluntly, we 5593 do not assume that our children obtain permanent possessions from their 5594 study of history in the lower grades. If mathematicians followed the 5595 same method, high school texts on algebra and geometry would include the 5596 multiplication table and fractions. 5597 5598 There is, of course, a ready answer to the criticism advanced above. It 5599 is that teachers have learned from bitter experience how little history 5600 their pupils retain as they pass along the regular route. No teacher of 5601 history will deny this. Still it is a standing challenge to existing 5602 methods of historical instruction. If the study of history cannot be 5603 made truly progressive like the study of mathematics, science, and 5604 languages, then the historians assume a grave responsibility in adding 5605 their subject to the already overloaded curriculum. If the successive 5606 historical texts are only enlarged editions of the first text--more 5607 facts, more dates, more words--then history deserves most of the sharp 5608 criticism which it is receiving from teachers of science, civics, and 5609 economics. 5610 5611 In this condition of affairs we find our justification for offering a 5612 new high school text in American history. Our first contribution is one 5613 of omission. The time-honored stories of exploration and the 5614 biographies of heroes are left out. We frankly hold that, if pupils know 5615 little or nothing about Columbus, Cortes, Magellan, or Captain John 5616 Smith by the time they reach the high school, it is useless to tell the 5617 same stories for perhaps the fourth time. It is worse than useless. It 5618 is an offense against the teachers of those subjects that are 5619 demonstrated to be progressive in character. 5620 5621 In the next place we have omitted all descriptions of battles. Our 5622 reasons for this are simple. The strategy of a campaign or of a single 5623 battle is a highly technical, and usually a highly controversial, matter 5624 about which experts differ widely. In the field of military and naval 5625 operations most writers and teachers of history are mere novices. To 5626 dispose of Gettysburg or the Wilderness in ten lines or ten pages is 5627 equally absurd to the serious student of military affairs. Any one who 5628 compares the ordinary textbook account of a single Civil War campaign 5629 with the account given by Ropes, for instance, will ask for no further 5630 comment. No youth called upon to serve our country in arms would think 5631 of turning to a high school manual for information about the art of 5632 warfare. The dramatic scene or episode, so useful in arousing the 5633 interest of the immature pupil, seems out of place in a book that 5634 deliberately appeals to boys and girls on the very threshold of life's 5635 serious responsibilities. 5636 5637 It is not upon negative features, however, that we rest our case. It is 5638 rather upon constructive features. 5639 5640 _First._ We have written a topical, not a narrative, history. We have 5641 tried to set forth the important aspects, problems, and movements of 5642 each period, bringing in the narrative rather by way of illustration. 5643 5644 _Second._ We have emphasized those historical topics which help to 5645 explain how our nation has come to be what it is to-day. 5646 5647 _Third._ We have dwelt fully upon the social and economic aspects of our 5648 history, especially in relation to the politics of each period. 5649 5650 _Fourth._ We have treated the causes and results of wars, the problems 5651 of financing and sustaining armed forces, rather than military strategy. 5652 These are the subjects which belong to a history for civilians. These 5653 are matters which civilians can understand--matters which they must 5654 understand, if they are to play well their part in war and peace. 5655 5656 _Fifth._ By omitting the period of exploration, we have been able to 5657 enlarge the treatment of our own time. We have given special attention 5658 to the history of those current questions which must form the subject 5659 matter of sound instruction in citizenship. 5660 5661 _Sixth._ We have borne in mind that America, with all her unique 5662 characteristics, is a part of a general civilization. Accordingly we 5663 have given diplomacy, foreign affairs, world relations, and the 5664 reciprocal influences of nations their appropriate place. 5665 5666 _Seventh._ We have deliberately aimed at standards of maturity. The 5667 study of a mere narrative calls mainly for the use of the memory. We 5668 have aimed to stimulate habits of analysis, comparison, association, 5669 reflection, and generalization--habits calculated to enlarge as well as 5670 inform the mind. We have been at great pains to make our text clear, 5671 simple, and direct; but we have earnestly sought to stretch the 5672 intellects of our readers--to put them upon their mettle. Most of them 5673 will receive the last of their formal instruction in the high school. 5674 The world will soon expect maturity from them. Their achievements will 5675 depend upon the possession of other powers than memory alone. The 5676 effectiveness of their citizenship in our republic will be measured by 5677 the excellence of their judgment as well as the fullness of their 5678 information. 5679 5680 C.A.B. 5681 M.R.B. 5682 5683 NEW YORK CITY, 5684 February 8, 1921.

[...]

Some may yet have 30029 to be unlearned, and others have but little bearing on the problems 30030 presented to the civilian surgeon. Save in its broadest principles, the 30031 surgery of warfare is a thing apart from the general surgery of civil 30032 life, and the exhaustive literature now available on every aspect of it 30033 makes it unnecessary that it should receive detailed consideration in a 30034 manual for students. In preparing this new edition, therefore, we have 30035 endeavoured to incorporate only such additions to our knowledge and 30036 resources as our experience leads us to believe will prove of permanent 30037 value in civil practice. 30038 30039 For the rest, the text has been revised, condensed, and in places 30040 rearranged; a number of old illustrations have been discarded, and a 30041 greater number of new ones added. Descriptions of operative procedures 30042 have been omitted from the _Manual_, as they are to be found in the 30043 companion volume on _Operative Surgery_, the third edition of which 30044 appeared some months ago. 30045 30046 We have retained the Basle anatomical nomenclature, as extended 30047 experience has confirmed our preference for it. For the convenience of 30048 readers who still employ the old terms, these are given in brackets 30049 after the new. 30050 30051 This edition of the _Manual_ appears in three volumes; the first being 30052 devoted to General Surgery, the other two to Regional Surgery. This 30053 arrangement has enabled us to deal in a more consecutive manner than 30054 hitherto with the surgery of the Extremities, including Fractures and 30055 Dislocations. 30056 30057 We have once more to express our thanks to colleagues in the Edinburgh 30058 School and to other friends for aiding us in providing new 30059 illustrations, and for other valuable help, as well as to our publishers 30060 for their generosity in the matter of illustrations. 30061 30062 EDINBURGH, 30063 _March_ 1921. 30064 30065 30066 30067 30068 CONTENTS 30069 30070 30071 PAGE 30072 CHAPTER I 30073 REPAIR 1 30074 30075 CHAPTER II 30076 CONDITIONS WHICH INTERFERE WITH REPAIR 17 30077 30078 CHAPTER III 30079 INFLAMMATION 31 30080 30081 CHAPTER IV 30082 SUPPURATION 45 30083 30084 CHAPTER V 30085 ULCERATION AND ULCERS 68 30086 30087 CHAPTER VI 30088 GANGRENE 86 30089 30090 CHAPTER VII 30091 BACTERIAL AND OTHER WOUND INFECTIONS 107 30092 30093 CHAPTER VIII 30094 TUBERCULOSIS 133 30095 30096 CHAPTER IX 30097 SYPHILIS 146 30098 30099 CHAPTER X 30100 TUMOURS 181 30101 30102 CHAPTER XI 30103 INJURIES 218 30104 30105 CHAPTER XII 30106 METHODS OF WOUND TREATMENT 241 30107 30108 CHAPTER XIII 30109 CONSTITUTIONAL EFFECTS OF INJURIES 249 30110 30111 CHAPTER XIV 30112 THE BLOOD VESSELS 258 30113 30114 CHAPTER XV 30115 THE LYMPH VESSELS AND GLANDS 321 30116 30117 CHAPTER XVI 30118 THE NERVES 342 30119 30120 CHAPTER XVII 30121 SKIN AND SUBCUTANEOUS TISSUES 376 30122 30123 CHAPTER XVIII 30124 THE MUSCLES, TENDONS, AND TENDON SHEATHS 405 30125 30126 CHAPTER XIX 30127 THE BURSAE 426 30128 30129 CHAPTER XX 30130 DISEASES OF BONE 434 30131 30132 CHAPTER XXI 30133 DISEASES OF JOINTS 501 30134 30135 INDEX 547

54265 The Project Gutenberg EBook of War and Peace, by Leo Tolstoy 54266 (#9 in our series by Leo Tolstoy) 54267 54268 Copyright laws are changing all over the world. Be sure to check the 54269 copyright laws for your country before downloading or redistributing 54270 this or any other Project Gutenberg eBook. 54271 54272 This header should be the first thing seen when viewing this Project 54273 Gutenberg file. Please do not remove it. Do not change or edit the 54274 header without written permission. 54275 54276 Please read the "legal small print," and other information about the 54277 eBook and Project Gutenberg at the bottom of this file. Included is 54278 important information about your specific rights and restrictions in 54279 how the file may be used. You can also find out about how to make a 54280 donation to Project Gutenberg, and how to get involved. 54281 54282 54283 **Welcome To The World of Free Plain Vanilla Electronic Texts** 54284 54285 **eBooks Readable By Both Humans and By Computers, Since 1971** 54286 54287 *****These eBooks Were Prepared By Thousands of Volunteers!***** 54288 54289 54290 Title: War and Peace 54291 54292 Author: Leo Tolstoy 54293 54294 Translator: Louise and Aylmer Maude 54295 54296 Release Date: April, 2001 [EBook #2600] 54297 [This file was first posted on October 7, 2003] 54298 [Most recently updated: May 21, 2006] 54299 54300 Edition: 11 54301 54302 Language: English 54303 54304 Character set encoding: US-ASCII 54305 54306 *** START OF THE PROJECT GUTENBERG EBOOK, WAR AND PEACE *** 54307 54308 54309 54310 54311 54312 54313 54314 54315 54316 54317 War and Peace 54318 54319 by Leo Tolstoy/Tolstoi 54320 54321 54322 54323 54324 BOOK ONE: 1805 54325 54326 54327 54328 54329 CHAPTER I 54330 54331 54332 "Well, Prince, so Genoa and Lucca are now just family estates of the 54333 Buonapartes. But I warn you, if you don't tell me that this means war, 54334 if you still try to defend the infamies and horrors perpetrated by 54335 that Antichrist--I really believe he is Antichrist--I will have 54336 nothing more to do with you and you are no longer my friend, no longer 54337 my 'faithful slave,' as you call yourself! But how do you do? I see 54338 I have frightened you--sit down and tell me all the news." 54339 54340 It was in July, 1805, and the speaker was the well-known Anna 54341 Pavlovna Scherer, maid of honor and favorite of the Empress Marya 54342 Fedorovna. With these words she greeted Prince Vasili Kuragin, a man 54343 of high rank and importance, who was the first to arrive at her 54344 reception. Anna Pavlovna had had a cough for some days. She was, as 54345 she said, suffering from la grippe; grippe being then a new word in 54346 St. Petersburg, used only by the elite. 54347 54348 All her invitations without exception, written in French, and 54349 delivered by a scarlet-liveried footman that morning, ran as follows: 54350 54351 "If you have nothing better to do, Count [or Prince], and if the 54352 prospect of spending an evening with a poor invalid is not too 54353 terrible, I shall be very charmed to see you tonight between 7 and 10- 54354 Annette Scherer." 54355 54356 "Heavens! what a virulent attack!" replied the prince, not in the 54357 least disconcerted by this reception. He had just entered, wearing 54358 an embroidered court uniform, knee breeches, and shoes, and had 54359 stars on his breast and a serene expression on his flat face. He spoke 54360 in that refined French in which our grandfathers not only spoke but 54361 thought, and with the gentle, patronizing intonation natural to a 54362 man of importance who had grown old in society and at court. He went 54363 up to Anna Pavlovna, kissed her hand, presenting to her his bald, 54364 scented, and shining head, and complacently seated himself on the 54365 sofa. 54366 54367 "First of all, dear friend, tell me how you are. Set your friend's 54368 mind at rest," said he without altering his tone, beneath the 54369 politeness and affected sympathy of which indifference and even 54370 irony could be discerned. 54371 54372 "Can one be well while suffering morally? Can one be calm in times 54373 like these if one has any feeling?" said Anna Pavlovna. "You are 54374 staying the whole evening, I hope?" 54375 54376 "And the fete at the English ambassador's? Today is Wednesday. I 54377 must put in an appearance there," said the prince. "My daughter is 54378 coming for me to take me there." 54379 54380 "I thought today's fete had been canceled. I confess all these 54381 festivities and fireworks are becoming wearisome." 54382 54383 "If they had known that you wished it, the entertainment would 54384 have been put off," said the prince, who, like a wound-up clock, by 54385 force of habit said things he did not even wish to be believed. 54386 54387 "Don't tease! Well, and what has been decided about Novosiltsev's 54388 dispatch? You know everything." 54389 54390 "What can one say about it?" replied the prince in a cold, 54391 listless tone. "What has been decided? They have decided that 54392 Buonaparte has burnt his boats, and I believe that we are ready to 54393 burn ours." 54394 54395 Prince Vasili always spoke languidly, like an actor repeating a 54396 stale part. Anna Pavlovna Scherer on the contrary, despite her forty 54397 years, overflowed with animation and impulsiveness. To be an 54398 enthusiast had become her social vocation and, sometimes even when she 54399 did not feel like it, she became enthusiastic in order not to 54400 disappoint the expectations of those who knew her. The subdued smile 54401 which, though it did not suit her faded features, always played 54402 round her lips expressed, as in a spoiled child, a continual 54403 consciousness of her charming defect, which she neither wished, nor 54404 could, nor considered it necessary, to correct. 54405 54406 In the midst of a conversation on political matters Anna Pavlovna 54407 burst out: 54408 54409 "Oh, don't speak to me of Austria. Perhaps I don't understand 54410 things, but Austria never has wished, and does not wish, for war. 54411 She is betraying us! Russia alone must save Europe. Our gracious 54412 sovereign recognizes his high vocation and will be true to it. That is 54413 the one thing I have faith in! Our good and wonderful sovereign has to 54414 perform the noblest role on earth, and he is so virtuous and noble 54415 that God will not forsake him. He will fulfill his vocation and 54416 crush the hydra of revolution, which has become more terrible than 54417 ever in the person of this murderer and villain! We alone must 54418 avenge the blood of the just one.... Whom, I ask you, can we rely 54419 on?... England with her commercial spirit will not and cannot 54420 understand the Emperor Alexander's loftiness of soul. She has 54421 refused to evacuate Malta. She wanted to find, and still seeks, some 54422 secret motive in our actions. What answer did Novosiltsev get? None. 54423 The English have not understood and cannot understand the 54424 self-abnegation of our Emperor who wants nothing for himself, but only 54425 desires the good of mankind. And what have they promised? Nothing! And 54426 what little they have promised they will not perform! Prussia has 54427 always declared that Buonaparte is invincible, and that all Europe 54428 is powerless before him.... And I don't believe a word that Hardenburg 54429 says, or Haugwitz either. This famous Prussian neutrality is just a 54430 trap. I have faith only in God and the lofty destiny of our adored 54431 monarch. He will save Europe!" 54432 54433 She suddenly paused, smiling at her own impetuosity. 54434 54435 "I think," said the prince with a smile, "that if you had been 54436 sent instead of our dear Wintzingerode you would have captured the 54437 King of Prussia's consent by assault. You are so eloquent. Will you 54438 give me a cup of tea?" 54439 54440 "In a moment. A propos," she added, becoming calm again, "I am 54441 expecting two very interesting men tonight, le Vicomte de Mortemart, 54442 who is connected with the Montmorencys through the Rohans, one of 54443 the best French families. He is one of the genuine emigres, the good 54444 ones. And also the Abbe Morio. Do you know that profound thinker? He 54445 has been received by the Emperor. Had you heard?" 54446 54447 "I shall be delighted to meet them," said the prince. "But tell me," 54448 he added with studied carelessness as if it had only just occurred 54449 to him, though the question he was about to ask was the chief motive 54450 of his visit, "is it true that the Dowager Empress wants Baron Funke 54451 to be appointed first secretary at Vienna? The baron by all accounts 54452 is a poor creature." 54453 54454 Prince Vasili wished to obtain this post for his son, but others 54455 were trying through the Dowager Empress Marya Fedorovna to secure it 54456 for the baron. 54457 54458 Anna Pavlovna almost closed her eyes to indicate that neither she 54459 nor anyone else had a right to criticize what the Empress desired or 54460 was pleased with. 54461 54462 "Baron Funke has been recommended to the Dowager Empress by her 54463 sister," was all she said, in a dry and mournful tone. 54464 54465 As she named the Empress, Anna Pavlovna's face suddenly assumed an 54466 expression of profound and sincere devotion and respect mingled with 54467 sadness, and this occurred every time she mentioned her illustrious 54468 patroness. She added that Her Majesty had deigned to show Baron 54469 Funke beaucoup d'estime, and again her face clouded over with sadness. 54470 54471 The prince was silent and looked indifferent. But, with the 54472 womanly and courtierlike quickness and tact habitual to her, Anna 54473 Pavlovna wished both to rebuke him (for daring to speak he had done of 54474 a man recommended to the Empress) and at the same time to console him, 54475 so she said: 54476 54477 "Now about your family. Do you know that since your daughter came 54478 out everyone has been enraptured by her? They say she is amazingly 54479 beautiful." 54480 54481 The prince bowed to signify his respect and gratitude. 54482 54483 "I often think," she continued after a short pause, drawing nearer 54484 to the prince and smiling amiably at him as if to show that 54485 political and social topics were ended and the time had come for 54486 intimate conversation--"I often think how unfairly sometimes the 54487 joys of life are distributed. Why has fate given you two such splendid 54488 children? I don't speak of Anatole, your youngest. I don't like 54489 him," she added in a tone admitting of no rejoinder and raising her 54490 eyebrows. "Two such charming children. And really you appreciate 54491 them less than anyone, and so you don't deserve to have them." 54492 54493 And she smiled her ecstatic smile. 54494 54495 "I can't help it," said the prince. "Lavater would have said I 54496 lack the bump of paternity." 54497 54498 "Don't joke; I mean to have a serious talk with you. Do you know I 54499 am dissatisfied with your younger son? Between ourselves" (and her 54500 face assumed its melancholy expression), "he was mentioned at Her 54501 Majesty's and you were pitied...." 54502 54503 The prince answered nothing, but she looked at him significantly, 54504 awaiting a reply. He frowned. 54505 54506 "What would you have me do?" he said at last. "You know I did all 54507 a father could for their education, and they have both turned out 54508 fools. Hippolyte is at least a quiet fool, but Anatole is an active 54509 one. That is the only difference between them." He said this smiling 54510 in a way more natural and animated than usual, so that the wrinkles 54511 round his mouth very clearly revealed something unexpectedly coarse 54512 and unpleasant. 54513 54514 "And why are children born to such men as you? If you were not a 54515 father there would be nothing I could reproach you with," said Anna 54516 Pavlovna, looking up pensively. 54517 54518 "I am your faithful slave and to you alone I can confess that my 54519 children are the bane of my life. It is the cross I have to bear. That 54520 is how I explain it to myself. It can't be helped!" 54521 54522 He said no more, but expressed his resignation to cruel fate by a 54523 gesture. Anna Pavlovna meditated. 54524 54525 "Have you never thought of marrying your prodigal son Anatole?" 54526 she asked. "They say old maids have a mania for matchmaking, and 54527 though I don't feel that weakness in myself as yet, I know a little 54528 person who is very unhappy with her father. She is a relation of 54529 yours, Princess Mary Bolkonskaya." 54530 54531 Prince Vasili did not reply, though, with the quickness of memory 54532 and perception befitting a man of the world, he indicated by a 54533 movement of the head that he was considering this information. 54534 54535 "Do you know," he said at last, evidently unable to check the sad 54536 current of his thoughts, "that Anatole is costing me forty thousand 54537 rubles a year? And," he went on after a pause, "what will it be in 54538 five years, if he goes on like this?" Presently he added: "That's what 54539 we fathers have to put up with.... Is this princess of yours rich?" 54540 54541 "Her father is very rich and stingy. He lives in the country. He 54542 is the well-known Prince Bolkonski who had to retire from the army 54543 under the late Emperor, and was nicknamed 'the King of Prussia.' He is 54544 very clever but eccentric, and a bore. The poor girl is very 54545 unhappy. She has a brother; I think you know him, he married Lise 54546 Meinen lately. He is an aide-de-camp of Kutuzov's and will be here 54547 tonight." 54548 54549 "Listen, dear Annette," said the prince, suddenly taking Anna 54550 Pavlovna's hand and for some reason drawing it downwards. "Arrange 54551 that affair for me and I shall always be your most devoted slave- 54552 slafe with an f, as a village elder of mine writes in his reports. 54553 She is rich and of good family and that's all I want." 54554 54555 And with the familiarity and easy grace peculiar to him, he raised 54556 the maid of honor's hand to his lips, kissed it, and swung it to and 54557 fro as he lay back in his armchair, looking in another direction. 54558 54559 "Attendez," said Anna Pavlovna, reflecting, "I'll speak to Lise, 54560 young Bolkonski's wife, this very evening, and perhaps the thing can 54561 be arranged. It shall be on your family's behalf that I'll start my 54562 apprenticeship as old maid."

Chapter 51
— Assignment 2(C)
— Memory Leak





51.1    Summary



This assignment was submitted on Wednesday 12/02/2020 at 19:27.

64 days later (on Thursday 16/04/2020 at 22:36), RMIT released its results.


They did not look good.


I was reprimanded for a gigantic memory leak.

RMIT claimed that my program caused a colossal memory leak of — wait for it — 11,755,745 bytes.

Again, 11 million, 755 thousand and 745 bytes.


Subsequent to their reprimand, RMIT hit me with a penalty.


I was disappointed and devastated.

I scratched my head trying to figure out what went wrong.

Scouring the source code, I frantically looked for the rouge (and unaccounted for) allocation that precipitated the leak but did not find any.

I even hypothesized a myriad of scenarios and put them to the test but came up with nothing.

On the contrary.

The more I searched, the more it became apparent that no leak was possible.


I had to wait until Wednesday 13/05/2020 at 10:39 (91 days after the assignment was submitted) to finally get access to the incriminating evidence.


Looking at their logs, I got the shock of my life.


It turns out, no leak ever occurred.

Not even one byte!

Zero. Zilch. Zip. Nada. Nothing.


Wait, there is more!

RMIT penalized me for their own error.


Meaning, RMIT misconfigured their servers.

As a result, programs (i.e. the tests used by RMIT) were crashing left and right.

And instead of inspecting the output (that clearly explained their own mistake), they opted to do the convenient thing and blamed the student behind his back.

Because RMIT's policy is to — secretly — blame its own mistakes on the students.


This is, exactly, what employees are turned into when you consistently steal their wages.

Lazy, deceitful and unscrupulous.

This is RMIT in a nutshell.


51.2    Wage Theft



51.2.1    Time Allocation per Assignment Grading



Tutors were paid for only a few minutes per each assignment grading.

The assignment grading included (at least, in theory):

  1. Compiling the submitted source code and dealing with compilation errors/warnings, if any.
  2. Executing 100+ tests under Valgrind running at a snail's pace.
  3. Inspect the logs of the aforementioned tests and investigate the root cause of unexpected/incompatible outputs.
  4. Provide tailor-made feedback for errors found.
  5. Inflict penalties for the above.
  6. Document and store all of the above in RMIT's filing system.
  7. Finally, send its summary to the student.



51.2.2    Number of Tests



The students had to submit their own test files.


67 tests were written by the student:

  1. delete/delete_0_input
  2. delete/delete_arg_dash_arg_input
  3. delete/delete_arg_dash_input
  4. delete/delete_dash_arg_input
  5. delete/delete_empty_buffer_input
  6. delete/delete_invalid_number_input
  7. delete/delete_last_dash_first_input
  8. delete/delete_no_arg_input
  9. delete/delete_no_loaded_file_input
  10. delete/delete_one_arg_input
  11. delete/delete_range_with_sapces_input
  12. help/help_ambiguous_s_input
  13. help/help_invalid_arg_input
  14. help/help_no_arg_input
  15. help/help_sa_input
  16. help/help_se_input
  17. insert/insert_after_last_line_input
  18. insert/insert_at_empty_buffer_for_loaded_file_input
  19. insert/insert_at_line_0_input
  20. insert/insert_at_modified_buffer_input
  21. insert/insert_general_input
  22. insert/insert_when_no_loaded_file_input
  23. load/load_after_modified_input
  24. load/load_after_throw_input
  25. load/load_general_input
  26. load/load_missing_file_input
  27. load/load_reload_file_input
  28. load/load_too_long_input
  29. print/print_0_input
  30. print/print_arg_dash_arg_input
  31. print/print_arg_dash_input
  32. print/print_dash_arg_input
  33. print/print_empty_buffer_input
  34. print/print_invalid_number_input
  35. print/print_last_dash_first_input
  36. print/print_no_arg_input
  37. print/print_no_loaded_file_input
  38. print/print_one_arg_input
  39. print/print_range_with_sapces_input
  40. quit/quit_after_throw_input
  41. quit/quit_before_load_input
  42. quit/quit_modified_input
  43. quit/quit_w_invalid_arg_input
  44. quit/quit_w_modified_input
  45. quit/quit_w_no_arg_input
  46. quit/quit_w_white_space_after_w_input
  47. replace/replace_empty_pattern_and_replacement_input
  48. replace/replace_empty_pattern_input
  49. replace/replace_empty_replacement_input
  50. replace/replace_global_input
  51. replace/replace_modified_not_saved_buffer_input

  53. save/save_bad_arg_input
  54. save/save_change_fname_after_load_input
  55. save/save_modify_save_load_input
  56. save/save_no_arg_input

  65. throw/throw_load_another_file_input

Add to them the 44 tests developed (internally) by RMIT.



  1. r4_load_large_file_input
  2. r4_load_long_file_input
  3. r4_load_missing_file_input

51.2.3    Time Required to Run the Tests



Each of those tests entails a brand new instance of a (slow) Valgrind run.

For example, loading big.txt takes 14 minutes and 22.5 seconds.

The following test files loaded big.txt as part of their operation:

  • r8_print_big_first30_input
  • r9_delete_middle_input
  • r11_save_big_input



51.2.4    Two Sets of Tests Required for Assignment Grading



Extract from instructions to assignment 2 part 3

Please note that the testing is much more central to this assignment than the amount of marks would suggest. We will run your program both with your tests and a set of tests that we will construct as well. A HD assignment must be able to pass both sets of tests.




51.2.5    Mission Impossible



RMIT expected the marker to do the following in a few minutes of paid work.

Namely:

  1. Run all the 111 (67 + 44 = 111) tests. Each of them was running for up to 14 minutes and 22.5 seconds.
  2. Scour 2061 lines of C code in a quest to find the culprit line or the missing iota that precipitated the incompatible output.
  3. Read a long readme.txt file that discusses dozens of bugs in RMIT's implementation and provides a rationale for choices made by the student.



When Prof. Aleksandar Subic pretends that RMIT is not stealing from its (casually-employed) tutors, please point out the above.


51.3    Crash of RMIT's Test



As noted, I got hit with a penalty because my program manifested a leak of 11,755,745 bytes when RMIT ran one of their test files.

Or so they claimed.


51.3.1    The Test



The test input-file was: r11_save_big_input.


The readme file for that test reads:

mytests/r11_save_big_readme

1 tests that a large file can be loaded , have three lines deleted and then 2 saved back out immediately. Do a diff of newbig.txt with testfiles.txt to 3 verify that only three lines are missing.




Again, part of the test was to "do a diff" and "verify that only three lines are missing".

As shown, RMIT expected the tutor to investigate the diff in his free time (without pay).


51.3.2    Tutors do Not Read



Had the tutor done so (and read newbig.txt or the output), he would have found that:

  • Every single leak was classified as "still reachable". As quoted later, still reachable leaks are "not a problem".
  • More importantly, the program got aborted in the middle of its execution. You would think that RMIT would be more worried about a crash than an elusive still reachable memory leak.
  • He would have seen that the reason for the crash was due to, quote: "File size limit exceeded". A fault of RMIT's own configuration.
  • As quoted above, the tutor had to "do a diff of newbig.txt with testfiles.txt to verify that only three lines are missing.". Such a "diff" would have shown that 29,635 lines were missing, not "only three lines".



51.3.3    Root-Cause of the Crash Outputted by Valgrind



Now, Valgrind is unambiguous about the root cause of the crash.

Extract from Valgrind's output for the crash

63 ==47146== Process terminating with default action of signal 25 (SIGXFSZ) 64 ==47146== at 0x4F269F0 __write_nocancel (in /usr/lib64/libc-2.17.so) 65 ==47146== by 0x4EB1252 _IO_file_write@@GLIBC_2.2.5 (in /usr/lib64/libc-2.17.so) 66 ==47146== by 0x4EB2A6D _IO_do_write@@GLIBC_2.2.5 (in /usr/lib64/libc-2.17.so) 67 ==47146== by 0x4EB2217 _IO_file_close_it@@GLIBC_2.2.5 (in /usr/lib64/libc-2.17.so) 68 ==47146== by 0x4EA51E7 fclose@@GLIBC_2.2.5 (in /usr/lib64/libc-2.17.so) 69 ==47146== by 0x402D7B save_file (in student_submission/cpt220_ed) 70 ==47146== by 0x402EDA repl (in student_submission/cpt220_ed) 71 ==47146== by 0x400EDD main (in student_submission/cpt220_ed)




51.3.4    Resource Limits



POSIX says:

RLIMIT_FSIZE This is the maximum size of a file, in bytes, that may be created by a process. If a write or truncate operation would cause this limit to be exceeded, SIGXFSZ shall be generated for the thread.




Clearly, the root cause is a RLIMIT_FSIZE.

Namely, a resource limit regarding the maximum size of files written by the process.


A program — constrained by a limit — crashes when it exceeds the limit.

It is that simple.

And if run under Valgrind, it will output diagnostics about still reachable leaks.


However, are the leaks the root cause of the crash?

No.

In fact, Valgrind itself is unambiguous about the root cause.


51.4    Case Study: Programs Constrained by a Resource Limit



For example, setting a resource limit will crash any of the following three programs.

  • cat.
  • cpt220_ed (developed by RMIT).
  • cpt220_ed (developed by the student).



The following demonstrates the above by running each of the programs twice.

The running environment for all the tests was RMIT's own platform (the exact same one used by RMIT for running the tests on my assignment).


The first run is constrained by a permissive ulimit (i.e. larger than the size of big.txt).

All three programs run successfully.


The second run is constrained by a restrictive ulimit (i.e. just short of the attempted write size of the programs).

All three programs crash as soon as they attempt to exceed that limit.

And when run under Valgrind, you are warned about still reachable leaks not before it outputs the root cause of the crash, namely, the fatal SIGXFSZ signal.


The arithmetic behind the 6,336 and 6,337 blocks used later is explained here:

Basic facts:

  • The size of big.txt is 6,488,666 bytes.
  • A block is 1024 bytes (bash in non-posix mode).

    • 6,336 blocks are 6,488,064 bytes.
    • 6,337 blocks are 6,489,088 bytes.


In other words:

  • 6,336 blocks fall short of big.txt by 602 bytes.
  • 6,337 blocks exceed big.txt by 422 bytes.



51.4.1    cat(1) Constrained by 'ulimit -f 6337'



In the following:

  1. We impose a ulimit of 6337 blocks.
  2. Then, a test program copies 'big.txt' to '/tmp/x'. — The test program is the UNIX utility cat(1).
  3. Execution is successful since the size of 'big.txt' does not exceed the ulimit (of 6337 blocks).

1 # Number of bytes in 'big.txt' is: 6,488,666. 2 $ byte_count=$(cat /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/testfiles/big.txt | wc -c) 3 4 5 $ echo "$byte_count" 6 6488666 7 8 9 # Round-up the number of (1024-bytes) blocks of text contained in 'big.txt'. 10 $ block_count=$(((byte_count + 1023)/1024)) 11 12 13 # 6,488,666 == ((6,336 * 1,024) + 602). 14 $ echo $block_count 15 6337 16 17 18 # Put a file-size writing limit on the shell and its children. 19 # The limit is 6,337 blocks (of 1024 bytes) i.e. 6,489,088 bytes (which is 422 bytes larger than 20 # 'big.txt'). 21 # 22 # Consequently, this does not affect the following test program. 23 $ ulimit -f 6337 24 25 26 # This is the actual test. 27 # The test program is run from within Valgrind. 28 # The program copies 'big.txt' to '/tmp/x' 29 # 30 # Note how the previous ulimit does not affect the test 31 # because the limit is larger than 'big.txt'. 32 $ valgrind --leak-check=yes --show-leak-kinds=all \ 33 cat /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/testfiles/big.txt >/tmp/x 34 ==59631== Memcheck, a memory error detector 35 ==59631== Copyright (C) 2002-2017, and GNU GPL'd, by Julian Seward et al. 36 ==59631== Using Valgrind-3.14.0 and LibVEX; rerun with -h for copyright info 37 ==59631== Command: cat /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/testfiles/big.txt 38 ==59631== 39 ==59631== 40 ==59631== HEAP SUMMARY: 41 ==59631== in use at exit: 0 bytes in 0 blocks 42 ==59631== total heap usage: 46 allocs, 46 frees, 77,062 bytes allocated 43 ==59631== 44 ==59631== All heap blocks were freed -- no leaks are possible 45 ==59631== 46 ==59631== For counts of detected and suppressed errors, rerun with: -v 47 ==59631== ERROR SUMMARY: 0 errors from 0 contexts (suppressed: 0 from 0) 48 49 50 # Line/byte count of the original file 'big.txt': 51 # – 128,457 lines. 52 # – 6,488,666 bytes. 53 $ wc /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/testfiles/big.txt 54 128457 1095695 6488666 /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/testfiles/big.txt 55 56 57 # Line/byte count of the new file '/tmp/x': 58 # – 128,457 lines (identical to original 'big.txt'). 59 # – 6,488,666 bytes (identical to original 'big.txt'). 60 $ wc /tmp/x 61 128457 1095695 6488666 /tmp/x




51.4.2    cat(1) Constrained by 'ulimit -f 6336'



In the following:

  1. We impose a ulimit of 6336 blocks.
  2. Then, the program tries to exceed that limit by copying 'big.txt' to '/tmp/x'. — The test program is the UNIX utility cat(1).
  3. Process is killed by signal 25 (SIGXFSZ) since 'big.txt' exceeds the ulimit of 6336 blocks.

1 # Number of bytes in 'big.txt' is: 6,488,666. 2 $ byte_count=$(cat /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/testfiles/big.txt | wc -c) 3 4 5 $ echo "$byte_count" 6 6488666 7 8 9 # Round-up the number of (1024-bytes) blocks of text contained in 'big.txt'. 10 $ block_count=$(((byte_count + 1023)/1024)) 11 12 13 # 6,488,666 == ((6,336 * 1,024) + 602). 14 $ echo $block_count 15 6337 16 17 18 # Put a file-size writing limit on the shell and its children. 19 # The limit is 6,336 blocks (of 1024 bytes) i.e. 6,488,064 bytes (which is 602 bytes short of the 20 # actual size of 'big.txt'). 21 # 22 # Offending programs will be killed by signal 25 (SIGXFSZ). 23 $ ulimit -f 6336 24 25 26 # This is the actual test. 27 # The test program is run from within Valgrind. 28 # The program tries to copy 'big.txt' to '/tmp/x'. 29 # 30 # As noted, ulimit put a resource limit of 6336 blocks (of 1024 bytes). 31 # This file-size limit falls short of the actual size of 'big.txt'. 32 $ valgrind --leak-check=yes --show-leak-kinds=all \ 33 cat /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/testfiles/big.txt >/tmp/x 34 ==44871== Memcheck, a memory error detector 35 ==44871== Copyright (C) 2002-2017, and GNU GPL'd, by Julian Seward et al. 36 ==44871== Using Valgrind-3.14.0 and LibVEX; rerun with -h for copyright info 37 ==44871== Command: cat /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/testfiles/big.txt 38 ==44871== 39 ==44871== 40 ==44871== Process terminating with default action of signal 25 (SIGXFSZ) 41 ==44871== at 0x4F269F0 __write_nocancel (in /usr/lib64/libc-2.17.so) 42 ==44871== by 0x404FD5 ??? (in /usr/bin/cat) 43 ==44871== by 0x402BAD ??? (in /usr/bin/cat) 44 ==44871== by 0x4024CC ??? (in /usr/bin/cat) 45 ==44871== by 0x4E59544 (below main) (in /usr/lib64/libc-2.17.so) 46 ==44871== 47 ==44871== HEAP SUMMARY: 48 ==44871== in use at exit: 69,631 bytes in 1 blocks 49 ==44871== total heap usage: 46 allocs, 45 frees, 77,062 bytes allocated 50 ==44871== 51 ==44871== 69,631 bytes in 1 blocks are still reachable in loss record 1 of 1 52 ==44871== at 0x4C29E63 malloc (vg_replace_malloc.c:309) 53 ==44871== by 0x405CD8 ??? (in /usr/bin/cat) 54 ==44871== by 0x402497 ??? (in /usr/bin/cat) 55 ==44871== by 0x4E59544 (below main) (in /usr/lib64/libc-2.17.so) 56 ==44871== 57 ==44871== LEAK SUMMARY: 58 ==44871== definitely lost: 0 bytes in 0 blocks 59 ==44871== indirectly lost: 0 bytes in 0 blocks 60 ==44871== possibly lost: 0 bytes in 0 blocks 61 ==44871== still reachable: 69,631 bytes in 1 blocks 62 ==44871== suppressed: 0 bytes in 0 blocks 63 ==44871== 64 ==44871== For counts of detected and suppressed errors, rerun with: -v 65 ==44871== ERROR SUMMARY: 0 errors from 0 contexts (suppressed: 0 from 0) 66 file size limit exceeded 67 68 69 # Line/byte count of the original file 'big.txt': 70 # – 128,457 lines. 71 # – 6,488,666 bytes. 72 $ wc /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/testfiles/big.txt 73 128457 1095695 6488666 /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/testfiles/big.txt 74 75 76 # Line/byte count of the new file '/tmp/x': 77 # – 128,442 lines. 78 # – 6,488,064 bytes (Notice how this matches exactly the 6,336 blocks ulimit). 79 $ wc /tmp/x 80 128442 1095612 6488064 /tmp/x




51.4.3    cpt220_ed Constrained by 'ulimit -f 6337'



In the following:

  1. We impose a ulimit of 6337 blocks.
  2. Then, a test program saves (the modified) 'big.txt' to '/tmp/newbig.txt'. — The test program is the text editor developed and released by RMIT.
  3. Execution is successful since the size of 'big.txt' does not exceed the ulimit (of 6337 blocks).

1 # '/tmp/input' is a batch file containing the commands to be executed by the program. 2 # 3 # It includes the same 4 commands as r11_save_big_input, namely: 4 # 1. To 'l(oad)' (i.e. edit) the 'big.txt' file. 5 # 2. To 'd(elete)' the first 3 lines ('-3' means from (the missing) start up to line 3, included). 6 # 3. To 's(ave)' the modified file under a new name '/tmp/newbig.txt'. 7 # 4. To 'q(uit)' the program. 8 $ cat /tmp/input 9 l /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/testfiles/big.txt 10 d-3 11 s /tmp/newbig.txt 12 q 13 14 15 # Number of bytes in 'big.txt' is: 6,488,666. 16 $ byte_count=$(cat /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/testfiles/big.txt | wc -c) 17 18 19 $ echo "$byte_count" 20 6488666 21 22 23 # Round-up the number of (1024-bytes) blocks of text contained in 'big.txt'. 24 $ block_count=$(((byte_count + 1023)/1024)) 25 26 27 # 6,488,666 == ((6,336 * 1,024) + 602). 28 $ echo $block_count 29 6337 30 31 32 # Put a file-size writing limit on the shell and its children. 33 # The limit is 6,337 blocks (of 1024 bytes) i.e. 6,489,088 bytes (which is 422 bytes larger than 34 # 'big.txt'). 35 # 36 # Consequently, this does not affect the following test program. 37 $ ulimit -f 6337 38 39 40 # cpt220_ed, a text editor developed by RMIT. 41 # The very binary released by RMIT. 42 $ readelf -a /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed \ 43 | grep 'Build ID' 44 Build ID: 0f27b56d6523065e799b430313e3035c6b64b786 45 46 47 # This is the actual test. 48 # The test program is run from within Valgrind. 49 # The program saves (the modified) 'big.txt' to '/tmp/newbig.txt'. 50 # 51 # Note how the previous ulimit does not affect the test 52 # because the limit is larger than 'big.txt'. 53 $ valgrind --leak-check=yes --show-leak-kinds=all \ 54 /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed </tmp/foo 55 ==58127== Memcheck, a memory error detector 56 ==58127== Copyright (C) 2002-2017, and GNU GPL'd, by Julian Seward et al. 57 ==58127== Using Valgrind-3.14.0 and LibVEX; rerun with -h for copyright info 58 ==58127== Command: /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed 59 ==58127== 60 > Successfully loaded /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/testfiles/big.txt 61 > > Successfully saved /tmp/newbig.txt 62 > ==58127== 63 ==58127== HEAP SUMMARY: 64 ==58127== in use at exit: 0 bytes in 0 blocks 65 ==58127== total heap usage: 385,381 allocs, 385,381 frees, 11,756,753 bytes allocated 66 ==58127== 67 ==58127== All heap blocks were freed -- no leaks are possible 68 ==58127== 69 ==58127== For counts of detected and suppressed errors, rerun with: -v 70 ==58127== ERROR SUMMARY: 0 errors from 0 contexts (suppressed: 0 from 0) 71 72 73 # Line/byte count of the original file 'big.txt': 74 # – 128,457 lines. 75 # – 6,488,666 bytes. 76 $ wc /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/testfiles/big.txt 77 128457 1095695 6488666 /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/testfiles/big.txt 78 79 80 # Line/byte count of the new file '/tmp/newbig.txt': 81 # – 128,454 lines (Notice the 3 lines difference from original due to the 'd-3' command). 82 # – 6,488,529 bytes (Notice that the (modified) file 'big.txt' was fully copied). 83 $ wc /tmp/newbig.txt 84 128454 1095671 6488529 /tmp/newbig.txt




51.4.4    cpt220_ed Constrained by 'ulimit -f 6336'



In the following:

  1. We impose a ulimit of 6336 blocks.
  2. Then, the limit is exceeded, by saving (the modified) 'big.txt' to '/tmp/newbig.txt'. — The test program is the text editor developed and released by RMIT.
  3. Process is killed by signal 25 (SIGXFSZ) since 'big.txt' exceeds the ulimit of 6336 blocks.

1 # '/tmp/input' is a batch file containing the commands to be executed by the program. 2 # 3 # It includes the same 4 commands as r11_save_big_input, namely: 4 # 1. To 'l(oad)' (i.e. edit) the 'big.txt' file. 5 # 2. To 'd(elete)' the first 3 lines ('-3' means from (the missing) start up to line 3, included). 6 # 3. To 's(ave)' the modified file under a new name '/tmp/newbig.txt'. 7 # 4. To 'q(uit)' the program. 8 $ cat /tmp/input 9 l /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/testfiles/big.txt 10 d-3 11 s /tmp/newbig.txt 12 q 13 14 15 # Number of bytes in 'big.txt' is: 6,488,666. 16 $ byte_count=$(cat /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/testfiles/big.txt | wc -c) 17 18 19 $ echo "$byte_count" 20 6488666 21 22 23 # Round-up the number of (1024-bytes) blocks of text contained in 'big.txt'. 24 $ block_count=$(((byte_count + 1023)/1024)) 25 26 27 # 6,488,666 == ((6,336 * 1,024) + 602). 28 $ echo $block_count 29 6337 30 31 32 # Put a file-size writing limit on the shell and its children. 33 # The limit is 6,336 blocks (of 1024 bytes) i.e. 6,488,064 bytes (which is 602 bytes short of the 34 # actual size of 'big.txt'). 35 # 36 # Offending programs will be killed by signal 25 (SIGXFSZ). 37 $ ulimit -f 6336 38 39 40 # cpt220_ed, a text editor developed by RMIT. 41 # The very binary released by RMIT. 42 $ readelf -a /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed \ 43 | grep 'Build ID' 44 Build ID: 0f27b56d6523065e799b430313e3035c6b64b786 45 46 47 # This is the actual test. 48 # The test program is run from within Valgrind. 49 # The program ends up trying to save (the modified) 'big.txt' to '/tmp/newbig.txt'. 50 # 51 # As noted, ulimit put a resource limit of 6336 blocks (of 1024 bytes). 52 # This file-size limit falls short of the actual size of the (modified) 'big.txt' file. 53 $ valgrind --leak-check=yes --show-leak-kinds=all \ 54 51.4.5    Student's Program Constrained by 'ulimit -f 6337'



In the following:

  1. We impose a ulimit of 6337 blocks.
  2. Then, a test program saves (the modified) 'big.txt' to '/tmp/newbig.txt'. — The test program is the binary compiled by RMIT from the source-code provided by the student in his assignment 2(C) submission.
  3. Execution is successful since the size of 'big.txt' does not exceed the ulimit (of 6337 blocks).

1 # '/tmp/input' is a batch file containing the commands to be executed by the program. 2 # 3 # It includes the same 4 commands as r11_save_big_input, namely: 4 # 1. To 'l(oad)' (i.e. edit) the 'big.txt' file. 5 # 2. To 'd(elete)' the first 3 lines ('-3' means from (the missing) start up to line 3, included). 6 # 3. To 's(ave)' the modified file under a new name '/tmp/newbig.txt'. 7 # 4. To 'q(uit)' the program. 8 $ cat /tmp/input 9 l /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/testfiles/big.txt 10 d-3 11 s /tmp/newbig.txt 12 q 13 14 15 # Number of bytes in 'big.txt' is: 6,488,666. 16 $ byte_count=$(cat /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/testfiles/big.txt | wc -c) 17 18 19 $ echo "$byte_count" 20 6488666 21 22 23 # Round-up the number of (1024-bytes) blocks of text contained in 'big.txt'. 24 $ block_count=$(((byte_count + 1023)/1024)) 25 26 27 # 6,488,666 == ((6,336 * 1,024) + 602). 28 $ echo $block_count 29 6337 30 31 32 # Put a file-size writing limit on the shell and its children. 33 # The limit is 6,337 blocks (of 1024 bytes) i.e. 6,489,088 bytes (which is 422 bytes larger than 34 # 'big.txt'). 35 # 36 Consequently, this does not affect the following test program. 37 $ ulimit -f 6337 38 39 40 # This binary was compiled by RMIT based on the source code written by the student 41 # and was used by RMIT while running the tests for grading the assignment. 42 $ readelf -a student_submission/cpt220_ed | grep 'Build ID' 43 Build ID: a97cf4506485514308efd07905e00fdbd97d47de 44 45 46 # This is the actual test. 47 # The test program is run from within Valgrind. 48 # The program will end up saving (the modified) 'big.txt' into '/tmp/newbig.txt'. 49 # 50 # Note how the previous ulimit does not affect the test 51 # because the limit is larger than 'big.txt'. 52 $ valgrind --leak-check=yes --show-leak-kinds=all student_submission/cpt220_ed </tmp/foo 53 ==58108== Memcheck, a memory error detector 54 ==58108== Copyright (C) 2002-2017, and GNU GPL'd, by Julian Seward et al. 55 ==58108== Using Valgrind-3.14.0 and LibVEX; rerun with -h for copyright info 56 ==58108== Command: student_submission/cpt220_ed 57 ==58108== 58 > 59 Successfully loaded /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/testfiles/big.txt 60 > 61 > 62 Successfully saved /tmp/newbig.txt 63 > 64 ==58108== 65 ==58108== HEAP SUMMARY: 66 ==58108== in use at exit: 0 bytes in 0 blocks 67 ==58108== total heap usage: 385,376 allocs, 385,376 frees, 11,756,623 bytes allocated 68 ==58108== 69 ==58108== All heap blocks were freed -- no leaks are possible 70 ==58108== 71 ==58108== For counts of detected and suppressed errors, rerun with: -v 72 ==58108== ERROR SUMMARY: 0 errors from 0 contexts (suppressed: 0 from 0) 73 74 75 # Line/byte count of the original file 'big.txt': 76 # – 128,457 lines. 77 # – 6,488,666 bytes. 78 $ wc /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/testfiles/big.txt 79 128457 1095695 6488666 /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/testfiles/big.txt 80 81 82 # Line/byte count of the new file '/tmp/newbig.txt': 83 # – 128,454 lines (Notice the 3 lines difference from original due to the 'd-3' command). 84 # – 6,488,529 bytes (Notice that the (modified) file 'big.txt' was fully copied). 85 $ wc /tmp/newbig.txt 86 128454 1095671 6488529 /tmp/newbig.txt




51.4.6    Student's Program Constrained by 'ulimit -f 6336'



In the following:

  1. We impose a ulimit of 6336 blocks.
  2. Then, the limit is exceeded by saving (the modified) 'big.txt' to '/tmp/newbig.txt'. — The test program is the binary compiled by RMIT from the source-code provided by the student in his assignment 2(C) submission.
  3. Process is killed by signal 25 (SIGXFSZ) since 'big.txt' exceeds the ulimit of 6336 blocks.

1 # '/tmp/input' is a batch file containing the commands to be executed by the program. 2 # 3 # It includes the same 4 commands as r11_save_big_input, namely: 4 # 1. To 'l(oad)' (i.e. edit) the 'big.txt' file. 5 # 2. To 'd(elete)' the first 3 lines ('-3' means from (the missing) start up to line 3, included). 6 # 3. To 's(ave)' the modified file under a new name '/tmp/newbig.txt'. 7 # 4. To 'q(uit)' the program. 8 $ cat /tmp/input 9 l /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/testfiles/big.txt 10 d-3 11 s /tmp/newbig.txt 12 q 13 14 15 # Number of bytes in 'big.txt' is: 6,488,666. 16 $ byte_count=$(cat /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/testfiles/big.txt | wc -c) 17 18 19 $ echo "$byte_count" 20 6488666 21 22 23 # Round-up the number of (1024-bytes) blocks of text contained in 'big.txt'. 24 $ block_count=$(((byte_count + 1023)/1024)) 25 26 27 # 6,488,666 == ((6,336 * 1,024) + 602). 28 $ echo $block_count 29 6337 30 31 32 # Put a file-size writing limit on the shell and its children. 33 # The limit is 6,336 blocks (of 1024 bytes) i.e. 6,488,064 bytes (which is 602 bytes short of the 34 # actual size of 'big.txt'). 35 # 36 # Offending programs will be killed by signal 25 (SIGXFSZ). 37 $ ulimit -f 6336 38 39 40 # This binary was compiled by RMIT based on the source code written by the student 41 # and was used by RMIT while running the tests for grading the assignment. 42 $ readelf -a student_submission/cpt220_ed | grep 'Build ID' 43 Build ID: a97cf4506485514308efd07905e00fdbd97d47de 44 45 46 # This is the actual test. 47 # The test program is run from within Valgrind. 48 # The program ends up trying to save (the modified) 'big.txt' to '/tmp/newbig.txt'. 49 # 50 # As noted, ulimit put a resource limit of 6336 blocks (of 1024 bytes). 51 # This file-size limit falls short of the actual size of the (modified) 'big.txt' file. 52 $ valgrind --leak-check=yes --show-leak-kinds=all student_submission/cpt220_ed </tmp/foo 53 ==47146== Memcheck, a memory error detector 54 ==47146== Copyright (C) 2002-2017, and GNU GPL'd, by Julian Seward et al. 55 ==47146== Using Valgrind-3.14.0 and LibVEX; rerun with -h for copyright info with default action of signal 25 (SIGXFSZ) 64 ==47146== at 0x4F269F0 __write_nocancel (in /usr/lib64/libc-2.17.so) 65 ==47146== by 0x4EB1252 _IO_file_write@@GLIBC_2.2.5 (in /usr/lib64/libc-2.17.so) 66 51.5.2    r11_save_big_readme



The 'readme' file associated with 'r11_save_big_input', namely: 'r11_save_big_readme'

1 tests that a large file can be loaded , have three lines deleted and then 2 saved back out immediately. Do a diff of newbig.txt with testfiles.txt to 3 verify that only three lines are missing.




51.5.3    r11_save_big_input



The test input-file 'r11_save_big_input'

1 ltestfiles/big.txt 2 d-3 3 s newbig.txt 4 q




51.6    Resource Limit and Size of Newly-Written File in RMIT-Run Tests



Since the marker was not paid to read, let's do the hard work on his behalf.

As noted, part of the test was to "do a diff" and "verify that only three lines are missing."

The diff is between big.txt and its modified version that was copied to newbig.txt.


51.6.1    Size of newbig.txt in RMIT's Logs



A look into assignment2-part3-autotesting.zip (containing the output of RMIT-run tests)
Sent on Wednesday 13/05/2020 at 10:39

# Zip-file of RMIT's internal tests (and their output) for this assignment. $ unzip assignment2-part3-autotesting.zip >/dev/null $ lines_count_of_big.txt=$(cat /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/testfiles/big.txt | wc -l) $ echo $lines_count_of_big.txt 128457 $ lines_count_of_newbig.txt=$(cat newbig.txt | wc -l) $ echo $lines_count_of_newbig.txt 98822 $ diff=$((lines_count_of_big.txt - lines_count_of_newbig.txt)) # The marker had to ensure that "only three lines are missing". # Obviously, 29,635 is a far cry from 3 lines. Right? $ echo $diff 29635




51.6.2    The Resource Limit in RMIT's Environment



And, just for fun, let's discover the resource limit that precipitated the crash.

$ bytes_count_of_big.txt=$(cat /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/testfiles/big.txt | wc -c)

$ echo $bytes_count_of_big.txt 6488666 $ bytes_count_of_newbig.txt=$(cat newbig.txt | wc -c) $ echo $bytes_count_of_newbig.txt 5242880 $ diff=$((bytes_count_of_big.txt - bytes_count_of_newbig.txt)) # 1,245,786 bytes were truncated. $ echo $diff 1245786 $ blocks=$((bytes_count_of_newbig.txt / 1024)) # 5,242,880 is an exact multiple of 1,024 (namely, 5,120 blocks of 1,024 bytes). $ remainder=$((bytes_count_of_newbig.txt % 1024)) $ echo $remainder 0 # Finally, the resource limit was 5,120 blocks of 1,024 bytes (or 10 * (1<<19) bytes). $ echo $blocks 5120




51.7    Valgrind: Still Reachable vs. Definitely Lost Leaks



There is a distinction in Valgrind between still reachable and unreachable ("definitely lost") leaks.

This is not unlike the difference between "good" and "bad" viruses.

While the latter are nasty or even outright lethal, the "good" viruses have the potential to cure cancer, correct genetic disorders or fight pathogenic viral infections.


The Documentation is very clear:

"Still reachable" blocks are very common and arguably not a problem. So, by default, Memcheck won't report such blocks individually. Valgrind User Manual – 4.2.8. Memory leak detection









Chapter 52
— Assignment 2(C)
— Long Lines in Source Code





52.1    Summary



RMIT told me I lost 50% of my marks because "lines [were] longer than 80 characters".


My submission strictly complied with the 80-characters long lines limit

However, there was a deliberate exception made for 2 lines in a block of "help" strings.


This block was separated from the rest by the INDENT-OFF and INDENT-ON demarcation strings.

Why?

Because this block necessitated its own style and a specific formatting.


Either RMIT are ignorant, or they did not read the assignment before its grading.

What is it?

Probably both.


52.2    Do as I Say, Not as I Do



Students were required to compare their output with the output of cpt220_ed, the exemplary model developed by RMIT.

This means that in order to achieve successful matches, students had to mimic all the idiosyncrasies of RMIT's code.


For some reason, after preaching about the importance of the 80-characters limit, RMIT decided to output 120-characters long lines in its help messages.

This was done twice, namely, for the load and insert commands.

"Do as I say, not as I do".


Students — reluctantly — had to follow suit or, else, fail the tests when comparing their output with RMIT's one.


Alternatively, a student could have cheated and (artificially) broken the line(s) in half to comply with the 80-characters limit.

However, a common formatting convention when writing a block of text messages sent to the user is to illustrate and "mirror" the resulting text format (as shown to the user) in the source code itself.

Right?


Compare the source code for the usage output in any UNIX command.


Again, the clue was INDENT-OFF and INDENT-ON.


52.3    Resources



52.3.1    Help Strings Bounded by Demarcation Strings



Assignment 2 part 3: action.c – submitted by student on Wednesday 12/02/2020 at 19:27
. Emphasis was added to the "offending" lines (namely, 490 and 501).

479 /* *INDENT-OFF* */ 480 481 482 help_menu[AT_HELP] = 483 "The following commands are available: \n" 484 " help, load, insert, delete, search, replace, print, throw, save, quit.\n" 485 "\n" 486 "You may get further details on any command by typing ? followed by the command name.\n"; 487 488 489 help_menu[AT_LOAD] = 490 "loads a file into memory. Will not succeed if there is a file loaded into memory already that has unsaved modifications.\n" 491 "Usage: \n" 492 "\n" 493 " l[filename]\n" 494 "\n" 495 "Where [filename] is a valid filename on the file system.\n"; 496 497 498 help_menu[AT_INSERT] = 499 "insert\n" 500 "------\n" 501 "put the editor into insert mode so you can insert some text. We can only insert a line at a time, not a word at a time. \n" 502 "When you want to leave insert mode, press ctrl-d as input at the beginning of any line.\n" 503 "For example: \n" 504 " > i20\n" 505 " 20: foo is funny. \n" 506 " 21: baz is not.\n" 507 " 22:\n"; 508 509 510 help_menu[AT_DELETE] = 511 "delete\n" 512 "------\n" 513 "deletes a line from the loaded file in memory.\n" 514 "Supports the specification of either single line numbers or ranges.\n" 515 "Some valid examples: \n" 516 "d1 – would delete the first line in the file.\n" 517 "d2-7 – woudl delete the lines 2 through to 7 inclusive.\n" 518 "d-8 – would delete the first 8 lines of the file.\n" 519 "d15- – would delete lines 15 through to the end of the file.\n"; 520 521 522 help_menu[AT_SEARCH] = 523 "search\n" 524 "------\n" 525 "displays a list of all lines that contain an occurence of a given\n" 526 "word in the loaded file.\n" 527 "Command is invoked by typing the / key followed by your search term.\n"; 528 529 help_menu[AT_REPLACE] = 530 "replace\n" 531 "-------\n" 532 "This functionality allows you to search for a term in the \n" 533 "document and replace it with something else. This may be done\n" 534 "only once per line or for all occurences of the search target\n" 535 "on all lines of the file. \n" 536 "For example\n" 537 " r/foo/bar/ \n" 538 "would search for foo and replace it with bar. But only once per line.\n" 539 " r/foo/bar/g\n" 540 " would replace all occurences on each line.\n"; 541 542 help_menu[AT_PRINT] = 543 "print\n" 544 "-----\n" 545 "Prints out one or more lines from a file loaded into memory.\n" 546 "Supports the specification of either single line numbers or ranges.\n" 547 "Some valid examples: \n" 548 "p1 – would print the first line in the file.\n" 549 "p2-7 – woudl print the lines 2 through to 7 inclusive.\n" 550 "p-8 – would print the first 8 lines of the file.\n" 551 "p15- – would print lines 15 through to the end of the file.\n"; 552 553 help_menu[AT_THROW] = 554 "throw\n" 555 "-----\n" 556 "Throws away the current file and resets the loaded file to be empty and unmodified.\n" 557 "This functionality is invoked by typing t on a line on its own.\n"; 558 559 help_menu[AT_SAVE] = 560 "save\n" 561 "----\n" 562 "saves the current file to disk.\n" 563 "If you just press s on its own, the currently open file will \n" 564 "be saved to file it was opened from. If the file was not loaded\n" 565 "from disk, an error message will display.\n" 566 "if you press s followed by non-space characters, this will \n" 567 "be treated as a path to save the file to and that becomes the\n" 568 "current filename for the open file.\n"; 569 570 help_menu[AT_QUIT] = 571 "quit\n" 572 "----\n" 573 "Quits the program.\n" 574 "Optionally you may choose to specify that the current file should be saved by appending w.\n" 575 "If you use the 'w' option, you may also specify the name of the file to write to. \n" 576 "If you specify a filename to write to and it cannot be written, cpt220_ed will not exit.\n"; 577 578 579 /* *INDENT-ON* */




52.3.2    INDENT-OFF and INDENT-ON Demarcation Strings



GNU Indent Documentation

1.10 Disabling Formatting Formatting of C code may be disabled for portions of a program by embedding special control comments in the program. To turn off formatting for a section of a program, place the disabling control comment /* *INDENT-OFF* */ on a line by itself just before that section. Program text scanned after this control comment is output precisely as input with no modifications until the corresponding enabling comment is scanned on a line by itself. The disabling (sic) control comment is /* *INDENT-ON* */, and any text following the comment on the line is also output unformatted.




52.3.3    Long Lines Outputted by RMIT's Program



/home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed
Example run of RMIT's cpt220_ed; outputs two 120-characters long lines

$ /home/el9/E70949/shared/prog_in_c/assignments/a2/smaple/cpt220_ed > ?l loads a file into memory. Will not succeed if there is a file loaded into memory already that has unsaved modifications. Usage: l[filename] Where [filename] is a valid filename on the file system. > ?i insert ------ puts the editor into insert mode so you can insert some text. We can only insert a line at a time, not a word at a time. When you want to leave insert mode, press ctrl-d as input at the beginning of any line. For example: > i20 20: foo is funny. 21: baz is not. 22: > q

Chapter 53
— Assignment 2(C)
— Local Identifier Names





53.1    Introduction



53.1.1    "the" Prefix



Say what you want about RMIT, but they like their 'the'.

Every other local variable was important enough to get prefixed with the single most common word in the English language, namely: 'the'.


Did it improve the readability of the code?

No.

On the contrary.


There is more.

RMIT hit me with a penalty for daring to remove a 'the' prefix from a local variable.


Now, let me make it clear.

All of those "the" identifiers were local variables.

Renaming a local variable has zero effect on its containing function's external interfaces.


Local variables (and their naming choices) are intimately related to their confining function.

None of those variables are visible outside its confining block.

Whether those variables are called tmp, thefoo or foo makes little difference.


53.1.2    Verbose Identifiers



There is more.

An identifier size_t s got also penalized by RMIT.

According to RMIT, since you did not name your local variable as the_size_of_lines, etc., it was not "meaningful".


I was also penalized for changing the following "meaningful" local identifier.

130 BOOLEAN linkedlist_save(FILE* receiver, const struct linkedlist* thelist)



"receiver", I suppose because the file "receives" the text written to it...


In RMIT, you don't pay for the grades but for the comedic relief.


And also, in that same function (of less than 5 lines), I removed the 'the' from 'thelist' (a local variable).

How dare you?


53.1.3    Linux Coding Style Regarding Naming Convention



However, industry standards are overwhelmingly on the student's side.

For example, the following is from the Linux kernel's coding style.

linux/Documentation/process/coding-style.rst (lines 289-320)

289 4) Naming 290 --------- 291 292 C is a Spartan language, and your naming conventions should follow suit. 293 Unlike Modula-2 and Pascal programmers, C programmers do not use cute 294 names like ThisVariableIsATemporaryCounter. A C programmer would call that 295 variable `tmp`, which is much easier to write, and not the least more 296 difficult to understand. 297 298 HOWEVER, while mixed-case names are frowned upon, descriptive names for 299 global variables are a must. To call a global function `foo` is a 300 shooting offense. 301 302 GLOBAL variables (to be used only if you **really** need them) need to 303 have descriptive names, as do global functions. If you have a function 304 that counts the number of active users, you should call that 305 `count_active_users() or similar, you should **not** call it cntusr()`. 306 307 Encoding the type of a function into the name (so-called Hungarian 308 notation) is asinine – the compiler knows the types anyway and can check 309 those, and it only confuses the programmer. No wonder Microsoft makes buggy 310 programs. 311 312 LOCAL variable names should be short, and to the point. If you have 313 some random integer loop counter, it should probably be called `i`. 314 Calling it `loop_counter` is non-productive, if there is no chance of it 315 being mis-understood. Similarly, `tmp` can be just about any type of 316 variable that is used to hold a temporary value. 317 318 If you are afraid to mix up your local variable names, you have another 319 problem, which is called the function-growth-hormone-imbalance syndrome. 320 See chapter 6 (Functions).




53.1.4    Case Study: Naming Convention and Readability



As another example, this was deemed by RMIT to be "readable" code.

Extract from answer 4(B) by RMIT

836 static int word_score(char const word[], const struct letter_score scoretable[], 837 int scoretable_size) 838 { 839 int lettercount, tablecount; 840 int wordlen = strlen(word); 841 int score = 0; 842 843 for (lettercount = 0; lettercount < wordlen; ++lettercount) { 844 for (tablecount = 0; tablecount < scoretable_size; ++tablecount) { 845 if (word[lettercount] == scoretable[tablecount].letter) { 846 score += scoretable[tablecount].score; 847 } 848 } 849 } 850 return score; 851 }




"Normal" programmers (abiding by the coding-style quoted above) will rather prefer the following.



Replacing lettercount, tablecount, wordlen, scoretable, and scoretable_size
with i, k, n, table, and size

static int word_score(char const word[], const struct letter_score table[], int size) { int i, k; int n = strlen(word); int score = 0;

for (i = 0; i < n; ++i) { for (k = 0; k < size; ++k) { if (word[i] == table[k].letter) { score += table[k].score; } } } return score; }




What a difference!

The second version is far more readable than the unnecessarily-verbose and cumbersome version of the "approved" answer quoted above.

Right?

In fact, the Linux coding style was very adamant regarding the naming of loop counters.


53.2    Inflation of "the" Identifiers



By comparison to the 5 "the" variables found repeatedly in RMIT's "approved" answers, you can find only 57 "the" variables in all of the source code of the Linux kernel.


Furthermore, some of the "the" identifiers in Linux are legitimately worthy of the "the" prefix.

Like the global variable the_device.

Unlike the local variables (like theline) in the "approved" answer of RMIT where they lacked in their "the" credentials, so to speak, since they were local variable.


Let's put it in perspective.

Combining all of the "approved" answers in the marking guide, you get 414 lines of code.

As noted, there were 5 different "the" variables in their code.

5 / 414 = 0.012 "the" variables per lines of code.


Compare to the 57 "the" variables in 26,541,346 lines of source code of the Linux kernel (in its '*.[ch]' files).

57 / 26,541,346 = 0.000002 "the" variables per lines of code.


Meaning, RMIT was 5,623.643 times more likely to use "the" variables than the Linux kernel.

In other words, there is a 562,264% inflation of "the" variables in RMIT's code.


Out of 5,623+ programmers, only one of them was eager to add his beloved prefix 'the' to any other local variable.

This one developer ended up in RMIT, penalizing anyone who didn't follow suit.


53.3    Naming Convention: Variables Prefixed With 'the'
