Chapter 54
— Recovery From realloc() Errors





Note(1): This chapter is referenced here, here, and here.

Note(2): This course — strictly — assumed Linux as the only "legitimate" platform.

Note(3): This chapter focuses on realloc(), as it was the key topic in the links above.



54.1    Overcommit in Linux



Due to its (default) memory overcommit strategy, it is (virtually) impossible to recover from allocation errors in a Linux environment because "when malloc() returns non-NULL there is no guarantee that the memory really is available."

And, later on, upon access to the allocated memory, if resources are not available to handle the page fault exception, processes will be killed by the operating system's out-of-memory killer, making it impossible to recover from user-space.


Malloc(3) – Linux Manual Page

NOTES

By default, Linux follows an optimistic memory allocation strategy. This means that when malloc() returns non-NULL there is no guarantee that the memory really is available.

In case it turns out that the system is out of memory, one or more processes will be killed by the OOM killer.

For more information, see the description of /proc/sys/vm/overcommit_memory and /proc/sys/vm/oom_adj in proc(5), and the Linux kernel source file Documentation/vm/overcommit-accounting.




Wait, there is more.

Allocation errors (by exhausting physical + swap memory) are rare, and, on that occasion, this thrashing system (operating at a snail's pace) offers nothing but frustration to the user.

And, most likely, the user is right now frantically smashing his mouse and keyboard in a desperate attempt to get rid of the unresponsive process.


Consequently, the overwhelming convention is to abort() or exit() upon an allocation error as is evident in the following library interfaces

The same is evident in programs that embody the Linux culture.


54.2    realloc() Recovery in Libiberty/Gnulib/BusyBox/Git



54.2.1    Libibery



Following links refer to commit a948551942824947baaf6a077745fb5480d264a7.



binutils/libiberty/xmalloc.c:169

169 PTR 170 xrealloc (PTR oldmem, size_t size) 171 { 172 PTR newmem; 173 174 if (size == 0) 175 size = 1; 176 if (!oldmem) 177 newmem = malloc (size); 178 else 179 newmem = realloc (oldmem, size); 180 if (!newmem) 181 xmalloc_failed (size); 182 183 return (newmem); 184 }




binutils/libiberty/xmalloc.c:117

117 void 118 xmalloc_failed (size_t size) 119 { 120 #ifdef HAVE_SBRK 121 size_t allocated; 122 123 if (first_break != NULL) 124 allocated = (char *) sbrk (0) – first_break; 125 else 126 allocated = (char *) sbrk (0) – (char *) &environ; 127 fprintf (stderr, 128 "\n%s%sout of memory allocating %lu bytes after a total of %lu bytes\n", 129 name, *name ? ": " : "", 130 (unsigned long) size, (unsigned long) allocated); 131 #else /* HAVE_SBRK */ 132 fprintf (stderr, 133 "\n%s%sout of memory allocating %lu bytes\n", 134 name, *name ? ": " : "", 135 (unsigned long) size); 136 #endif /* HAVE_SBRK */ 137 xexit (1); 138 }




binutils/libiberty/xexit.c:46

46 void 47 xexit (int code) 48 { 49 if (_xexit_cleanup != NULL) 50 (*_xexit_cleanup) (); 51 exit (code); 52 }




54.2.2    Gnulib



Following links refer to commit a106791c87881cac20adc6d957289a55a638f557.



coreutils/gnulib/lib/xmalloc.c:62

62 void * 63 xrealloc (void *p, size_t n) 64 { 65 if (!HAVE_GNU_REALLOC && !n && p) 66 { 67 /* The GNU and C99 realloc behaviors disagree here. Act like GNU. */ 68 free (p); 69 return NULL; 70 } 71 72 void *r = realloc (p, n); 73 if (!r && (n || (HAVE_GNU_REALLOC && !p))) 74 xalloc_die (); 75 return r; 76 }




coreutils/gnulib/lib/xalloc-die.c:31

31 void 32 xalloc_die (void) 33 { 34 error (exit_failure, 0, "%s", _("memory exhausted")); 35 36 /* _Noreturn cannot be given to error, since it may return if 37 its first argument is 0. To help compilers understand the 38 xalloc_die does not return, call abort. Also, the abort is a 39 safety feature if exit_failure is 0 (which shouldn't happen). */ 40 abort (); 41 }




54.2.3    BusyBox



Following links refer to commit 079487b48724d936b31a6696ae0f929b0251eaa3.



busybox/libbb/xfuncs_printf.c:56

56 // Die if we can't resize previously allocated memory. (This returns a pointer 57 // to the new memory, which may or may not be the same as the old memory. 58 // It'll copy the contents to a new chunk and free the old one if necessary.) 59 void* FAST_FUNC xrealloc(void *ptr, size_t size) 60 { 61 ptr = realloc(ptr, size); 62 if (ptr == NULL && size != 0) 63 bb_die_memory_exhausted(); 64 return ptr; 65 }




busybox/libbb/xfuncs_printf.c:28

28 void FAST_FUNC bb_die_memory_exhausted(void) 29 { 30 bb_simple_error_msg_and_die(bb_msg_memory_exhausted); 31 }




busybox/libbb/verror_msg.c:212

212 void FAST_FUNC bb_simple_error_msg_and_die(const char *s) 213 { 214 bb_error_msg_and_die("%s", s); 215 }




busybox/libbb/verror_msg.c:165

165 void FAST_FUNC bb_error_msg_and_die(const char *s, ...) 166 { 167 va_list p; 168 169 va_start(p, s); 170 bb_verror_msg(s, p, NULL); 171 va_end(p); 172 xfunc_die(); 173 }




busybox/libbb/xfunc_die.c:16

16 void FAST_FUNC xfunc_die(void) 17 { 18 if (die_func) 19 die_func(); 20 exit(xfunc_error_retval); 21 }




54.2.4    Git



Following links refer to commit 328c10930387d301560f7cbcd3351cc485a13381.



wrapper.c:116

116 void *xrealloc(void *ptr, size_t size) 117 { 118 void *ret; 119 120 if (!size) { 121 free(ptr); 122 return xmalloc(0); 123 } 124 125 memory_limit_check(size, 0); 126 ret = realloc(ptr, size); 127 if (!ret) 128 die("Out of memory, realloc failed"); 129 return ret; 130 }




usage.c:167

167 void NORETURN die(const char *err, ...) 168 { 169 va_list params; 170 171 if (die_is_recursing()) { 172 fputs("fatal: recursion detected in die handler\n", stderr); 173 exit(128); 174 } 175 176 va_start(params, err); 177 die_routine(err, params); 178 va_end(params); 179 }




usage.c:118

118 static NORETURN_PTR report_fn die_routine = die_builtin;




usage.c:58

58 static NORETURN void die_builtin(const char *err, va_list params) 59 { 60 /* 61 * We call this trace2 function first and expect it to va_copy 'params' 62 * before using it (because an 'ap' can only be walked once). 63 */ 64 trace2_cmd_error_va(err, params); 65 66 vreportf("fatal: ", err, params); 67 68 exit(128); 69 }









Chapter 55
— C Language Macros Expanding to 'return'





55.1    Summary



I was once told to interview prospective candidates for a retail company.

In the first interview I conducted, I asked the candidate: "How long does it take for a person to walk 1 km?"

"About 10 minutes, more or less" he replied.

"No!" I told him.

"That person was dead. He could not walk."

Then I proceeded to reprimand him for failing the question and sent him home.

One day later, my employer told me that the candidate sent him an email calling me an idiot.


If you think I was ridiculous, wait until you enrol at RMIT.


In their exam, RMIT showed a chunk of code and claimed it contained an error.

We had to pinpoint the error.


The problem is, there was no error, to begin with.

RMIT waited until after the exam to add an outlandish detail to the question in order to artificially inject the error we had to find.

But since it was done after the exam, it was already too late.


Unfair, deceitful and manipulative.


I pointed out to RMIT how they were unreasonable, to say the least.

As a response, RMIT resorted to insults, claiming there was a problem with my "understanding", and, as a result, I "may not be able to answer" the "difficult" questions.


As always, RMIT (ab)uses its bully pulpit to control its students by resorting to personal insults, knowing full-well that a student responding in kind will be stripped off his visa and deported back to his home country.


55.2    Macros and the return Keyword



55.2.1    The Exam Question



The following is the question from the exam.

Study Period 4, 2018 — Exam: Question 1(D)

Question 1(D) There is a compiler error generated by the following macro declaration. What is the problem? #define ISPOSITIVE(NUM) { \ return NUM > 0; \ }




55.2.2    Ridiculous Assumptions



However, there is no "compiler error generated" by a macro expanding to the return keyword.

On the contrary.

This is a ubiquitous macro definition found in everyday software projects.

The Linux kernel source code, for example, contains 1,412 such definitions.


In its contrived and forced apologetics, RMIT explained that the "error" would be apparent if you placed the macro outside a function body.

Because over there (outside a function body), a return keyword is illegal.

Hence, there was an error in the macro, they concluded.


There are two reasons why this response is deceptive.

First, who the hell would ever place this macro outside a function.

The C programming language does not allow any statement (except global declarations) outside a function body.

Meaning, even other macros that expand to other keywords, including: for, do, while, etc., would equally fail; there is nothing special about the return keyword for that matter.

In fact, nearly all macros would fail if placed outside a function body (unless they expand to complete functions on their own).


And second, why didn't RMIT mention (in that question) this crucial, outlandish (and utterly bizarre) detail, namely, that this macro was placed outside a function body.


55.2.3    Discussion Board



Exam Discussion Board

Feb 22, 2020 at 14:17

Yes, but using the macro to return from a function is ok, and there is no "error generation for the macro declaration".

When you said that "you cant return from a macro", as if return and macro do not mix, i wondered why. I would have failed this question.


Feb 22, 2020 at 14:24

As always if the answer you give shows that understanding, then you would get the marks. To be honest though, "I would have failed at question" is not really a measure of a good or bad question. It might reflect more on your understanding. There is a range of difficulty of question provided in assessment and you may not be able to answer all of them. The exam is meant to categorise the degree of understanding you have of course material and macros are fair game here.


Feb 22, 2020 at 14:28 "there is a compilor error" -> there is not. Every macro will fail, depending where you insert it, either syntactically or logically.


Feb 22, 2020 at 15:05 I'm not arguing the point here as this is yet another to and fro with potentially no end. The point is that it makes no sense to return from a macro in this way. You won't gain anything from this argument as it's not a concrete point about something in your actual assessment. If your point is that this is not a legitimate question to ask, it's a moot point as this is a past exam and has come and gone. It is my view that the way students were marked on this was fairly as if they made an argument such as what you are making they would get the marks.



55.2.4    Lack of Transparency



RMIT claimed that "the way students were marked on this was fairly".

Was it "fairly"?

We will never know.

Why?

Because RMIT has a dubious policy to destroy all records and shred all exam papers not long after it releases the results.


RMIT and transparency are sworn enemies.

And to make matters worse, authorities let RMIT run amok with its crooked policies, evasions, and cover-ups.


55.3    Case Study: Linux Kernel and Macros Expanding to the return Keyword



This is a list of the 1,412 macros in the Linux kernel that expand to the return keyword.

All expansions are direct and immediate, meaning, unlike _bsc0(type, name) that expands to __bsc_return(type, res), which — in turn — expands to return.


Following links refer to commit 071a0578b0ce0b0e543d1e38ee6926b9cc21c198.

Chapter 56
— Theft by Finding





56.1    Theft by Finding Is Illegal



Theft by finding is a crime in Victoria under The Crimes Act (1958) Section 73.2(c), punishable by a maximum of 10 years' imprisonment.

A person commits theft by finding if he fails to take "reasonable steps" to locate the owner of a lost property.


The authorities use this law to prosecute various types of theft by finding.

For example, several years ago, a faulty ATM was over-dispensing free money to customers withdrawing cash from their bank accounts.

A dream come true.

However, the Victoria police spokesperson was quick to issue a press release warning that any person failing to amend the errors would be prosecuted to the fullest extent of the law.


56.2    RMIT's Illegal Practice of Theft by Finding



56.2.1    The Appeal Process



On Friday 03/07/2020 at 14:15, I went into length in my email to Prof. Aleksandar Subic explaining how the university was defrauding its paying students by withholding their rightfully-earned marks due to an error in the exam.

RMIT knew it was their own mistake, but, in order to protect their own, they — secretly — concocted a cover-up, falsely blamed the students behind their back and then refused to publish the results.


56.2.2    Prof. Aleksandar Subic Perpetuating Theft



He never replied.

Perhaps he was busy appeasing the lords of his (private) lobbying group.

No blame here.


56.3    RMIT Is Rotten to Its Core



56.3.1    RMIT's Dual Act of Corruption



However, note how the this case of theft by finding is worse than the examples shown above, which saw people sentenced to prison time.

Why is it worse?

Because the culprit here (namely, RMIT) is guilty — not only — for perpetuating the mistake but also for precipitating the mistake itself, to begin with.


56.3.2    Theft Committed in Two Stages



When you break it down, you see that this theft consisted of two stages:

  1. First, an error occurred in the exam.
  2. Then, RMIT perpetuated the error by refusing to make amends.



56.3.3    RMIT's Corrupt Practices



Make no mistake.

RMIT is criminally negligent and fully liable for the occurrence of the error itself due to its predatory business practices, which include:

  1. Wage theft of its casual, insecurely-employed tutors who mark (and write) the exams.
  2. Misappropriating federal funding meant to "verify the technical accuracy of the exams."
  3. Refuses to pay for services (available in all other universities) that would have ensured that errors (in the exam papers) were promptly addressed and fixed at the exam venue.



RMIT created a hostile environment that made it impossible for any errors to be looked into and fixed on the spot.

When I requested help from the invigilators regarding this error, they told me that teachers were not available to help.


This is a far cry from the passive customer mentioned above, who, through no fault of his own, was – by luck – awarded extra cash while withdrawing from his bank account.

You can not blame him for the mistake itself.

Yet, you witness the men in blue storming his house guns blazing for failing to return the money, while, at the same time, RMIT continues, to this day, to bully its students by failing to acknowledge any of their petitions regarding this theft.


56.3.4    Government Shoring Up RMIT's Corrupt Practices



And when I sought the help of the authorities, they could have — at least — ordered the publicly-funded university to comply and respond.

Did they?

No.

Did the government ensure that the law was followed, and a third-party venue was provided?

No.

Instead, they bullied the foreigner, stalled their response for 42 days and, then, told him that the university is "not responding" and there is nothing in the law to "force" their hands.


56.3.5    Prof. Aleksandar Subic Fails to Acknowledge Students as Human Beings



On Monday 06/07/2020 at 23:29, I requested Prof. Subic to confirm my previous email and/or provide an update.

No response or acknowledgement followed.


56.3.6    RMIT's General Counsel Affirming Theft



Behind the scenes, however, the office of Prof. Subic conspired with the university Ombudsman and the self-described "values-driven" General Counsel to keep the students in the dark.

You see, students expect these "independent" and "impartial" offices to launch investigative enquiries of their own and uphold students' rights.

Sadly, in reality, they do the direct opposite and act in loyal servitude to the Academic Board (which would play a pivotal role in advancing their careers).

Consequently, they — consistently — upheld the rulings of the Academic Board and use their power and government-delegated authority to bully and shut-up the students.


Unsurprisingly, RMIT's Ombudsman lied through their teeth to prevent the student from appealing.

Then, RMIT's General Counsel sent an inexplicable email on Thursday 16/07/2020 at 13:02 in which she "confirm[s]" the decision of the Academic Board, adding she "understand[s]" the issue was "closed".

No details or reasoning were provided, but I was urged to contact the office of Prof. Subic (the very same office I had just complained about) to "obtain further information."

Meaning, RMIT's General Counsel sent the victim back to his perpetrator to "obtain further information".


You see, the Chief Legal Counsel of RMIT was presented with clear-cut evidence of theft by the university where hundreds of students were — secretly — defrauded in the exam's grading, and those incorrect results were never disclosed to these victims.

Facing a choice, the "values-driven" General Counsel could have followed the law and ordered a third-party review.

She could have also contacted all affected students, provided a full disclosure and urged them to appeal.

Instead, she was quick to defend her masters, "confirmed" the theft and called it a day.

RMIT in a nutshell.


56.4    Empty Rhetoric



In his own press release — paid by my tuition fees — Prof. Aleksandar Subic let the world know that:

A key priority for Subic will be engaging with RMIT’s ongoing gender equality initiatives to promote women in STEMM industries, a priority the College is leading on at RMIT.

“This is a complex issue that requires a comprehensive diversity and inclusion strategy involving a range of different approaches,” he said.

“I will focus on supporting the development of female leaders and role models in STEMM while continuing to promote a culture of inclusion and diversity.”



56.4.1    All Talk, No Action



Now, Prof. Subic, in order to "promote a culture of inclusion and diversity", one has to ensure, at least, the following three:

• To stop wage theft regardless of race or gender.

• To stop racial discrimination regardless of race or gender.

• To stop stealing from unsuspecting students – behind their back – as was shown here.







Chapter 57
— Scrabble





57.1    Summary



Scrabble is a popular game in English-speaking countries.

Approximately one-third of American and half of British homes have a Scrabble set.

And, as a popular TV game show, Scrabble once dominated daytime television (running for 1,335 episodes between 2/7/84 and 23/3/90 and later in 1993).

Consequently, a foreign student who never heard about this game should not be allowed to work as a programmer in Australia.

Or so claimed RMIT.


57.2    Scrabble and the English Language



Scrabble was originally designed and based on facts and realities uniquely present in the English language.

Scrabble is defined in Wikipedia as:

In an English-language set, the game contains 100 tiles, 98 of which are marked with a letter and a point value ranging from 1 to 10.

The number of points for each lettered tile is based on the letter's frequency in standard English; commonly used letters such as vowels are worth one point, while less common letters score higher, with Q and Z each worth 10 points.

Scrabble – Wikipedia



RMIT is uniquely (among Australian universities) "the most reliant on revenue from international student fees."

Most of the foreign students come from Asian countries, including China.

Scrabble, as anybody (except RMIT) would acknowledge, is not part of their culture.

Neither the game nor its concepts of tile values.

Most Chinese words are between one and three characters long, and there are thousands of different characters.

Translating (and adapting) Scrabble into their language is mission impossible.


57.3    Scrabble and Non-Alphabetic Writing Systems



57.3.1    Scrabble and English



The English language uses the Latin alphabet, which is classified as an Alphabetic writing system.

As already noted, Scrabble was originally based on facts and realities found in the English language and its Alphabetic writing systems.

Consequently, its concepts are not readily adaptable to other writing systems utilized in other languages.


For example, let's consider either one of the following writing systems:

  • Logographic writing systems (used in Chinese languages, etc.)
  • Abjad writing systems (used in Arabic, etc.)



There are plenty of reasons (see later in this chapter) why adapting this game into those languages and their writing systems is either impossible or rather contrived and unnatural.

It is not a coincidence that Scrabble is not widespread among nations whose writing systems are not based on the Latin alphabet.


57.3.2    Bigotry Galore



RMIT's top-echelon allows itself excessive 7-figure salaries and unlimited perks and benefits.

This monstrous expense is heavily reliant on overpriced and exorbitant tuition fees paid by poor students from foreign countries.

However, look with horror at how many nationals were discriminated against by the bigoted (and narrow-minded) culture of RMIT.

As the following table will demonstrate.


57.3.3    List of Writing Scripts and Their Associated Languages



Wikipedia: List of Writing Scripts

Name of script Type Population actively using (in millions) Languages associated with Regions with predominant usage
Latin Alphabet 4900+ Latin and Romance languages (Italian, French, Portuguese, Spanish and Romanian), Germanic languages (English, Dutch, German, Nordic languages), Finnish, Malaysian, Indonesian, Filipino, Visayan languages, Turkish, Azerbaijani, Polish, Somali, Vietnamese, others Worldwide
Chinese Logographic 1340 Chinese, Japanese (Kanji), Korean (Hanja), Vietnamese (Chu Nom obsolete), Zhuang (Sawndip) Eastern Asia, Singapore, Malaysia
Arabic Abjad or abugida (when diacritics are used) 660+ Arabic, Persian, Urdu, Punjabi (Shahmukhi in Pakistan), Pashto, Sindhi, Balochi, Kashmiri, Malay (Jawi), Uyghur, Kazakh (in China), Kurdish, Azeri (in Iran), and others Middle East and North Africa, Pakistan, India (Urdu co-official in some states), China (Xinjiang), Malaysia
Devanagari Abugida 608+ Hindi, Marathi, Konkani, Nepali, Sanskrit, several others India, Nepal
Cyrillic Alphabet 250 Bulgarian, Russian, Serbian, Ukrainian, Macedonian, others Eastern Europe, Central Asia and Mongolia, the Russian Far East
Kana Syllabary 120 Japanese, Okinawan, Ainu Japan
Javanese Abugida 80 Javanese Central Java (Indonesia), Javanese diaspora
Hangul Alphabet, featural 78.7 Korean Korea (North and South), Jilin Province (China), Cia-Cia Tribe (Buton Island, Indonesia)
Telugu Abugida 74 Telugu Andhra Pradesh, Telangana, Puducherry (India)
Tamil Abugida 70 Tamil Tamil Nadu (India), Puducherry (India), Sri Lanka, Singapore, Malaysia, Mauritius
Gujarati Abugida 48 Gujarati, Kutchi, Vasavi, Sanskrit, Avestan India, Pakistan
Kannada Abugida 45 Kannada Karnataka (India)
Burmese Abugida 39 Burmese Myanmar
Malayalam Abugida 38 Malayalam Kerala, Puducherry (India)
Thai Abugida 38 Thai, Southern Thai, Northern Khmer and Lao (Isan) Thailand
Sundanese Abugida 38 Sundanese Java, Indonesia
Gurmukhi Abugida 22 Punjabi Punjab (India)
Lao Abugida 22 Lao Laos
Odia Abugida 21 Odia Odisha (India)
Ge'ez Abugida 18 Amharic, Tigrinya Ethiopia, Eritrea
Sinhala Abugida 14.4 Sinhalese Sri Lanka
Hebrew Abjad 14 Hebrew and other Jewish languages Israel



57.3.4    The Abjad Writing System



In case you don't know Arabic (or any related language), you may find the following explanation from Wikipedia helpful.

"Abjad is a type of writing system in which (in contrast to true alphabets) each symbol or glyph stands for a consonant, in effect leaving it to readers to infer or otherwise supply an appropriate vowel."

In Hebrew, for example, the word 'ספר' has nine different pronunciations, each with a different meaning.


57.4    Complex Orthography and Redundancy



English orthography is notoriously complex and full of redundancies.

Some examples follow.


57.4.1    The 'ough' Tetragraph



In the English language, one has to grapple with the 'ough' tetragraph:

  • enough, rough, tough
  • although, dough, doughnut, furlough, though
  • bought, brought, fought, nought, ought, sought, thought, wrought 
  • borough, thorough
  • through
  • cough, trough
  • drought, plough



"Though the tough cough and hiccough plough him thoroughly through, he ought to cross the lough."


57.4.2    The 'eigh' Tetragraph



Another example is the eigh tetragraph (eight, freight, inveigh, neigh, neighbour, sleigh, weigh).


57.4.3    The 'augh' Tetragraph



Yet another example is the augh tetragraph (caught, daughter, distraught, fraught, naught, onslaught, slaughter, taught).


57.4.4    The 'ou' Digraph



The common 'ou' digraph is not much more fun.

Compare the following:

  • abound, about, announce, around, astound, blouse, bounce, bound bounty, bout, cloud, clout, couch, council, counsel, count crouch, douse, flounder, flour, flout, foul, found, fount, fountain gouge, grouch, ground, grout, hound, hour, house, joust, loud, lounge louse, mound, mount, mountain, mouse, mouth, noun, ouch, ounce, our oust, out, outdoor, outside, pouch, pounce, pound, pout, proud, round rouse, rout, scoundrel, scour, scout, scrounge, shout, shroud slouch, sound, sour, south, spouse, spout, thou, tout, trounce, trout vouch, voucher, without
  • course, court, four, fourth, mourn, pour, source, your
  • acoustics, boulevard, boutique, cougar, coup, coupon, courier, crouton goulash, group, routine, soup, tour, uncouth, wound, you, youth
  • country, couple, courage, cousin, double, encourage, enough, flourish, nourish, rough, southern, touch, tough, trouble, young
  • soul
  • would, should, could



57.4.5    Orthography and Scrabble



What a pain!

This pain is what made Scrabble challenging and successful.

"No pain, no gain."


Other languages (Hebrew included) do not have the damn digraphs, trigraphs, tetragraphs, and pentagraphs.

Each consonant has exactly one corresponding letter, while the vowels have zero letters.


57.4.6    Kaped Rosho



In fact, a common Israeli word game is to repeatedly "behead" the first letter of a word, only to end up, again and again, with yet another word.

Can you name an example in English?

In Hebrew:

  • עכביש, כביש, ביש, יש, ש
  • מאזנַיִם, אָזְנַיִם, זנים, נים, ים



57.4.7    Two-Letter Words in Hebrew



In Hebrew, if you randomly select two letters, you probably got yourself a word.

In fact, many of the 2-letter words amount to multiple words depending on the pronunciation.

Take the first Hebrew letter Aleph, for example:

אב father
אד a vapour
או or
אז then
אח brother
אט slowly
אי island; not
אך but
אל god; to; do not
אם if; mother
אס ace
אף even; nose
אץ hurry
אש fire
את you; "the" (PRE); shovel



You see how easy it is to build a word (given a random selection of tiles) in this language.

A game of Scrabble in this language is just way too tame, boring, and dull as hell.


57.5    Prefixes, Suffixes and Verb Conjugations



Furthermore, in Hebrew there are unlimited prefixes and suffixes that can be added to almost any word, including:

  • Possessive suffixes ("my/his book"; further divided to reflect person/gender/number).
  • The definite article ("the book").
  • Prepositions ("from", "to", "in", "as", "than", and countless others).
  • Conjunctions ("and").
  • Directional suffixes ("to his house", "eastward").
  • And many more ("which", vav hahipuch, to name a few).



Then, you have the verbs.

First, verbs are conjugated to reflect tense, mood, person, gender, and number.

Then you multiply by seven to get all the binyanim ("stems") of each "root".


You see, there is no need for "hooking" strategies and memorization tricks while playing Scrabble in this language.

Adding "random" letters to existing words on the board is just damn too easy.


57.6    Hebrew and Standardized Spelling



And there is more.

In Hebrew, you have to deal with the reality that it can be spelled in a myriad of ways, which, although different, are still equally legitimate.


The entry Ktiv Hasar niqqud (in Wikipedia) reads:

Despite the Academy's standardization of the rules for ktiv male, there is a substantial lack of unity in writing, partly because of a lack of grammatical knowledge, partly because of the historical layers of the language, and partly because of a number of linguistic categories in which the Academy's decisions are not popular. As a result, book publishers and newspaper editors make their own judgments.




Do we agree that without standardized spelling, a game of Scrabble is impossible?


57.7    Scrabble in Israel



57.7.1    Sam Orbaum



The Jerusalem Scrabble Club is "one of the largest Scrabble clubs in the world."

It was founded by Sam Orbaum, a rated North American Scrabble player, who immigrated to Israel in 1981.

To pursue his hobby, he founded the club on April 5, 1983.

He managed the club until he passed away in December 2002, and it was since renamed in his honour.


Sam Orbaum is quoted regarding Scrabble and the Hebrew language:

Sam Orbaum tells me that Scrabble in Israel is played almost exclusively in English (by adults at any rate).

The lack of redundancy in the orthography of the language and lack of vowels when written (similar to Arabic) means that almost any string of tiles can be a word.

Consequently, the game is much less challenging and, therefore, the province primarily of children and learners of Hebrew as a foreign language.

If there is a preferred dictionary for play in Hebrew, it is probably the one edited by Even Shoshan, but due to the lack of organised Hebrew play — that has no official standing.



57.7.2    Haaretz



The Haaretz newspaper from 06/07/2008 reads:

Israel's Anglo Scrabble Players Take Their Game Very Seriously

The 200 competitive Scrabble players in Israel play in English, saying Hebrew doesn't lend itself to the popular board game.

[...]

The players in Cohen's club use the English version of the game – not because they despise the language of the Bible, heaven forbid, but simply because "Hebrew is not suited to Scrabble. English has good letters and bad letters, common ones and infrequent ones, but in Hebrew you don't have that. V, for example, is a bad letter, because it is in very few words, and Q is worth a lot of points. In Hebrew, almost every two letters make a word, which makes the game a lot easier. Hebrew also has a problem with standard [biblical] versus full [modern] spelling, and there are no authoritative rules as to how to spell a particular word. English has a special Scrabble dictionary, containing all the words that may be used (as of today, 267,751), but Hebrew doesn't have that."

Cohen and the 200 competitive Scrabble players in Israel (all of whom use the English version) owe their hobby [...]



57.8    Most Common Words in English



As an official part of assignment 2, students in this course were required to test their (developed) text editors using example files authored (or collected) by RMIT.

The main example file contained 2 lists of the most common words in the English Language.

Those lists were:

  • 6,318 Most frequent words in the British National Corpus (800+ occurrences).
    — Lines 121,708 to 128,025 of big.txt.
  • 10,000 Most Frequent Words in Project Gutenberg as of 04/2006.
    — Lines 128,027 to 128,443 of big.txt.



None of those lists (of most common words) contained the word 'Scrabble'.

Those lists were collected by the Unit Coordinator himself.

Meaning, RMIT knew full-well that 'Scrabble' is not a common word, and, therefore, foreign students may be unfamiliar with.

But they couldn't care less.


57.9    Level of English Proficiency Required for This Course



RMIT lays out the English requirements for international students seeking a bachelor's degree in Information Technology as:

"IELTS (Academic): minimum overall band of 6.5 (with no individual band below 6.0)."


The Official Cambridge Guide to IELTS at this level (or even higher ones) does not contain the word 'Scrabble'.


57.10    RMIT's Adaptation of Exam to Foreign Students



57.10.1    Culture-Specific Assumption in the Exam



Finally, RMIT based its question on the concept of tile values in Scrabble where different tiles – representing different letters – have different values.

For example, the letter 'e' (which is 100 to 150 times more frequent than the letters 'q' and 'z') has a low value of 1 point because it is too common and thus deemed "easy".

The "hard" letters, like 'q' and 'z', have a value of 10 points.


In Hebrew, however, the most frequent letters are only 5 to 10 times more common than the least frequent ones.

Hence, you don't generally encounter a 10-level hierarchy of tile values in Hebrew like the one cited in the exam.


57.10.2    RMIT's Offhand Explanation



Needless to say, the exam did not even bother to explain the hierarchy other than — offhandedly — refer to "the scores of each letter".

What scores?

Very few languages have frequency-dependent tile values associated with their letters.

Many do not.

Nor is it conceivable for Chinese Languages (and its 50,000+ characters).


57.10.3    RMIT's Gibberish and Incorrect Explanation



There is more!

RMIT left the foreign student to grapple with gibberish and false descriptions of Scrabble that made no sense.


This was their "explanation".

820 word score which is the same of the scores of each letter.




"A word score, which is the same of the scores of each letter".

Let's try again.

"A word score, which is the same of the scores of each letter".

Hello! Is this English?


Does RMIT believe that foreign students (who were unfamiliar with this game) were given a fair go?

Or they couldn't care less.


Besides, isn't it false that a word score is the "same" as "each" of its letters?

Why is RMIT lying to its foreign students?


57.10.4    RMIT's Typos in Data Structure Shown to the Students



Shockingly, there is more.

RMIT mangled the prototype and, as a result, distorted the essence of the data structure; meaning, the data type shown to the students had zero resemblance to Scrabble.

In other words, not only did they fail to provide a reasonably-correct explanation (as shown above), but RMIT confused the hell out of its foreign students by showing a data type that defied the very basics of Scrabble.


57.11    Unfair Hurdles



57.11.1    Unfair Time Constraint for Foreign Students



As noted, RMIT expected the student to provide his answer in 12.5 minutes.

A full answer consisted of 2,073 characters.

However, due to the errors and gibberish shown above, RMIT forced the foreign student to waste all of his 12.5 minutes trying to make sense of their rubbish explanations.

So, how much time did RMIT afford the foreign student to write the answer (that consisted of 2,073 characters)?

Zero.


57.11.2    Teachers Not Available During the Exam



As noted, RMIT is the only university (in Australia) that doesn't pay its teachers to be available during the exam to answer students' queries.


57.11.3    No Proof-Reading or Sanity Checks of Its Sloppily-Written Exams



And as noted, RMIT looted the federal grants meant to ensure that their exam does not disadvantage foreign students (who pay the most in tuition fees) in its use of esoteric language and culture-specific concepts that foreigners may not be familiar with.

RMIT is also criminally negligent by looting the funds meant for proof-reading of the exams.


57.11.4    Hostile to Foreign Students by Disallowing Dictionaries



And RMIT is the only university (in Australia) that doesn't allow its foreign students access to a dictionary (as was set out on top of the examination paper).

And unlawful in Victoria under the Equal Opportunity Act 2010.

Chapter 58
— Antisemitism





58.1    Extreme Rhetoric



There is a type of extreme rhetoric on social media that is widely regarded as antisemitic propaganda.

For example, the Unit-Coordinator for Information Technology courses at RMIT is very vocal on social media where he:

  1. Shows support for deadly terrorist attacks on civilians in Israel.
  2. Writes that the "horrific Zionist regime" should have long been "abolished" and it's a shame it "managed to last for so long".
  3. Attacks Jewish American lawmakers and calls them traitors who "swear allegiance" to a "foreign power".
  4. Vilifies the Ultra-Orthodox Jewish community.
  5. Claims that Jews should not be Members of Congress because they "put the needs of a foreign power over those of American citizens."
  6. Refers to Israel as an apartheid state and — routinely — circulates blood libels and vile propaganda against it (including that Israel has killed half of the population in Gaza).
  7. Consistently, hurls antisemitic abuse at Jewish minority, claiming, among others, that Jews were "exactly the crowd I would expect to recriminate" and blame others for their own deaths.



Yet, RMIT saw fit to let this academic (who — routinely — retweets BDS campaigns to boycott and punish Israeli Jews in Australia, and to "push Israel off campus") grade my exam.

What could possibly go wrong?


When he was not grading Jewish students, this academic used his influence to promote his bloodthirsty propaganda against Israel.

And, sadly, his students (from my class) bought his lies and signed his petition "Australians Said No to Apartheid — Prevent Australian Companies from Trading With Israel".

Then, he would use RMIT's computers and/or allowance to brand Jews as the enemy of the state.

Welcome to RMIT.


58.2    Inexplicable Decisions



My answers to the very first assignment were 100% correct.

However, there was one "problem", namely, I made a spelling error in copying the name of the file.

The marker decided to make a fuss about a spelling error (in a programming assignment) and gave me zero marks.

Yes, you read that right; zero marks for a fully correct answer.


Then, there was the issue of a language barrier in the exam.

For some reason, RMIT decided to base one of the questions in the exam on a culture-specific game, which meant that only local students were able to understand it.

I wrote on the exam paper that I was discriminated against because teachers were not available during the exam, and invigilators were not of any help.

This academic decided to hit me with a full penalty for not being able — culturally and linguistically — to answer the question.

This decision defies law, policy and common sense.

It readily suggests an undisclosed and sinister motive at play.

Right?


Then, of course, there were dozens of bold-faced lies told by this academic (laid out in detail in the preceding chapters).

For example, look here and here (which I complained about, only to be laughed off by the Academic Board headed by Prof. Subic).


58.3    Abuse of Power



RMIT's academics who grade the exams are given unparalleled powers to secretly and single-handedly seal the fate and sabotage the employment prospects of their students without any oversight or accountability.


In RMIT — unlike other Australian universities — there is neither blind-grading (where students' names are concealed) nor double-marking (where a second marker grades independently of the first one).

Furthermore, appeals are neglected, reviews by independent third-parties are thwarted, state authorities are ignored, and litigation and/or lawsuits are barred by the High Court.

No checks and balances.


Teachers do not (nor will they ever) give any explanation for their decisions; no feedback or reasoning behind the grade is written on the examination paper.


Exam results at RMIT are kept as a top-secret.

Nobody is allowed to see the marked exam or know its results, not even the student himself (yes, you read that right).

Not long after the release of the final results, all exam papers are shredded, and all records of the results are permanently disposed of and destroyed.

Zero transparency.


This was an ideal environment for this rabid academic to carry out his personal vendetta against the ultimate evil of the world.

Would he resist the temptation?


US President Abraham Lincoln famously said:

If you want to test a man's character, give him power.



Inspecting the exam and its grading, one cannot help but notice the ruthless retribution inflicted on the "Zionist" by this glorious freedom fighter.

While hiding behind the "sanctity of academic freedom" that prohibits outside scrutiny of his "infallible" decisions, he ambushed and — secretly — assailed the unsuspecting Zionist by taking away just about all of his marks.


The many lines of code skimmed over by the marker speak for themselves.

Somehow, when reading the answers of the Jewish student, the marker got distracted.

Fully correct answers, identical word by word to the "approved" ones, went inexplicably unnoticed by this heroic crusader.

And while he gave him — on occasion — a few marks, he plundered the majority of the marks of the Jewish scum.

Long live the holy crusade!


My grade plummeted down to 45%, which is below the minimum threshold of 50%.

As a result, this evil Zionist will be blocked from seeking (credible) employment based on this grade.

Yet another victory for the glorified intifada!


By contrast, students from my class — who conformed to his ideology, signed his antisemitic pamphlet and cheered on his blood libels against Israel (that he maliciously made up on his own in order to stir up barbaric hatred of Israeli Jews) — successfully passed the exam.

RMIT has two choices.

The first one is to preserve all the records and allow for a fair comparison between the marking of the Jewish student and the antisemitic one.

The second one is to destroy the records and rot in jail.




Appendix: Exam




1 Study Period 4, 2019 2 3 University: RMIT University 4 Exam Code(s): CPT220 5 Title of Paper: Programming in C 6 Exam Duration: 2 hours 7 Reading Time: 10 minutes 8 9 10 During an exam, you must not have in your possession, a book, notes, paper, 11 electronic device(s), calculator, pencil case, mobile phone, smart watch/device 12 or any other material/item which has not been authorized for the exam or 13 specifically permitted as noted below. 14 15 Any material or item on your desk, chair or person will be deemed to be in your 16 possession. You are reminded that possession of unauthorized materials in an 17 exam is a disciplinary offence. 18 19 No examination papers are to be removed from the room. 20 21 22 Authorized material 23 24 Calculators ☐ Yes ☒ No 25 Open Book ☐ Yes ☒ No 26 Specifically Permitted Items ☐ Yes ☒ No 27

Question 1(A)

28 Please note that you may assume for all questions that a BOOLEAN type is 29 defined with valid values of TRUE and FALSE. 30 31 Question 1 (30 Marks) 32 33 A) What is the output of the following code? 34 35 Clearly indicate in your output the line number of each line of output, 36 and show any newline characters as '\n' (10 marks). 37 38 1 #include <stdio.h> 39 2 #include <stdlib.h> 40 3 #include <string.h> 41 4 42 5 int main(void) 43 6 { 44 7 char *strings[] = { "no", "good", "deed", "is", "left", "unpunished" }; 45 8 puts(*strings); 46 9 puts(*(strings + 2)); 47 10 putchar(*(*(strings + 5) + 4)); 48 11 putchar(*(*(strings + 4) + 2) + 4); 49 12 puts("happy" + 3); 50 13 51 14 return EXIT_SUCCESS; 52 15 }

"Approved" Answer 1(A) of RMIT

53 Line 8: no\n 2 marks 54 Line 9: deed\n 2 marks 55 Line 10: n 2 marks 56 Line 11: j 2 marks 57 Line 12: py\n 2 marks 58 59 Allocate 1 mark, for the output of the line, 60 and 1 mark, for the presence or the absence of a newline character.

Answer 1(A) of the Student

61 8) "no\n" 2 marks 62 9) "deed\n" 2 marks 63 10) 'n' 2 marks 64 10) 'j' 2 marks 65 11) "py\n" 2 marks

Question 1(B)

66 B) C Macros are a unique aspect of the C programming language. 67 68 It is often said however that C macros are much harder to debug than normal 69 functions. 70 71 Why is this? What benefit do macros give us over normal functions? (5 Marks)

"Approved" Answer 1(B) of RMIT

72 C macros are evaluated as a single line of code and thus we cannot debug 73 the code with a debugger such as gdb. 74 75 However macros are evaluated at compile time and thus do not have the overheads 76 of calling and cleanup that functions do. 5 marks

Answer 1(B) of the Student

77 Positive: 5 marks 78 1) Code is re-used, easier to maintain/modify. 79 Code is clearer to read, able to modify the var itself, and not copy. 80 2) No runtime cost of pushing on the stack, register assignments etc., on entry 81 to the function and pop up on exit. 82 83 Negative: 84 1) No call-trace - as there is no actual call, push and pop. Harder to debug. 85 2) May be less readable if the macro expansion is not that obvious.

Question 1(C)

86 C) There is a potential bug in the following function. 87 88 What is it and how would I fix it (5 Marks)? 89 90 Hint: this has something to do with the use of the realloc() function. 91 92 Please identify the line numbers you would change and what you would 93 replace them with. 94 95 1 BOOLEAN lengthen_string(char *string, const char newcontents[]) 96 2 { 97 3 int newlen = strlen(string) + strlen(newcontents) + 1; 98 4 string = realloc(string, newlen); 99 5 if (!string) 100 6 { 101 7 perror("malloc"); 102 8 return FALSE; 103 9 } 104 10 strcat(string, newcontents); 105 11 return TRUE; 106 12 }

"Approved" Answer 1(C) of RMIT

107 Line 4 realloc returns a NULL pointer when it fails to allocate. 108 This means that on failure the original data is lost. 109 110 To fix this, 111 assign the result of realloc to a temporary variable and test that first. 112 113 i.e. line 4: 114 char *temp = realloc(string, newlen); 115 if(!temp) ... (all remains the same) 116 117 After old line 9: 118 string = temp; 119 120 5 marks for identifying the problem and the solution.

Answer 1(C) of the Student

121 Modifies the local @string, 122 where the caller will still hold the memory to the old area. 0 marks

Question 1(D)

123 D) Consider the follow C program. 124 Lines 42-43 cause an error to be printed by valgrind. 125 What is the error message? 126 127 (I don't need all the detail, just the first line of the error message). 128 129 Also, it turns out the culprit is the list_init() function. 130 How would you change this to avoid the problem? 131 Identify the line numbers you would change and the new code. (10 Marks) 132 133 1 #include <stdio.h> 134 2 #include <stdlib.h> 135 3 #include <string.h> 136 2 137 5 typedef enum 138 6 { 139 7 FALSE, 140 8 TRUE 141 9 } BOOLEAN; 142 10 143 11 struct node { 144 12 struct node *next; 145 13 int data; 146 14 }; 147 15 148 16 149 17 struct list 150 18 { 151 19 struct node *head; 152 20 int size; 153 21 }; 154 22 155 23 BOOLEAN list_init(struct list *alist) 156 24 { 157 25 alist = malloc(sizeof(struct list)); 158 26 if (!alist) { 159 27 return FALSE; 160 28 } 161 29 162 30 alist->head = NULL; 163 31 alist->size = 0; 164 32 return TRUE; 165 33 } 166 34 167 35 int main() 168 36 { 169 37 struct list newlist; 170 38 if (!list_init(&newlist)) { 171 39 return EXIT_FAILURE; 172 40 } 173 41 174 42 printf("Contents of the new list is: %p, %d\n",(void *)newlist.head, 175 43 newlist.size); 176 44 return EXIT_SUCCESS; 177 45 }

"Approved" Answer 1(D) of RMIT

178 Error message: conditional based on uninitialised values 179 Fix: simply delete lines 25-29 (5 marks for error message and 5 marks for fix).

Answer 1(D) of the Student

180 All assignments are to a local copy of @alist. 1 mark 181 182 Fix: Delete lines 25-29, 183 as @newlist resides on the stack and not from the heap. 5 marks

Question 2(A)

184 Question 2: Strings and Memory Allocation (30 Marks) 185 186 Consider the following structures as a representation of a text file in memory: 187 188 struct line { 189 char *text; 190 int len; 191 }; 192 193 struct document { 194 struct line **lines; /* array of line pointers */ 195 int numlines; /* the count of the lines that have been used */ 196 int lines_alloced; /* the number of line pointers in the lines array, 197 whether used or not. */ 198 }; 199 200 201 A) Write a function called document_make() that allocates memory for an 202 empty document and initialises it to a known empty state. 203 204 You should allocate 50 empty lines to the array to begin with.(10 marks) 205 206 The function prototype for the function you are to implement is: 207 208 struct document *document_make(void);

"Approved" Answer 2(A) of RMIT

209 struct document *document_make(void) 210 { 211 /* 2 marks for correct declarations */ 212 struct document *thedoc; 213 214 215 /* 216 * allocate memory for the document itself and check it succeeded 217 * (success checks are worth half the marks) - 3 marks 218 */ 219 220 thedoc = (struct document *)malloc(sizeof(struct document)); 221 if (!thedoc) { 222 perror("malloc"); 223 return NULL; 224 } 225 226 227 /* allocate memory for the lines - 3 marks */ 228 229 thedoc->lines = (struct line **)malloc(sizeof(struct line) * MINLINES); 230 if (!thedoc->lines) { 231 perror("malloc"); 232 free(thedoc); 233 return NULL; 234 } 235 236 237 /* initialise with sensible values - 2 marks */ 238 239 memset(thedoc->lines, 0, sizeof(struct line) * MINLINES); 240 thedoc->numlines = 0; 241 thedoc->lines_alloced = MINLINES; 242 243 /* return the pointer - 1 mark */ 244 return thedoc; 245 }

Answer 2(A) of the Student

246 struct document *document_make(void) 247 { 248 struct document *d; /* 2 marks */ 249 250 if ((d = calloc(1, sizeof *d)) == NULL) { /* 3 marks */ 251 fprintf(stderr, "calloc() failed\n"); 252 exit(1); 253 } 254 255 if ((d->lines = malloc(50 * sizeof *d->lines)) == NULL) { 256 fprintf(stderr, "alloc error\n"); 257 exit(1); 258 } 259 260 d->numlines = 0; /* 2 marks */ 261 d->num_allocated = 50; 262 263 return d; 264 }

Question 2(B)

265 B) Write a function to add a line passed in into this document. 266 You should check that the line can fit in the document first and if not, 267 double the number of lines the document can store. 268 269 Then, add the line to the list of lines.(15 Marks) 270 271 The function prototype for this function is: 272 273 BOOLEAN doc_add_line(struct document * thedoc, const char newline[]);

"Approved" Answer 2(B) of RMIT

274 /* 275 * make_line is part of the solution to part b of question 2 - they don't need 276 * to make a new function but they do need to implement its functionality 277 */ 278 279 struct line *make_line(const char line[]) 280 { 281 /* allocate space for the line and check it succeeded - 3 marks */ 282 283 struct line *theline = (struct line *)malloc(sizeof(struct line)); 284 if (!theline) { 285 perror("malloc"); 286 return NULL; 287 } 288 289 290 /*initialise the line's data */ 291 /* set the line's length - 1 mark */ 292 293 theline->len = strlen(line); 294 295 296 /* allocate space for the string and copy the data in - 3 marks */ 297 298 theline->text = (char *)malloc(sizeof(char) * (theline->len + 1)); 299 strcpy(theline->text, line); 300 301 return theline; 302 } 303 304 305 /* 306 * the core of question 2B 307 */ 308 BOOLEAN doc_add_line(struct document *thedoc, const char line[]) 309 { 310 /* 2 marks for reasonable variable declarations */ 311 struct line *aline; 312 313 aline = make_line(line); 314 if (!aline) { 315 return FALSE; 316 } 317 318 /* check if we have enough space for the lines - 1 mark */ 319 if (thedoc->numlines == thedoc->lines_alloced) { 320 321 /* allocate space for more lines - 4 marks */ 322 int newsize = thedoc->numlines * 2; 323 324 struct line **newlines = (struct line **)realloc(thedoc->lines, 325 sizeof(struct line *) * newsize); 326 if (!newlines) { 327 perror("realloc"); 328 return FALSE; 329 } 330 331 thedoc->lines = newlines; 332 thedoc->lines_alloced = newsize; 333 } 334 335 /* store the line - 1 mark */ 336 337 thedoc->lines[thedoc->numlines++] = aline; 338 339 return TRUE; 340 }

Answer 2(B) of the Student

341 static BOOLEAN expand(struct document *d); 342 343 BOOLEAN doc_add_line(struct document *d, const char *l) 344 { 345 /* Assumption: 346 All occupied lines follow each other. 347 There are no holes. */ 348 349 struct line *line; 350 351 if (d->numlines >= d->num_allocated) { /* 1 mark */ 352 if (!expand(d)) 353 return FALSE; 354 } 355 356 /* No strdup() on line */ 357 358 if ((line = calloc(1, sizeof *line)) == NULL) { /* 3 marks */ 359 fprintf(stderr, "calloc() failed\n"); 360 exit(1); 361 } 362 363 line->text = l; 364 line->len = strlen(l); /* 1 mark */ 365 d->lines[d->numlines++] = line; /* 0.5 mark */ 366 367 return TRUE; 368 } 369 370 static BOOLEAN expand(struct document *d) 371 { 372 int len; 373 len = d->lines_allocated + 50; 374 375 if ((d->lines = realloc(d->lines, sizeof d->lines * len)) == NULL) { /* 3 marks */ 376 fprintf(stderr, "realloc() failed\n"); 377 return FALSE; 378 } 379 380 d->num_allocated = len; 381 return TRUE; 382 }

Question 2(C)

383 C) Write a function to free a given document, including its pointer. (5 Marks) 384 385 The function prototype for this function is: 386 BOOLEAN document_free(struct document * thedoc);

"Approved" Answer 2(C) of RMIT

387 /* 388 * question 2C - please note that even though they are asked to implement 389 * document_free(), both document_free and line_free form part of my solution 390 */ 391 392 void linefree(struct line * theline) 393 { 394 free(theline->text); /* 1 mark */ 395 free(theline); /* 1 mark */ 396 } 397 398 void document_free(struct document *thedoc) 399 { 400 int count; 401 402 /* iterate over the lines and free each line, 2 marks */ 403 for (count = 0; count < thedoc->numlines; ++count) { 404 linefree(thedoc->lines[count]); 405 } 406 407 /* free the lines and the doc individual pointers. */ 408 free(thedoc->lines); /* 0.5 mark */ 409 free(thedoc); /* 0.5 mark */ 410 } 411

Answer 2(C) of the Student

412 static void line_free(struct line *l); 413 414 /* Assumption: 415 * There are no holes and the lines occupied follow each other. 416 */ 417 static void document_free(struct document *d) 418 { 419 int i; 420 for (i = 0; i < d->numlines; i++) { 421 struct line *line = d->lines[i]; /* 2 marks */ 422 line_free(line); 423 } 424 free(d->lines); /* 0.5 mark */ 425 free(d); /* 0.5 mark */ 426 } 427 428 static void line_free(struct line *l) 429 { 430 free(l->text); 431 free(l); 432 }

Question 3(A)

433 Question 3: Loading a Document and collecting analysis for display (30 Marks). 434 435 For this question you will call the functions from question 2 but we will not 436 assume that you have question 2 implemented correctly or incorrectly in marking 437 this. 438 You may assume that you have versions of the question 2 functions on hand 439 and they have been implemented correctly. 440 441 A) write a function to load the lines from a file into the document structure. 442 (10 Marks) 443 444 The function prototype for this function is: 445 446 struct document *document_load(const char filename[]); 447 448

"Approved" Answer 3(A) of RMIT

449 /* 450 * question 3A solution 451 */ 452 453 struct document *document_load(const char filename[]) 454 { 455 /* 1 mark for reasonable variable declarations */ 456 457 FILE *reader; 458 struct document *doc; 459 char line[BUFSIZ + 2]; 460 461 462 /* open the reader and check for success - 2 marks */ 463 464 reader = fopen(filename, "r"); 465 if (!reader) { 466 perror("fopen"); 467 return NULL; 468 } 469 470 /* call document_make to allocate the document or reimplement its 471 * functionality - 1 mark 472 */ 473 doc = document_make(); 474 475 476 /* read each line from the file - 2 marks */ 477 478 while (fgets(line, BUFSIZ + 2, reader)) { 479 480 /* remove the newline characters - 1 mark */ 481 line[strlen(line) - 1] = 0; 482 483 484 /* add the line to the document - 1 mark */ 485 486 if (!doc_add_line(doc, line)) { 487 document_free(doc); 488 return NULL; 489 } 490 } 491 492 /* close the file pointer - 1 mark */ 493 fclose(reader); 494 495 /* return the document - 1 mark */ 496 return doc; 497 } 498

Answer 3(A) of the Student

499 #define BUFSIZE (1<<12) 500 struct document *document_load(const char *f) 501 { 502 char buf[BUFSIZE]; 503 FILE *F; 504 Document *d; 505 506 if ((F = fopen(f, "r")) == NULL) /* 1 mark */ 507 fprintf(stderr, "error\n"), exit(1); 508 509 d = document_make(); /* 1 mark */ 510 if (d == NULL) 511 return NULL; 512 513 while (fgets(buf, sizeof buf, F) != NULL) { /* 1 mark */ 514 /* Strip newlines ? */ 515 516 if (doc_add_line(d, strdup(buf)) == FALSE) 517 return NULL; 518 } 519 520 return d; /* 1 mark */ 521 }

Question 3(B)

522 B) write a function that parses the loaded document to collect stats on the document. 523 (15 Marks) 524 525 The stats you need to collect on the file are summarised in the follow stats struct: 526 527 struct stats { 528 int linecount; 529 int wordcount; 530 int alphacount; 531 int uppercount; 532 int lowercount; 533 int spacecount; 534 int whitespacecount; 535 int punctcount; 536 int digitcount; 537 }; 538 539 A word is considered to be alphabetical characters surrounded by 540 whitespace or punctuation. 541 Digits may be part of a word.

"Approved" Answer 3(B) of RMIT

542 struct stats collect_stats(struct document * doc) 543 { 544 struct stats thestats = { 0 }; 545 546 int count; 547 BOOLEAN isword = FALSE; 548 549 550 /* iterate over each line in the document - 1 mark */ 551 552 for (count = 0; count < doc->numlines; ++count) { 553 int charcount; 554 struct line *curline = doc->lines[count]; 555 char *text = doc->lines[count]->text; 556 557 558 /* iterate over each line of text - 1 mark */ 559 560 for (charcount = 0; charcount < curline->len; ++charcount) { 561 char curchar = text[charcount]; 562 563 564 /* handle new line chars - 1 mark */ 565 566 if (curchar == '\n') { 567 thestats.linecount++; 568 569 570 /* handle turning off the word marker - 1 mark */ 571 572 if (isword) { 573 /* increment the word count - 1 mark */ 574 ++ thestats.wordcount; 575 isword = FALSE; 576 } 577 578 break; 579 } 580 581 582 /* handle alphabetical characters - 1 mark */ 583 584 else if (isalpha(curchar)) { 585 ++thestats.alphacount; 586 587 588 /* handle upper case characters - 1 mark */ 589 590 if (isupper(curchar)) { 591 ++thestats.uppercount; 592 } else { 593 594 /* handle lower case characters - 1 mark */ 595 ++ thestats.lowercount; 596 } 597 598 599 /* handle beginning of word - 1 mark */ 600 601 if (!isword) { 602 isword = TRUE; 603 } 604 } 605 606 607 /* handle digits - 1 mark */ 608 609 else if (isdigit(curchar)) { 610 ++thestats.digitcount; 611 } else { 612 613 /* handle end of word not at end of line - 1 mark */ 614 615 if (isword) { 616 thestats.wordcount++; 617 isword = FALSE; 618 } 619 620 621 /* handle white spaces - 1 mark */ 622 if (isspace(curchar)) { 623 624 ++thestats.whitespacecount; 625 /* handle spaces separate from whitespace - 1 mark */ 626 627 if (curchar == ' ') { 628 ++thestats.spacecount; 629 } 630 } 631 632 633 /* handle punctuation - 1 mark */ 634 635 if (ispunct(curchar)) { 636 ++thestats.punctcount; 637 } 638 } 639 } 640 } 641 642 /* return the structure - 1 mark */ 643 return thestats; 644 }

Answer 3(B) of the Student

674 static void line_count_engine(struct line *line, struct stats *s) 675 { 676 char c; 677 char *p = line->text; 678 679 while ((c = *p++)) { 680 if (c == '\n') s->linecount++; /* 1 mark */ 681 682 // for wordcount, if (!isalnum(c)) /* 2.5 marks */ 683 684 // for alphacount, if (isalpha(c)) 685 // for uppercount, if (isupper(c)) 686 // for lower, if (islower(c)) 687 // for space, if (c == ' ') 688 // for whitespace, if (isspace(c)) 689 // for punct, if (ispunct(c)) 690 // for digital, if (isdigit(c)) 691 } 692 }

Question 3(C)

693 C) Write a function that prints out the stats on the document. 694 695 To get an idea, here is some sample output from the function (5 Marks): 696 697 There were 511 lines in the file. 698 There were 6134 words in the file. 699 There were 28433 alphabetic characters of which 418 were upper 700 and 28015 were lower case. 701 There were 785 punctuation characters in the file. 702 There were 6301 whitespace characters of which 6301 were space characters. 703 704 705 The function prototype for this function is: 706 707 void print_stats(struct stats thestats); 708 709 Please note that we are not requiring you to write a main function. 710 however it can be useful to see such a function in terms of situating your 711 thinking. 712 With this in mind, I have provided you with my main() function which 713 is on the next page. 714 715 /* Assume relevant headers are included */ 716 #define REQUIRED_ARGS 2 717 #define FILE_ARG 1 718 719 int main(int argc, char **argv) 720 { 721 if (argc != REQUIRED_ARGS) { 722 fprintf(stderr, "Error: invalid number of arguments.\n"); 723 return EXIT_FAILURE; 724 } 725 726 doc = document_load(argv[FILE_ARG]); 727 thestats = collect_stats(doc); 728 display_stats(thestats); 729 document_free(doc); 730 731 return EXIT_SUCCESS; 732 }

"Approved" Answer 3(C) of RMIT

733 void display_stats(struct stats thestats) 734 { 735 /* line count - 1 mark */ 736 printf("There were %d lines in the file.\n", thestats.linecount); 737 738 /* word count - 1 mark */ 739 printf("There were %d words in the file.\n", thestats.wordcount); 740 741 /* alphas, upper and lower case, 1 mark */ 742 printf( 743 "There were %d alphabetic characters of which %d were upper and " 744 "%d were lower case.\n", 745 thestats.alphacount, thestats.uppercount, thestats.lowercount); 746 747 /* punctuation and whitepsace - 1 mark */ 748 printf("There were %d punctuation characters in the file.\n", 749 thestats.punctcount); 750 751 printf("There were %d whitespace characters of which %d were space " 752 "characters.\n", 753 thestats.whitespacecount, thestats.spacecount); 754 755 /* digits - 1 mark */ 756 printf("There were %d digits in the file.\n", thestats.digitcount); 757 } 758

Answer 3(C) of the Student

759 // @s is passed by value and not as a pointer 760 void print_stats(struct stats s) /* 5 marks */ 761 { 762 printf("There are %d lines in the file\n", s.linecount); 763 printf("There are %d words in the file\n", s.wordcount); 764 printf("There are %d alpha, %d upper, %d lower\n", s.alphacount, s.uppercount, 765 s.lowercount); 766 printf("There are %d punctuation\n", s.punctcount); 767 printf("There are %d whitespace, %d space\n", s.whitespacecount, s.spacecount); 768 }

Question 4(A)

769 Question 4: Linked Lists (30 Marks) 770 771 Consider the following data structure for a word list, that is a linked list that 772 holds words and their length: 773 774 struct word { 775 char *text; 776 ssize_t line_len; 777 }; 778 779 struct word_node { 780 struct word_node *next; 781 struct word *theword; 782 }; 783 784 struct word_list { 785 struct word_node *head; 786 ssize_t len; 787 }; 788 789 790 A) You have been asked by your employer to modify these definitions, 791 with the aim being to use this code in various word games like scrabble. 792 793 They want to be able to store three things (5 Marks): 794 I. A word score for each word. 795 II. A count of how many times this word has been played. 796 III. An entry somewhere in this data structure that stored the best 797 scoring word and its score.

"Approved" Answer 4(A) of RMIT

798 Lines in bold are new. 799 800 struct word { 801 char *text; 802 ssize_t line_len; 803 int score; 804 int play_count; 805 }; 806 807 struct word_list { 808 struct word_node *head; 809 struct word *best_word; 810 ssize_t len; 811 }; 812 813 1.5 mark for score, 1.5 mark for play_count and 2 marks for best_word.

Answer 4(A) of the Student

814 I don't know - as a foreigner - the meaning of the word "scrabble". 0 marks 815 And I am discriminated. 816 817 Supervisor did not help me with the meaning.

Question 4(B)

818 B) Next, we want you to implement the function to add a new word in sorted 819 order to the defined list structure. As part of this you should calculate the 820 word score which is the same of the scores of each letter. (25 Marks) 821 822 The parameter scoretable is an array letter scores. 823 The words must be inserted in sorted order as lower case. 824 Please note that each letter is stored A letter score is an instance of the following struct: 825 826 struct letter_score { 827 char letter; 828 int score; 829 }; 830 831 The function prototype for this function is (25 Marks): 832 833 BOOLEAN add_word(struct word_list *thelist, const char newword[], 834 const struct letter_score scoretable, int scoretable_size);

"Approved" Answer 4(B) of RMIT

835 /* 4 marks for score calculation */ 836 static int word_score(char const word[], const struct letter_score scoretable[], 837 int scoretable_size) 838 { 839 int lettercount, tablecount; 840 int wordlen = strlen(word); 841 int score = 0; 842 843 for (lettercount = 0; lettercount < wordlen; ++lettercount) { 844 for (tablecount = 0; tablecount < scoretable_size; ++tablecount) { 845 if (word[lettercount] == scoretable[tablecount].letter) { 846 score += scoretable[tablecount].score; 847 } 848 } 849 } 850 return score; 851 } 852 853 struct word_node *make_node(const char word[], const struct letter_score score_table[], 854 int scoretable_size) 855 { 856 struct word *newword = make_word(word, score_table, scoretable_size); 857 struct word_node *newnode; 858 859 if (!newword) { 860 return NULL; 861 862 } 863 864 newnode = (struct word_node *)malloc(sizeof(struct word_node)); 865 if (!newnode) { 866 perror("malloc"); 867 word_free(newword); 868 return FALSE; 869 } 870 871 newnode->theword = newword; 872 newnode->next = NULL; 873 return newnode; 874 } 875 876 int wordcmp(const struct word *first, const struct word *second) 877 { 878 return strcmp(first->text, second->text); 879 } 880 881 882 /* 883 * the main function for q4b although there are some helper functionis that 884 * contribute marks 885 */ 886 887 BOOLEAN word_list_add(struct word_list *thelist, const char newword[], 888 const struct letter_score scoretable[], int scoretable_size) 889 { 890 /* 2 marks for reasonable declarations */ 891 struct word_node *current, *prev = NULL; 892 struct word_node *new; 893 894 /* 5 marks for memory allocations and checking they succeed */ 895 new = make_node(newword, scoretable, scoretable_size); 896 if (!new) { 897 return FALSE; 898 } 899 900 /* 2 marks for insertion at the head */ 901 if (!thelist->head) { 902 assert(thelist->len == 0); 903 thelist->head = new; 904 ++thelist->len; 905 return TRUE; 906 } 907 908 /* 4 marks for iteration */ 909 for (current = thelist->head; current && wordcmp(current->theword, new->theword) < 0; 910 prev = current, current = current->next) ; 911 912 /* 3 marks for insertion at the start */ 913 if (!prev) { 914 new->next = thelist->head; 915 thelist->head = new; 916 } 917 918 /* 3 marks for inseration elsewhere */ 919 else { 920 prev->next = new; 921 new->next = current; 922 } 923 924 /* 2 marks for increment */ 925 ++thelist->len; 926 return TRUE; 927 }

Answer 4(B) of the Student

928 See Answer 4(A)
